column1: Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Clears Key Hurdle on French Election;4/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBank of America Corp(NYSE:BAC) has mustered a 3.5% gain so far on Monday
column3: and with just a quick look at the headlines
column4: it'd be easy to doubt there will be any follow-through buying. While a fortuitous outcome in France's presidential election bodes relatively well for BAC stock - in that BofA has a respectable amount of exposure to the European market - at the end of the day
column5: the party in power in Paris doesn't inherently bolster the bottom line.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockOn the other hand
column6: sometimes a stock just needs the right nudge to reach the price it deserves to be trading it.Thanks to Monday's bump
column7: BAC stock has cleared a key technical hurdle that clears the decks for more gains.The News Investors Cared AboutAs a refresher
column8: Bank of America postedblowout first-quarter numbers. The company earned 41 cents per share on $22.2 billion in revenue
column9: versus expectations for a profit of only 35 cents per share of BAC stock and sales of $21.6 billion. Even more impressive was the bottom line's year-over-year growth of 46%
column10: and top-line growth of 12.5%.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeThe numbers were a strong affirmation that BofA is very much on the right track
column11: having shrugged off the worst of bad loans to the energy sector. The subprime debacle (and fallout) is now only a fading memory.And yet
column12: considering BAC stock had fallen 13% from its March high heading into earnings - suggesting traders weren't terribly optimistic - the post-earnings response from BofA shares felt lacking. The effort stalled just as soon as resistance was met at the stock's 20-day moving average
column13: limiting the post-announcement gain to less than 4%.The phenomenon wasn't limited to Bank of America shares though.JPMorgan Chase & Co.(NYSE:JPM)crushed its earnings estimates as well
column14: and the stock did nothing.DittoforCitigroup Inc(NYSE:C).For whatever reason
column15: though
column16: investors interpreted news from France's political scene as a big reason to buy U.S.-based banks
column17: even as their solid earnings reports weren't a bullish prod. Broadly speaking
column18: investors have been simply more concerned thatthe non-establishment candidate would mark the beginning of the end of the European Unionnow that the United Kingdom is out. Such a disruption poses a threat to all the big banks' business overseas.Now that threat has been at least partially abated.BAC Stock Shoots Above ResistanceWhile the response to the news from Bank of America is fundamentally a bullish one
column19: the dramatic change for the better is a technical one: BofA's chart just cleared a key hurdle. That is
column20: the 20-day moving average line (blue) that had been holding the stock back was cleared thanks to today's strength.It wasn't just a move above a key line in the sand
column21: however
column22: that makes this thrust such a high-potential one. There's also the bullish foundation it's built on.A closer look at the chart also indicates a slightly rising technical floor (orange
column23: dashed) played a role in setting the stage for this turnaround.Click to EnlargeIt's not the ideal situation. Today's big move in BAC stock also left behind a bullish gap that could be filled in before all is said and done
column24: upending the bullish move before it has a chance to get going in earnest. Still
column25: as long as any gap-filling pullback doesn't drag shares back below the 20-day MA
column26: currently at $23.12
column27: the bulls will have the technical edge they need to keep the rally going.Bottom Line for Bank of AmericaThis is anything but a textbook reason to step into BofA now. Then again
column28: the market has been anything but textbook for a long time now.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Will Survive Earnings. It Always Does.If the masses think a continuation of France's political and economic policies are a good reason to own BAC stock
column29: then it's a good reason to own it. The company's earnings growth just bolsters the argument.Just don't grip the stock so tightly you're unable to let go of it should the need arise. Although French centrist Emmanuel Macron appears to be the odds-on favorite - suggesting France will remain in the European Union - anti-establishment underdog Donald Trump wasn't expected to win either.As of this writing
column30: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.The postBank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Clears Key Hurdle on French Electionappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Will Survive Earnings. It Always Does.;4/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhen you look at the big picture
column3: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) has had a good year. The company grew both sales and earnings by more than 20% across calendar 2016
column4: and GOOGL stock has risen accordingly - more than 15% in the past 12 months
column5: and 11% year-to-date.makeArticleAd();Source:Travis Wise via FlickrIn fact
column6: with Monday's push
column7: shares are again trading at all-time highs.But there have been a few potholes along the way
column8: and earnings misses were responsible for two of them - a pertinent fact as we head into Alphabet's Q1 earnings report
column9: out Thursday after the bell.Earnings Misses Have Slowed Alphabet BeforeAlphabet has fallen shy of analyst earnings estimates in two of the past four quarters
column10: including a 3% shortfall in Q4 2016. That miss prompted Google's parent to plummet from $857 to $815 in just four trading sessions across late January and early February.Last April
column11: when the company missed first-quarter estimates by nearly 6%
column12: GOOGL stock also fell hard
column13: dropping nearly 10% in a week.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeOn both occasions
column14: shares took a few weeks to recover from their earnings-induced losses. Those pullbacks
column15: along with a couple other big declines around the Brexit and the presidential election
column16: were enough to prevent GOOGL from keeping pace with otherNasdaqstocks. In fact
column17: while Alphabet's 15% tally over the past 12 months sounds nice
column18: it actually trails a 20% return in the broader composite.All of that is to say: Alphabet's earnings report this Thursdaydoesmatter
column19: it's just not make-or-break.A miss could stunt shares' progress again and knock them off their perch at all-time highs. An earnings beat could send GOOGL stock even higher - likely to at least $900 before the calendar flips to May. Last July
column20: for example
column21: the stock jumped above $800 for the first time ever after the company beat earnings estimates by 4.7%.Alphabet is a rare bird. It's one of the largest companies in the world
column22: and yet it still manages to routinely grow its top and bottom lines by double digits
column23: putting it in a class with a select few
column24: includingFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) andAmazon.com
column25: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).Sometimes
column26: GOOGL is a victim of its own success
column27: similar toApple(NASDAQ:AAPL) a few years ago. Alphabet has set the growth bar so high that analysts expect a lot from the company every quarter. When earnings (or sales) fall short of those expectations
column28: investors punish the stock.But that's also why Alphabet is one of the most desirable stocks on the market.Those quick selloffs tend not to do any lasting damage. GOOGL stock has been on an upward trajectory for about five years
column29: suffering no real comeuppance. Alphabet's difficulties might have slowed the stock down
column30: but again â€¦ here we are
column31: discussing the stock as it sits at all-time highs.A Low Bar Should Help GOOGL StockEstimates for this past quarter are more muted than usual. Analysts anticipate 19.5% sales growth with a small earnings decline
column32: which would be the first since the third quarter of 2014. So the earnings bar is lower than usual for Alphabet this time around.Why Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Will Cool Down After Q1 EarningsA miss
column33: combined with a rare profit decline
column34: could spark a serious selloff - particularly with GOOGL stock at its lofty perch.My advice? If you already own - which I'm sure many of you do - simply hold on and weather whatever storm comes your way if the company misses earnings again on Thursday. Things will likely turn ugly
column35: but if history is any indication
column36: shares will recover their losses within a month.It's a bit more tricky if you're considering jumping in
column37: but I suggest you wait for earnings and hope for a post-earnings dip in GOOGL stock before purchasing. Wall Street's typical overreaction to a miss could result in a prime buying opportunity in one of the market's great long-term growth stocks.Either way
column38: Thursday's report looms large for Alphabet.As of this writing

column1: What Apple Inc. (AAPL) Self-Driving Car Technology Looks Like;4/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe rumors have been flying for several years thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is secretly working on autonomous driving technology. We even had the code name for the effort: Project Titan. However
column3: the cat was officially out of the bag two weeks ago when AAPL received a permit to test an autonomous car in California.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleNow
column4: thanks to official training documents obtained byBusiness Insider
column5: we know what Apple's self-driving car technology looks like.Why Apple Is Interested in Autonomous Car TechnologyThe closest Apple has ever come to releasing a product for automobiles is its CarPlay standard for integrating an iPhone into a car's entertainment system. So why the apparent fascination with futuristic auto technology like an autonomous car?The company has exploded in value and influence over the past decade because of the iPhone
column6: but it's looking for the next big hit. With the successTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) has had
column7: and the publicityAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google has reaped from it's self-driving car program
column8: Apple clearly saw an opportunity. Over88 million cars and light duty trucks were sold in 2016and the revenue for automotive suppliers alone surpassed $670 billion in 2015.Even carving out a small slice of this market would be huge for AAPL stock holders.Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Is Going to Burn Amid Flex 2 Explosion ReportWe started to hear about Apple's Project Titan in 2015. At first
column9: it was thought to be an electric car to compete with Tesla. Even Tesla'sElon Musk seemed convincedApple was preparing to directly take on his company. However
column10: last fall there was an apparentshake-up in Project Titan. It was believed that Apple was pivoting from developing its own electric Apple car to instead developing an autonomous car software platform it could sell to automakers.Two weeks ago
column11: Apple officially tipped its hand. The company received a permit to drive three Lexus vehicles equipped with autonomous car technology on California roads.Apple's Self-Driving Car Technology Outed by Training ManualBusiness Insidergot the scoop on what AAPL is up toby obtaining a copy of a training manual and official government documentation filed by the company.Called the Apple Automated System
column12: AAPL's self-driving car platform uses a combination of hardware and software. Apple says its system is ""capable of sending electronic commands for steering
column13: accelerating
column14: and decelerating and may carry out portions of the dynamic driving task.""The documentation describes the testing Apple drivers must undergo on a private course before being allowed to take the Lexus autonomous car onto public roads. It also includes photographs of the cockpit of the cars and even details the modifications made to the vehicles.AAPL has equipped its test cars with a steering wheel and pedals made byLogitech(NASDAQ:LOGI) -the manufacturer of video game peripherals. The human ""driver"" can instantly take over control of the self-driving car by touching the brakes or grabbing the steering wheel.Where Does the Apple Automated System Go From Here?The end game for the Apple Automated System is clearly not to power an Apple car. At least not yet. Instead
column15: AAPL will take aim at the traditional auto makers
column16: hoping to convince them to license its system in their vehicles instead of spending the time and money to develop their own in-house technology.7 Tech Stocks That Are a Sneeze Away From CollapsingEven though it's now public knowledge
column17: expect AAPL to remain tight-lipped on its autonomous car project. The Apple Lexus test vehicles will be spotted on California roads
column18: but with so much at stake -Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) recently dropped $15 billion onMobileyetodevelop its own autonomous vehicle platform- Apple is likely to keep its cards close until it's ready for the big reveal.As of this writing

column1: 3 Driverless Car Stocks You Won't Have to Babysit;4/24/2017;"Driverless cars are still in their infancy
column2: but many   technology companies and automakers have shifted their efforts to   develop semi-autonomous systems into high gear as they wait   for the tech and the market to fully materialize. And well they   should -- by 2035
column3: some analysts foresee the market for partially   and fully autonomous vehicles hitting $77 billion a year.We're still years away from fully autonomous vehicles
column4: but a   handful of companies are making bigger strides toward them than   their rivals. Among those areAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google
column5: NVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) . Each is taking a different approach the   driverless car market
column6: but all are solid plays that investors   don't need to babysit.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();AlphabetAlphabet's well-known efforts to develop driverless car   technologies began back in 2009
column7: first as a project run by its   Google X R&D unit
column8: and later spun off into their own   subsidiary
column9: called Waymo.Through Waymo
column10: Alphabet is working withFiat Chryslerto release 100 self-driving minivans later this year. Waymo CEO   John Krafcik said in press release last year that the   company wants to bring driverless car services to ride-sharing
column11: as well trucking
column12: logistics
column13: and consumer vehicles -- which   represents
column14: essentially
column15: nearly every facet of the automotive   market.Considering its just a small subsidiary
column16: investors shouldn't   expect revenues from Waymo to move the needle at all for Alphabet   right now. But the parent company is very adept at figuring how   to monetize its businesses
column17: and the fact that it was spun out   shows that management is confident that the unit could bring in   revenues of its own.With more than eight years of autonomous vehicle experience   under its belt already
column18: and the $86 billion in cash Alphabet has   on hand to exploit whatever opportunities it finds
column19: this   driverless car play is the epitome of a set-it-and-forget-it   stock.TeslaTesla has made some bold claims about its driverless-car plans   in the past. CEO Elon Musk said last year that by 2018
column20: the   company's cars would be able to be summoned remotely by their   owners -- as in not driven by anyone -- from across the   country.It's looking highly unlikely that Tesla will havethatfeature live by next year
column21: but the electric automaker's vehicles   are still far ahead of its competition. New Teslas already come   equipped with fully autonomous driving hardware
column22: and ongoing   updates to the vehicles' software are slowly making more and more   self-driving features available to their owners.Investors should note that Tesla's valuation issky high right now
column23: with a price-to-sales ratio of 7.1
column24: compared to 0.29 for   competitors likeFord
column25: and a forward P/E that sits above 150.There's likely to be some volatility ahead forTesla stockfor that reason
column26: but that doesn't mean thatcurrentTesla shareholders will have to babysit their investment.   Tesla is ahead of other automakers in the semi-autonomous space
column27: and will likely continue to keep its lead for the foreseeable   future. But investors considering opening up a position in the   company should know that Tesla will likely have a hard time   growing at the rate it needs to justify its current   valuations.NVIDIAAnother solid bet on the driverless car market is graphics   processing unit (GPU) maker NVIDIA. The company has developed an   automotive AI computing platform called Drive PX 2
column28: that can   rapidly process data from cameras and give semi-autonomous   vehicles situational awareness -- allowing them to ""understand""   and properly react to what they see around them.Already about 80 automakers and Tier 1 suppliers are using or   testing Drive PX
column29: and Tesla is the latest company to partner with   NVIDIA for semi-autonomous driving systems. NVIDIA earned about   7% of its total revenue in its fiscal 2017 (which ended Jan. 29)   from its automotive segment
column30: and sales from the business grew by   37% year over year in fiscal Q4 2017.Aside from that growth and its early lead in selling   semi-autonomous vehicle supercomputers to automakers
column31: NVIDIA is   the leader in the GPU space
column32: and earns most of its money (59% in   fiscal 2017) from sales in the gaming market. This will continue   to provide NVIDIA a lot of stability -- and resources -- as it   builds out its driverless car technologies. And it's a key reason   why investors won't have to keep a close eye on the company.To be clear
column33: any investment comes with its own level of risk
column34: and investors shouldn't assume that Alphabet
column35: Tesla
column36: or NVIDIA   are now
column37: or will remain
column38: sure bets. But each company is poised to   dominate the driverless car market in their own way
column39: which means   investors can rest a little easier with these companies in their   portfolios.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Google vs. Ad Blockers: If You Can't Beat 'Em
column2: Join 'Em;4/23/2017;"Google is the biggest internet-advertising company in the   world
column3: so it's ironic that theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary is considering   including an ad blocking feature in its popular Chrome web   browser. Ad blocking has grown increasingly popular over the last   few years; roughly 26% of U.S. internet users now employ   ad-blocking software.Google may be looking to preempt further adoption of ad   blockers by automatically disabling the most annoying kinds of   ads on the web
column4: like full-screen takeovers and autoplay video   ads. Google is backed by the Coalition for Better Ads
column5: which   includes some of the largest marketers
column6: ad agencies
column7: and media   organizations
column8: along withFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) .The rise of ad blocking is a threat to companies like Google   and Facebook that generate nearly all of their revenue from   online advertising. If they can control the ad-blocking software
column9: they can control which ads get blocked and which ones don't
column10: a   win-win-win for internet users
column11: publishers
column12: and advertising   companies.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Don't block every ad
column13: just the bad onesGoogle has already built functions into its Chrome browser to   block ads that result in the biggest drains on laptop and   smartphone batteries. The updates it's discussing with publishers   and the Coalition will take another step
column14: to block the ad formats   that overwhelmingly lead users to seek out ad blockers.Publishers are drawn to ads like full-screen takeovers and   autoplay videos because they typically fetch higher rates than   other ad units. However
column15: they can also ruin the user experience
column16: potentially leading to high website abandonment rates. Top   publishers understand this and generally stay away from these   annoying formats
column17: but with the proliferation of small publishers   through Facebook
column18: it's more and more common to come across these   types of ads.The Coalition for Better Ads is in the process of setting   standards for publishers to follow. Google's Chrome browser is   just one vehicle through which it will enforce those standards.   Chrome is used by 58.6% of all web users; with that much of the   market
column19: Google should be able to get most publishers to adopt the   standards
column20: for fear they'll miss out on a lot of potential ad   revenue.Won't Google be hurting itself?Google is one of the biggest digital display advertisers in   the world
column21: but most of its ad revenue actually comes from its   search business. Google doesn't break out search specifically
column22: but its owned and operated properties accounted for over 80% of   its total ad revenue last quarter. The other 20% came from its ad   network
column23: which it splits with publishers.Google's own websites have increased their share of Google's   total ad revenue in recent years
column24: as people spend more time   watching ads on YouTube and searching Google on their mobile   devices. While paid clicks on network member sites continue to   increase (despite the proliferation of ad blockers)
column25: Google's   revenue per click is declining.Facebook actually generates more revenue from display ads than   Google. But Facebook investors shouldn't be worried either.   Facebook's main ad unit -- native News Feed ads -- certainly   falls within the standards set forth by the coalition. Moreover
column26: most of Facebook's audience accesses its platform through a   dedicated mobile app
column27: which is immune to ad-blocking services   like the one Google is reportedly developing.Even blocking the most annoying kinds of ads
column28: Google can still   let nonintrusive ads through. That's better for both Google and   publishers than third-party software
column29: which generally blocks any   and all ads. If Google integrates ad blocking into Chrome
column30: it   could stop many consumers from going for those third-party apps
column31: saving some revenue for Google and its network partners.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (C     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Alphabet and Apple: 2 of the Best Healthcare Stocks on the Market?;4/22/2017;"Every company is a healthcare company now. At least
column2: that's   what it seems like sometimes.BothApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) and Google parentAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)  are working on technology to   help manage diabetes and address other healthcare issues. Could   Alphabet and Apple now be considered two of the best healthcare   stocks around? Maybe so.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Teaming upAlphabet has a couple of companies focusing on healthcare --   Calico and Verily. And these companies have forged partnerships   with some big established healthcare companies along the way.Calico was formed in 2013 to develop technologies that   increase the human lifespan. The following year
column3: AbbVieteamed up with Calico
column4: investing $750 million to try to bring new   therapies to market for patients with age-related diseases
column5: including neurodegeneration and cancer.In late 2015
column6: Google Life Sciences changed its name to Verily   Life Sciences. Verily is working withDexcom(NASDAQ: DXCM) to develop miniaturized continuous glucose   monitors for type 2 diabetic patients. It formed a joint venture   withGlaxoSmithKlineto create bioelectronic medicines that use tiny implanted devices   to treat disease. The Alphabet business unit also   formed other joint ventures withJohnson & Johnsonto develop robotic surgical systems and withSanofito create technology that helps diabetic patients better manage   their health.Perhaps the most intriguing project that Verily is working on   is its effort withNovartisto develop a smart contact lens that senses glucose level in   tears. The goal is to have contact lenses that change color if   diabetic patients' glucose levels aren't where they need to   be.No pain
column7: big gainCNBCrecently reportedthat Apple has a secret initiative underway that's trying a   different approach in monitoring glucose levels. Currently
column8: patients must use finger sticks that pierce their skin four times   per day to monitor their glucose levels. Apple's team is trying   to develop a solution that uses optical sensors instead.The ultimate goal is to fulfill Apple founder Steve Jobs'   vision of wearable devices that could continually monitor   important vital signs. Apple Watch already enables monitoring of   heart rates. Apple has applied for a patent to send alerts to   family or emergency staff if an Apple Watch wearer has heart   problems
column9: such as arrhythmia. However
column10: monitoring glucose in a   completely non-invasive way has been impossible so far.Dexcom does have a continuous glucose monitoring system that   interfaces with Apple Watch. However
column11: the system uses a sensor   that is placed underneath the skin. It also requires a minimum of   two finger sticks each day for calibration. Apple's hope appears   to be to eliminate the need for finger sticks entirely.Apple is looking at other healthcare opportunities as well.Bloombergreported last yearthat the company intends to transform its HealthKit app that runs   on iPhones and Apple Watches from a primarily fitness application   to a tool that helps improve diagnoses. Apple also bought a small   company in early 2016
column12: Gliimpse
column13: which is developing software   that stores electronic health records from multiple sources in   one place.Top healthcare picks?There's no question that both Alphabet and Apple are trying to   solve some of the most challenging problems in healthcare. But   are the stocks good choices for investors wanting to profit from   the growth in the healthcare industry? Yes and no.The negative response isn't because Alphabet and Apple aren't   solid stock picks. They are. However
column14: in the near term
column15: neither   company will generate enough revenue from healthcare to rank the   stocks among the best ways to ride the healthcare wave.On the other hand
column16: investors should look at the long run. If   Alphabet and Apple are successful in achieving their goals
column17: the   financial opportunities in healthcare for both companies are   enormous. The diabetes testing market could reach $17 billion by   2021. If Alphabet's smart contact lens pans out and Apple's   optical sensor technology works
column18: the two technology giants could   also become healthcare giants.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Google Wallet is Making Strides
column2: But it's No Venmo Killer;4/22/2017;"Last month
column3: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG)announcedGmail users would now be able to send and receive money on   Android devices through its Google Wallet platform. The service   had been available through Gmail since 2013 but
column4: until last   month
column5: was unavailable on mobile devices.To use the service
column6: all that is needed is to compose a new   email in the Gmail app on any Android mobile device. Once a new   email is opened
column7: users simply choose the ""Send money"" or ""Request   money"" options under he attachment icon. After a debit card is   linked and the amount of money is selected
column8: the funds can then be   sent to anyone with an email address or phone number. The   recipient does not need to be an existing Google Wallet user or   have a Gmail account and is free to all users. The service is   currently only available in the United States and United   Kingdom.Image source: Pixabay.makeArticleAd();The feature is the latest attempt by Alphabet to engage its   over one billion active Gmail users. The Android operating   system
column9: which runs on most smartphones and tablets
column10: had 1.4   billion active users as of September 2015. The overlap between   the two is almost certain to be in the hundreds of millions
column11: making this new feature an avenue Alphabet could pursue to deepen   its relationships with its huge account holder base.Google Wallet's uninspiring pastWhile Alphabet has never released official figures on how many   active users exist on Google Wallet
column12: it doesn't take too much   digging to discover it is not widely used; a situation almost   assuredly of Alphabet's own making. From the beginning
column13: the   platform has struggled from a lack of attention and strategy from   its parent company. As a prime example of this neglect
column14: this very   feature of using Gmail to send money to other people was first   available to desktop users in 2013. Yet it took four additional   years for Google to incorporate it into Gmail's app on mobile   devices.Image source: Alphabet Inc'sGoogle blog.Originally
column15: NFC (near field communication) technology was to   be used in conjunction with Google Wallet so that the app could   be used to make point-of-sale (POS) purchases. However
column16: this   capability was dropped in September 2015. In 2016
column17: Google   discontinued the Google Wallet card
column18: a physical debit card linked   directly to one's Google Wallet account. These decisions   effectively ended any way customers could use their Google Wallet   accounts to make POS transactions at physical retail locations
column19: though there are some work-arounds
column20: such as linking a Google   Wallet account to Android Pay
column21: a separate payment app available   only to Android users.Google Wallet's uneven presentThe constant meddling with Google Wallet's capabilities has   certainly contributed to its lagging popularity. It is now   essentially a P2P payment platform left to compete with the likes   ofPayPal Holdings Inc's(NASDAQ: PYPL) Venmo and the newly launched Zelle
column22: a P2P app   provided by many of the nation's largest banks to their   customers.Google Wallet will have to overcome many obstacles if it is to   capture significant market share. InAccenture's2016 North America Consumer Digital Payments   Survey
column23: consumers indicated they trusted traditional card providers
column24: alternative payment providers (e.g. PayPal)

column1: Twitter Wants to Litter Your Timeline With Video Ads;4/21/2017;"There's no questionTwitter(NYSE:TWTR) is making a big bet on video. From integrating live Periscope   streams with its flagship app to paying for premium content
column2: Twitter is pushing more and more video into users' timelines. But   likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column3: Twitter is still looking for ways to maximize the   value of those videos.It has stand-alone video ads that show up between organic   posts. It's also allowed marketers to buy pre-roll ads
column4: which   play ahead of videos produced by top content creators. That's   something Facebook has long resisted. Instead
column5: Facebook decided   to test mid-roll video ads
column6: and now Twitter is copying that idea   for its videos.Twitter has been de-emphasizing its non-video ad formats
column7: so   the push for more video ads is integral to its future ability to   grow. The new mid-roll ad format could increase Twitter's ad   inventory at a time when marketers are looking for new places for   their digital video ads.makeArticleAd();Image source: Twitter.Big competition in videoOnline video continues to explode
column8: and Twitter has some big   competitors vying for people's attention. The champion of viral   videos and time sucks is YouTube
column9: the subsidiary of Google
column10: anAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) company. Meanwhile
column11: Facebook has   continued to push more videos into users' News Feeds
column12: and it even   launched a dedicated section in its app just for users to watch   more videos.Snap's Snapchat has built a nice video-advertising business on   top of 10-second disappearing messages. Smaller competitors (some   backed by large companies) are popping up every day.Twitter says video impressions ""grew significantly from Q3 to   Q4 2016
column13: but declined to give any specifics. That's not too   surprising
column14: though
column15: considering both Facebook and YouTube have   also shied away from giving specific numbers recently.But given the amount of emphasis Twitter is putting on video
column16: it needs to start giving investors some idea of how much users   are engaging with video
column17: at least on a relative basis. Without   those details
column18: it's impossible to tell if Twitter is gaining   share in the digital video market -- which is growing rapidly
column19: but also becoming extremely crowded.The market is getting big fast
column20: but it's dominated by two   playersFrom 2014 to 2016
column21: U.S. digital video advertising grew from   49% of total digital-ad spend to 57%
column22: according to the   Interactive Advertising Bureau. The average advertiser expected   to spend 85% more on video ads in 2016 than in 2014. eMarketer   expects U.S. digital video advertising to grow at a double-digit   rate through 2020
column23: reaching $16.7 billion.That growth
column24: however
column25: is largely fueled by just Facebook and   YouTube. A whopping 72% of marketers intend to increase spending   on YouTube
column26: according to a survey published by eMarketer.   Facebook was the second most popular choice
column27: with 46% of   marketers intending to increase video ad spending on the   platform. Twitter garnered the favor of just 25% of   marketers.Those numbers may have changed following controversy over ads   playing before offensive content on YouTube. Several big brands   have boycotted Google
column28: opening the door for smaller players like   Facebook or Twitter. But YouTube remains one of the most popular   places to watch online videos and Google is taking steps to curb   the ability to monetize offensive content
column29: which means it should   continue to attract tons of interest from marketers.Does Twitter need more video ad inventory?Twitter is looking to increase video ads
column30: but it might be   looking at it from the wrong side of the equation. Offering a   bigger supply without a bigger demand won't do much to move the   needle. In fact
column31: Twitter is taking a risk of turning users away   from watching videos if they dislike watching ads in the middle.   That's why Facebook has been very slow to roll out the new ad   format itself.Twitter
column32: understandably
column33: wants to give marketers as many   options as possible
column34: and mid-roll ads do have the potential to be   more effective and valuable than pre-roll or stand-alone ads.   Users are paying attention already
column35: the sound is probably on
column36: and   the video is likely fully in view. But it's unlikely to have a   meaningful impact on revenue without Twitter working to increase   the attractiveness of its platform.That means it needs to start showing marketers real numbers   with regard to video engagement on its platform. Twitter has   provided lots of positive numbers showing how its video ads   improve recall
column37: brand awareness
column38: and purchase intent among   viewers who see them
column39: but it's not providing the bigger picture:   how many people actually see Twitter video ads. Without that data   showing improvements in video engagement
column40: Twitter will continue   to fall out of favor with marketers.10 stocks we like better than TwitterWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Amazon Offers AI Technology Powering Alexa to AWS Users;4/21/2017;"Amazon.com
column2: Inc.'sAMZNAmazon Web Services (AWS) has made Amazon Lex
column3: the machine learning technology behind Alexa
column4: available to all customers.Amazon Lex algorithms facilitate natural language understanding
column5: automatic speech recognition and text to speech. Amazon is now offering these technologies as a fully managed service.Building Voice and Text-based Apps is Now EasyWith Amazon Lex
column6: developers can build conversational apps easily
column7: which were otherwise extremely difficult to create as these involved complicated deep learning algorithms on enormous amount of data.Moreover
column8: the integration of Amazon Lex with AWS Lambda (Amazon's event-driven
column9: serverless computing platform) will enable developers to run serverless codes
column10: apply business logic and fetch data from enterprise applications and AWS services like Amazon DynamoDB.Further
column11: inbuilt connectors enable the conversational apps to collect data from Software as a Service (SaaS) applications such as Salesforce
column12: QuickBooks
column13: Zendesk and Marketo.Developers can also use analytics provided by Amazon Lex to assess different application performance and accuracy metrics that they can employ to better their apps over time.We note that Amazon's shares appreciated 42.9% in the last one year compared with the Zacks Internet Commerce industry's gain of 37.6%. AWS' growth is expected to back the momentum going ahead.Banking on Alexa's SuccessAmazon Alexa is powered by Amazon Lex's sophisticated deep learning algorithms. Alexa powered Echo devices are going great guns and help the company sell products and services. Alexa has already been integrated into a host of everyday devices for the digital home and there are agreements for more.Amazon is racing to build an ecosystem around Alexa and it's safe to say that it's taken an early lead over AlphabetGOOGLowned Google's smart assistant and Microsoft'sMSFTCortana.Driven by its Alexa-powered Echo devices
column14: the company has converted the nascent smart home market into a potential area of growth in a very short time.So
column15: it appears that by bringing the artificial intelligence (AI) platform that powers Alexa to AWS customers
column16: Amazon is trying to bank on Alexa's success to boost AWS.Amazon.com
column17: Inc. Net Income (TTM)Amazon.com
column18: Inc. Net Income (TTM)|Amazon.com
column19: Inc. QuoteAWS Under the SpotlightThe move underscores the fact that Amazon continues to beef up AWS and why not? The unit that was started for the purpose of handling the company's own storage needs has quickly become a billion-dollar business and the cash cow for Amazon. The business generates much higher margins than retail
column20: so it has a positive impact on Amazon's profitability.We believe that the move will boost functionality
column21: partner ecosystem and the experience AWS offers and leads to continued customer wins. AWS has already taken a lead over rival services
column22: such as Microsoft Azure
column23: Google Cloud Platform and International Business Machines'IBMIBM Cloud.If AWS continues to witness the same kind of success
column24: investors can hope for far more growth.Currently
column25: Amazon has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: 3 Stocks to Hold for the Next 50 Years;4/21/2017;"Stocks to hold for 50 years? At first
column2: that seems like an   impossible request. We've all seen it in recent years: Even huge
column3: great companies fade
column4: get disrupted
column5: or run aground on scandals   or disasters of various kinds.But sometimes
column6: you can tell that a company isn't just great   now
column7: it's built to be great for decades to come. With the caveat   that nothing in the future is certain
column8: our Foolish contributors   thinkAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column9: Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column10: andEaton Corporation(NYSE: ETN) are good choices to add to a truly long-term   portfolio.Alphabet's self-driving car company
column11: Waymo
column12: is just one of     its many moon shots. Image source: Fiat Chrysler     Automobiles.makeArticleAd();Possibly the world's greatest innovation engineKeith Speights(Alphabet):If you didn't use Alphabet's Google nearly every day this week
column13: you're probably one of the few in the developed world who didn't.   Alphabet is best known for its Google search engine
column14: Chrome   browser
column15: YouTube video site
column16: and Android mobile operating system
column17: which powers nearly 9 out of 10 smartphones.Why buy and hold Alphabet for the next 50 years? The company   simply doesn't stop innovating. Innovation doesn't just   apply to Alphabet's moon shot efforts. The company continues to   improve its existing products
column18: sometimes in ways that you don't   even notice. (Those can be the best kinds of innovations
column19: actually.)However
column20: I admit to being intrigued by the moonshot programs.   Alphabet's ""other bets"" business segment includes Calico
column21: Nest
column22: Verily
column23: Waymo
column24: and X. Two of these initiatives are in the   healthcare arena. Calico is focused on increasing the human   lifespan
column25: while Verily works on technology like developing   glucose-sensing contact lenses for diabetic patients. Nest is   developing home automation technology. Waymo is a pioneer in   self-driving cars. And X focuses on a variety of   projects including using a network of balloons to bring   internet access to the two-thirds of the world's population that   doesn't have it yet.While Alphabet pursues these incredibly cool ideas
column26: its core   businesses are generating revenue of more than $90 billion and   earnings of $19.5 billion annually. Many of the company's moon   shots won't pan out. But I suspect that some will. I also think   that 50 years from now
column27: Alphabet will still be innovating -- and   still making investors a lot of money.""E-commerce king"" is just the beginningJohn Rosevear(Amazon.com):Amazon hardly needs an introduction
column28: but it always surprises me   to find that many tech-savvy investors don't own any shares of   the online-retail-and-more colossus.If you're one of those investors
column29: it's time to reconsider.   Yes
column30: Amazon is already huge. Yes
column31: its stock price is high. But it   still has immense growth potential
column32: and it genuinely has the   cash-generation ability and management team to fully pursue that   potential.Between Amazon's Alexa voice-recognition software (and the   powerful artificial intelligence capabilities that underlie it)
column33: its Amazon Web Services cloud-computing empire
column34: its incredibly   dominant online-retail business
column35: and the dozens of small bets   that CEO Jeff Bezos seems to add every quarter... the upside here   probably isn't limitless
column36: but it's big. Twenty-plus years in
column37: it's still seems like Amazon is just getting started.And while other companies will come and go
column38: Amazon isn't going   anywhere. It's got plenty of cash
column39: management that is heavily   invested
column40: and good wide moats around its core businesses --   together
column41: a recipe for profitable growth for decades to come. I   own Amazon shares
column42: and I suspect my sons will inherit them   -- hopefully
column43: many years from now.Always adjusting to the timesReuben Gregg Brewer(Eaton):Global industrial giant Eaton Corp.'s sales have fallen in each   of the last two years
column44: buffeted by slow economic growth and   currency volatility. However
column45: the company managed to increase its   operating margin in both years because of aggressive   restructuring efforts. The bottom line
column46: meanwhile
column47: has held up   relatively well (Eaton made $4.21 a share in 2016
column48: down just   $0.02 from 2015)
column49: and the dividend has been increased every year   for the past seven years.Eaton's focus is on power management
column50: which it covers through   its electrical products
column51: electrical systems and services
column52: hydraulics
column53: automotive
column54: and aerospace segments. It has a long   history of buying and selling businesses to adjust its portfolio   over time. Its biggest recent deal was the 2012 acquisition of   Cooper Industries
column55: a $12 billion transaction that materially   expanded its electrical operations. Tweaking businesses to get   the most out of them
column56: as highlighted above
column57: is another ongoing   focus.Essentially
column58: Eaton is a pro at shifting with the changing   times via acquisition and internal tweaks. In fact
column59: it started   its life over 100 years ago as an axle manufacturer
column60: eventually   selling that division in 1998 to focus on more lucrative   operations. It's unlikely that you will ever find Eaton an   exciting stock to own
column61: but you can rest assured that it will   deftly navigate the ups and downs of the business cycle over the   next 50 years
column62: transforming itself with the market as it goes.   Meanwhile
column63: you'll be rewarded with a nice 3.2% dividend yield   that has a long history of increases behind it.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column64: it can pay to listen. After all
column65: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column66: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column67: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (C shares)     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column1: PayPal Holdings Inc (PYPL) Hopes Partnership Will Make It the King of Mobile Payments;4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEarlier this week
column3: it was announced thatPayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL) and Google parent companyAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column4: NASDAQ:GOOG) will be partnering up to integrate PayPal's mobile payment options into Google's NFC-enabled smartphone payment app
column5: Android Pay.makeArticleAd();Source:Via PayPalNo specific details of the arrangements were revealed
column6: but according toFortune
column7: ""PayPal's chief operating officer
column8: Bill Ready
column9: said that his company's partnership with Googlewill be implemented in the coming weeks.""Executives at both GOOGL and PYPL hope that the addition of PayPal as a funding source for Android Pay will serve to increase the number of smartphone owners who actively use Google's digital wallet
column10: while also making PayPal a more common choice for consumers making in-store purchases.PayPal Dominates Online
column11: But Not In-StoreFor years
column12: PYPL has led the industry; last year
column13: PayPal processedmore than 6 billion mobile transactionsworth more than $350 billion. As of December 2016
column14: PayPal held a commanding lead in the mobile payments industry
column15: with76% of digital wallet users reporting that they used PYPL.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeThe second most popular digital wallet service
column16: Amazon.com
column17: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Amazon Pay
column18: trailed PayPal by more than 50 percentage points. And
column19: not surprisingly
column20: the mobile payment services offered by competitors Google andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) were used by only 14% and 12% of smartphone owners
column21: respectively.Samsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) sat at the bottom of the ladder with a mere 6% of users claiming to actually use the company's digital wallet.Clearly
column22: PayPal dominates the online payment arena. However
column23: since the launch of Apple Pay in October 2014

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Wonâ€™t Buy Walt Disney Co (DIS) â€“ But It Will Do This;4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA report from RBC Capital Markets last week suggested thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) could acquireWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS). Analyst Amit Daryanani said that multiple investors had asked him about the possibility of a merger between Apple and Disney
column3: arguing that there wasa non-zero possibilityof such a deal occurring.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockA combination of AAPL and Disney stock would be the largest merger in history - and in RBC's estimation
column4: a strong positive for Apple stock.The idea has been greeted with almost universal skepticism
column5: and the report had little
column6: if any
column7: impact on trading in Apple shares. Indeed
column8: the merger seems highly unlikely.But it does appear that Apple
column9: which traditionally has shunned major acquisitions
column10: could be in the market for a bigger target. That target may not be Disney. But there's reason to believe Apple has a major deal in its future.What Would an Apple-Disney Merger Cost?Disney has an enterprise value of about $196 billion at the moment. Apple likely would offer a roughly 40% premium for Disney stock. In that case
column11: the acquisition would cost Apple about $267 billion
column12: including assumption of debt.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeThat's a huge price tag
column13: obviously - but it's not insurmountable. Apple could fund at least some of the purchase price with Apple stock. Apple already has about $226 billion in cash and securities as well. The one major problem is that most of the cash remains trapped overseas.If the Trump administration can't push through a repatriation holiday
column14: the cash portion of a Disney acquisition could be tougher to fund.Would Disney Benefit AAPL Stock?The strategic value of such a deal for Apple and AAPL stock is more complicated. On its face
column15: the addition of Disney's content would provide a huge leg up to Apple's services business - notably both Apple TV and Apple Music. Apple has been trying to put together a streaming TV package for years -only to fall behindAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) YouTube
column16: among others. Disney's ABC and ESPN properties could form the beginning of a content package that could rival YouTube streaming
column17: Huluand other bundles.The counterargument is that adding Disney could ruin Apple's ambitions in TV. The whole point of providing a streaming platform is to be provider-agnostic
column18: something that Apple is â€¦ but it wouldn't be if it owned Disney's programming. Would a provider likeAMC Networks Inc(NASDAQ:AMCX) want to licenseThe Walking Deadto an Apple TV package if Apple also is a major competitor?The most interesting aspect of the deal would be Apple's ownership of ESPN. ESPN isstruggling badlywith cord-cutting
column19: which threatens its business model of charging $7-plus per subscriber per month - whether subscribers are interested in sports or not. The Apple delivery system
column20: from one standpoint
column21: could invigorate ESPN.From another standpoint
column22: however
column23: ESPN would be an anchor.Liberty Media Corporation(NASDAQ:FWONA) CEO John Malonespeculated last yearthat Disney could split off ESPN and sell the rest of its assets to Apple for cash and/or Apple stock.Apple may not want to enter the live sports fray - and it may not be interested in what could be a long-term decline in ESPN viewership.All told
column24: an Apple-Disney merger seems unlikely. Even RBC admitted as much â€¦ but that doesn't mean Apple isn't making a deal of some sort.The Big Apple DealOne argument against an AAPL-DIS merger is that Apple doesn't do big deals. Its purchase of Beats Music for $3 billion was the largest deal Apple has ever pulled off.But there's reason to think that strategy may change. In January
column25: AAPL CEO Tim Cook said Apple's goal was to double services revenue in four years. AsFortunepointed out
column26: that goal isunlikely without an acquisition- and it would take a reasonably large deal to get Apple to its ~$50 billion target. And Cook did say on the Q1 call that the company wasn't constrained by size in considering acquisition targets.That doesn't mean Disney will be the target
column27: of course. But Apple's cash pile - particularly with some help from tax reform - and strategy creates a world of possibilities. Last September
column28: another analystspeculatedabout an Apple takeover ofNetflix
column29: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX).Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) Stock Drops After Earnings (As It Should)Bloomberg pointed out in February that Apple could have purchasedTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) to move along its self-driving car ambitions. The site also reported thatAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) feared a competing bid from Apple forTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX).At some point
column30: Apple likely will make a move. And the fact that Apple likely has to make such a move explains some of my skepticism toward Apple stock. The company simplyhasn't been able to drive growthbeyond the iPhone on its own. If it has to buy that growth
column31: it could bring added risk to AAPL stock.As of this writing
column32: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace5 Oil Stocks Collapsing Under the Crude SelloffApple Inc. Wants to Make Recycled iPhones7 Tech Stocks That Are a Sneeze Away From CollapsingThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Won't Buy Walt Disney Co (DIS) - But It Will Do Thisappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Under Armour Inc (UAA) Stock Stumbles by Going the Apple Way;4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIn technology
column3: there are two ways to introduce something. Think of them as theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) way and theAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) or Google way.makeArticleAd();Source:SandyDover via Flickr (Modified)The Apple way seeks proprietary advantage. All intellectual property is tightly controlled. There is a price for everything. The brand absorbs the savings Moore's Law brings to the technology inside it
column5: and profits.The Google way seeks market growth. You offer an open-source method that allows others to benefit. It's all free to try. You grow with the market.In the world of athletic technology
column6: Under Armour Inc(NYSE:UAA) has chosen the Apple way. The market is killing it for this. Its offerings are being called""too technical""andteens are said to preferarch-rivalNike Inc.(NYSE:NKE).Really? Under Armour Is a Dog?InvestorPlacewriters agree. There's a ""glut"" of athleisure apparel
column7: writes Joseph Hargett.UAA stock has a ""serious branding problem
column8: writes Vince Martin.Think twice
column9: writes Will Ashworth.It's ""still a loser
column10: writes Josh Enomoto.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeI can't argue with them.Since its April 2016 stock split
column11: meant to give founder and CEO Kevin Plank the control Google's founders have over the company
column12: the shares are down 56%.The problem isn't in the financials. Under Armour's December quarter showed revenue of $1.305 billion
column13: up from $1.170 billion a year earlier. Net income only fell marginally
column14: from $105.6 million in 2015 to $103.23 million a year later. Debt is down
column15: and cash flow is up.Yet the market has reacted as though UAA stock were going out of business. Shares fell from $29 to less than $22 immediately after the report came out
column16: and opened for trade Apr 13 at $19.28. They need a change
column17: and soon
column18: writes James Brumley
column19: because the March quarter looks terrible
column20: witha loss of three cents per share expected
column21: albeit on revenue of $1.14 billion.The change Under Armour needs is simple. Plank needs to find his inner Google.The Apple MistakeEverything about UAA stock today
column22: like Apple
column23: screams proprietary advantage.Stung by the failures of old retail partners like theSports Authority
column24: Under Armour is opening its own stores. They even look like Apple stores
column25: located in urban centers. Plank is even building his own ""spaceship
column26: a re-imagination of the waterfrontin his hometown of Baltimore.Don't be athletic
column27: the company says.Be The Rock. In my fantasies
column28: I would love to be Dwayne Johnson. Unfortunately
column29: my mom gave birth to Dana Blankenhorn
column30: with a bunion on one foot
column31: and while I like my bicycle I am not going to spend all day working on my abs when I have stories to write. Apple
column32: it should be noted
column33: hasbarely 10% of the smartphone market.Winning in the mass market
column34: it turns out
column35: means winning in the mass market. Under Armour boughtMapMyFitnessfor $150 million in 2013
column36: then spentanother $560 milliononMyFitnessPalandEndomondo
column37: transforming them from tools for casual athletes into tools for elite athletes. As companies likeFitBit Inc(NYSE:FIT) captured the athletic band market
column38: MapMyFitness refused to support them
column39: in favor of competing Under Armour products.There's your problem. We can't all be The Rock. But we can be better Dana Blankenhorns
column40: if technology will give us a chance. Under Armour needs to give us that chance.Aspiration vs. Reality for UAA StockBased on a discounted cash flow model
column41: Under Armourshould be worth 44% morethan it presently is. Technically
column42: the chart presentsa pretty compelling setup.General Electric Company (GE) Q1 Earnings Will Make or Break the StockAll Plank needs to do to score those gains is recognize the difference between a weekend athlete's aspiration and their reality. Athletic technology isn't just for elite athletes. It's for everyone. It's a lifestyle choice
column43: to measure ourselves against yesterday and at least try to match it.Once Under Armour opens its technology to the mass market
column44: taking advantage of Moore's Law rather than trying to fight it as Apple does
column45: today's stock price will look like a bargain.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud

column2: IBM
column3: Alphabet
column4: Verizon and Qualcomm;4/20/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - April 20
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeApple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column7: IBM(NYSE:IBM-Free Report)
column8: Alphabet Inc.(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)
column9: Verizon(NYSE:VZ-Free Report) andQualcomm(NASDAQ:QCOM-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Wednesday's Analyst   Blog:How to Invest in the ""Internet of Things""All around us
column11: the world grows more intertwined every day. Thanks in part to our global web connections
column12: we have the ability to interact with people and things on an incredible level. This online experience can be life-saving and important
column13: or it can be as arbitrary as simplifying monotonous tasks.There are many industries and companies that aim to advance this experience. One growing market
column14: known as the Internet of Things (IoT)
column15: connects our household or commercial items to a wireless network by embedding them with electronic
column16: software
column17: or sensor technology. This network of devices allows us to take the next step into a wireless world that relies less and less on direct human-to-computer interaction.You might actually be using products in the IoT without knowing it. Some common examples include the remote operation of a house's security system
column18: wearable motion and activity tacking products
column19: and even public trash bins that automatically alert a municipality when it is full.The Internet of Things is definitely present in our everyday lives right now
column20: but it also has a lot more room to grow. According to research firm IDC
column21: via theWall Street Journal
column22: the IoT market could nearly triple in the coming years. In 2014
column23: the global IoT market was worth $655.8 billion
column24: but it could reach up to $1.7 trillion by the year 2020.With the industry showing that much room for growth
column25: investors need to start thinking about investing in the IoT now
column26: and we've highlighted a few companies and strategies for those who would like get the IoT into their portfolios.Big Name Patent HoldersOne of the most important steps a company needs to take to capitalize on emerging technology is locking down patents at the earliest possible point. In regards to the Internet of Things market
column27: we've seen a lot of companies filing for patents that put them in a good position to grow as the IoT grows.One such company is technology behemoth Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report). Apple holds a patent named ""Local Device Awareness""
column28: which describes an automated relationship between multiple close-range devices. The technology could be used for position tracking
column29: such as finding a lost remote control
column30: or even proximity-based virtual reality
column31: like a video game that depends on one's actual position in a room.Another major IoT patent holder is IBM (NYSE:IBM-Free Report). Primarily an information technology-focused company
column32: IBM figures to be a major player in the IoT. Currently
column33: IBM holds a patent regarding data filtering in Internet of Things devices
column34: which describes a process in which devices receive and interpret information. This patent puts IBM amongst the frontrunners in technology that allows devices to communicate without human interaction.Furthermore
column35: IBM just announced an Internet of Things partnership with Cisco. IBM will implement its Watson technology into Cisco's wide network of edge devices and end points in an effort to provide real-time feedback and data for the oil & gas
column36: manufacturing
column37: shipping
column38: and mining industries.Today's Leading ProductsWhile patents are important for future growth and development
column39: we also have to look at the already-available IoT devices. Again
column40: we are looking at some of the world's biggest tech companies here.One of the more obvious industry leaders is Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) and its line of Nest home monitoring products. Alphabet
column41: under the Google name at the time
column42: acquired Nest for $3.2 billion in early 2014
column43: and since then the brand has become one of the biggest names in home automation with its smart thermostats
column44: smoke detectors
column45: and safety cameras.(Also read:Google's New ""Home"" Internet of Things Device Challenges Amazon Echo)Finally
column46: Samsung is another major player with its SmartThings brand. Samsung SmartThings are a series of in-home products
column47: ranging from electric outlets to motion sensors
column48: which allow for easier control of a users' entire home.5G RevolutionIt's also important to pay attention to the rise of 5G data networks. The term ""5G"" is short for ""5th generation mobile networks
column49: and it refers to the proposed telecommunications standards that will replace the current 4G standards.While previous standards have focused on human-to-human communication
column50: 5G will need to power the growing Internet of Things and other technologies that seek to bring people closer to the world around them.Telecom giants like Verizon (NYSE:VZ-Free Report) have been building up their portfolios of 5G-compatible wireless spectrum
column51: while chipmakers like Qualcomm (NASDAQ:QCOM-Free Report) are focused on building the needed hardware (also read:Here's How To Invest In The 5G Data Revolution).Bottom LineThe Internet of Things has the potential to change the consumer electronics industry as we know it. The growth of the market will be another indication of humanity's expansion into an autonomous world
column52: and investors need to start taking note of the IoT now.Whether you want to focus on the major technology players or the small companies at the heart of the IoT movement
column53: the time is now to add this industry to your portfolio.Today

column5: April 27.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Can Twitter restore investor confidence?Going into Twitter's first-quarter report
column6: investors seem to   have little confidence in the company's ability to turnaround its   business. With shares trading at $14.54 at the time of this   writing
column7: they're less than a dollar away from an all-time low of   $13.73 and are down 15.1% in the past three months. Twitter's   worse-than-expected revenue in its most recent quarter
column8: combined   with slow revenue growth recently
column9: has set the bar low.Analysts have a gloomy outlook for the quarter. On average
column10: analysts expect Twitter to report revenue and non-GAAP EPS of   $513 million and $0.01
column11: respectively
column12: down from $595 million and   $0.15 in the year-ago quarter.In Twitter's fourth-quarter shareholder letter
column13: management   said it's seen ""increased competitive pressure resulting in a   decline in our original Promoted Tweet engagement format."" WithFacebook's popularity with advertisersshowing no signs of letting up
column14: and the social network continuing to rapidly innovate with its   ad products across its core Facebook app and Instagram
column15: competitive pressure could continue to hurt Twitter.Investors should look for management to provide some concrete   evidence of a turnaround.Will Alphabet live up to high expectations?Unlike with Twitter
column16: investors have high expectations for   Alphabet when the company reports first-quarter results on   Thursday. Look no further than the stock's price-to-earnings   ratio of 30 for insight into just how bullish investors are on   the company's growth potential. This P/E ratio is well above the   average P/E ratio of 24.5 of stocks in the S&P 500 and tech   peerApple's P/E ratio of 16.9.On average
column17: analysts expect Alphabet to report revenue and   non-GAAP EPS of $24.2 billion and $7.38
column18: respectively. While   analysts' consensus estimate for non-GAAP EPS is below non-GAAP   EPS of $7.50 in the year-ago quarter
column19: investors should keep in   mind that Alphabet isno longer excluding stock-based compensation from   its non-GAAP resultsstarting with its first quarter of 2017. So it makes sense that   Alphabet's non-GAAP EPS would decline year over year. Analysts'   consensus estimate for Alphabet's revenue is a better reflection   of the company's growth. A consensus estimate for revenue of   $24.2 billion is up 19.4% year over year.Beyond Alphabet's total revenue growth and its adjusted EPS
column20: investors may want to look out for any commentary from management   about mobile search and YouTube -- two areas of the company's   business that have served as key catalysts for growth   recently.In addition
column21: investors should look for an update on Alphabet's   ""other bets"" revenue. While still representing only a fraction of   total revenue
column22: the segment saw its revenue soar 75% in the   company's most recent quarter
column23: hitting $262 million. Further
column24: its   operating loss narrowed from $1.2 billion to $1.1 billion.Twitter reports its first-quarter results before the market   opens on Wednesday
