column1: Google's New Chip May Be the Future of AI Systems;4/18/2017;"Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) Google announced at its I/O   Developers Conference in May 2016 that it had designed a new   chip
column2: called the tensor processing unit (TPU)
column3: specifically   designed for the demands of training artificial intelligence (AI)   systems. The company didn't divulge much at the time
column4: but in ablog postthat same week
column5: hardware engineer Norm Jouppi revealed that   Google had been running the TPU in the company's data centers for   more than a year and ""found them to deliver an order of magnitude   better-optimized performance per watt for machine learning. This   is roughly equivalent to fast-forwarding technology about seven   years into the future (three generations of Moore's Law).""The chip was an application-specific integrated circuit   (ASIC)
column6: a microchip designed for a specific application. Little   else was known about the enigmatic TPU and the mystery continued   until last week
column7: when Google pulled back the curtain to reveal   the inner workings of this new groundbreaking advancement for   AI.Google's tensor processing unit could revolutionize AI     processing. Image source: Google.makeArticleAd();Speed and efficiencyThe TPU underlies TensorFlow
column8: Google's open-source machine   learning framework
column9: a collection of algorithms that power the   company's deep neural networks. These AI systems are capable of   teaching themselves by processing large amounts of data. Google   tailored the TPU to meet the unique demands of training its AI   systems
column10: which had previously been run primarily on graphics   processing units (GPUs) manufactured byNVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ: NVDA) . While the company currently runs the TPU and GPU   side by side (for now)
column11: this could have drastic implications for   how AI systems are trained going forward.Google released a study -- authored by more than 70   contributors -- that provided a detailed analysis of the   TPU. In ablog postearlier this month
column12: Jouppi laid out the capabilities of the chip.   He described how it processed AI production workloads 15 to 30   times faster than CPUs and GPUs performing the same task
column13: and   achieved a 30 to 80 times improvement in energy efficiency.Saved the cost of 12 new data centersGoogle realized several years ago that if customers were to   use Google voice search for just three minutes each day
column14: that   would require the company to double its existing number of data   centers. The company also credits the TPU with providing faster   response times for search
column15: acting as the linchpin for   improvements in Google Translate
column16: and was a key factor in its AI   system's defeat of a world champion in the ancient Chinesegame of Go.Companies are taking a variety of approaches to bring   improvements to AI systems.Intel Corporation's(NASDAQ: INTC) recently acquired start-up Nervana has developed   its own ASIC
column17: the Nervana Engine
column18: that eliminates components from   the GPU not essential to the functions necessary for AI. The   company also re-engineered the memory and believed it could   realize 10 times the processing currently performed by   GPUs. Intel isworking to integratethis capability on its existing processor platforms to better   compete with NVIDIA's offering.Not the only game in townA field-programmable gate array (FPGA) processor can be   reprogrammed after installation and is another chip being   leveraged for gains in AI. FPGAs have increasingly been used in   data centers to accelerate machine learning.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ: AAPL) is widely believed to haveinstalled this chipin its iPhone 7 to promote sophisticated AI advances locally on   each phone. The company has emphasized not sacrificing user   privacy to make advances in AI
column19: so this would be a logical move   for its smartphones.NVIDIA Tesla P100 powers Facebook's AI server. Image source:     NVIDIA.Facebook
column20: Inc.(NASDAQ: FB) has taken adifferent approachin optimizing its recently released data center server named Big   Basin. The company created a platform that utilizes eight NVIDIA   Tesla P100 GPU accelerators attached with NVLink connectors   designed to reduce bottlenecks
column21: in what it described as ""the most   advanced data center GPU ever built."" The company revealed that   this latest server is capable of training 30% larger machine   learning data systems in about half the time. Facebook also   indicated that the architecture was based NVIDIA's DGX-1 ""AI   supercomputer in a box.""Much more innovation to comeThough we have been hearing about almost daily breakthroughs   in AI
column22: it is important to remember that the science is still in   its infancy and new developments will likely continue at a rapid   pace. These advances provide for more efficient systems and lay   the foundation for future progress in the field. These necessary   advances will propel future innovation
column23: but are difficult to   quantify in terms of dollars and cents
column24: as well as the potential   effects on future revenue and profitability.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column25: it can pay to listen. After all
column26: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column27: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column28: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares) wasn't   one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column2: Western Digital

column4: Alphabet and Amazon;4/18/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - April 18
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeBroadcom(NASDAQ:AVGO-Free Report)
column7: Western Digital(NASDAQ:WDC-Free Report)
column8: Apple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column9: Alphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) andAmazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Monday's Analyst Blog:Why Suitors Are Flocking to Toshiba's Chip BusinessToshiba has been in trouble since the surfacing of accounting irregularities in its Westinghouse nuclear business that included cost overruns on nuclear construction projects as well as overstatement of profit from the years 2008 through 2014. The company expects to report an annual loss of $9 billion this year due to write-downs related to Westinghouse and has given a warning that it may not be able to continue as a going concern as a result. This ultimately also led to tensions with auditors PriceWaterhouseCoopers.But not all of this 142-year old electronics conglomerate is mired in losses; one section that is doing rather well is the flash memory chip business
column11: where it has a JV with SanDisk (now Western Digital). So Toshiba needs to sell this business and install proper internal controls
column12: which if unsatisfactory
column13: will lead to its de-listing. Which is why it has put this business on auction.While the front runners in the bidding process are Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO-Free Report) and private equity firm Silver Lake Partners
column14: Taiwan's Foxconn (Honhai Precision Industry)
column15: South Korean chipmaker SK Hynix
column16: and Western Digital (NASDAQ:WDC-Free Report) itself
column17: some news reports indicate that Softbank
column18: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column19: Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report) may also be interested.Of these
column20: Broadcom's first round offer of 2.5 trillion yen ($23 billion) and Foxconn's 2 trillion yen are the highest bids. Hynix's bid is unknown as is Western Digital's
column21: but WDC has said that analysts estimate the fair value to be around 1.5 trillion yen.Why the Excitement?Toshiba is the second largest NAND flash memory maker
column22: a technology that is increasingly taking over mobile devices and finding application in the cloud. The advantage of flash memory is in its speed and reliability
column23: while the regular hard drive storage is cheaper but shorter-lived. As the cost of flash drives falls over time
column24: it will be used more broadly and will replace or at least supplement hard drive storage.Since most tech players mentioned in the previous section either sell memory or buy it
column25: they would gain leverage from acquiring the technology. Those that sell can augment their current offerings while those that buy will have another way to consolidate their supply chain and thus lower costs while also gaining technological advantage.What Could Be the ResultThe deal will have a political angle to it
column26: since the Japanese government is unlikely to approve a sale to investors that might bring risk to national security. Because of its links to China
column27: a sale to Foxconn will likely not be approved by the government
column28: even if Japanese banks agree to partner with it to finance the deal. So Hynix is better placed to win.On the other hand
column29: the government will be quicker to approve the deal if the unit stays between Japanese and American owners. Since Western Digital has issues with Broadcom
column30: and it will most likely have a say (given its $13 billion investment in the JV over several years and current agreement with Toshiba)
column31: Broadcom may not be able to bid successfully in this case. But Western Digital won't be able to buy out the unit unless it gets itself some partners (the company may not be able to dish out more cash so soon after SanDisk).That leaves combinations of American and Japanese players
column32: which may include Apple and Softbank. Apple will prefer that Foxconn gets a stake because it is its major supplier. So Toshiba may successfully sell a portion of the business to the Apple-Foxconn combination or Apple-Softbank-Foxconn combination or a combination that includes Softbank and other players.The Best & Worst of ZacksToday you are invited to download the full

column1: Should You Steer Clear of Microsoft this Earnings Season?;4/18/2017;"Microsoft CorpMSFTis one of those few technology bellwethers that have consistently reported positive earnings beat in the trailing twelve months. column2: with an average positive surprise of 8.55%.makeArticleAd();Earnings growth has also been impressive over this period. In the last quarter (second-quarter fiscal 2017)
column3: Microsoft reported earnings of 83 cents per share
column4: which increased 9.2% on both year-over-year and sequential basis.Microsoft Unlikely to Beat in Q3However
column5: we will prefer to avoid Microsoft this earnings season due to the unfavorable combination of a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) and anEarnings ESPof -1.45%. Earnings ESP is the difference between Most Accurate Estimate and the Zacks Consensus Estimate.As per our proven model a stock is likely to post an earnings beat when it has a favorable combination of positive Earnings ESP and a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy)
column6: 2 (Buy) or 3 (Hold). You can uncover the best stocks to buy or sell before they're reported with ourEarnings ESP Filter.Conversely

column9: while the industry gained 9.7%. The underperformance can be attributed to slowing Azure cloud services revenue growth

However

column1: Will Virtual Assistants Revolutionize Home Automation?;4/18/2017;"Almost everyone with a smartphone is familiar with some of the   capabilities of voice-controlled virtual assistants. Siri fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ: AAPL) was the first out of the gate and may be the most   well known. Google Assistant fromAlphabet
column2: Inc.(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) is the search giant's latest   version of Google Now.Amazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ: AMZN) gave us Alexa
column4: though she is mostly limited to   home speakers.Until the release of these virtual helpers
column5: home automation   was primarily the dominion of expensive professionally installed   systems that controlled everything
column6: or managed services that   provided monthly monitoring of things like alarm systems. Both   are still available
column7: but the revolution in the smart-home market   is playing out in the individual components and smart devices   that homeowners can purchase and control with these ubiquitous   virtual assistants.One thing to be aware of: Each virtual assistant has   advantages and drawbacks
column8: with no clear winner -- yet.makeArticleAd();Virtual assistants will drive smart-home adoption. Image     source: Getty images.Apple HomeKitSiri is the backbone for Apple's HomeKit
column9: the smartphone app   that can be used to control a variety of smart-home products.   This platform provides a variety of helpful features to simplify   the process of adding devices and labeling ""Favorites."" You   can also organize the various components by ""Rooms"" and create   ""Scenes"" that will control multiple devices with one command.Another feature is that you can automate certain functions to   occur at a specific time of day
column10: or when you leave home. The best   feature of HomeKit
column11: in typical Apple fashion
column12: is its ease of   operation -- and it can be controlled by the app
column13: or using voice   control.A key point is that HomeKit-compatible devices have been   reviewed and vetted by Apple
column14: providing end-to-end security. This   limits the number of available devices
column15: but will likely prevent   you from being hacked. On the downside
column16: Apple lacks a home   speaker system.Amazon Alexa and EchoAmazon's Alexa powers the Echo
column17: Echo Dot
column18: and Tap smart-home   speakers
column19: but lacks a dedicated smartphone app. Amazon has   integrated access to Alexa via its Amazon shopping app on the   iPhone by tapping the microphone button in the app. Alexa's   advantage is in the number of things she can do -- she accepts   over 10
column20: 000 commands
column21: called ""skills
column22: though they require   remembering the very specific wording of each command.These skills address a variety of areas
column23: not just the smart   home
column24: though the system integrates with dozens of smart-home   devices that work directly with Alexa
column25: and hundreds that operate   using a variety of manufacturer-specific apps. Integrating many   of these products requires a special If This Then That (IFTTT)   device to connect them and to set up routines to control multiple   components with a single command. There's also no independent   verification regarding device security.Smart homes powered by virtual assistants. Image source:     Pixabay.Google Home and Home ControlGoogle recently introduced Home
column26: a smart-home speaker similar   to Amazon's Echo. It's powered by a Google Assistant
column27: though not   the same Assistant that operates on Google's Android phones or   the Allo messaging app -- and they aren't integrated as of this   writing.The Assistant on Home works with components from four   smart-home partners currently (Nest
column28: Philips Hue
column29: IFTTT
column30: and   SmartThings) -- far fewer than Alexa. Google plans to add   additional partners over time
column31: though those currently available   cover the most used home-automation components.Integrating multiple smart-home products through Home requires   an IFTTT device to connect them to each other and set up   routines
column32: similar to Alexa. Also similar to Alexa
column33: there's no   independent verification of device security
column34: which varies by   manufacturer. Home has Google search at its heart
column35: so it   understands detailed questions and requests rather than the   specific skills commands required by Alexa.Some consumers will be drawn to Echo or Home by the novelty   factor
column36: or for the variety of other capabilities
column37: and adding   smart-home products will be an unintended result of   ownership.Something for investorsEach system has advantages and downfalls regarding its   home-automation capabilities. No one has yet developed a ""killer   app."" At this point
column38: smart-home products seem to represent more   of a hobby than something designed to produce significant revenue   growth for any of these companies. However
column39: the team of Alexa and   Echo has an advantage for Amazon not available to Apple or   Google.A recent analyst note by Jim Shaughnessy and Mark Mahaney of   RBC Capital Markets reported that 17% of current users of the   Echo family of products placed orders to Amazon.com with their   devices
column40: which could result in additional sales of $10 billion in   both products and devices annually by 2020.While the hardware war is being waged
column41: Amazon might enjoy a   nice little boost on the e-commerce side.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Why Facebook's Payments Strategy Isn't About Payments;4/17/2017;"ByKaren Webster:If you want to know how and where a company will strategically spend its time
column2: money and efforts
column3: then look no further than how itmakesits money. So
column4: tomorrow whenFacebook's (FB) Developer Conference
column5: dubbedF8
column6: kicks off
column7: don't be surprised if payments isn't the star of the show.Except for when â€¦For that
column8: you'll have to read on. I've read that cliffhangers that build slowly are all the rage now.makeArticleAd();Named after Facebook'sinfamous dusk-to-dawn
column9: eight-hour Hackathons
column10: F8 is an annual confab intended to give developers a look at new tools that will help them reach and engage the 1.9 billion and 1.2 billion unique people who now visit Facebook every month and every day
column11: respectively.Over those two days
column12: it seems a near certainty that those developers will hear more about the things thatMark Zuckerberglaid out in his F8 keynote last year: how to make video more plentiful and engaging
column13: how to use AI to make user experiences more meaningful and personalized
column14: how to use AR/VR to create new user experiences and what Facebook is doing to give the 4 billion people in the world who don't have internet access today the chance to get it inexpensively.All things intended to support Facebook'score missionof ""giving people the power to share and remain open and connected.""Those people also include advertisers - and giving that group of people the ability to share their messages supports another core Facebook mission: generating a return for their shareholders. Those are the people who generate Facebook's revenue. So that will make the star(s) of the show tomorrow those things that Facebook can do to tie those people ever closer to its ecosystem - without alienating the users whospend nearly an hour every dayscrolling through their news feed and whose eyeballs they monetize.From Social Network to Advertising NetworkFacebook may still be described by its users as a social network
column15: but it's far from that - 13 years after it was launched and five years since it went public. Facebook is a gigantic advertising platform
column16: the second largest in the world behind Google (GOOG) (GOOGL). Facebook'stotal 2016 revenue
column17: at $27.6 billion
column18: was almost entirely the result of selling ads to brands that wanted to get their message in front of its massive and highly engaged user base. (By way of comparison
column19: Google's ad revenue was $79 billion in 2016.)Payments accounted for a relatively paltry $753 million in revenue by comparison
column20: down from the $849 million the year before. The decline of 11 percent year over year didn't exactly blow much of a hole in Facebook's bottom line or dampen investor interest.What would - and has in years past - is falling short on Facebook's ability to feed the ad beast. When Facebook announced that it was dangerously close to running out of ad inventory on its platform last fall
column21: its share price dropped sharply. That's because the market rightfully pegs Facebook's biggest adversary as Google and its competitive playing field as advertising.Not payments.That didn't stop everyone - and maybe even Facebook at one point - from thinking that Facebook wanted to be a payments platform. Once upon a time and back when ""FarmVille"" and""CityVille"" were the rage
column22: payments drove an interesting revenue stream for Facebook. Millions of people buying chickens and cherry trees for their FarmVille farms
column23: in turn
column24: sparked a payments ambition - remember Facebook credits? But once gaming moved to apps
column25: Facebook lost those eyeballs and that revenue stream and
column26: appropriately
column27: any interest in creating a new form of currency for the Facebook platform.Its vision of turning Facebook into a giant shopping mall where people would shop and pay on the Facebook platform never materialized either. Remember Payvment and the social commerce movement? The notion that brands could launch Facebook storefronts and turn hundreds of millions of Facebook fans into buyers flopped
column28: too. Consumers didn't want to shop on their social network
column29: and those storefront operators - even those with tens of thousands of fans - found that unless they bought ads that directed people to those storefronts
column30: Facebook's news feed algorithms made conversions abysmal and the ROI unappealing. Even selling gift cards on Facebook fizzled.But if one needed any further proof that ""getting into"" and monetizing payments inside of Facebook was an experiment that has long outlived its strategic purpose
column31: one need to look no further than Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg's response to an analyst question about buy buttons duringFebruary's Q4 2016 earnings call.""The core of our focus is still very much focused on ads and how we can do ads at the product level
column32: was her answer.A strategy that means that Facebook has moved away from thinking of itself as the place where commerce happens and payment is monetizedinsideof its ecosystem - but as an ecosystem that builds contextual and targeted ad-driven experiences that engage its users and direct them off Facebook to the brand's website to buy.Because advertising - and not payments - is how Facebook makes it money. And their own website is where brands want their users to conduct business.Facebook and Its Massive Ad EngineIt makes perfect sense.Platforms - the ones that scale and survive - figure out ways to build and monetize their platform assets. Facebook's assets are its users
column33: the data they share about themselves and the time that they spend soaking up content in their news feeds.Facebook
column34: therefore
column35: knows a lot about its users - and that knowledge is highly monetizable as their ~$20 ARPU suggests. Facebook keeps track of every post their users like
column36: every group they belong to
column37: every update they make to their favorites
column38: every change in their status
column39: every comment they make and about what or who
column40: places they tag and people with whom they are tagged.Facebook enriches that data set - which is already pretty valuable - with information from data aggregators. Data on users' income
column41: marital status
column42: loans
column43: mortgages
column44: credit cards
column45: how much their house is worth
column46: where they were born
column47: where they went to school
column48: how many kids they have and their ages
column49: what kind of car they drive
column50: where they work and the town in which they live (and much more) is mashed up with information Facebook gets from sites that its users visit that have the Facebook sharing button and what those users are looking at and clicking on. Facebook can then offer advertisers more than 1
column51: 300 attributes to reach a very relevant set of eyeballs.In the Belly of the Facebook Ad BeastOver the past several years
column52: Facebook has innovated on how those brands can grab their targeted user's attention.Dynamic adson Facebook allow brands to present a carousel of their products from their product catalogue inside a user's news feed. Facebook's newly launched travelCityGuidesgive users information on what's happening in cities like Boston and allow them to book hotel rooms and make other travel arrangements. Facebook reports that for brands using these dynamic formats
column53: recall increases 20 percent and awareness by as much 11 percent.Facebook's Canvas product turns product ads into app-like experiences and gives advertisers new ways to showcase them.Western Unionreported a 13 percent increase in brand recall and affinity and a 7 percent increase in purchase intent when such a campaign targets Hispanic consumers.Shopping on Instagramoffers brands a way to engage with users and show them new and/or curated products. Launched last fall as a trial
column54: last month
column55: that trial was expanded from its 20 pilot set of brands to many more brands. Kate Spade said that their customers loved the ability to seamlessly move from information to inspiration to purchase -one pilot retailerreported a 33 percent lift in conversions.And in every case - via dynamic ads or Canvas or Shopping on Facebook - those conversions and sales lifts were measured by users who clicked through those ad experiences and off Facebook to the brand's own websites to complete the purchase.What's NextThe opportunity for brands to engage with Facebook will expand as soon as Facebook expands the reach of its ad exchange - the Facebook Audience Network
column56: or FAN - beyond Facebook and innovates the formats in which brands can promote their products and services on its platform.Last month
column57: Facebook announced its partnership with Amazon (AMZN) to take FAN off Facebook by leveraging Amazon's header-bidding system to expand its inventory off Facebook. That partnership will help Facebook compete more effectively in the display ad business and give its brands the chance to be featured in those ads. It's also a pretty big shot across Google's bow
column58: who's now the de facto king of the header bidding business.Video is another area of growth for Facebook - and another direct hit to Google's YouTube. Facebook has said that it will focus its efforts
column59: at least right now
column60: on the 90-second spots that include advertising after 20 seconds has been watched. Those ads also will allow consumers to punch out to brand websites to make a buy. Video ads were cited as a success story in Facebook's Q4 earnings call
column61: as driving double-digit increases in brand recall and brand awareness for the launch of Hershey's Cookie Layer Crunch and Nielsen data reported and a 3.5 percent lift in sales for Motorola when used in support of a new product launch.Now
column62: here's where the crescendo starts to build.More than 90 percent of Facebook's users access it via mobile devices that direct those users to a mobile website. And we all know what happens when users end up on merchant sites via their mobile devices to make a purchase.Checkout fail
column63: a large number of times.And that failure to convert a click to a sale is one of the reasons why Facebook ad rates are so low.Payments and payments innovators can help.What should be clear is that Facebook's interest isn't to payment-enable Facebook and commerce inside of its ecosystems
column64: because payments isn't how Facebook makes its money.But it could make more of it if it found a way to streamline the checkout process once users clicked off a product page and onto the website of the brand.And that's where payments and the payments ecosystem can help - and the opportunity for the payments ecosystems as gigantic as the advertising opportunity that Facebook is enabling on its platform. Optimizing the payments experience for the brands that Facebook users interact with will help Facebook create even more value for the brands that turn to them to generate their leads. It also will increase the value of the Facebook advertising platform by more closely correlating clicks to sales - and giving Facebook the ammo it needs to increase the rates that it charges advertisers.And from what ourCheckout Conversion Indexreflects
column65: there's a lot of work to be done by the brands to make their checkout process smoother.Facebook has proven that it can lead the horse to water. Now it's up to the payments ecosystem to get it to drink.But What about Chatbots and Group Payments?Yes
column66: Facebook made news a few weeks ago when it launched group payments
column67: and a year ago when it launched chatbots and payment-enabled them inside of Messenger.Here's my take on both.Messenger has enabled P2P payments since July 2015 and that wasn't about payments either. P2P payments are free to users and so are group payments - not exactly a monetization opportunity. But what is: creating a network inside of Messenger that would make Messenger more valuable to advertisers.Messenger is now starting to testads inside of Messenger.Chatbots
column68: well
column69: I think you know where I stand on those.Yes
column70: there are tens of thousands of them
column71: and yes
column72: some 30
column73: 000 of them are also payment-enabled. And no
column74: not a whole lot of payments activity is happening inside of them
column75: because
column76: even by David Marcus' admission
column77: they are overhyped and they underdeliver.I'll spare you my ""Poncho the Weather Cat"" story.Chatbots though
column78: TechCrunch reported
column79: also will make their debut at F8 (mostly
column80: they say) as a way to keep groups informed of such mission-critical information like whetherDustin Pedoria'shit was a home run recently. Chatbots
column81: in my book
column82: still have a long
column83: long way to go - and like with anything else
column84: are up against some stiff competition with a running head start - and where time and consumer patience in putting up with the not-so-intelligent chatbots inside of Messenger could quickly turn the tide against them.I'm thinking here about voice-activated ecosystems and Amazon's Alexa - but that's another column for another Monday.But
column85: hey
column86: even Facebook needs its moonshots - it bought Oculus Rift
column87: didn't it?See alsoConocoPhillips

column1: Why Suitors Are Flocking to Toshiba's Chip Business;4/17/2017;"Toshiba has been in trouble since the surfacing of accounting irregularities in its Westinghouse nuclear business that included cost overruns on nuclear construction projects as well as overstatement of profit from the years 2008 through 2014. The company expects to report an annual loss of $9 billion this year due to write-downs related to Westinghouse and has given a warning that it may not be able to continue as a going concern as a result. This ultimately also led to tensions with auditors PriceWaterhouseCoopers.But not all of this 142-year old electronics conglomerate is mired in losses; one section that is doing rather well is the flash memory chip business
column2: where it has a JV with SanDisk (now Western Digital). So Toshiba needs to sell this business and install proper internal controls
column3: which if unsatisfactory
column4: will lead to its de-listing. Which is why it has put this business on auction.While the front runners in the bidding process are BroadcomAVGOand private equity firm Silver Lake Partners
column5: Taiwan's Foxconn (Honhai Precision Industry)
column6: South Korean chipmaker SK Hynix
column7: and Western DigitalWDCitself
column8: some news reports indicate that Softbank
column9: AppleAAPL
column10: AlphabetGOOGLand AmazonAMZNmay also be interested.Of these
column11: Broadcom's first round offer of 2.5 trillion yen ($23 billion) and Foxconn's 2 trillion yen are the highest bids. Hynix's bid is unknown as is Western Digital's
column12: but WDC has said that analysts estimate the fair value to be around 1.5 trillion yen.Why the Excitement?Toshiba is the second largest NAND flash memory maker
column13: a technology that is increasingly taking over mobile devices and finding application in the cloud. The advantage of flash memory is in its speed and reliability
column14: while the regular hard drive storage is cheaper but shorter-lived. As the cost of flash drives falls over time
column15: it will be used more broadly and will replace or at least supplement hard drive storage.Since most tech players mentioned in the previous section either sell memory or buy it
column16: they would gain leverage from acquiring the technology. Those that sell can augment their current offerings while those that buy will have another way to consolidate their supply chain and thus lower costs while also gaining technological advamtage.What Could Be the ResultThe deal will have a political angle to it
column17: since the Japanese government is unlikely to approve a sale to investors that might bring risk to national security. Because of its links to China
column18: a sale to Foxconn will likely not be approved by the government
column19: even if Japanese banks agree to partner with it to finance the deal. So Hynix is better placed to win.On the other hand
column20: the government will be quicker to approve the deal if the unit stays between Japanese and American owners. Since Western Digital has issues with Broadcom
column21: and it will most likely have a say (given its $13 billion investment in the JV over several years and current agreement with Toshiba)
column22: Broadcom may not be able to bid successfully in this case. But Western Digital won't be able to buy out the unit unless it gets itself some partners (the company may not be able to dish out more cash so soon after SanDisk).That leaves combinations of American and Japanese players
column23: which may include Apple and Softbank. Apple will prefer that Foxconn gets a stake because it is its major supplier. So Toshiba may successfully sell a portion of the business to the Apple-Foxconn combination or Apple-Softbank-Foxconn combination or a combination that includes Softbank and other players.The Best & Worst of ZacksToday you are invited to download the full

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Rumor Points to Multi-User Support for iOS 11;4/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of the biggest advantagesApple Inc.'s(NADAQ:AAPL) tablet competitors hold over the iPad is the support for multiple user accounts. With the exception of the education market
column3: AAPL's stance has always been one iPad
column4: one user. But that could change with iOS 11. A new report claims the latest version of Apple's tvOS for the Apple TV includes support for multiple accounts. And if that's the case
column5: there's a possibility we would see iOS multi-user capability as well
column6: when Apple introduces iOS 11 at WWDC 2017.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleOn the surface
column7: a tablet being able to support multiple user accounts may not seem like a big deal. But for many people - especially families - it is. Since Apple first started selling iPads
column8: consumers have had the choice of buying one for each person in their family
column9: or dealing with the consequences of everyone sharing the same Apple user ID.Why Support for Multiple User Accounts MattersBecause there is no iOS multi-user support
column10: this means that if a parent let a child borrow their iPad
column11: any changes that child made would stick when the adult went to use it. That includes apps downloaded (or deleted)
column12: preferences and user settings changed. In addition
column13: the person borrowing the iPad would have full access to any content
column14: including potentially sensitive documents and photos.With kids trying to share a single iPad
column15: this is a virtual guarantee of non-stop fighting that simply isn't worth the hassle for most parents.Apple's tablet competition supports multiple user accounts on one device.Microsoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Windows tablets support multi-user login.Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column16: NASDAQ:GOOGL) introduced multiple user support for tablets with Android 4.2 in 2012.Amazon.com
column17: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire tablets offer Household Profiles with support for two adults and four children on each device
column18: with shared content access plus private content and personal settings based on who's signed in on the device.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyAppleMaybe Working on iOS Multi-User Support for iOS 119to5Macpicked up on a report fromThe Verifierthat claimsAAPL is adding support for multiple accounts to the next version of tvOSfor the Apple TV.What does this have to do with iPads? AAPL's tvOS is based on iOS. If Apple introduces a fundamental feature like support for multiple accounts in tvOS
column19: there's a good chance the same capability is built into iOS. With that new version of tvOS scheduled to be unveiled atWWDC 2017in June
column20: that means we may just hear about iOS multi-user support when Apple takes the wraps off iOS 11 at that same event.And Appledidbuild in a form of support for multiple users on iPads -available exclusively to the education market- with iOS 9.3 in early 2016.What AAPL Would GainWith support for multiple user accounts
column21: Apple would have a shot at selling iPads to a demographic it hasn't really actively targeted in the past.There are many families with limited income for buying gadgets. The cost of an iPad isn't necessarily a barrier. But buying one for each child (plus the parents) may well be out of reach. Many of these households have turned to Android and Amazon Fire tablets not because they prefer these over iPads
column22: but because with support for multiple users
column23: they are more affordable.Apple Inc. Scores Higher Global Mac Sales Amid Broad PC DeclinesIf AAPL introduces iOS multi-user support for the iPad
column24: it stands a far better chance of capturing a bigger chunk of this market that it has largely ignored.The idea of iOS multi-user support for iPads may seem far-fetched. After all
column25: Apple has always followed the strategy of one iPad per user. Supporting multiple accounts has always been seen as a potential threat to iPad sales.However
column26: times are changing. AAPL's iPad sales continue to slide. And the company has already done the unthinkable
column27: with therelease in March of the new full-sized iPad for just $329. We'll find out at WWDC 2017 if Apple is willing to take the next step toward making the iPad accessible to a much wider demographic with iOS multi-user support.As of this writing
column28: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. Order Telegraphs Record iPhone 8 Sales (AAPL)Apple Inc. (AAPL) Promises New Mac Pro in 2018
column29: New Pro iMac in 201710 Hopeless Stocks to Wash From Your Portfolio ForeverThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Rumor Points to Multi-User Support for iOS 11appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Buy Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Without Worry;4/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsPrice action following a recent downgrade inNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) is enough to make Goldman Sachs blush. But after a steep and swift decline over the past month that's left NVDA 8% in the red despite today's 2% bump
column3: is it really time to buy NVDA stock?makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockLet's take a look at what's happening both off and on the NVDA chart and then present a limited-risk options strategy to match our view.If you thought the venerable Goldman Sachs holds sway with investors
column4: think again. Shares of NVDA are off 10% since broker Pacific Crest cut semiconductor outfit Nvidia to ""underweight"" from ""sector weight"" back on April 4.Pacific Crest cited a saturated GPU market
column5: lowerNintendo Co.
column6: Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY) Switch sales margins and a likely pause in the company's data center business asreasons behind the downgradein NVDA.However
column7: repeated bullish analyst noteson Nvidia from Goldman over the past couple months are net-net underwater and well-removed from a $130 price target in NVDA stock.10 Spring Cleaning Tips for Your PortfolioSo
column8: who's right and who's wrong? Only time is really going to tell
column9: but I personally welcome the near-sighted focus on Pac Crest's bearish Nvidia stock narrative by other investors.The way I see the situation in Nvidia
column10: the current about-face in one of 2016's best-performing stocks is creating an opportunity
column11: to pick up a company entrenched in some of the market's strongest
column12: secular growth areas
column13: on the cheap and maybe a good deal cheaper.NVDA Stock Daily ChartClick to EnlargeLast month
column14: following a 21% corrective move that reset NVDA stock's base count
column15: I was optimistic of higher prices in the making. The constructive price action looked sufficient to have removed prior excessive and erratic behavior that grew over the course of NVDA's massive bullish run during 2016.Over the past couple weeks
column16: though
column17: Nvidia stock has proceeded to get knocked back down and challenge its corrective lows. The evolving price action puts shares into a potentially bullish
column18: double-bottom situation if NVDA is able to reverse higher.If NVDA shares continue to move down in price
column19: a lower-low variation of the double-bottom pattern could set up as low as the drawn in neckline near $91.50.Below the neckline and Nvidia stock bears will have momentum in their favor down to $84 a share. A decline of that size works out to a corrective move of just over 30%. It also offers a test of the 200-day simple moving average and 38% retracement level from the February 2016 low.So what if NVDA still isn't finished correcting and fails to hold those supports above today's pop? That's potentially very bad news. Technically
column20: Nvidia stock could be following through on a measured move from a head-and-shoulders pattern. Conservatively
column21: a break of the neckline signals an eventual move in NVDA down near $68.NVDA Bullish Spread ComboFor investors that are inclined to be bullish on NVDA
column22: but appreciate the risk of a topping pattern and earnings on the horizon
column23: I like the idea of combining a bullishly targeted long call butterfly and out-of-the-money put vertical spread.Reviewing the Nvidia options board and with shares closing the past trading day at $95.49
column24: a package of selling the May $85/$80 put spread and purchasing the May $100/$110/$120 call butterfly is priced for 75 cents or better. For 75 cents
column25: the combination allows the trader to have an upside profit range from $100.75 to $119.25. The sweet spot at $110 allows for profits to max out at $9.25 if NVDA were to land on the strike at expiration.Above $120
column26: the trader would forfeit 75 cents at expiration. For bulls of course this represents a sacrifice. Our view is this is a reasonable allowance considering it matches the prior high in Nvidia and should take more than an earnings beat
column27: to be cleared.Go Long Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Into EarningsIf NVDA fails to rally above $100 or declines in price
column28: at expiration the trader is out 75 cents if the stock is between $85 and $100 a share. Below $85 and losses begin to accrue one-for-one with a decline in Nvidia shares. At $80 or lower
column29: a loss of $5.75 would be realized.In the event of this type of dramatic move
column30: however
column31: and a stock purchase price that's never worse than $85.75
column32: the trader may see this as a nice starting point for building a longer-term position.Investment accounts under Christopher Tyler's management do not currently own positions in any of the securities or their derivatives mentioned in this article. column1: Qualcomm
column2: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Is Still a Buy Despite Its Issues;4/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIn the bookHow Google Works
column4: Eric Schmidt and Jonathan Rosenberg talk extensively about the convergence of three big trends in business: the Internet
column5: mobile communication
column6: and cloud computing. Semiconductor giantQualcomm
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of this convergence.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIts chip technology has helped power billions of cellphones since its founding in the mid-1980s. QCOM offers both chips and licenses to its technology that resulted in $23.6 billion in sales last year and $7.4 billion in operating cash flow.That 31.4% cash flow margin demonstrates that Qualcomm is fantastically profitable. Last year
column8: that totaled $3.81 in reported earnings. For the full current year
column9: analysts project a big jump in earnings to $4.66 per share on sales of $23.8 billion. They expect only a modest bump in sales and profits for fiscal 2018.The Dangers of QualcommThe slow growth in recent years (sales peaked in fiscal 2014 at $26.5 billion) is a key reason that QCOM stock has sagged. Its highest level was a hair above $81 per share in April 2014. However
column10: shares now trade below $53 per share
column11: close to its lows over the past 52 weeks.The competition also doesn't appreciate that Qualcomm is so dominant. Its CDMA (Code Division Multiple Access) technology is prevalent in nearly every cell phone the 3G and 4G wireless communication standards. Any cell phone manufacturer that makes these handsets has to pay a royalty to Qualcomm.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyThis has led to a slew of legal challenges to its patents. Just this week
column12: Blackberry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY)
column13: an erstwhile giant in the cell phone market
column14: was awardedan $815 million ""refund."" A court ruled that Qualcomm owed the refund to Blackberry
column15: suggesting that Blackberry had overpaid on its royalties to Qualcomm because of its flagging sales of Blackberry mobile devices. The decision looks to be binding
column16: and Qualcomm will make the payment out of its large cash reserves.iPhone juggernautApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)is also fightingwith Qualcomm. The dispute involves both of Qualcomm's businesses - it supplies chips to iPhones
column17: and Apple also pays it royalties. The current spat is said to total $1 billion
column18: or slightly more than the Blackberry settlement.A quick search of Qualcomm's other disputes includeSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) and Chinese firms includingMeizu. China went after Qualcomm recently
column19: accusing it of violating antitrust rules because of its chip and patent stronghold on mobile devices. Since then
column20: it has sought to settle and renegotiate patent agreements.Add it all up
column21: and investing in Qualcomm is not exactly straightforward.The Bull CaseQCOM stock currently yields close to 4%
column22: though
column23: so there is consolation for patient investors hoping that the company can successfully navigate current and future disputes
column24: and eventually grow steadily again.A considerable cash hoard also helps protect on the downside. First quarter cash and marketable securities totaled nearly $30 billion. Clearly
column25: it can afford a large number of unfavorable patent dispute results
column26: if it came to that.Qualcomm also announced last fall the acquisition ofNXP Semiconductors NV(NASDAQ:NXPI). The deal totals $38 billion and adds chip exposure to new markets including automotive
column27: the internet of things (IoT)
column28: data centers
column29: and networking. The deal could be a game changer for QCOM
column30: whose current market capitalization is only about $75 billion.The merger has been approved by NXP Semiconductors shareholders and is expected to close by the end of the year. It will put Qualcomm in more direct competition with other chip providers
column31: includingNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) (autonomous driving cars) andIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) (cell phones and data centers).Bottom Line on QCOM StockThe NXP Semiconductors purchase offers the best potential for Qualcomm to boost sales and profit growth. However
column32: it is largely outside of its core mobile phone chip expertise. At worst
column33: it suggests QCOM doesn't think its current businesses have appealing growth potential going forward.How to Trade Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Ahead of Q1 EarningsBut at 11.3 times forward earnings estimates and with a dividend yield double that of the overall market
column34: QCOM stock looks like an interesting investment candidate. The low valuation provides downside protection should patent disputes continue to be costly and if the core chip and licensing business fails to grow again.The NXP Semiconductor purchase adds more potential for growth
column35: though the new businesses are also extremely competitive. But while Qualcomm's management figures out the new businesses
column36: the existing ones will continue to generate billions in cash flow for many years to come.As of this writing
column37: Ryan Fuhrmann was long INTC.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. Doesn't Need an iPhone Supercycle to Survive3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Netflix

column1: Disney Studios Continues Its Box Office Domination;4/15/2017;"2016 was a pretty good year for movies. According to areport(link opens PDF) by the Motion Picture Association of   America (MPAA)
column2: the North American box office total reached $11.4   billion
column3: a record-setting year. And the undisputed box   office champ wasThe Walt Disney Company(NYSE: DIS) .The House of Mouse had four of the top five
column4: and six of the   top 10 grossing movies as measured by domestic box office
column5: according to website Box Office Mojo. The global totals are even   more impressive: Disney landed all of the top five spots for   worldwide box office. As icing on the cake
column6: the company became   the first film studio to rake in over $7 billion in ticket sales   in a single year.RankTitleDistributorWorldwide Box Office (millions)1Captain America: Civil WarBuena Vista$1
column7: 153.302Rogue One: A Star Wars StoryBuena Vista$1
column8: 055.573Finding DoryBuena Vista$1
column9: 028.604ZootopiaBuena Vista$1
column10: 023.805The Jungle Book(2016)Buena Vista$966.606The Secret Life of PetsUniversal$875.507Batman v Superman: Dawn of JusticeWarner Bros.$873.308Fantastic Beasts and Where To Find ThemWarner Bros.$813.209Deadpool21st Century Fox$783.1010Suicide SquadWarner Bros.$745.60Data source: Box Office Mojo.makeArticleAd();Another banner year?It appears that this year
column11: Disney's studios will continue its   winning ways. By the time you read this
column12: fan favoriteBeauty and the Beastwill likely have crossed $1 billion in worldwide ticket sales.   Earlier this week
column13: Piper Jaffray released its semiannual survey   of U.S. teens
column14: ""Taking Stock With Teens"" (TSWT). One of the key   takeaways from the report was that Disney dominated the list of   most anticipated films among teens for 2017
column15: nabbing three of the   top eight spots. The aforementionedBeauty and the Beast
column16: Star Wars: The Last Jedi
column17: andGuardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2took second
column18: third
column19: and fourth places
column20: respectively.According to the MPAA
column21: audiences between 18 and 25 attend more   movies than any other demographic
column22: so this helps shed light on   their prospects for the coming year. If you thought the   anticipation of a blockbuster movie season would be reflected in   the stock price
column23: you might be surprised to learn that the stock   hasn't made much headway in the last two years.What gives?The cable industry has come under pressure in recent years due   to the rise of streaming services like those offered byNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX)
column24: as well as other online offerings likeAlphabet's subsidiary Google's YouTube.TWST reported that 38% of teens reported using Netflix and 26%   viewed YouTube on a daily basis. Those who reported watching   cable TV had declined in each of the previous four reports from   29% in late 2015 to 23% most recently. The phenomenon of   cord-cutting -- those canceling their cable subscriptions in   favor of free and lower-priced options -- is the culprit.   Research firm Leichtman Researchreportedthat the top cable providers lost an estimated 795
column25: 000 net video   subscribers in 2016
column26: up from estimated losses of 445
column27: 000 in   2015.The majority of cable packages include a subscription to   Disney's flagship cable sports channel
column28: ESPN. Over the years
column29: it   had emerged as a powerhouse in sports programming. It negotiated   lengthy multibillion-dollar contracts to acquire exclusive rights   to broadcast games from all the major sports in the U.S. and is   now tied to those in the face of a falling subscriber base.   Disney doesn't break out ESPN from its broader media networks   segment
column30: which accounts for 42% of Disney's revenue
column31: but revenue   from the segment declined 2% year over year in the most recent   quarter
column32: while income fell 11%. Investors fear that if   subscribers continue to defect
column33: rising costs and fewer   subscribers will pressure Disney's results.Beauty and the Beastis closing in on $1 billion in worldwide box office. Image     source: Disney.Missing the big pictureThe knee-jerk reaction by some investors fails to take into   account the bigger picture. Losing only about 2% of its   subscribers in each of the last three years is hardly a death   sentence. Disney has been working behind the scenes on   measures to stem the tide of losses at its sports behemoth. ESPN   is included in most skinny bundles
column34: and Disney has been   experimenting with a direct-to-consumer service
column35: powered by its   $1 billion minority acquisition of BAMTech
column36: a video-streaming   service developed by Major League Baseball. Disney has also   embarked on a campaign of cost savings
column37: laying off some of ESPN's   high-priced on-air personalities.While ESPN may continue to weigh on Disney's results
column38: other   areas will be picking up the slack. The company opened its newest   theme park
column39: Shanghai Disneyland
column40: in mid-2016
column41: which should ramp   up and provide a revenue boost to the parks and resorts segment.   Disney is licensing recent theatrical releases to Netflix through   2018 and the two are partnering on a series of programs featuring   Marvel's Defenders -- Daredevil
column42: Jessica Jones
column43: Luke Cage
column44: and   Iron Fist. As its studio continues to churn out hits
column45: Disney's marketing machine incorporates those characters   into every facet of the its empire
column46: from plush toys to lunch   boxes to streaming deals with Netflix. ESPN may be the lion's   share of Disney's revenue now
column47: but over time
column48: it will become less   of the total and investors can go back to focusing on what the   company does best: telling stories.10 stocks we like better than Walt DisneyWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Machine Learning Stocks: 3 Things Investors Should Know;4/15/2017;"You may have come across the term ""machine learning"" while   digging around for new technology ideas to invest in
column2: or perhaps   you've heard of it while researching the broader (but related)   artificial intelligence space. In any case
column3: machine learning   probably isn't an idea that most investors know about
column4: so it's   worth taking the time to walk through a few basic aspects to help   you get started.Let's take a quick look at where the term came from
column5: how   machine learning is being used right now
column6: and what its market   opportunity is. Of course
column7: I'll discuss a few machine learning   stocks investors should know about as well.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();1. What exactly is machine learning and how is it being   used?Machine learning may sound like a new tech concept
column8: but it's   been around for decades. Back in 1959
column9: the computer scientist and   artificial intelligence pioneer Arthur Samuel coined the term and   described it as the ""field of study that gives computers the   ability to learn without being explicitly   programmed."" Samuel worked on early machine learning systems   atIBM(NYSE: IBM) and evendeveloped a checkers programthat was capable of beating a checkers master. This was a   significant feat for a computer at the time (1962)
column10: and it is one   of the earliest examples of artificial intelligence.For a solid example of machine learning that we can all   recognize
column11: consider the search results provided byAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google. Lukas Biewald
column12: the CEO   of an AI company
column13: wrote in TechCrunchlast yearthat ""What makes Google special is that it knows which matching   result is the most relevant; the way that it knows is through   machine learning.""Google has applied machine learning to its other businesses as   well. The company's recently spun-offdriverless car company
column14: Waymo
column15: uses machine learning to teach cars how they should   react to specific situations by letting them observe how a   driver
column16: or another car
column17: responds to certain driving   scenarios.Other tech companies are doing exciting things with machine   learning as well. Graphics processing unit (GPU) makerNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) uses machine learning for computer vision
column18: which   allows computers to see and interpret what they're looking at   (e.g.
column19: the cameras on a driverless car being able to identify a   stop sign).2. How big will this market be?Many estimates for the machine learning market are lumped   together with the broader artificial intelligence market
column20: but a   few specific estimates do exist. For example
column21: research firm   MarketsandMarkets says that machine learning as a service (MLaaS)   will grow from $613.4 million in 2016 to $3.7 billion by   2021.A separate estimate by Transparency Market Research says the   compound annual growth rate of MLaaS will be 38.4% between 2017   and 2025
column22: and become a $19.8 billion market by the end of that   time.Whichever estimate you choose
column23: it's clear that machine   learning applications are expanding
column24: and that should fuel growth   for companies creating services based on that technology.3. Who are the major players?I've already mentioned how Google has tapped into machine   learning for some of its business and how NVIDIA is using machine   learning for computer vision. It's worth mentioning that aside   from NVIDIA's own machine learning uses for semi-autonomous   vehicles
column25: it also sells its GPUs to other companies
column26: including   Google andFacebook
column27: for machine learning. That's helping the company tap into   broader AI market
column28: which is creating a$5 billion opportunity for NVIDIA.But NVIDIA isn't the only chipmaker that stands to benefit   from machine learning.Intel(NASDAQ: INTC)  is looking to machine learning to spur new   chip sales as the PC market dwindles. The company is in the   process of buying the semi-autonomous car technology makerMobileyeso that it can set itself up to benefit from the   driverless-car market
column29: which relies heavily on machine learning.   AnMIT Technology Reviewarticlenoted that ""Intel's acquisition of Mobileye shows how   critical data and machine learning are to the auto industry's   future.""And just as IBM was at the forefront of machine learning   decades ago
column30: the company is still helping to lead the way with   its own enterprise machine learning services. The company   says that its machine learning solutions
column31: like Watson
column32: can use   enterprise data to automatically create self-learning behavioral   models for businesses.The company is so bullish on machine learning and its impact   on businesses that it calls the technology the ""21st century's   Industrial Revolution"" and believes that machine learning is the   first step toward a broader cognitive computing world.Just a few months ago
column33: Deloitte published areportmentioning that 300 million smartphones will have some form of   machine learning built into them this year
column34: and that soon drones
column35: cars
column36: virtual and augmented reality devices
column37: and even medical   tools will have their own built-in machine learning capabilities.   It's clear from these predictions -- and the current machine   learning uses -- that this technology revolution is already   underway. And investors would be wise to take a closer look at   the companies that are leading the charge.Find out why Nvidiais one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. column2: driven by explosive growth   in its core gaming business coupled with even more impressive   growth in its enterprise and automotive segments. NVIDIA is at   the center of multiple trends

column12: and offers investors a strong angle in   the future of driverless cars

column34: and Qualcomm is also   facing someserious headwindsthat could derail the stock. The company was sued byAppleearlier this year

That news came just   days after the Federal Trade Commission charged Qualcomm with   anti-competitive sales and licensing tactics. With the majority   of Qualcomm's pre-tax profit derived from licensing
column36: any threat   to the licensing business could be big trouble for the   company.It's impossible to tell how these lawsuits will play out
column37: but   investors have pushed down the stock in reaction. Shares of   Qualcomm are down 13% so far this year
column38: creating an opportunity   for those who believe the company will emerge from these   challenges unscathed. With the stock trading for just 12 times   the average analyst estimate for fiscal 2017 adjusted earnings
column39: a   favorable outcome for Qualcomm
column40: or the successful closing of the   NXP deal
column41: could send the stock soaring.Stop searching for a great tech stockDan Caplinger(Alphabet):Technology stocks come in and out of vogue

column44: posting only minimal gains   in 2016 and underperforming the Nasdaq Composite so far this year   as well.Yet over the long run
column45: Alphabet has a number of growth drivers   that should help push the stock higher. The key search engine   market continues to be a cash cow for the company
column46: with Google   having huge penetration rates both on mobile and on desktop   devices. In addition
column47: YouTube has retained its dominance in the   video realm
column48: and efforts like the Gmail service

column50: and the Android operating system for mobile   devices have been extremely popular as well.Some investors worry that non-core projects like self-driving   cars might end up siphoning profits from the more successful   businesses. Yet those moonshots also carry some potential for   outsized gains if they pan out well.With NVIDIA having already generated impressive returns

Alphabet has room to move higher if it can keep delivering with   its core business.Find out why Nvidiais one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. column1: Better Buy: Alphabet Inc vs. Baidu Inc (ADR);4/14/2017;"They say that data is so valuable
column2: it is the new oil. With it
column3: you can offer advertisers the most targeted ads possible. Without   it
column4: you are drowning in a sea of competition with absolutely no   edge.This is the true advantage that investors in search engines   likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)  Google andBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) enjoy. Aside fromFacebook
column5: no other companies have collected as much data
column6: and managed to   monetize it.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();But which is the better buy today? That's an impossible   question to answer
column7: especially because geo-politics can play an   important role. Baidu operates almost entirely within the borders   of China
column8: and is at the behest of the Chinese government. But   that alone shouldn't determine which is the better buy.Instead
column9: we can get an idea for whatyouare more comfortable with by approaching the question through   three key lenses.Sustainable competitive advantagesAbsolutely nothing is more important to the long-term success   of an investment than the sustainable competitive advantage of   the underlying company you are investing in. Often referred to as   a ""moat"" in investing circles
column10: this represents that specialsomethingthat separates a company from its competitors.Alphabet's moat began with Google's unique algorithm that spit   out search results faster and more accurately than any other   alternative. That algorithm was very popular; it's the reason we   ""Google"" for information
column11: instead of ""Altavista"" it.But Google's moat is wider than that: The company has six   services in addition to search that have logged over 1 billion   users: Google Play
column12: YouTube
column13: Chrome
column14: Android
column15: Gmail
column16: and Maps.   Combined
column17: this ecosystem conveys two huge moats. First
column18: Google   has more information on user habits than anyone else. This means   it can continually offer up products that people are looking for.   Other wannabe search engines don't have this data advantage
column19: and   can never know for sure where the Next Big Product should be.Second
column20: Google is slowly building out high switching costs.   Because users can sign into a dizzying array of sites today just   by being signed into their Google account
column21: the switching costs to   another search engine have slowly crept up. Who wants to go back   and remember all those passwords if they decide against having a   Google account?Just about everything I just said about Google applies to   Baidu. Google has decided that it isn't going to compete actively   in China due to government intervention. Although Baidu has had   to deal with a few pesky upstarts
column22: that decision has largely left   the Middle Kingdom to Baidu.Baidu has two additional variables worth mentioning. As stated   above
column23: the ruling Communist Party in China can exert much more   control over Baidu than any other government could on Google
column24: and   that's a risk worth considering. At the same time
column25: because the   Chinese populace is entering the Age of the Internet much later   than Americans
column26: Baidu is trying to capitalize on opportunities   Google missed stateside -- namely through creating an   Online-to-Offline (O2O) ecosystem
column27: which you can read more abouthere.In the end
column28: both companies have very wide moats.Winner: TieFinancial fortitudeI wouldn't be the least bit surprised to see both Alphabet and   Baidu start paying dividends before I retire (note: I'm 35 years   old now). For now
column29: however
column30: investors want to see cash being   poured into profitable new growth opportunities.But as exciting as those growth opportunities may be
column31: the   companiesmustkeep a sizable cash stash on hand. That's because every company
column32: at some point
column33: will have to endure difficult financial times.   Those that enter such times with cash have options: buy back   stock on the cheap
column34: make a strategic acquisition
column35: or -- perhaps   most important -- outspend rivals to gain market share.Debt-heavy companies are in the opposite situation
column36: forced to   myopically focus on meeting their debt obligations. Keeping in   mind that Alphabet is valued at almostten timesthe size of Baidu
column37: here's how the two stack up.CompanyCashDebtNet IncomeFree Cash FlowAlphabet$86 billion$4 billion$19.5 billion$25.8 billionBaidu$20 billion$5 billion$1.7 billion$2.6 billionData sources: Yahoo! Finance
column38: SEC filings.Both of these companies are invery safepositions. Relative to its size
column39: Baidu has much more cash
column40: but   also carries much more debt. Net income and free cash flow are   about even
column41: and very strong for both companies.Over a decades-long time horizon
column42: I think both wouldbenefitfrom a downturn
column43: as it would drive smaller players out of markets   where Alphabet and Baidu are working on offering ancillary   services or products.Winner: TieValuationFinally
column44: we have valuation. While this isn't an exact science
column45: there are some straightforward metrics we can consult to give us   an idea of how expensive each stock is.CompanyP/EP/FCFP/SPEG RatioAlphabet25226.31.6Baidu38235.92.3Data sources: Yahoo! Finance
column46: E*Trade
column47: Nasdaq.com. P/E uses   figures from non-GAAP earnings.Here again we have a very close battle. While Baidu appears to   be much more expensive on an earnings basis
column48: the companies are   virtually identical in terms of free cash flow -- a metric I give   more credence to.In terms of growth -- measured via the PEG Ratio -- Alphabet   trades at a 30% discount to Baidu. That's largely because   investments in O2O will be holding down Baidu's earnings for the   foreseeable future.While it's not a huge difference
column49: we need a tiebreaker here
column50: and it will go to Alphabet.Winner: AlphabetThe winner is...So there you have it
column51: by the thinnest of margins
column52: Alphabet   comes out ahead. It has a more developed business line and more   favorable valuation. At the same time
column53: Baidu's O2O aspirations   could prove to be an enormous boon to investors -- but it's just   too early to know for sure.As for myself
column54: I have an enormous sum of money tied up inbothcompanies. Combined
column55: they constitute 22% of my real-life   holdings. I believebothare worthy of your consideration.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column56: it can pay to listen. After all
column57: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: This Virtual Reality Device Is Running Circles Around the Competition
column2: New Survey Shows;4/14/2017;"Possibly no other consumer technology is getting as much   attention as virtual reality (VR) right now. Tech companies are   spending billions of dollars to develop new VR tech
column3: or acquire   it
column4: and some
column5: likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)

column8: which are expected to hit worldwide sales of 200 million for the   six-year period ending in 2020
column9: according to Tractica.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();All of these stats point to potentially good times ahead for   companies focusing on VR. The question

column11: is which companies   are beginning to dominate the space. Arecent surveyreleased by ReportLinker sheds some light on the subject
column12: and   shows thatSamsung's(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) Gear VR headset is already the most   recognizable VR headset among consumers

column7: so supply will increase. But new product launches will be consuming more memory than they did last year. column8: Micron's own expectations are as follows:2017 DRAM Disk supply growth is expected to be 15-20% based on the assumption that natural supply growth will continue but suppliers will be more focused on process node migrations to enable cost reductions than on capacity adds. column2: Inc. vs. Google;4/13/2017;"It's a battle of theFANG stocks.Digital video veteranNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) takes on online search and advertising giantAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column3: best know for its Google-branded   operations. If you could only buy one of these today
column4: which one's   the better choice?Let's find out.makeArticleAd();Image source: Google.The case for GoogleAlphabet is a deceptively simple business these days. The   Google segment stands for a staggering 99% of the umbrella   company's total sales
column5: and all of its profits.Morethan all
column6: actually -- the ""other bets"" division is still stuck   with negative operating profits.If you understand internet-based search and advertising
column7: you   understand the current iteration of Alphabet. In that space
column8: Google holds unequaled market share and industry clout. Revenues   are soaring
column9: free cash flow growth has accelerated in recent   quarters
column10: and share prices more than doubled over the last three   years.GOOGLdata byYCharts.Business is good
column11: but Alphabet will not fit that mold   forever.Search ads brought the company this far
column12: building a massive   revenue base from which it can launch many new operations. Some   will fail and fade; others are sure to catch on and start   producing serious bottom-line profits. The best bets on the table   so far include theWaymoself-driving car platform
column13: theCalicomedical research company
column14: and an Internet of Things strategy   built around theNestline of smart home products.Alphabet is getting ready to go offline
column15: becoming a   conglomerate of wildly different operations in the process.   That's how you build a business for the very
column16: very long haul.Buy Alphabet if you don't want to worry about the ""sell""   button for several decades.Image source: Netflix.The case for NetflixUnlike Alphabet
column17: Netflix can't boast solid bottom-line results   quite yet. Earnings are barely positive
column18: cash flows are diving   deep into red ink
column19: and the stock is incredibly overvalued by   nearly every traditional metric.Yet
column20: I heartily recommend investors take a closer look at   Netflix. All is not as it seems.The company announced and then executed a global rollout
column21: installing streaming video services in nearly every nation on   Earth. China remains a difficult nut to crack
column22: and American   businesses simply can't work in embargoed territories like North   Korea and Syria
column23: so it's not quite 100% coverage. Still
column24: that   ambitious
column25: market-growing project is essentially complete.   Without the budget pressures of a worldwide service installation   to worry about
column26: Netflix's management has promised to increase its   bottom-line earnings in 2017 and beyond.Granted
column27: cash flows will stay negative for a few more years.   That's a side effect of the company's massive content production   plans. The company has financed its production budget via new   debt in recent years
column28: and it will probably hit the debt market   again in 2017 and 2018.But look at what Netflix will have built
column29: just a couple of   years down the road. A global content distribution network will   be married to a first-class entertainment studio
column30: creating a   two-pronged video entertainment attack like nothing we've seen   before. Meanwhile
column31: the portion of humanity that has access to   Netflix-grade network connections is growing explosively. Netflix   hopes to establish itself as the player to beat in an expanding   market
column32: kind of like the Google we knew 15 years ago.The cash investments Netflix is making now are building an   impressive content portfolio for the long run
column33: which will   continue to bring in and hold onto paying customers for years to   come.This is the stock to pick if you're looking for exciting   growth in the next 5 to 10 years. Beyond that
column34: I have no idea   where Netflix will go.Image source: Getty Images.Two winnersLet me be clear: There are no bad choices
column35: here. It's the   ultimate cop-out
column36: but I'll stand by it. Alphabet and Netflix are   two fine long-term investments
column37: but also dramatically different   ones.I own both and plan to hold them for many more years. Netflix   may need some attention in
column38: say
column40: as the mature company   enters a new era. I could probably leave Alphabet leave alone   until my kids graduate from elementary school
column41: grow up
