column2: Inc.(NASDAQ: FB) processes that and more every day. Now imagine   sifting through all that data to perform facial recognition
column3: describe the contents of photos and video
column4: and populate your news   feed with relevant content. Those tasks are all handled by   Facebook's servers that have been infused with its homegrownbrand of artificial intelligence(AI).The training that takes place behind the scenes has been the   job of Facebook's AI brain named Big Sur
column5: which has been handling   the task since 2015. Now
column6: the system that has been at the heart   of the company's AI activity for the last two years is being   replaced by a newer
column7: faster model. Facebook revealed in ablog postthat its successor is dubbed Big Basin
column8: and this new platform   boasts some impressive credentials. The upgraded AI server can   train machine-learning models that are 30% larger in about half   the time.Facebook data center in Prineville
column9: Oregon. Image source:     Facebook.makeArticleAd();If you've used Facebook
column10: you've used AIMachine learning is a combination of software models and   algorithms that sort through data at lightning speeds to make   deductions based on what it finds. This might sound somewhat   futuristic
column11: but this AI technology is being used today. An   example would be running facial recognition and comparing a newly   uploaded photo with all the photos in its database to suggest a   name when tagging a friend in the picture. ""If you've logged into   Facebook
column12: it's very likely you've used some type of AI system   we've been developing
column13: according to Kevin Lee
column14: a technical   program manager at Facebook and author of the blog.Lee detailed that the new system was built using graphics   processing units (GPUs) fromNVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ: NVDA) to achieve this new level of AI computing. The   platform hosts eight Tesla P100 GPU accelerators
column15: which NVIDIA   describes as ""the most advanced data center GPU ever built."" The   system also features NVIDIA NVLink
column16: which connects the GPUs in   what Facebook describes as a ""hybrid mesh cube."" The speed of   these systems can bog down
column17: caused by a bottleneck at the   connections
column18: which the NVLink seeks to prevent. Lee indicated   that the architecture was similar NVIDIA's DGX-1 -- its AI   supercomputer in a box. Lee quipped that ""Big Basin behaves like   a JBOD [just a bunch of disks] -- or as we call it
column19: JBOG
column20: just a   bunch of GPUs.""More computing power was necessaryFacebook's recent emphasis on live video streaming provided   challenges because of how quickly it was adopted by users. Larger   and more complex data sets required additional computing power at   higher speeds. The company uses AI to not only classify its   real-time video but in other applications
column21: such as speech and   text translations. This new platform provides the data capacity   and speed to train Facebook's next generation of AI models.Facebook plans to release the design specifications of its AI   server via the Open Compute Project in the near future. Once that   happens
column22: any ambitious computer engineer with sufficient time and   money could conceivably build one of these systems in his or her   basement.Big Basin AI Server can train 30% larger data sets than its     predecessor in half the time! Image source: Facebook.Groundbreaking AI chipFacebook isn't the only company creating innovative AI   applications.Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) Google revealed the details   behind its Tensor Processing Unit (TPU)
column23: a specialized chip it   designed and has been using to power its AI systems -- called   deep neural networks -- for the last two years. These   machine-learning systems are created using algorithms and   software modeled on the human brain
column24: and they learn by analyzing   vast quantities of data.In aGoogle blog post
column25: hardware engineer Norm Jouppi described the capabilities of the   TPU chip
column26: saying that it processed AI workloads 15 to 30 times   faster than conventional CPUs and GPUs while achieving a 30 to 80   times reduction in energy consumption. Google realized six years   ago that the AI speech-recognition technology that it was   deploying to users required the storage of vast amounts of data
column27: and worried that it would have to double the number of data   centers just to keep up. Google credits the development of TPU   for improvements in its Translate
column28: Image Search
column29: and Photos   programs
column30: and for itsvictory over world's best Go players.Final thoughtsIt would be difficult to quantify the value these innovations   bring to the companies that develop them
column31: and even more so since   they are being shared with the world. Very few of the companies   involved in AI research reveal any direct financial benefit
column32: though the advances make their products more useful to consumers
column33: as the resulting technologies affect the things we do and the   products we use every day.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column36: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Facebook wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column12: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Monday's Analyst Blog:Will Uber Be the Hottest IPO of 2017?y now
column13: I think we all know what Uber is
column14: what it does
column15: and how it makes our lives easier. Have too many groceries? Get an Uber. Too drunk? Get an Uber. Stressful day at work? Uber. Like magic-now
column16: it's really an expectation-any transportation woes vanish with the digital sight of a car heading your way.Launched only seven years ago
column17: Uber Technologies Inc.is an app-based transportation company headquartered in San Francisco
column18: California
column19: and operates in about 270 cities and more than 60 countries worldwide. Using the app is easy: just type in your current location
column20: where you want to go
column21: and hit request Uber. From there
column22: Uber uses its app to receive its ride requests
column23: sending them out to drivers who transport customers to their final destination.Increased CompetitionThe emergence of on-demand rides has become a popular business venture all over the world
column24: but it has proved difficult for companies to break away from the congested pack. At the end of 2015
column25: Sidecar
column26: another on-demand car service
column27: officially stopped offering rides and deliveries.In addition to the now-defunct Sidecar
column28: companies like Lyft
column29: Curb
column30: Southeast Asia-based Grab
column31: India's Ola
column32: and especially China's Didi Chuxing have all started to eat into the ride-hailing market share
column33: becominghuge competitorsfor Uber. Didi is arguably Uber's biggest threat overseas
column34: and the ride-sharing giant conceded defeat in August
column35: selling its UberChina operationsto Didi and ending an expensive
column36: bruising battle between the two companies.Even Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) is becoming a threat to Uber
column37: with plans to make its self-driving cars unit a stand-alone business. This initiative could put the company in direct competition with Uber
column38: as the lack of a driver could keep costs down in the long-term. The company's Google division also recently began a pilot program with Waze
column39: a company they acquired in 2013
column40: that enables thousands of San Francisco commuters to join carpools; Waze also offers real-time driving directions based on information from other drivers.Self-Driving
column41: Uber StyleBut Uber is right on Google's heels
column42: and asself-driving car technologybecomes more commercially available
column43: Uber has been constantly beefing up its business strategies focused on autonomous driving. Back in September
column44: it began testing its self-driving Ford (NYSE:F-Free Report) Fusions in Pittsburgh; engineers rode in the driver's seat
column45: ready to take over whenever things got tricky.Uber then introduced self-driving Volvo XC90s to San Francisco in December
column46: and riders who requested an uberX were matched with one of these vehicles if one was available. Just days later
column47: however
column48: the California Department of Motor Vehicles revoked the registrations for its self-driving cars
column49: as the company didn't have the proper permits.But Uber being Uber
column50: the fleet of Volvos were on their way to Arizona within days. Uber already operates a self-driving car program in the state
column51: and in 2015
column52: partnered with the University of Arizona to research mapping technology.Uber also recently acquired a car start-up Otto
column53: which specializes in self-driving trucks. Otto is a 90-person company
column54: and its co-founder
column55: Anthony Levandowski
column56: will now lead Uber into the self-driving car market. Impressively
column57: Otto engineers have worked at Tesla Motors (NASDAQ:TSLA-Free Report)
column58: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column59: and Google
column60: and with this knowledge and expertise
column61: Uber is bound to be a top player in the self-driving car industry.ControversyWhile Uber has seen great success
column62: it's journey has been a bumpy one. The company has been in and out of the news thanks to a number of recent legal (Alphabet iscurrently suingthem for theft of its self-driving car technology) and reputation-hurting (note the company'ssexual harassment scandaland CEO Travis Kalanick's rude behavior towards a driver) headlines. And from noncompliance issues in New York City to regulatory concerns and lack of driver background checks
column63: Uber has drawn scrutiny and criticism
column64: and has even been banned in The Netherlands and in parts of Thailand
column65: India
column66: and China.It's no secret that traditional taxi services are not happy with the rise of Uber and other ride-hailing companies
column67: and many argue that Uber should be subject to the same regulations that they face. In dozens of cities it has moved in to
column68: Uber has faced intense opposition
column69: lobbying
column70: and legal challenges against it from these taxi companies.Uber has also been embroiled in along-standing battlewith its drivers. A group of drivers first sued the company back in 2013
column71: claiming they should be classified as employees rather than independent contractors. As a result
column72: Uber had been set to pay up to $100 million in reimbursement damages to almost 400
column73: 000 drivers
column74: but recently
column75: a federal judge in California ruled that the settlement was unfair.But as the saying goes
column76: any publicity is good publicity
column77: and all of the bad press has yet to really negatively affect Uber. Despitelosing over $1 billionin the first half of 2016
column78: Uber gained just as much revenue in that same time period. Its ability to raise exorbitant amounts of money is incredibly impressive for a company who is less than a decade old
column79: and this skill makes Uber that much more attractive to venture capital investors.IPO PotentialDespite these controversies
column80: investors are eagerly awaiting an Uber IPO. Many have believed
column81: or hoped
column82: the company would go public for a few years now
column83: but Mr. Kalanick wants ""to make sure [an IPO] happens as late as possible
column84: said in an interview with CNBC last year.If and when Uber finally decides to go public
column85: its potential would depend on the broader IPO market and economic environment. According to Renaissance Capital
column86: IPOs only raised a paltry $18.9 billion in 2016
column87: with annual proceeds falling to the lowest level since 2003. Just four companies filed public offerings that grossed over $1 billion.Looking ahead
column88: it's difficult to pinpoint how busy the IPO market will be this year. Snap Inc. (NYSE:SNAP-Free Report)
column89: the parent company of Snapchat
column90: finally made that giant step last month
column91: but it's hard to say what
column92: and if any
column93: other high-profile unicorns-i.e. Spotify
column94: Pinterest
column95: Airbnb
column96: and yes
column97: Uber-will follow. And recent high-growth IPOs like Twilio Inc. (NYSE:TWLO-Free Report) have traded strongly since their debut
column98: a good sign for tech companies everywhere looking to make their trading debut.How Might Uber Perform?An IPO for Uber could be massive for both the company and Wall Street. It's currently valued at $68 billion after a total of nine rounds of funding worth $12.9 billion since its launch. And thanks to Uber's structure-a unique combination of transportation company
column99: mobile Internet company
column100: and real world engineering-the company has been touted as one of the best future IPOs.It's IPO
column101: then
column102: could go either way
column103: but let one number stay in your mind: $68 billion. Let me write that again: $68 billion. This number is a hard one to forget
column104: and a figure that will be on the forefront of many investors' minds come the time of its public offering
column105: as it impressively showcases just how far this startup has come in a few short years.Today

column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeAmazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)

column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Monday's Analyst Blog:Amazon and Google: Head to Head?Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report) and Google are increasingly pitted against each other in all the markets in which they operate. But who will be the winner is a harder question to answer. As things stand now
column11: the scales are evenly balanced
column12: but who knows what the next decade will see?Competition for Ad DollarsLast week
column13: a couple of analysts had things to say about Amazon's advertising business
column14: which has been gaining momentum in recent months.BMO Capital's Daniel Salmon has said that the leading online retailer was stealthily creeping up on Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)-owned Google and Facebook (NASDAQ:FB-Free Report) and would steal digital advertising dollars from the market leaders. He thinks Amazon's North America ""Other"" segment (attributed mostly to advertising) will grow 65% to $3.5 billion this year.eMarketer estimates that Amazon will generate more than a 1 billion dollars in U.S. ad revenue in 2017 compared to Google's $34 billion and Facebook's $15 billion. But more importantly
column15: Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak estimates that this number will grow to $5 billion next year and $7 billion by 2020.It's apparent that Amazon is far from catching up with the leaders
column16: but the thing to note here is that it has all that is required to have a very successful advertising business
column17: so it may not be long before it is more than an experiment.At the moment
column18: Amazon mostly shows targeted ads to people based on their browsing patterns and buying decisions
column19: whether it's with respect to products or media. This therefore appears less intrusive and safeguards customer experience.Its store house of customer data is very attractive for advertisers but can be a serious privacy concern if shared with them. Amazon reportedly doesn't offer more than a broad description of a customer such as a ""tech geek"" or ""fashionista"" that advertisers can target
column20: but it has the capability to offer more. For now
column21: advertisers aren't complaining.Competition for Voice Controlled PlatformsAmazon has the lead in online retail
column22: but that isn't the only lead it has. The company's Echo devices are going great guns and help it sell products and services. The artificial intelligence (AI) driven voice assistant Alexa has already been worked into a host of other everyday devices for the digital home and there are agreements to get it into even more. So Amazon is racing to build an ecosystem around Alexa and it's safe to say that it's taken an early lead.The opportunity is not lost on Google of course
column23: which also has its Google Assistant powering Google Home that can personalize your experience probably more completely (when linked to your Google profile) and also help you search for pretty much everything under the sun.Selling ads on voice controlled devices isn't cool yet
column24: but Google may have tried something that wasn't too well-received that it later said was a mistake. Since ads for the platform are yet to be figured out
column25: Amazon has a better model at the moment
column26: because it isn't just selling the device but through it
column27: also products that customers need.Competition for Cloud Infrastructure ServicesHere again
column28: Amazon has the lead with Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report) in hot pursuit. While some place Google in the third position
column29: others say it is preceded by IBM (NYSE:IBM-Free Report).According to Canalys
column30: Cloud infrastructure services generated $10.3 billion in the fourth quarter
column31: of which Amazon's AWS alone accounted for 33.8% while Microsoft
column32: Google and IBM together accounted for 30.8%. The market is expected to grow 46% this year from $38.1 billion to $55.8 billion. So there's plenty of room for all the players to grow.Amazon seems to be expanding the fastest because of its first mover advantage
column33: adding 11 new availability zones globally. Google added its first in Japan. Google's advantage is that it already has servers in major regions because of its ubiquitous search engine. So it can probably expand by building those out further. But it has a very long way to go to catch up with Amazon
column34: and also Microsoft
column35: which has its strong product range and enterprise customer base to fall back on.ConclusionGoogle is in for some very tough competition
column36: which will likely unfold over the next five years or so. As things stand now
column37: Amazon looks very strongly positioned to take in some nice profits
column38: both from AWS and its advertising business that can help it offset effect of aggressive pricing in the retail business.Zacks' Hidden TradesWhile we share many recommendations and ideas with the public

column1: Qualcomm (QCOM) Counter Attacks Apple on its Allegations;4/11/2017;"Qualcomm Inc.QCOM

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Is Poised to Kick 32-Bit Apps From App Store;4/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) hasn't held the title of biggest app store for three years. But despite being eclipsed byAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Play for sheer number of apps and the total user base of iOS being a fraction of the size of Android
column4: AAPL's App Store remains firmly in top for revenue generated. App developers love the App Store and so do iPhone and iPad owners.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleBut Apple appears poised to make a sweeping change
column5: switching solely to 64-bit apps for iOS 11 and killing off thousands of older apps that haven't yet been updated. Will that move impact the App Store?AAPL and the Switch to 64-Bit64-bit CPUs are able to process data far faster than 32-bit versions
column6: and they're able to take advantage of more RAM. There's a catch
column7: though. 32-bit CPUs can't run code written specifically for 64-bit CPUs. And while 64-bit CPUscanrun software written for 32-bit processors
column8: they have to use emulation and the user doesn't see the performance gain the more powerful CPU should offer.Apple was the first smartphone manufacturer to switch to 64-bit CPUs
column9: with the iPhone 5S in 2013. Every iPhone and iPad released since then has been powered by a 64-bit version of AAPL's AX processors. However
column10: we are now in 2017 and a significant number of apps in the App Store have not been updated to offer native 64-bit support.And it looks as though the clock is ticking. 9to5Macis reporting Apple is stepping up its campaign to crack down on older apps and willeliminate support for 32-bit apps in iOS 11this fall. At this point any of these apps would fall under theApp Store Improvementsprogram launched by AAPL in September
column11: 2016. They would also stop working on iPhones and iPads that update to iOS 11.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyTrimming the App Store ClutterShortly after announcing that improvement program
column12: AAPL began actively reviewing and removing apps that didn't comply. Last October alone
column13: the companypulled nearly 50
column14: 000 apps.To put that in some perspective
column15: it took about a year from its launch for the App Store to hit a grandtotal of 50
column16: 000 apps in 2009.Apple held the app store lead for several years before the momentum of Android caught up. In 2011
column17: Android smartphones took the lead over Apple iPhones in the U.S. market
column18: in 2013 Google Play took the lead in app downloads and in 2015 Google Play took the crown for sheer number of apps available.However
column19: Apple has never been shy about aggressively policing its app store
column20: because sheer numbers don't matter any more. Bragging rights for having the most apps were important in the early days
column21: not so much now. Despite actions like pulling 50
column22: 000 apps in a single month
column23: AAPL's App Store remains the most popular for premium apps andcontinues to dominate in terms of revenue- both for Apple and for developers.Who Loses When 32-bit Apps Get DumpedIf a 32-bit app is a paid app
column24: the developer and any iPhone or iPad owner who bought that app will be on the losing end. The developer because their app will be removed from the App Store and the iPhone and iPad owners because once they update to iOS 11
column25: if9to5Macis right
column26: that app will no longer be usable.Warnings when launching 32-bit apps have been added by AAPL and are getting sterner. They first notified users that the older apps may slow their devices and in the latest developer version of iOS 10.3.1
column27: 9to5Macreports they state: ""This app will not work with future versions of iOS. The developer of this app needs to update it to improve its compatibility.""Apple Inc. (AAPL) Promises New Mac Pro in 2018
column28: New Pro iMac in 2017Apple's own Clips app
column29: which was just recently released
column30: drops support for 32-bit processors. That means owners of popular iOS devices like the iPhone 5
column31: iPhone 5c and iPad 4 can't use Clips
column32: even though their device runs the latest iOS 10.3 operating system.The Writing's on the Wall for 32-Bit AppsAAPL will likely anger a few users who have favorite apps that haven't been - and won't be - updated for 64-bit support. And it's already beginning the process of shutting out legacy hardware users from accessing cool new apps. But Apple has never been shy about this sort of thing. Trimming the app fat has only made its App Store business stronger. Cutting off legacy hardware can lead to some owner frustration
column33: but it makes the App Store stronger (developers don't have to support such a wide range of hardware) and helps to drive iPhone and iPad owners to upgrade to new models.Given the many hints
column34: increasingly strong messaging and AAPL's pattern of operating
column35: it seems likely iOS 11 will mark the death of 32-bit apps in Apple's iOS ecosystem.As of this writing
column36: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: Still the Best?The New Apple Inc. iPad Strategy Is Sneakier Than You ThinkMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Will Sell You a Galaxy S8The postApple Inc. (AAPL) Is Poised to Kick 32-Bit Apps From App Storeappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Stocks We're Never Selling;4/10/2017;"Finding winning stocks is tough. That's why we Fools tend to   hold on tenaciously when we think we have bought a winner.So what stocks do we currently own that we plan on holding   forever? We asked that very question to a team of Fools
column2: and they   pickedAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column3: Brookfield Property Partners(NYSE: BPY)
column4: andMarketAxess Holdings(NASDAQ: MKTX) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Google is growing up into a cross-sector conglomerateAnders Bylund(Alphabet): "" Never"" is a very long time
column5: but I certainly don't have any   plans to sell my holdings in Alphabet for the foreseeable   future.The company is best known for its Google-branded range of   online tools and services today. Through Google
column6: Alphabet   dominates the lucrative fields of online search and advertising.   YouTube is another market-defining property under the Google   umbrella. The Android platform for smartphones and tablets also   dominates its industry on a global level
column7: again under Google's   aegis. It's safe to say that you know what the company does
column8: and   you probably use its services every day. The Google segment   provided 99% of Alphabet's total revenue in the recently reportedfourth quarter.In short
column9: AlphabetisGoogle. And with Google's sales rising 22% year over year
column10: driving operating income 17% higher
column11: that's not a bad thing.But Alphabet won't look like that forever.The minuscule ""other bets"" segment is tiny and unprofitable   today but represents Alphabet's long-term future. The internet as   we know it may go away as quickly as it rose out of nowhere in   the 1990s
column12: replaced by whatever comes next. (No
column13: I can't tell you   what that might be. If I knew
column14: I'd be getting rich developing   that idea rather than talking about the current state of affairs.   Sorry.)So Alphabet is getting ready for the day when online search   and marketing no longer supports a strong business foundation.   Other bets includeself-driving cars
column15: advanced medical research
column16: theGoogle Fiberhigh-speed internet service
column17: and theNestline of smart thermostats. Beyond these familiar names
column18: Alphabet   is working up many more not-so-obvious business ideas out of the   public eye.Any or all of these experiments may turn into profitable   businesses one day
column19: and the Alphabet company was designed to   contain many long-term bets on the far future. Some of the   so-called moonshots contain an online element
column20: but others don't.   In short
column21: Alphabet is remaking itself as a whole new kind of   industry-spanning conglomerate.With or without the internet
column22: Alphabet will be around for the   very long haul. The company is just getting started
column23: using Google   to kindle the fires under a brand new bundle of growth   engines.A core real estate holdingMatt DiLallo(Brookfield Property Partners): I'm a firm believer that investors should hold some form of   real estate for the long term. The numbers back up this view
column24: as   investors who added real estate or other alternatives to a   portfolio of stocks and bonds have significantly outperformed   those holding a more traditional portfolio over the long term.   While there are plenty of good ways to get into real estate
column25: the   best
column26: in my opinion
column27: is by investing in Brookfield Property   Partners.The real estate partnership owns a core portfolio of office   properties in gateway cities around the world and a significant   stake in leading U.S. mall ownerGeneral Growth Properties(NYSE: GGP) . In addition
column28: it has investments in several   opportunistic real estate funds that hold stakes in a variety of   other property classes
column29: including multi-family
column30: industrial
column31: and   hospitality. That makes it a one-stop shop for real estate   investing.These real estate portfolios throw off very predictable cash   flow
column32: 80% of which Brookfield Property Partners distributes back   to investors through a generous payout currently yielding 5.3%.   Meanwhile
column33: the company reinvests the other 20% into redevelopment   projects to obtain higher rents. The upside from those   redevelopment projects
column34: when combined with rent escalations and   development projects in the pipeline
column35: provide Brookfield with the   ability to increase its payout by 5% to 8% annually over the long   term. That steadily growing payout
column36: along with capital   appreciation across its portfolio

column38: which is why this is   one stock I'd never consider selling.This disruptor has a long runway aheadBrian Feroldi(MarketAxess Holdings): Did you know that the majority of fixed-income trading still   takes place over the phone or by email? column40: making it easy for its users   to buy
column41: sell
column42: or research fixed-income securities. Not only   does this platform make far more sense than holding one-on-one   conversations to transact
column43: but it also brings a whole new level   of transparency to this market.Being the top dog in this small but growing niche provides   MarketAxess with a big advantage. Just like every other   marketplace
column44: bond buyers and sellers will naturally gravitate   toward the largest platform since it maximizes their chance of   getting a good price on either side of the transaction. This   network effect will make it nearly impossible for a potential   rival to catch up.One big financial benefit of running an electronic trading   platform is that it costs the company very little to add one more   user. That means the company's margins can consistently expand   over time

column1: Amazon and Google: Head to Head?;4/10/2017;"AmazonAMZNand Google are increasingly pitted against each other in all the markets in which they operate. But who will be the winner is a harder question to answer. As things stand now
column2: the scales are evenly balanced
column3: but who knows what the next decade will see?Competition for Ad DollarsLast week
column4: a couple of analysts had things to say about Amazon's advertising business
column5: which has been gaining momentum in recent months.BMO Capital's Daniel Salmon has said that the leading online retailer was stealthily creeping up on AlphabetGOOGL-owned Google and FacebookFBand would steal digital advertising dollars from the market leaders. He thinks Amazon's North America ""Other"" segment (attributed mostly to advertising) will grow 65% to $3.5 billion this year.eMarketer estimates that Amazon will generate more than a 1 billion dollars in U.S. ad revenue in 2017 compared to Google's $34 billion and Facebook's $15 billion. But more importantly
column6: Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak estimates that this number will grow to $5 billion next year and $7 billion by 2020.It's apparent that Amazon is far from catching up with the leaders
column7: but the thing to note here is that it has all that is required to have a very successful advertising business
column8: so it may not be long before it is more than an experiment.At the moment
column9: Amazon mostly shows targeted ads to people based on their browsing patterns and buying decisions
column10: whether it's with respect to products or media. This therefore appears less intrusive and safeguards customer experience.Its store house of customer data is very attractive for advertisers but can be a serious privacy concern if shared with them. Amazon reportedly doesn't offer more than a broad description of a customer such as a ""tech geek"" or ""fashionista"" that advertisers can target
column11: but it has the capability to offer more. For now
column12: advertisers aren't complaining.Competition for Voice Controlled PlatformsAmazon has the lead in online retail
column13: but that isn't the only lead it has. The company's Echo devices are going great guns and help it sell products and services. The artificial intelligence (AI) driven voice assistant Alexa has already been worked into a host of other everyday devices for the digital home and there are agreements to get it into even more. So Amazon is racing to build an ecosystem around Alexa and it's safe to say that it's taken an early lead.The opportunity is not lost on Google of course
column14: which also has its Google Assistant powering Google Home that can personalize your experience probably more completely (when linked to your Google profile) and also help you search for pretty much everything under the sun.Selling ads on voice controlled devices isn't cool yet
column15: but Google may have tried something that wasn't too well-received that it later said was a mistake. Since ads for the platform are yet to be figured out
column16: Amazon has a better model at the moment
column17: because it isn't just selling the device but through it
column18: also products that customers need.Competition for Cloud Infrastructure ServicesHere again
column19: Amazon has the lead with MicrosoftMSFTin hot pursuit. While some place Google in the third position
column20: others say it is preceded by IBMIBM.According to Canalys
column21: Cloud infrastructure services generated $10.3 billion in the fourth quarter
column22: of which Amazon's AWS alone accounted for 33.8% while Microsoft
column23: Google and IBM together accounted for 30.8%. The market is expected to grow 46% this year from $38.1 billion to $55.8 billion. So there's plenty of room for all the players to grow.Amazon seems to be expanding the fastest because of its first mover advantage
column24: adding 11 new availability zones globally. Google added its first in Japan. Google's advantage is that it already has servers in major regions because of its ubiquitous search engine. So it can probably expand by building those out further. But it has a very long way to go to catch up with Amazon
column25: and also Microsoft
column26: which has its strong product range and enterprise customer base to fall back on.ConclusionGoogle is in for some very tough competition
column27: which will likely unfold over the next five years or so. As things stand now
column28: Amazon looks very strongly positioned to take in some nice profits
column29: both from AWS and its advertising business that can help it offset effect of aggressive pricing in the retail business.Zacks' Hidden TradesWhile we share many recommendations and ideas with the public

column1: Will Uber Be the Hottest IPO of 2017?;4/10/2017;"By now
column2: I think we all know what Uber is
column3: what it does
column4: and how it makes our lives easier. Have too many groceries? Get an Uber. Too drunk? Get an Uber. Stressful day at work? Uber. Like magic-now
column5: it's really an expectation-any transportation woes vanish with the digital sight of a car heading your way.Launched only seven years ago
column6: Uber Technologies Inc.is an app-based transportation company headquartered in San Francisco
column7: California
column8: and operates in about 270 cities and more than 60 countries worldwide. Using the app is easy: just type in your current location
column9: where you want to go
column10: and hit request Uber. From there
column11: Uber uses its app to receive its ride requests
column12: sending them out to drivers who transport customers to their final destination.Increased CompetitionThe emergence of on-demand rides has become a popular business venture all over the world
column13: but it has proved difficult for companies to break away from the congested pack. At the end of 2015
column14: Sidecar
column15: another on-demand car service
column16: officially stopped offering rides and deliveries.In addition to the now-defunct Sidecar
column17: companies like Lyft
column18: Curb
column19: Southeast Asia-based Grab
column20: India's Ola
column21: and especially China's Didi Chuxing have all started to eat into the ride-hailing market share
column22: becominghuge competitorsfor Uber. Didi is arguably Uber's biggest threat overseas
column23: and the ride-sharing giant conceded defeat in August
column24: selling its UberChina operationsto Didi and ending an expensive
column25: bruising battle between the two companies.Even Alphabet Inc.GOOGLis becoming a threat to Uber
column26: with plans to make its self-driving cars unit a stand-alone business. This initiative could put the company in direct competition with Uber
column27: as the lack of a driver could keep costs down in the long-term. The company's Google division also recently began a pilot program with Waze
column28: a company they acquired in 2013
column29: that enables thousands of San Francisco commuters to join carpools; Waze also offers real-time driving directions based on information from other drivers.Self-Driving
column30: Uber StyleBut Uber is right on Google's heels
column31: and asself-driving car technologybecomes more commercially available
column32: Uber has been constantly beefing up its business strategies focused on autonomous driving. Back in September
column33: it began testing its self-driving FordFFusions in Pittsburgh; engineers rode in the driver's seat
column34: ready to take over whenever things got tricky.Uber then introduced self-driving Volvo XC90s to San Francisco in December
column35: and riders who requested an uberX were matched with one of these vehicles if one was available. Just days later
column36: however
column37: the California Department of Motor Vehicles revoked the registrations for its self-driving cars
column38: as the company didn't have the proper permits.But Uber being Uber
column39: the fleet of Volvos were on their way to Arizona within days. Uber already operates a self-driving car program in the state
column40: and in 2015
column41: partnered with the University of Arizona to research mapping technology.Uber also recently acquired a car start-up Otto
column42: which specializes in self-driving trucks. Otto is a 90-person company
column43: and its co-founder
column44: Anthony Levandowski
column45: will now lead Uber into the self-driving car market. Impressively
column46: Otto engineers have worked at Tesla MotorsTSLA
column47: AppleAAPL)
column48: and Google
column49: and with this knowledge and expertise
column50: Uber is bound to be a top player in the self-driving car industry.ControversyWhile Uber has seen great success
column51: it's journey has been a bumpy one. The company has been in and out of the news thanks to a number of recent legal (Alphabet iscurrently suingthem for theft of its self-driving car technology) and reputation-hurting (note the company'ssexual harassment scandaland CEO Travis Kalanick's rude behavior towards a driver) headlines. And from noncompliance issues in New York City to regulatory concerns and lack of driver background checks
column52: Uber has drawn scrutiny and criticism
column53: and has even been banned in The Netherlands and in parts of Thailand
column54: India
column55: and China.It's no secret that traditional taxi services are not happy with the rise of Uber and other ride-hailing companies
column56: and many argue that Uber should be subject to the same regulations that they face. In dozens of cities it has moved in to
column57: Uber has faced intense opposition
column58: lobbying
column59: and legal challenges against it from these taxi companies.Uber has also been embroiled in along-standing battlewith its drivers. A group of drivers first sued the company back in 2013
column60: claiming they should be classified as employees rather than independent contractors. As a result
column61: Uber had been set to pay up to $100 million in reimbursement damages to almost 400
column62: 000 drivers
column63: but recently
column64: a federal judge in California ruled that the settlement was unfair.But as the saying goes
column65: any publicity is good publicity
column66: and all of the bad press has yet to really negatively affect Uber. Despitelosing over $1 billionin the first half of 2016
column67: Uber gained just as much revenue in that same time period. Its ability to raise exorbitant amounts of money is incredibly impressive for a company who is less than a decade old
column68: and this skill makes Uber that much more attractive to venture capital investors.IPO PotentialDespite these controversies
column69: investors are eagerly awaiting an Uber IPO. Many have believed
column70: or hoped
column71: the company would go public for a few years now
column72: but Mr. Kalanick wants ""to make sure [an IPO] happens as late as possible
column73: said in an interview with CNBC last year.If and when Uber finally decides to go public
column74: its potential would depend on the broader IPO market and economic environment. According to Renaissance Capital
column75: IPOs only raised a paltry $18.9 billion in 2016
column76: with annual proceeds falling to the lowest level since 2003. Just four companies filed public offerings that grossed over $1 billion.Looking ahead
column77: it's difficult to pinpoint how busy the IPO market will be this year. Snap Inc.SNAP
column78: the parent company of Snapchat
column79: finally made that giant step last month
column80: but it's hard to say what
column81: and if any
column82: other high-profile unicorns-i.e. Spotify
column83: Pinterest
column84: Airbnb
column85: and yes
column86: Uber-will follow. And recent high-growth IPOs like Twilio Inc.TWLOand NutanixNTNXhave traded strongly since their debut
column87: a good sign for tech companies everywhere looking to make their trading debut.How Might Uber Perform?An IPO for Uber could be massive for both the company and Wall Street. It's currently valued at $68 billion after a total of nine rounds of funding worth $12.9 billion since its launch. And thanks to Uber's structure-a unique combination of transportation company
column88: mobile Internet company
column89: and real world engineering-the company has been touted as one of the best future IPOs.It's IPO
column90: then
column91: could go either way
column92: but let one number stay in your mind: $68 billion. Let me write that again: $68 billion. This number is a hard one to forget
column93: and a figure that will be on the forefront of many investors' minds come the time of its public offering
column94: as it impressively showcases just how far this startup has come in a few short years.Now That Snapchat is Public

column1: How to Trade Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock While It Corrects;4/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNot much has changed forAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL) off the price chart in the past couple of weeks. But if we're to believe price action is a leading indicator
column4: the current narrative in GOOGL stock points more authoritatively at a corrective move in shares. Let me explain.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIt's been two full weeks sincelast writing about GOOGL.Not much has happened
column5: except investors trying to forgive and forget. And conditions may have quieted somewhat for Alphabet
column6: but the GOOGL stock chart is now looking a bit more like an enemy of the state.At the time
column7: Alphabet was and still is facing repercussions of marketing agencies and companies dropping YouTube and the Google Display Network advertising after learning content was placed alongside media showing terrorism and other acts of extremism.For its part
column8: Alphabet was quick to begin taking action and improve its""brand safety controls.""But for some prominent foreign and U.S. based advertisers
column9: improvements haven't happened quick enough and some key clients have pulled the plug on ad time.The latest step in fighting this pervasive problem is Alphabet will only allow ads on YouTube channels when the number of views hit a threshold level of 10
column10: 000. Theverdict is outwhether that will actually help advertisers and the new protocol does have its critics.In the interim and while the controversy plays out
column11: if we're to watch how Alphabet shares have traded since our last analysis
column12: it's looking more and more like a situation pointing to deeper corrective testing for GOOGL stock price.GOOGL Stock Daily ChartClick to EnlargeMy view of the technical situation has improved. In this context
column13: however
column14: it means I'm looking for a lower share price and larger correction to play out in the near term.On March 24
column15: as annotated on the daily chart of GOOGL
column16: I wrote of wanting to see a test of $795 to $825.The zone holds a couple retracement levels
column17: the 200-day simple moving average and would allow for a second test of the prior highs within an established uptrend.Two days later
column18: the upper band of support at $825 in GOOGL stock was tested. That's the good news. What's also occurred more recently is a bearish flag has developed against trendline resistance dating back to November.With GOOGL stock now back below the 50-day simple moving average
column19: the expectation is for the price action to break below the bear flag into a deeper double-bottom style. This would challenge the low set on March 26 and more significant penetration of the support zone.GOOGL Targeted Long Put ButterflyConsidering my belief GOOGL's corrective move isn't finished
column20: but not being overly bearish on the stock either
column21: I like the long bearish-targeted April $830/$815/$800 put butterfly.If the position sounds familiar
column22: it is. Other than slightly lower strikes and adjusting the target down by $5
column23: it's the same strategy and virtually the same debit to enter as from our last analysis. The spread is valued at $2.15 with GOOGL stock near $840 and achieves its maximum profit of $12.85 if GOOGL falls by roughly 3.0% to $815 on expiration.More achievable
column24: the limited risk spread maintains a profit range from $802.15 to $827.85. Prior to that third Friday
column25: gains can also be realized outside this area under the right market conditions.Money management wasn't required of the other butterfly position as the spread value held up. But like last time
column26: I do believe cutting risk with a stop of 50% or $1.05 to $1.10 is a good policy.Buy Advanced Micro Devices

column28: the initial debit is small with this type spread
column29: but continuing to hold during adverse conditions
column30: a bullish reaction that nixes GOOGL stock's bearish flag makes sense and possibly less cents lost.Disclosure: Investment accounts under Christopher Tyler's management do not currently own positions in any of the securities or their derivatives mentioned in this article. column1: Google Is Using AI to Combat Internet Trolls;4/10/2017;"One of the biggest challenges facing websites
column2: news   organizations
column3: and social media is online abuse and harassment.   Since the dawn of the internet
column4: sites have battled against   abusive
column5: toxic
column6: and inappropriate comments posted in their online   forums. With the millions of comments posted
column7: news organization   quickly became overwhelmed by the magnitude of data produced.Websites and publishers have become so concerned by the volume   of vitriolic comments and fear of lawsuits that many have removed   the ability to post comments on their sites. Consider that 72% of   internet users in America have witnessed online harassment
column8: and   nearly half have experienced it themselves. Social media sites   have been under fire to control hate speech and online abuse by   their members. Technological advancements in artificial   intelligence (AI) may finally provide the answer.Google uses AI to battle abusive content. Image source:     Pixabay.makeArticleAd();An important piece of the puzzleJigsaw
column9: a technology incubator of Google parentAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG)
column10: has developed an artificial   neural network -- an AI system that replicates the structure and   learning capacity of the human brain using algorithms and   software models. Using this technology
column11: it aims to identify and   control abusive online comments. Google and Jigsaw are making the   program available free of charge
column12: and it's being added to the   Google's TensorFlow library and Cloud Machine Learning Platform.   The product
column13: dubbed Perspective
column14: uses deep learning to sift   through reams of data to detect harassment
column15: insults
column16: and abusive   speech in online forums in real time. Jigsaw explains how the   program works:Perspective scores comments based on the perceived impact a     comment might have on a conversation
column17: which publishers can use     to give real-time feedback to commenters
column18: help moderators sort     comments more effectively
column19: or allow readers to more easily find     relevant information. We'll be releasing more machine learning     models later in the year
column20: but our first model identifies     whether a comment could be perceived as ""toxic"" to a     discussion.Do you kiss your mother with that mouth?Google and Jigsaw used comment data fromThe New York Times Company(NYSE: NYT)
column21: Wikipedia
column22: and several unnamed partners. They then   showed that data to panels of people and had them rate whether   the comments were toxic. They used these human responses as   training data for the AI system
column23: which will provide ratings of a   phrase based on its toxicity on a scale of 100 and allows you to   testthe   system. Type in the phrase ""you are ignoring important information""   rates a 10%
column24: ""your mother wears combat boots"" garnered 55%
column25: while   ""you're a jerk"" gets a response of 86% toxicity.The New York Times reports that it only has the resources to   allow comments on 10% of its articles. The company provided the   archives of comments in hopes of expanding its comments section   and to ""increase the speed at which comments are reviewed."" With   only 14 moderators to manually review every comment
column26: the task   became overwhelming
column27: reviewing on average 11
column28: 000 comments   daily.The New York Times joins Google to curb online abuse. Image     source: Pixabay.Twitter tries to clean up its actGoogle is not the only company seeking to curb online bullying   using AI. AtIBM's(NYSE: IBM) InterConnect conference last month
column29: Twitter
column30: Inc.'s(NYSE:TWTR) vice-president of data strategy Chris Moody announced that the   popular social network had partnered with IBM's Watson
column31: the   AI-based cognitive computer
column32: to address online abuse. He   stated:We're starting just now to partner with the Watson team.     Watson is really good at understanding nuances in language and     intention. What we want to do is be able to identify abuse     patterns early and stop this behavior before it starts.This comes at a crucial time for Twitter
column33: which has been under   fire for not policing its users. The company announced last month   that it was working to make the site a safer place by limiting   abusive users' ability to create new accounts and updating how   users can report abusive tweets.That didn't end wellAI systems have been tested on social media before
column34: though the   results have been less than stellar. In early 2016
column35: the folks atMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) research had used Twitter as a testing ground for   an AI-based chatbot
column36: @tayandyou
column37: aka TayTweets
column38: to learn the   speech patterns of millennials by interacting with them on the   site. Unfortunately
column39: within 24 hours and 96
column40: 000 tweets
column41: the   experiment was suspended when the fledgling AI began spewing   venomous vitriol. Microsoft later said:The AI chatbot Tay is a machine learning project
column42: designed     for human engagement. As it learns
column43: some of its responses are     inappropriate and indicative of the types of interactions some     people are having with it. We're making some adjustments to     Tay.Final thoughtsEach new technological innovation brings benefits and   challenges. The dawn of the internet age brought with it internet   trolls
column44: who sought to control the conversation and silence   dissenting voices. Programs like Perspective and Watson seek to   return voices to those vulnerable speakers

column1: Buy Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock When It Returns to Reality;4/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLast week
column4: Goldman Sachs started new analytical coverage ofAdvanced Micro Devices
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) at a ""sell
column6: suggesting the stock had rallied too far
column7: too fast. Judging from the 6% tumble AMD stock took that day
column8: the market didn't see it coming.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockSee
column9: as far as traders were concerned
column10: the 430% gain that Advanced Micro dished out over the prior 12 months implies that traders felt the development of theRyzencomputer processor and theVegagraphics processor were going to put the company back on a growth track. Goldman Sachs' thoughtscalled their whole logic into question.Does Goldman analyst Toshiya Hari have a point? He does. More than that
column11: though
column12: Hari serves up an important reminder that a stock and the underlying company aren't always necessarily one and the same.Yes
column13: AMD Stock Is OvervaluedHari specifically feels Advanced Micro Devices isovervalued to the tune of 236%based on a plausible projection of sales over the course of the coming five years. He finds the stock's valuation is ""difficult to justify"" simply because it's ""priced to perfection
column14: and then some.Once rivalsIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) turn it into a price war
column15: the ugly reality of this overvalued name could take a real toll.That's why Hari believes AMD stock worth just $11 per share. That's more than 18% less than last week's closing price. And
column16: with a forward-looking (2018) price-to-earnings ratio of 45.1
column17: his stance sounds less and less crazy.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: Still the Best?It all begs the question: How in the world did AMD shares get in this condition in the first place?The simplest answer is: human nature.But Advanced Micro DevicesIson TargetYes
column18: you own a stock not for where the company is
column19: but where the company is going to be six to 24 months down the road. It's not always easy to make a reasonable long-term guesstimate
column20: but most traders do it well enough most of the time.There are times
column21: however
column22: when common sense seems to get thrown out the window and investors decide today's a good day to buy simply because there's no bad news today. There's been no (relative) bad news from or about AMD stock for months now - because the company has been in regroup mode - and traders remained in buy mode without ever stopping to realize they've been in perpetual buy mode since April of last year. Hari only pointed that out.It's not the first time investors have needed to be reminded a stock can't rise forever on a company's ""promising future."" Sooner or later
column23: the future has to arrive and justify a frothy valuation. That future for Advanced Micro Devices is still a little too far off to keep the stock propped up at these levels.That being said
column24: the stock/company relationship is still a two-way street. A falling stock doesn't necessarily mean the underlying company is doomed. It's simply a matter of aligning a stock's price and a company's potential. Several observers still feel good about AMD (the company).Barron's Tiernan Ray is one of those optimists.Ray recently wrote:""My colleague Teresa Rivas has anice summary of the Goldman argument
column25: and Barron's positive view in contrast. The gist is that Hari is right about all the risks
column26: which have always been there. But the stock is not priced expensively
column27: as Hari implies
column28: if one believes the company can take significant market share back from Intel (INTC) and possibly Nvidia (NVDA).In hours of conversation with CEO Lisa Su
column29: CTO Mark Papermaster
column30: and other executives
column31: I did get a sense of a company with a more sober sense of purpose than in past days. I think the seriousness with which management recognizes both the opportunities and the risks is a meaningful factor. The company is aware that in past AMD fumbled leads it obtained. It is committed as an organization not to do so again.""All fair points.3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Tesla Inc (TSLA)
column32: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) and Delta Air Lines
column33: Inc. (DAL)But
column34: even Ray's commentary has a big ""if"" in it: If Advanced Micro Devices can steal market share back from INTC and NVDA. The consensus is
column35: Nvidia and Intel are ready to go to war.Bottom LineI'll repeat something I said back on March 10:""Don't confuse any future weakness from AMD as evidence of what's in store
column36: results-wise
column37: from the company. Advanced Micro Devices is very well positioned for a great 2017. The trick is just being patient enough to wait for a truly palatable entry price. That could still be well below the recent low.In other words
column38: you don't want to step into AMD stock for the long haul until it's almost uncomfortable to do so. We aren't there yet.""We still aren't there yet. I'm not even sure a retreat to Hari's target of $11 would get us all the way there. It's still a compelling company though.As of this writing

column1: Holy IMAX
column2: Batman: Movie Companies Plan to Create VR Superheroes!;4/10/2017;"Imagine going to a movie theater and experiencing the undersea   world of Aquaman or visiting Superman's Fortress of Solitude.   This may sound fanciful
column3: but these types of virtual reality (VR)   experiences may soon become actual reality thanks to a new   partnership betweenTime Warner Inc.'s(NYSE: TWX) Warner Bros. Home Entertainment andIMAX Corporation(NYSE: IMAX) . The companies have announced a co-financing   and production agreement to create original interactive VR   content forAquamanandJustice League
column4: as well as a third unnamed project.IMAX and Warner Bros. will create supersized VR experiences.     Image source: IMAX.makeArticleAd();Bringing superheroes to lifeRecent developments
column5: particularly in the area of special   effects
column6: have resulted in characters coming to life on the screen   like never before. This has given rise to a renaissance in comic   book movies that have delighted fans and created a worldwide   box-office phenomenon. This partnership creates exciting new   opportunities in VR.""A key component of our vision for VR is to help usher in the   first wave of high-end blockbuster-based content.Justice LeagueandAquamanfeature some of the most beloved characters on the planet
column7: providing iconic properties to launch this effort
column8: said IMAX CEO   Rich Gelfond. ""This type of premium content will introduce   audiences to virtual reality in stand-alone and multiplex-based   IMAX VR centres as well as other platforms.Warner Bros. hopes to leverage the box office success of its   movies likeMan of Steel
column9: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
column10: andSuicide Squadfor its upcoming creations while offering fans additional ways to   interact with their heroes.""Using content and characters from these upcoming films and   incorporating creative direction from some of Hollywood's most   innovative filmmakers will help us to bring a groundbreaking   experience to audiences and consumers who are hungry for a   cutting-edge virtual reality experience
column11: said Warner Bros. Home   Entertainment President Ron Sanders. Each super-sized   experience will be available during an exclusive window at IMAX   VR centers
column12: later expanding to other VR platforms. Details   regarding the exact nature of the content have not yet been   revealed.A communal experienceThis announcement tops off a busy few months for IMAX in the   area of VR. Though the company is best known for its premium   large-format theaters
column13: IMAX recently opened a pilot VR center in   Los Angeles
column14: andearly reviewshave been encouraging. It has plans to open five more locations   by the end of the year.These VR centers will employ IMAX's proprietary modular design   that will allow multiple players to interact and enjoy a communal   experience
column15: envisioning it as a destination for groups of   friends. If the testing at these initial locations proves   successful
column16: IMAX plans to expand the concept globally to   multiplexes
column17: shopping centers
column18: and select tourist   destinations.IMAX plans to revolutionize the virtual reality experience.     Image source: Getty Images.Google partners on techIMAXrecently partneredwithAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) Google to develop a   high-resolution cinema-grade VR camera using Google's Jump   platform
column19: which can stitch together 360-degree images into   seamless content. The combination will address the technological   challenges unique to VR.Google recentlymade wavesof its own in VR
column20: receiving an Oscar nomination for its short   filmPearl
column21: a movie that was specifically created to be viewed in virtual   reality. The story revolves around a father and daughter who   travel the country chasing stardom as witnessed from the front   seat of their car. Google Spotlight Stories has been creating   animated shorts for several years to experiment with the   challenges created by 360-degree storytelling.VR for the massesVirtual reality is in its infancy and systems can still run   into the thousands of dollars. Reaching an untapped market of   consumers that may be interested in the technology
column22: but unwilling   to make such a large expenditure on their own
column23: may represent a   huge payoff for the companies.Virtual reality and its sibling augmented reality are still   nascent technologies
column24: but represent huge potential. IDCestimatesthat revenue from these markets could exceed $143 billion   annually by 2020. These are early days for both IMAX and Warner   Bros. in the area of VR
column25: but by providing location-based options   tied directly to fan favorite blockbuster movies
column26: this could   generate a new stream of revenue
column27: and it looks like a smart way   to get a foothold in an emerging field.10 stocks we like better than IMAXWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Better Buy: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. vs Google;4/9/2017;"BothAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) and Google's parent company
column3: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column4: are trading near their all-time   highs. Amazon's stock has climbed so much in the past 12 months
column5: it's made its founder and CEO Jeff Bezos the second wealthiest   person in the world
column6: recently surpassing Warren Buffett and   Amancio Ortega. Alphabet shares are up a modest 11%
column7: compared   with Amazon's 51% increase.But investors can't dwell too much on the past. They need to   look to the future to determine which stocks offer the best   opportunities for further gains. Today we'll compare the two tech   giants head to head to determine which is a better buy:   Amazon.com or Alphabet.Image source: Amazon.com.makeArticleAd();Amazon is firing on all cylindersAmazon's core retail business is strong. It generated $124   billion in revenue in 2016 across its North American and   international retail segments. That's up 25% from $99 billion in   2015. Amazon's growth is fueled by increasing Prime membership
column8: which acts as a huge incentive for both customers and merchants   to use Amazon's marketplace before looking elsewhere. A survey   fromBloomReachfound that 55% of online shoppers begin their product search on   Amazon.com.But what's really driving Amazon's stock price higher is its   more profitable operating segment
column9: Amazon Web Services. AWS is   Amazon's cloud computing service
column10: which supports all sorts of web   applications
column11: from basic websites to huge data-consuming apps   such asNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) . AWS sales increased 55% last year to $12.2   billion. More importantly
column12: the segment's operating profit of $3.1   billion is about three times as much as Amazon's retail   business.Amazon is also expanding into other high-margin businesses.Its advertising business is growing rapidly
column13: albeit on a small base.Morgan Stanleyanalyst Brian Nowack estimates that Amazon's ad business could   grow to $5 billion by next year and $7 billion by 2020. And those   sales are high margin
column14: which means that despite the relatively   small revenue compared with the rest of Amazon's retail segment
column15: Amazon could see significant profit growth. Nowack notes
column16: however
column17: that Amazon's ad revenue growth shouldn't cut into   Google's core search ad sales.Alphabet is as steady as everAlphabet may have changed its name to reflect its other bets   besides Google
column18: but the online advertising business is still its   core business. Google accounted for 99% of the company's revenue   and 118% of its operating income in 2016
column19: while ""other bets""   produced an operating loss.Image source: GoogleGoogle is managing to expand its already dominant share of the   search advertising market. eMarketer expects Google to expand its   share by 16.1% to claim roughly 78% of the U.S. search market   this year.Google growth is being fueled by its Android operating system
column20: which recently became the most popular operating system across   all devices. Google is also extremely popular across other mobile   OSes
column21: and consumers are turning to their smartphones more often   to look up details on just about anything. That means more Google   searches and more search ad revenue.YouTube is also a dominant force on mobile
column22: with the average   mobile viewer spending 40 minutes watching video per session as   of mid-2015. YouTube is currently under scrutiny for displaying   ads before objectionable content
column23: but Google has quickly taken   steps to counteract the issues. The negative impact on Google   should be relatively small.Lots of growth
column24: but which should you buy?The growth outlook for both Amazon and Alphabet is quite   strong
column25: so how can investors decide which to buy?Both companies have strong balance sheets with huge amounts of   cash and relatively little debt. Alphabet's $86 billion in cash   and equivalents
column26: however
column27: completely dwarfs Amazon's $26 billion.   Alphabet even has less long-term debt than Amazon. Alphabet also   produces more cash from operations -- $36 billion
column28: versus $16   billion. That's not to say Amazon's struggling for cash
column29: but   Alphabet is in a better position.Perhaps more telling are the valuation multiples investors are   putting on both companies. Amazon currently trades for a   price-to-earnings multiple of 182.6. Alphabet (C shares) is   comparatively cheap at 29.6 times earnings.But analysts are significantly more bullish on Amazon's   earnings growth prospects
column30: expecting an average of 72.7% earnings   growth over the next five years
column31: compared with just 19% for   Alphabet.Google's growth is coming from the megatrend of advertisers   who are shifting more ad dollars to digital while consumers spend   more time searching and watching videos on their smartphones.   Amazon's growth will come from AWS and the emergence of other   high-margin categories such as advertising. Amazon is also   working off a much smaller net-income base than Alphabet. Its   growth is much less certain than Alphabet's
column32: but it has the   potential to pay off in the long run.If you can stomachthe up-and-down nature of Amazon stock
column33: I think it makes a better long-term buy despite its sky-high   valuation. For more conservative growth investors
column34: Alphabet is an   excellent option.10 stocks we like better than AmazonWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 2 Stocks You Can Buy and Hold Forever;4/9/2017;"Some might say I'm taking on way too much risk. Others might   say I've just gotten lucky. Both could be right.Here's the undeniable fact: When I combine my holdings ofAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column2: they account for 35% of my   family's stock holdings. So
column3: when I tell you I think you can buy   and hold these two companies forever
column4: my money is firmly where my   mouth is.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();It's worth pointing out that I never intended for things to be   this way. Both Amazon and Alphabet -- better known as Google --   have grown significantly into their current positions. I just   have no intention of selling. That's because both satisfy the   four most important things I look for in an investment.A wide moatOver time
column5: I've learned the hard way that the strength of a   moat -- or asustainablecompetitive advantage -- is the most important factor in   determining whether to invest in a company. Put the simplest way
column6: a moat is what differentiates one company from the next -- and   keeps the competition at bay.Alphabet's moat is provided by the dominance of Google's   search engine. Netmarketshare.com estimates that Google has a 77%   market share of desktop searches
column7: and 96% of mobile searches.   That allows the company to collect gobs of data to help   advertisers hit specific potential customers
column8: something   advertisers are more than willing to pay up for.But it doesn't stop at search. Alphabet now has six other   products with over 1billionusers: Google Maps
column9: Gmail
column10: Chrome
column11: Android
column12: Google Play Store
column13: and YouTube. That's a powerful ecosystem.Amazon
column14: on the other hand
column15: benefits from both physical   advantages of scale and -- increasingly -- the network effect. On   scale
column16: the company has spentbillionsbuilding out its network of mammoth fulfillment centers. These   centers -- there are an estimated 95 stateside
column17: with 26 more   on the way -- help ensure that everything you order on Amazon   gets to your front door as soon as possible. It would be   prohibitively expensive foranycompany to try and match this scale.On the other hand
column18: Amazon's third-party selling option has   gained a lot of attention lately. Sales from retail third-party   seller services doubled in the last two years alone
column19: to   $23 billion. What this means is that more non-Amazon   retailers are using Amazon's platform to sell products. That   incentivizes more buyers to use Amazon -- and based on estimates   of Amazon Prime customers counts
column20: they are doing so in droves.   It's a virtuous cycle that continues to build steam.Optionality in spadesHere's how optionality works in the real world: You do   hundreds of experiments
column21: tinkering with what will work. Most of   your efforts will fail
column22: but your losses will be small. Every now   and again
column23: you'll happen upon a big hit
column24: and it will provide a   meaningful source of future income. You have theoptionof killing off or further pursuing your experiments.Amazon is the King of Optionality. It started as an online   bookstore but has branched into e-readers
column25: retail
column26: cloud   services
column27: original content
column28: and even delivery services. No quote   better sums up CEO Jeff Bezos' attitude toward optionality than   this
column29: when addressing the failure of the company's Fire   Phone:You need to be making big
column30: noticeable failures. The great     thing is that
column31: when you take this approach
column32: a small number of     winners pay for dozens
column33: hundreds of failures.Alphabet's decision to rename itself to differentiate the   company's ""Other Bets"" is just another way of saying that it
column34: too
column35: is focused on optionality. The company is variously focusing   on a connected house through Nest
column36: self-driving cars
column37: and faster   Internet via Google Fiber. And there's no telling what might come   out of Google[x] in the coming years.Skin in the gameAuthor
column38: trader
column39: and academic Nassim Taleb has written often   about how important it is that decision-makers have their own   skin in the game. Without it
column40: those who rely on such   decision-makers have no recourse against the hidden risks   inherent in any complex organization.That's why I find it heartening that both Amazon and Alphabet   are founder-led companies
column41: with both founders having a   significant portion of their skin in the game.CompanyFounderShares OwnedValueVoting RightsAmazonJeff Bezos83 millionabout $74 billion17.6%AlphabetLarry Page21 millionabout $18 billion26.6%AlphabetSergey Brin20 millionabout $17 billion25.9%Data sources: Most recent company DEF 14A filings.The people running these companies have even more incentive   than you and I do to see long-term success take hold.Financial fortitudeFinally
column42: I think it's important that any business I invest in   have financial resources on hand to weather an economic downturn.   In both Amazon and Alphabet
column43: I believe we have those things.CompanyCashDebtFree Cash FlowAmazon$26 billion$7 billion$10 billionAlphabet$92 billion$4 billion$26 billionData source: Yahoo! Finance. All figures for the 2016 fiscal   year
column44: rounded to the nearest billion.When you combine these four factors: a wide moat
column45: optionality
column46: skin in the game
column47: and financial fortitude
column48: I believe you have the   ingredients for a winner. That's why these companies comprise   such an enormous part of my portfolio
column49: and it's why I think you   can buy and hold these stocks forever.10 stocks we like better than AmazonWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
