column1: 3 Top Dividend Stocks in the Server Industry;4/8/2017;"Servers are
column2: in many respects
column3: the backbones of technology   industry. They serve as critical infrastructure on which a host   of other functions rest. Considering their importance
column4: it should   come as no surprise that the server market is one of the largest   sub-industries in all of tech; global server sales totaled $14.6   billion in Q4 2016
column5: according to research firmIDC.Cloud computing is undoubtedly changing the industry
column6: but the   leading server manufacturers remain several well-known tech   companies. In this article
column7: we'll look at three dividend-paying
column8: large-cap stocks that investors interested in the server market   should consider.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Hewlett-Packard EnterpriseIt is the world's largest server provider
column9: and servers sales   constitute the single-largest revenue contributor amongHewlett-Packard Enterprises'(NYSE: HPE) six reporting sub-sections
column10: accounting for $14.0   billion of the IT giant's $50.1 billion FY 2016 sales. Like   the rest of the market
column11: Hewlett-Packard Enterprise's server sales   have remained fairly static
column12: declining just 0.7% from 2015 to   2016.For those unfamiliar with it
column13: the company was formed from the   2015 split of the iconic tech conglomerate Hewlett-Packard.HP Inc. was created to house the PC and printer division
column14: which remain   in secular decline
column15: while Hewlett-Packard Enterprise was created   to hold the more promising businesses. However
column16: looking at   current analyst estimates
column17: it isn't immediately clear that those   businesses are
column18: in fact
column19: more promising.Wall Street analysts see the company's 2017 estimated sales   falling 28% and its FY 2018 revenue declining a further   17%. Interestingly
column20: this kind of sales attrition did not   reveal itself in HPE's most recent 10-K filing; FY 2016 total   revenues fell a mere 3.8%. As such
column21: investors considering   buying HPE for its income-producing abilities should keep in mind   that many observers widely expect its business to gradually   deteriorate in the coming years. Buyer beware.In terms of its dividend stats
column22: HPE yields slightly less than   the market average of 1.94%. The company raised its dividend in   December
column23: so its shares yield 1.28% on a trailing-12-month rate   basis
column24: and 1.48% on a forward basis. It also enjoys plenty of   room for future rate increases -- HPE's payout ratio sits at just   12.6% -- though its revenue growth outlook profile remains a   critical consideration for anyone looking at HPE stock.International Business MachinesUnlike HPE
column25: the dynamics atInternational Business Machines'(NYSE: IBM) server business better reflect the on-the-ground   reality of the server industry. IBM organizes its sales of its   three main server products under the umbrella of its Systems   reporting segment. For its fiscal 2016
column26: sales of IBM's physical   servers plummeted 21.8% to $5.9 billion. This might seem dire
column27: but it's important to remember that cloud computing and IBM's   various software-as-a-service offerings still rely on servers to   power their systems. In fact
column28: IBM's cloud revenues grew 49% in   2016 to a run rate of $5.8 billion
column29: or roughly the same size as   IBM's current server sales base. Said another way
column30: IBM's shifting   business model hasn't eroded the server as a key driver of its   sales. Rather
column31: the rise of cloud computing means IBM is selling   server-powered software to customers
column32: rather than physical   servers themselves.In terms of its dividend payments
column33: IBM shares currently yield   3.2%
column34: well above market averages. The company has done an   admirable of job steadily increasing its payouts as well. Though   not a Dividend Aristocrat
column35: IBM has increased its annual cash   payments for 17 consecutive years. It also bears noting that IBM   has been one of the most active companies in corporate America in   terms of rewarding its shareholders through stock buybacks as   well. So
column36: while IBM doesn't command the same kind of server   market share as HPE
column37: the company's continued progress in its   ongoing business pivot and above-average yield make it one of the   more appealing income-producing stocks to appear on this   list.IntelAnother interesting dividend play tied to the server industry   could be investing in one of the suppliers that provides hardware   components to the industry at large. If that's your flavor
column38: then   chip giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) is perhaps your best bet.Intel is widely acknowledged to control an estimated 99% of   the server microprocessor market
column39: making it a proxy for the   industry as a whole. As such
column40: companies that make and sell   physical servers to customers
column41: like HPQ and IBM
column42: use Intel chips   to power their products. However
column43: major cloud computing providers   -- likeAmazon
column44: Alphabet
column45: and others -- also use Intel server chips to power their   respective cloud infrastructures. As such
column46: investing in Intel can   be seen as a nice way to invest in the industry growth as a   whole
column47: while saving the headache of having to determine which   specific server manufacturer will perform the best.Seasoned tech investors will also recognize Intel as one of   the industry's best-knowndividend   stocks. Though fairly mature from a sales growth perspective
column48: Intel   handsomely rewards its shareholders through cash distributions   and stock buybacks. Intel's current dividend yield sits at a   respectable 2.9%. Its 49% payout ratio should give the   company the flexibility to continue to raise payouts in the   future as well. And while not a Dividend Aristocrat -- Intel   missed raising its dividend as recently as two years ago -- the   company has demonstrated a general commitment to growing its   dividend. As just one example
column49: Intel's cash distributions grew   from just $0.07 in its FY 2000 to $1.04 in its FY 2016. So
column50: while   Intel doesn't directly produce servers
column51: its shares can still be   an interesting way for investors to generate dividend payments   from the server industry all the same.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column53: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: Alphabet Inc. Earnings: 3 Metrics to Watch;4/7/2017;"Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) has put its first-quarter earnings   release date on the calendar. The internet search giant will   report results for its most recently ended quarter on Thursday
column2: April 27. After missing estimates for earnings per share in its   most recent quarter
column3: investors will be watching the company's   profitability closely.Here's a preview of what to expect from Alphabet's EPS in Q1
column4: as well as a look at two other key metrics worth examining when   Google's parent company reports results later this month.Image source: Google.makeArticleAd();Earnings per shareFor Alphabet's first quarter of 2017
column5: analysts are expecting   non-GAAP EPS of $7.39
column6: on average. Notably
column7: analyst estimates are   no longer based on an EPS calculation that excludes stock-based   compensation
column8: as Alphabet has opted to beginincluding stock-based compensation in its   non-GAAP results. So
column9: Alphabet's year-ago EPS figures don't represent an   apples-to-apples comparison. But
column10: for reference
column11: Alphabet   reported GAAP and non-GAAP EPS of $6.47 and $7.50 in the first   quarter of 2016.The reasoning behind Alphabet's decision to include   stock-based compensation in its non-GAAP EPS? Stock-based   compensation has become a material and regular cost to running   Alphabet
column12: CFO Ruth Porat explained in the company's   fourth-quarter earnings call.Revenue growthAnother key item to watch in Alphabet's first quarter will be   revenue growth. On average

column14: up a nice 19.5% year over year.Analysts are interestingly expecting a slight deceleration in   the company's year-over-year revenue growth rate. In Alphabet's   fourth quarter of 2016

column16: or 24%   on a constant currency basis.Beyond checking in on Alphabet's revenue growth
column17: investors may   want to look for some insight from management into what the main   drivers for revenue growth during the quarter were. In Q4
column18: Alphabet's revenue growth was primarily driven by mobile search   and YouTube. Did these drivers remain key catalysts in Q4?Other revenueNot to be confused with Alphabet's ""other bets"" segment
column19: Alphabet's ""other revenue
column20: is another important segment to   watch. Accounting for over 10% of Alphabet's revenue
column21: the segment   has been growing rapidly
column22: thanks to revenue from the Google Play   store
column23: hardware sales
column24: and the company's cloud businesses.Google Home. Image source: Google.In 2016
column25: Alphabet's other revenue grew 41% on a full year   basis. And in Alphabet's fourth quarter
column26: other revenue increased   62% year over year.In Alphabet's fourth-quarter earnings call
column27: Porat said the   company sees ""tremendous potential"" in Play
column28: hardware
column29: and   cloud.A specific area of Alphabet's other revenue for investors to   look for more details on is hardware. Having just launched its   voice-activated smart speaker (Google Home) and a new smartphone   (Google Pixel) in Q4
column30: Alphabet had some insight into these   products' potential. Fortunately
column31: Google CEO Sundar Pichai said   during Alphabet's fourth-quarter call that the early success of   these products was ""promising.""Alphabet reports its first-quarter results after market close   on Thursday

column1: Facebook Launches Educational Tool to Fight Fake News Menace;4/7/2017;"Facebook IncFBhas unveiled an educational tool to help users spot fake news. Designed in collaboration with a nonprofit organization
column2: First Draft
column3: it will appear at the top of news feed for a few days in 14 selected countries
column4: including Germany
column5: France
column6: Indonesia
column7: Taiwan and Brazil
column8: per reports.By clicking on the tool
column9: users will be directed to Facebook Help center which will now have more information and resources to help them identify fake news.In a blog post
column10: Facebook VP Adam Mosseri said
column11: ""News Feed is a place for authentic communication. Improving news literacy is a global priority
column12: and we need to do our part to help people understand how to make decisions about which sources to trust. False news runs counter to our mission to connect people with the stories they find meaningful. We will continue working on this and we know we have more work to do.""Facebook

column16: Facebook suffered a heavy blow when it was accused of suppressing conservative news and doing little regarding the spread of fake news on its platform. Fake news dissemination on the popular social platform has been widely regarded as the primary reason for the surprise victory of Donald Trump in the U.S. Presidential elections. Apart from Facebook
column17: TwitterTWTRand AlphabetGOOGLhave also been accused of spreading fake stories
column18: resulting in the surprising elections outcome.After rejecting the allegations initially
column19: Facebook chief
column20: Mark Zuckerberg changed his stance on the matter. In an extensive blog post on Nov 19
column21: Zuckerberg said that Facebook is taking misinformation ""seriously"" but added that the ""percentage of misinformation is relatively small."" So far
column22: the initiatives taken up by the company include improvement of technical systems to develop more efficient detection of false stories. It is also working to help its 1.79 billion users report fake stories.Apart from availing the help of third parties for better verification of news and the option of ""labeling stories"" that are flagged
column23: the company had earlier declared that it is ""raising the bar for stories that appear in related articles under links in News Feed."" Facebook said it will also scrutinize ads that promote bogus stories for monetary gains. Lastly
column24: it added that it will work with the entire news industry to improve its fact checking systems.The company has also appointed ex-CNN anchor Campbell Brown as the head of its News Partnerships Team.Zacks Rank & Stock PickAt present
column25: Facebook has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).  In the past one year
column26: the company's shares have generated a return of 24.16%
column27: compared with the ZacksInternet Servicesindustry's gain of 7.26%.A better-ranked stock in the wider technology space is Tech Data CorporationTECD
column28: which sports a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank stocks   here.In the trailing four quarters
column29: Tech Data has yielded a positive average earnings surprise of 8.73%.Zacks' Best Private Investment IdeasWhile we are happy to share many articles like this on the website
column30: our best recommendations and most in-depth research are not available to the public.Starting today

column1: PayPal Is Still King of Online Payment Services;4/6/2017;"Online commerce continues to surge and take a bigger piece of   the overall retail pie. While this might seem obvious from our   own shopping patterns and those of our friends
column2: the data also   backs up this observation.Earlier this year
column3: the U.S. Census Bureauestimatedthat e-commerce sales for the fourth quarter of 2016 were   $102.7 billion
column4: an approximate 14.3% increase from the fourth   quarter of 2015. For the year
column5: e-commerce sales came in at $394.9   billion
column6: a 15.1% increase from 2015. All this growth occurred   while total 2016 domestic retail sales grew a much more anemic   2.9% from 2015's figures.With online sales growing
column7: investors should note who the   future winners might be in the online payment services space. One   metric that can be used to compare the different players is to   learn which companies have built up a loyal following of engaged   customers. Let's take a look atBrand Keys' Customer Loyalty Engagement Indexto see how they stack up.makeArticleAd();Online and mobile commerce continues to explode. Image     source: PayPal Holdings Inc.The Customer Loyalty Engagement Index examines the   relationships customers have with 740 brands across 83   categories. While Brand Keys doesn't fully reveal how they   determine their rankings
column8: the consulting group does tell us:The Brand Keys data paints a detailed picture of the     category drivers that engage customers
column9: engender loyalty and     drive real profits.These drivers not only define how the consumer will view the     category
column10: compare offerings
column11: and
column12: ultimately
column13: buy
column14: but also     identify the expectations the consumer holds for each driver.     The brand whose drivers come closest to meeting (or even     exceeding) those of the category Ideal is always the one whose     customers will demonstrate the highest levels of engagement and     loyalty over the next 12 to 18 months.Rounding out the top fiveImage source: Square Inc.In the online payment services category
column15: Square Inc(NYSE: SQ) placed fifth. Square is perhaps best known for making   it easy for small merchants to accept credit card payments with a   simple attachment to an iPhone
column16: but has recently been growing itsecosystemwell beyond its card-reading products.Amazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) Amazon Payments placed fourth in the category.   The platform allows customers to use the payment methods stored   on their Amazon.com accounts to make purchases at third-party   websites. In early February
column17: Amazon issued a press release on theprogressAmazon Payments had made over the past year and the numbers were   nothing if not impressive: 33 million customers had now used Pay   with Amazon to make a purchase
column18: more than half the customers   using the payment platform were also Prime members
column19: and the   number of merchants accepting the platform had grown 120% year   over year.Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) Google Wallet finished third.   The app allows the user to send money to family and friends via   the app
column20: online
column21: or through a Gmail account. There are also a few   commercial transactions where customers can use the app. The   neatest feature might be that users can send money to anyone with   an email address or phone number and the recipient doesn't need   to have the app to accept the payment.In second place came private company Stripe. Stripe makes it   easy for individuals and merchants to accept online payments   through a website. Stripe is raising capital that values the   company at $9.2 billion and has no plans to go public anytime   soon.But the online payment champion is still...Image source: PayPal Holdings Inc.Take a bow
column22: PayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ: PYPL) . PayPal recently took the opportunity to pat   itself on the back when it almost simultaneously reached 200   million active accounts and 50 million One Touch users. One Touch   has become the most rapidly adopted product in PayPal's history.   The platform allows users to register a device
column23: whether a   smartphone
column24: tablet
column25: or PC
column26: and stay logged into their PayPal   account on that device for forever afterward. This means users do   not have to retrieve their login information or enter   payment credentials when making purchases on that device. This   can become especially important when dealing with the small   screens on smartphones.Here is what PayPal CEO Dan Schulman said about the platform   during the company's latest conference call
column27: transcript provided   byS&P Global Market Intelligence:One Touch has redefined online checkout. Simply put
column28: it     produces
column29: by far and away
column30: the best conversion rate in the     payments industry by making it faster and simpler for customers     to pay with a single tap. Its adoption has well exceeded our     projection.PayPal has also made it a priority to forgepartnershipsacross the payments industry
column31: which it believes adds orders of   magnitude of convenience and choice to its customers. Schulman   routinely refers to this as being a ""customer champion."" At this   year's Goldman Sachs Technology and Internet Conference
column32: he   said
column33: ""To build a great company over the long term
column34: I think   it is absolutely essential that you embrace the mantra of being a   customer champion
column35: which means that you've got to solve pain   points for your customers
column36: all of them
column37: instead of creating   potentially pain points for them.""The partnerships have allowed PayPal to become much more than   just a button appearing on online checkout screens; it is now a   comprehensive payment platform that can be used for mobile
column38: online
column39: and in-store purchases.By all appearances
column40: this strategy is working. Active account   growth
column41: user engagement
column42: and total payment volume were all up by   double-digit percentages year over year last quarter. With a   corporate culture focused on solving customers' biggest problems   with the platform
column43: PayPal could well inspire customer loyalty for   years to come.10 stocks we like better than PayPal HoldingsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and PayPal Holdings wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column1: Everything You Need to Know About Comcast's Xfinity Mobile;4/6/2017;"On Thursday
column2: cable giantComcast Corp.CMCSAannounced its long-awaited wireless phone service
column3: Xfinity Mobile
column4: that promises to shake up the telecom industry by offering lower prices than other legacy carriers. While the mobile plan will mainly be powered by its 16 million Wi-Fi hotspots
column5: it will also leverage Verizon'sVZwireless network.Comcast is bundling the service with its other Xfinity offerings
column6: but customers must have
column7: at a minimum
column8: Xfinity Internet to sign up for the cable company's new mobile plan.At first glance
column9: though
column10: Xfinity Mobile sounds pretty enticing
column11: and at no extra cost
column12: customers can automatically get up to five phone lines if they choose to add the new plan to their Xfinity Internet service. There are no line-access fees
column13: and Xfinity Mobile includes talk and text with the first 100 megabytes of shared 4G LTE data included.Pricing breaks down as follows:X1 internet and cable package subscribers can get an   ""unlimited"" plan for $45 a month per line.Anyone who subscribes to a Comcast internet service below X1   can get an ""unlimited"" plan for $65 a month per line.You can also pay per gigabyte
column14: in which each GB costs $12.   This is good for someone who thinks they'll only use a small   amount of data per month.Xfinity Mobile plans aren't really unlimited. Like we all are accustomed to
column15: unlimited today really means ""unlimited
column16: or unlimited to a certain extent. Comcast says it will reduce speeds after you use more than 20GB of mobile data. But
column17: customers will get access to HD video streaming on all Comcast plans
column18: something that Verizon
column19: AT&TT
column20: SprintS
column21: and T-MobileTMUSonly offer on their highest-tier wireless mobile plans.As for phones
column22: Xfinity Mobile will offer the AppleAAPLiPhone-including the 7
column23: 7 Plus
column24: 6S
column25: 6S Plus
column26: and SE-Samsung smartphones
column27: like the Galaxy S8 and S8+
column28: and Galaxy S7 and S7 Edge
column29: as well as LG's X Power phone. You can either choose to buy the devices upfront or choose a 24-month payment plan
column30: but you cannot bring your own device to the service to start
column31: at least not now; Comcast may add that option in the future.Xfinity Mobile is set to launch by mid-2017
column32: but it's still in the testing phase. So far
column33: Comcast has run limited employee trials of the mobile plan
column34: and today
column35: those tests will expand to the company's entire employee base. Xfinity Mobile is similar to Google'sGOOGLProject Fi
column36: which found success before with the concept of automatically switching between Wi-Fi and network connectivity.Comcast
column37: Mobile Leader?The telecom industry has been evolving over the past few years due to changing consumer preferences
column38: and key players have responded in interesting ways. Most notably
column39: AT&T announced its eyebrow-raising $85 billion deal to buy media company Time WarnerTWXlast year
column40: in addition to its various moves to diversify into the entertainment industry
column41: like its purchase of DirecTV. Verizon has doubled down on digital media as well
column42: with plans to acquire Yahoo'sYHOOcore business.But where does this leave Comcast? Xfinity Mobile is not Comcast's first venture in the wireless market. The cable provider notably joined together with Sprint
column43: Cox Communications
column44: Time Warner Cable
column45: and Bright House Networks on a mobile platform called Pivot back in 2005
column46: but that failed after two years without gaining much traction.Xfinity Mobile will surely stir up this ultra-competitive industry
column47: and it's not that difficult to imagine Comcast as a telecom leader someday. Like AT&T and Verizon
column48: the cable company needed a way to diversify its central business
column49: especially as more and more customers cut the cord and turn to video streaming platforms like NetflixNFLX. Will a wireless phone service be the answer? We'll have to wait and see.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking   About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Snap Inc (SNAP) Stockâ€™s Goal-Based Bidding Is Nice
column2: But Wonâ€™t Help;4/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTo say thatSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP) has had a tough go of it since its March 2 IPO would be quite an understatement. It's (mostly)one of the analyst community's favorite punching bags
column4: and despite a good first couple of days as a publicly traded company
column5: SNAP stock is now down more than 30% from its March 3 high. Not good.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAs is the case with all companies
column6: though
column7: not everything the parent company of online messaging service Snapchat does is a trainwreck - there are some things you have to appreciate about the organization. One of those is Snap's recently updated advertising-bidding platform
column8: which takes so-called goal-based bidding to the next proverbial level.Advertising giants likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column9: NASDAQ:GOOG) may want to take notice.SNAP Stock's Goal-Based BiddingIf the topic and names seems strangely familiar
column10: it may because it was only a week agoFacebook officially launched its version of header biddingâ€¦ a means of real-time buying and selling of ad space that's more transparent for the buyer and the seller. The publisher knows how much it will be earning per click
column11: and the advertiser knows how and where its ads will appear. The win-win scenario means more efficient spending of advertising dollars.That evolution is just a microcosm of the ongoing improvement of the web's advertising business though. Goal-based bidding is another natural evolution of the business
column12: and one of the few things SNAP stock holders have to feel good about at this time.7 Tech Stocks That Will Crush the Market for YearsIn short
column13: goal-based bidding is exactly what it sounds like. That is
column14: a payment not for an ad impression or a click
column15: but a specific action. In the case of Snapchat
column16: the primary goal its advertisers are seeking isthe installation of a particular app. Once the app is installed on a phone or tablet
column17: revenue becomes infinitely easier to extract from that user.It's not actually a new idea
column18: though it's not an old one either. The market for revenue-bearing app installations is only expected to reach $7 billion by 2020. But
column19: it's a model that plays right into the hand Snap is holding with Snapchat. Whereas users know they can always download an app they found via Facebook or Google
column20: the fleeting nature of Snapchat's messages often makes an app installation a 'now or never' proposition. Out of fear
column21: those consumers often choose 'now.'The Downside of More Efficient BiddingThere are two sides to every coin
column22: of course
column23: and the downside for SNAP stock owners is simply that the more efficient and granulated web advertising becomes
column24: the cheaper it becomes (on a per-click or per-impression basis) for the advertiser
column25: and the less lucrative it becomes for the middleman. Performance-based ad revenue will only exacerbate this trend.One only has to look at the recent results from Alphabet's Google to recognize the adverse undertow. The company's ""aggregate cost-per-click""fell 11% last yearandthe year before
column26: aligning with the premise that advertisers are getting even pickier about their spending as they glean more specific data about users simply because they can.It's in stark contrast to the early days of the web
column27: when advertisers would pay a steep price for placement on high-traffic sites and then hope for the best.One could point out that Snapchat will limit its advertising of a specific app to only the users most likely to install a third-party app
column28: and then cash in big-time when that individual hits the 'install now' button. In the aggregate though
column29: it remains to be seen if the highly narrowed revenue path leads to more revenue
column30: or less. Remember
column31: up until this point
column32: better-targeted web advertising has lowered its overall cost as publishers/venues become more competitive and ad inventory becomes more of a commodity.Bottom Line for SNAP StockKudos to Snap for having the foresight and guts to make this kind of commitment to its advertisers. Although the messaging platform will continue to take a small cut every time an ad is displayed
column33: one has to presume the big payouts will only come when users install an app â€¦ something most of them (perhaps all) will never actually do.Advanced Micro Devices
column34: Inc. (AMD) Stock Plunges on Goldman ""Sell""From that perspective
column35: advertisers will have to love the low-risk/low-cost approach to promoting themselves.As for SNAP stock holders though
column36: goal-based bidding still isn't enough to suggest the company is going to grow into its lofty valuation anytime soon. One has to presume that at least Facebook if not Alphabet's Google will counter with something similar
column37: deflating Snapchat's advantage and sustaining the downward pressure on internet advertising prices.As of this writing
column38: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Under-the-Radar Stocks to Buy Now for Explosive UpsideThe 7 Best Stocks to Buy for an Income-Rich RetirementCisco Systems

column1: Twitter Lite: Twitter Inc (TWTR) Debuts Leaner Version of Service;4/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) is launching a new version of its social media platform called Twitter Lite.makeArticleAd();Twitter Lite is a leaner version of the social media service for customers with poor wireless connections. The service still includes all of the main features of Twitter
column3: such as Tweets
column4: Direct Messages
column5: Trends and more
column6: but handles it with less data.Another major advantage of Twitter Lite is that it doesn't take up much room on a mobile device. The new service isn't actually an app to download
column7: but is a special version of the company's website for mobile browsers. This means it will only take up about 1MB of space on a mobile device.This means that Twitter users that are hoping to use Twitter Lite will need a web browser on their mobile devices
column8: which shouldn't be a problem. The new way to access Twitter is available for tablets and smartphones. Computer users can also choose to use it if they are looking for a version of the service that looks a little cleaner.Twitter Lite also hasa new data saver mode. Selecting this option will blur images and videos so that they don't automatically load. Users can tap on Tweets with videos and images to see the media. The social media company estimates that this will help reduce data consumption by as much as 70%.10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotTwitter Lite also has special features when used with modern versions ofAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column9: GOOGL) mobile Chrome browser. This includes sending push notifications to users throughout the day to keep them up to date with what is happening on Twitter.TWTR stock was down slightly as of Thursday afternoon.More From InvestorPlace9 Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9 a ShareThe 7 Best Low-Risk Healthcare Stocks to Buy10 Small-Cap Stocks That Could Double in the Next 3 MonthsThe postTwitter Lite: Twitter Inc (TWTR) Debuts Leaner Version of Serviceappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Trade SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) for Free Profits;4/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe stock market had been on fire since February 2016. Even after this dip theSPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust(NYSEARCA:SPY) is still more than 20% higher than the February low. Equity markets as a whole have been behaving like momentum stocks (a.k.a. MOMOs).makeArticleAd();When MOMOs are rallying
column3: they are so hot that they seem perpetually over-valued
column4: thereby keeping most investors out. Conversely
column5: when they are falling
column6: they seem like falling machetes too scary to catch.So how do I invest in something this erratic? The bullish thesis was for the most part built upon hopes for fiscal spending promised to us by President Donald Trump. Investors quickly priced in the perfect scenario. From here it's a matter of chipping away at that perfect statue.Click to EnlargeI take a balanced approach. I don't short the bullish thesis with full force and I have to be cautious on both ends. Here is an example of aSPY ETF write that delivered over 20%on money risked.Yes
column7: theS&P 500is near all-time highs but individual companies likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) orAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG

column10: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) are two that come to mind.How to Trade the SPYThe Bullish Side:Sell the SPY Sep $210/$205 credit put spread for 60 cents per contract. This trade has a 90% theoretical chance of success. I need SPY to close above my spread in mid-September to win.Usually I like to balance my trades by selling opposing risk. But I have to still respect the so-called 'animal spirit' in the current equity markets.The Bearish Side:Sell the SPY Sep $250/$255 credit call spread for 75 cents per contract. This spread has a 75% theoretical chance of success. This is tighter than my usual comfort starting zone but makes sense near all-time highs.Taking both trades
column11: I would have sold an iron condor with +6% and -10% moves from here. This pair trade would yield over 30% it both spreads expire worthless for maximum gains. I could book partial gains or losses in either spread at any time if I want.Learn options as easy as 1-2-3here. Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing

column1: Here's How Snap is Beefing Up Its Advertising Model;4/6/2017;"It's pretty clear now of the full-fledged rivalry between Snap Inc.SNAPand Facebook Inc.FB. Where one just recently made its market debut
column2: and brought with it an immense
column3: dedicated following
column4: the other was committed to stealing its best ideas over the years.This competition likely began in earnest when Snap's co-founder and CEO
column5: Evan Spiegel
column6: turned down Facebook's $3 billion acquisition offer back in 2013
column7: and since then
column8: the tech giant has incorporated almost exact replicas of parts of its app
column9: Snapchat
column10: on Instagram
column11: Whatsapp
column12: Messenger
column13: and now its home Facebook app.Despite Facebook's numerous efforts
column14: Snapchat is incredibly popular
column15: especially among younger users
column16: and at this point
column17: the only way to get a leg up on its biggest rival is through advertising.Over the past few weeks
column18: Snap has been beefing up its core advertising model
column19: and if you take a step back
column20: this could be seen as a move aimed directly at Facebook. At the end of March
column21: the company launcheda new search functionthat lets all the content created by its 158 million users much more accessible. Dubbed ""Stories in Search
column22: the feature allows users to search through Stories that are shared through the public.""We've built a new way to understand what's happening in Snaps that are submitted to Our Story
column23: and to create new Stories using advanced machine learning. The results have been amazing: you can search over 1 million unique Stories on Snapchat
column24: Snap wrote in a blog post.""Stories in Search"" has the potential to increase engagement
column25: and in turn
column26: monetization. While there was no direct mention of advertising
column27: this clearly opens up a whole new way for Snap to make money through advertising. Like in GoogleGOOGL
column28: TwitterTWTR
column29: and even Facebook
column30: providing users a search functionality gives valuable information to help target ads.In addition to a search function
column31: Snap is rolling out two new methods of ad targeting. According toBusiness Insider
column32: advertisers on Snapchat will now have the ability to target users who are more likely to install the social media app than others. This is called ""goal-based bidding for app installed ads
column33: and these types of ads will ask users to swipe up on full-screen video ads that uses machine-learning technology developed by Snap.Advertisers can also target Snapchat users that have previously interacted with other ads they have ran in the app before. For instance
column34: if an advertiser purchases one of Snapchat's Lenses
column35: the app's pricier selfie filters
column36: for a campaign
column37: they can later target those same users again with other types of ads.These new types of advertising will be crucial for Snap going forward
column38: both because of its ongoing rivalry with Facebook and because ad dollars are the main source of revenue for the company. Since its IPO
column39: analysts and investors have wondered how Snap plans to make money-as of now
column40: it's still unprofitable-and innovating its advertising model is a key step to improving its bottom line.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking   About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Will Alphabet (GOOG
column2: GOOGL) Ever Pay a Dividend?;4/6/2017;"Ultimately the primary task of a corporation is to make money
column3: and eventually to share that money among its shareholders. To this point Alphabet (GOOG
column4: GOOGL) has been incredibly successful in almost everything they've done except this. In other words
column5: it is legitimate for investors to ask if and when Alphabet will distribute profits in the form of a dividend.Letâ€™s face it
column6: if there was ever a company that could afford to pay a dividend to shareholders
column7: it is Alphabet. The company is a giant cash machine
column8: with a market cap of over $580 billion
column9: revenues of over $90 billion
column10: operating cash flow of around $36 billion and with well over $86 billion of cash on hand.It is not a question of being able to pay a dividend
column11: it is simply a question of not wanting to. That attitude was common among tech successes of the internet age
column12: but most have subsequently given in to shareholder pressure and initiated dividend payments.makeArticleAd();Even Apple (AAPL)
column13: whose founder Steve Jobs was famously opposed to the idea of the company paying a dividend did so
column14: although admittedly only after his death. Microsoft (MSFT) and others gave in much earlier. Essentially at some point it is possible for any company to amass what is in effect an â€œembarrassment of richesâ€ and be almost forced into returning some money to shareholders.There are two main ways for companies to do that
column15: by paying a dividend or by buying back stock. So far
column16: Alphabet has relied on buybacks and
column17: as the three year chart below shows
column18: long term stockholders have had little reason to complain.In the opinion of some shareholders
column19: Alphabet is too involved in â€œmoon shotâ€ projects through its â€œGoogle Xâ€ division that oversees the investment into things like driverless cars and even teleportation and a space elevator. The veil of secrecy that has covered Google X since its inception was lifted somewhat last year
column20: whenit was revealedthat the venture was costing around $3.5 billion per year.That is less than ten percent of annual cash flow
column21: but to shareholders looking for a dividend
column22: it is wasted money.The other use for the cash
column23: M&A
column24: is less controversial in many ways. Buying companies like Nest to diversify away from the core search business is likely to show a quicker return and ultimately contribute to growth. Those calling for a dividend
column25: though
column26: would rightly point out that given the huge cash flow of the company an aggressive M&A program and a dividend are not mutually exclusive.The problem though is that the original owners of Google
column27: including founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin
column28: are not really answerable to other shareholders. When the company was restructured into Alphabet
column29: the share classes were also changed
column30: with a new class of powerful voting shares going to those original owners. That gives them permanent power to override other shareholders
column31: so the kind of institutional investor pressure that forced Apple to start paying a dividend cannot be a factor at Alphabet.If Alphabet is to ever pay a dividend
column32: therefore
column33: it would have to make sense to Page
column34: Brin and others with the original Google vision as their driving force. Their opposition to the idea remains intact for now
column35: so something would have to change for that to happen.One possible catalyst could be if President Trump does offer an amnesty window for the repatriation of overseas profits as he has indicated he will
column36: as Alphabet holds a lot of money overseas and tax considerations play are partly involved in the decision not to pay a dividend.The fact is that as long as Alphabet keeps growing revenue and expanding into ever more areas of business
column37: a dividend payment is not just unlikely but also
column38: for most investors
column39: unnecessary. Profits continue to grow and the stock continues to climb and until that situation changes
column40: it is hard to argue that sending money out of the company is a better use for it than where it is currently invested.At some point Alphabet might pay a dividend
column41: but for now
column42: donâ€™t hold your breath."

column24: but also allows for three simultaneous streams per household. Another distinct advantage could be with YouTubeâ€™s channel offerings
column25: which includes CBS (CBS) â€” the top-rated network on television. CBS is not available on either DirecTV Now or Sling TV.Likewise
column26: YouTube TV will soon offer AMC networks (AMCX) â€” home to top-rated shows such asThe Walking DeadandBetter Call Saul. For consumers who insists on having more choices without being held ransom to bloated channels they pay for (but don't watch)
column27: YouTube TV could be a viable option. And for those who crave technology with their TV-watching experience
column28: Googleâ€™s massive cloud storage feature and the ability to stream shows across multiple devices will be tough to match
column29: especially with Android dominating the smartphone OS market with a 90% share.Meanwhile
column30: the likes of Charter Communications (CHTR)
column31: which recently merged with Time Warner and other cable/satellite TV providers such as Comcast
column32: Dish Network and DirecTV should be terrified. With YouTube already boasting more than 1 billion users worldwide
column33: which amounts to about one-third of all internet users
column34: it was already a force to be reckoned with. And YouTube TV is just the horror scenario they expected
column35: but canâ€™t turn off."

column1: 3 Top Autonomous Car Companies to Buy in 2017;4/5/2017;"When it comes to developing self-driving cars
column2: who are the top   automakers? And which of those have stocks worth buying?Navigant Research recently attempted to answer the first   question. In a newreport
column3: the research firm examined ""the strategy and execution of 18   leading companies developing automated driving systems"" and   ranked the contenders by relative strengths and weaknesses.I think there are reasons to quibble with Navigant's   assessment -- specifically
column4: I think it underweighted companies   that might have good technology but that don't actually build   vehicles at scale right now. But its ranking of automakers is   probably pretty sound
column5: and in its top tier of ""Leaders
column6: there   are three that pay nice dividends and could be good buys   right now:Ford Motor Company(NYSE: F)
column7: General Motors(NYSE: GM)
column8: andDaimler(NASDAQOTH: DDAIF) .makeArticleAd();Ford was one of the first automakers to test self-driving     vehicles in winter conditions. Image source: Ford Motor     Company.FordFord is an intriguing buy right now forseveral reasons
column9: andself-driving is certainly one. The Blue Oval's autonomous-vehicle development effort took a   huge step forward in February with the creation of aFord-funded start-up called Argo AI.Simply put
column10: Argo AI is vehicle that will help Ford hire and   retain the best available software talent in what has become a   fiercely competitive market for the services of top engineers.   Argo's structure gives its employees the opportunities and equity   upside of a start-up with the assurance of an auto giant's   financial backing. (Ford gets dibs on its product
column11: of course --   but it might be offered for sale to other automakers.)Argo AI was co-founded by big-name veterans of self-driving   research programs atAlphabet's Waymo unit and Uber Technologies -- and funded to the tune of   $1 billion by Ford
column12: which is folding its existing self-driving   software team into the new company.Ford hasn't said a lot about its plans on the hardware side.   We do know it plans to begin mass-producing aLevel 4 self-driving vehicle for commercial   useby 2021. Ford also seems to be laying the groundwork for an   integrated ""mobility"" offering of its own that could include   Ford-branded ride-haling and car-sharing services
column13: summoned via a   smartphone app calledFordPass.Meanwhile
column14: Ford's stock is trading at just 6.5 times its 2016   earnings (net of special items)
column15: and itsvery sustainable dividendis yielding a fat 5.2%. It may take a few years for Ford's   self-driving investments to show in the bottom line
column16: but they   could generate good growth in time.General MotorsLike old rival Ford
column17: GM's stock is cheap at 5.7 times its 2016   earnings
column18: and it's paying a solid (and again
column19: sustainable) dividend yielding 4.4%.Also like Ford
column20: GM is emerging as a self-driving leader. In   fact
column21: GM may well be ahead: Under CEO Mary Barra
column22: GM tends to let   its products do the talking -- or put another way
column23: GM keeps its   future plans under wraps to a greater extent than many   rivals.But we know a few things:GM owns9% of ride-hailing company Lyft.GM last year bought self-driving start-up Cruise Automation     and made Cruise the center of its self-driving software     effort.GM is building out its OnStar network to serve connected     vehicles with high bandwidth.GM started anurban car-sharing servicecalled Maven early last year
column24: and it's growing quickly.We know one other thing: GM is shipping an innovative electric   car
column25: the Chevy Bolt
column26: which is designed to be a ""platform"" (GM's   term) for developing connected-vehicle and self-driving   technologies and bringing them to market. The Bolt is also
column27: by   design
column28: very well-suited for urban ride-hailing and car-sharing   duties.See the picture that's emerging? Here's a hint.GM CEO Mary Barra with a Chevy Bolt EV from GM's     self-driving test fleet. Image source: General Motors.Reportedly
column29: GM will soon -- as in
column30: within the next few months   -- build ""thousands"" of Bolts withprototype Level 4 self-driving systemsfor an extensive multicity test with Lyft. The data harvested   from that effort -- and the fact that the Bolt is already in mass   production today
column31: and the self-driving prototypes will be   built on the Bolt's regular assembly line -- could put GM at the   forefront of the early commercialization of self-driving   technology
column32: with obvious (good) implications for the General's   bottom line.DaimlerDaimler is mostly known to American investors as the owner of   the Mercedes-Benz brand. Less well-known is that it's also a   major player in heavy trucks and buses
column33: with several brands   including Freightliner
column34: Western Star
column35: Thomas Built
column36: and Setra
column37: along with Mercedes-Benz's own commercial-van and medium and   heavy truck lines.That gives it at least two separate and intriguing ways to   bring its self-driving technology to market. Daimler already has   an agreement with Lyft's larger rival
column38: Uber Technologies
column39: to   supply self-driving vehicles in a few years. It's known to be   working with Uber
column40: giantauto supplier Bosch
column41: NVIDIA
column42: and other big names to finish and commercialize a Level 4   systemover the next couple of years.That system won't just go in cars for Uber duty
column43: though. It'll   almost certainly be offered as a luxury option on Mercedes-Benz   vehicles -- and it'll definitely have a place in Daimler's big   trucks.This photo
column44: taken during a demonstration on the Autobahn last   year
column45: nicely sums up one of Daimler's big opportunities.Image source: Daimler AG.The three trucks are traveling in an automated convoy
column46: led by   the first truck -- which
column47: as you can see from the position of the   driver's hands
column48: is driving itself. I'm sure you can also see the   huge commercial implications.Right now
column49: Daimler is trading at about 8.4 times its 2016   earnings per share (7.97 euros). That's not as cheap as Ford or   GM
column50: but it's still fairly inexpensive for a company that   generates much of its revenue from luxury products. It's also   cheap enough that Daimler's generous dividend (3.25 euros) means   a 4.8% dividend yield.Again
column51: you'll have to wait a while for the benefits of this   technology to accrue to Daimler's bottom line. But as with Ford   and GM
column52: you'll get paid to wait -- and you might be quite happy   with the result in several years.10 stocks we like better than FordWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column53: it can pay to listen. After all
column54: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column56: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Ford wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column1: GoPro Inc: Bulls Need a Reality Check;4/5/2017;"In less than three years
column2: GoPro(NASDAQ: GPRO) went from being one of the hottest stocks on Wall   Street to being one of the most hated. GoPro surged from its IPO   price of $24 to nearly $90 in late 2014
column3: but plummeted to the   single digits as demand for its action cameras cooled. Many   investors clearly believe that further downside is ahead
column4: with    32% of shares still being shorted as of March 24.But whenever a stock falls so much
column5: contrarian bulls emerge.   GoProrallied stronglylast month after it announced a third round of layoffs. Citi   analysts subsequently upgraded the stock from  Sell to   Neutral
column6: noting that its revenue growth would likely stabilize
column7: it would reach its non-GAAP profitability targets
column8: and that it   probably wouldn't need to access its credit facility to stay   afloat. That upgrade likely convinced some bulls that the stock   was finally bottoming.GoPro's Karma drone. Image source: GoPro.makeArticleAd();But here's my message to those hopeful investors: it's time   for a reality check. GoPro's track record of broken promises and   its lack of compelling new products indicate that the bears are   probably still right about this beaten-down stock.Why GoPro crashed in the first placeGoPro's crash is often attributed to competition in the action   camera market
column9: the overall saturation of that market
column10: and the   longevity of existing devices making upgrades unnecessary for   most users. Meanwhile
column11: improving smartphone cameras made carrying   around a separate action camera -- especially one that cost as   much as a mid-range phone -- seem pointless for mainstream   users.However
column12: GoPro's decline was also exacerbated by blatant   exaggerations. When GoPro went public
column13: it declared that it could   become a ""media company
column14: but thoseplans collapsedlast year and it laid off most of the division
column15: which   included costly hires from other tech and media companies. GoPro   also repeatedly promoted virtual reality as its next growth   market
column16: even though the only VR products it offered were two   expensive multi-camera rigs (the $5
column17: 000 Omni and $15
column18: 000 Odyssey)   which cost thousands of dollars.GoPro's Odyssey (L) and Omni (R) VR rigs. Image source:     GoPro.Those devices were so expensive thatAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google -- which co-developed the   Odyssey with GoPro -- opened up YouTube's VR/360 channels to   cheaper camera makers like Yi Technology
column19: Ricoh
column20: and 360fly.   GoPro responded to that move by launching its own VR app and   site
column21: GoPro VR
column22: but that effort reached far fewer viewers than   its YouTube channel. CEO Nick Woodman also  vaguely hinted   at the development of a stand-alone 360-camera over the    past year
column23: but that device probably won't arrive anytime   soon.GoPro's management blunders are also easy to see. The company   priced the Hero 4 Session too high in 2015
column24: then took big   writedowns by repricing ittwice. It wasted nearly $36 millionbuying backits own shares before they were cut in half. It botched the   launch of the Karma drone
column25: its most eagerly anticipated product   of 2016
column26: with a humiliating recall. It continues developing all   of its new products -- drones
column27: handheld stabilizers
column28: and VR rigs   -- asaccessoriesfor selling more action cameras
column29: instead ofexpandinginto brand new product categories.Why the bulls think GoPro can recoverAfter all those missteps
column30: the bulls basically believe that   three rounds of layoffs -- which downsized its media and VR units   while reducing its headcount from 1
column31: 500 to 930 -- will stabilize   GoPro's business and help it achieve non-GAAP profitability   again. They probably also believe that GoPro's low EV/sales ratio   of 0.8 and its clean balance sheet will limit its downside   potential and make it a lucrative buyout target.Unfortunately
column32: downsizing in the face of rising competition   will likely reduce GoPro's brand presence
column33: throttle innovation
column34: and lead to more quality control issues like the Karma disaster.   GoPro also hasn't offered any viable solutions to counter the   competition in action cameras
column35: drones
column36: or smartphones
column37: and it's   been slow to respond to new product categories like stand-alone   360-degree cameras andaugmented reality glasses. Wall Street believes that  GoPro's revenue will rise 7%   this year and 2% to $1.3 billion next year -- but that will still   be well below the $1.62 billion in revenue it generated in   2015.If a bigger company wanted to buy GoPro
column38: which has an   enterprise value of less than $1 billion
column39: it also would have   likely made a move by now. Yet no serious reports about buyouts   ever surfaced
column40: indicating that it's simply cheaper for bigger   companies likeGarminto develop in-house action cameras instead of inheriting   all of GoPro's problems.Why a reality check is in orderI owned GoPro stock before
column41: and Ionce believedin the company's promises of expanding its brand into a media   ecosystem and growing in adjacent markets. But then the hard   truth set in -- the company was a one-trick pony without a moat
column42: and the management repeatedly failed to launch products on time   or even price them correctly. These failures indicate that while   layoffs might slow GoPro's decline this year
column43: they won't likely   help the stock rebound.10 stocks we like better than GoProWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and GoPro wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column1: Did Amazon Score a Touchdown with Its $50 Million NFL Deal?;4/5/2017;"Amazon.com
column2: Inc.AMZNjust paid $50 million to stream 10 NFL games during the upcoming 2017 season. The internet giant's move into live sports coverage has grabbed headlines
column3: but does it mean that internet power players are set to take a bite out of television's last big cash cow?The NFL agreed to a one-year deal with Amazon valued at around $50 million that will see the online retail giant live stream 10 ""Thursday Night Football"" games for its Amazon Prime members. Amazon will not have exclusive rights to these 10 games
column4: as the NFL's big television partners
column5: CBS
column6: NBC and its own NFL Network
column7: will split up coverage of the same 10 games for the traditional broadcast and cable television audience.Amazon outbid other giants such as Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle
column8: Twitter Inc.TWTR
column9: and Facebook
column10: Inc.FBfor the 10-game NFL streaming package.Amazon's stock was up 0.27% to $909.28 per share Wednesday. Amazon is currently a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).An estimated 60 million households use Amazon Prime. The membership includes the popular shipping incentives
column11: but it also includes Amazon's ever-growing music
column12: movies and TV offerings.Even as Amazon continues to expand its core business and grow its artificial intelligence and cloud computing sectors
column13: the company seems poised to keep pushing heavily into the media content business. Amazon already produces its own original television programming
column14: which includes the Emmy Award-winningTransparent. Amazon also recently put Hollywood on notice whenManchester by the Seatook home two Oscars.The Seattle-based company wants to give its Prime members not only more choices
column15: but also more reasons to keep paying the $99 annual fee that includes free two-day shipping
column16: as well as other services. ""We're focused on bringing our customers what they want to watch
column17: Prime members want the NFL
column18: Amazon Senior Vice President Jeff Blackburn told theWall Street Journal.The Thursday night NFL deal represents a win for Amazon over some of its rivals
column19: but does the small one-year
column20: $50 million deal truly matter to a company that has shook up the retail industry for good and is now set to take on global shipping giants?In short: Yes
column21: it really does. Amazon is just starting its long-term game to eventually become a live sports content power. This move has the potential to change TV forever.Now let's take a look at the big picture to get a better understanding of what Amazon hopes to do with its new NFL deal.2017 ImpactLast year
column22: Twitter broke into the NFL with its ""Thursday Night Football"" deal. Twitter's $10 million deal represented a step forward in the fight between non-traditional media companies and legacy media outlets to control live content.In 2015
column23: Yahoo! Inc.YHOOpaid $17 millionto live stream NFL games in London. Yahoo's live stream
column24: which played automatically on its homepage
column25: reached an estimated15.2 million people. However
column26: the average viewership per minute was only 2.36 million.Twitter's foray into the NFL last year was even less successful. The average Twitter viewership for the 10 Thursday night games at any givenminute was 266
column28: compared to 15.8 million for the same games on broadcast and cable television.So if the numbers aren't that great
column29: why did Jeff Bezos' company pay $40 million more than Twitter did last year for its new NFL streaming deal? Paying $50 million for roughly 30 hours of coverage isn't crazy for a company with a market cap of $439 billion. Still
column30: the answer is even more straightforward: Amazon is now in the live content business.The two deals are almost identical in terms of content and overall coverage hours. But Twitter streamed its NFL games for free. Amazon's users have to pay the $99 per year Amazon Prime fee in order to watch the ""Thursday Night Football"" games.But it's not about making money now
column31: it's about offering more content. Movies
column32: TV and now live sports will make Prime a long-term power in the content business as cable television's viability declines further every day.The NFL deal allows Amazon to offer a historic American product
column33: and with that comes more creditability in the content world.Amazon doesn't necessarily see its new NFL deal as a money making move now
column34: although it could end up profiting from the partnership by pushing NFL merchandise. But every company needs to have a proof of concept before it can really go to market and make it big.Amazon is simply testing the live sporting waters in 2017 for a very small fee
column35: and its first test subject isn't a random league or game
column36: it is the National Football League. Bezos and Amazon are investing in the future
column37: and the future is live sports streaming on televisions
column38: phones and tablets around the U.S. and the world.When Will The Future of Sports Arrive?Americans pay massive monthly cable fees in order to access hundreds of channels. However
column39: most people only watch a few of the channels they pay for.According to Nielsen
column41: the average cable package provided 189 channels
column42: but people watched an average of only 17.5 channels.This has helped lead to a cord-cutting revolution. The array of content that Netflix Inc.NFLX
column43: HULU and Amazon offer have helped lure the mostly-millennial audiences to leave cable television behind.Amazon has already looked into live rights for the NBA
column44: soccer
column45: surfing and Indian Premier League cricket. The NFL marks a giant win on a small scale. If Amazon can prove the viability of its NFL streaming
column46: then other leagues and live sporting events could soon join the party.The NFL and Amazon already have a working relationship. In 2016
column47: Amazon debuted its NFL Films-produced behind-the-scenes series ""All or Nothing
column48: which documented the Arizona Cardinals' entire 2015 season over eight roughly 50-minute episodes. Season two
column49: which will feature the Rams' first season back in Los Angeles in 2016
column50: was just announced.But none of the video on demand power players have ever really owned live sports rights until now. Some of the NFL's current TV rights deals will expire in less than a decade. Once the streaming services own live sports rights
column51: television
column52: as we know it
column53: will be changed forever.OvertimeAmazon has to wait 15 years before it can try to win rights to the Olympics or NCAA March Madness
column54: which are both tied up through 2032. However
column55: look for Amazon to potentially bid on both the English Premier League and Major League Soccer in five years when the current TV deals expire. The global and youthful appeal of soccer could officially kick-off the live streaming sports era.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking About?makeArticleAd();Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Uber Admits to Finding Allegedly Stolen Waymo File;4/5/2017;"The ongoing legal dispute between Alphabet Inc.GOOGLand Uber just took an interesting turn. The ride-sharing company admitted in court Wednesday that it found one of the documents that Waymo-formerly the Google self-driving car project-claims was stolen by a former employee.According to a new report fromTechCrunch
column2: Uber's attorney revealed that the company found one of the allegedly stolen documents on a personal device belonging to Sameer Kshirsagar
column3: one of the three people that Waymo has accused of stealing its trade secrets.Kshirsagar is accused of stealing several key documents before he left Waymo to join Uber
column4: but Alphabet's primary complaint surrounds Anthony Levandowski
column5: a former member of Google's self-driving car team that left the project to found autonomous trucking company Otto (also read:Alphabet Suing Uber Over Self-Driving Car Technology).Otto was launched in May
column6: 2016 and acquired by Uber just two months later.Levandowski is accused of downloading a whopping 14
column7: 000 confidential files
column8: including Waymo's LiDAR circuit board designs
column9: to an external disk drive using specialized software. In an effort to cover his track
column10: Levandowski allegedly download a new OS to his company laptop in order to delete information.Alphabet was first alerted to the potential theft when an Uber supplier inadvertently copied a Google executive in an email titled ""Otto files."" The message was being sent to people that at Uber that Google thinks were working on self-driving technology.Uber has reportedly many of its employees' devices
column11: and the company maintains that none of the allegedly stolen files ever made it to Uber. It's important to note that today's revelation only points toonedocument on apersonaldevice
column12: which is a far cry from thousands of documents circulating around between Uber employees.Nevertheless
column13: the battle between Waymo and Uber will rage on for the time being. For Uber
column14: the case is just another item on the growing list of controversies andcompetitionthat could threaten its future

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 May Be Delayed Until November;4/5/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEveryone is expectingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) to release its 10th anniversary iPhone 8 in September. Consumers
column3: wireless providers
column4: retailers and AAPL investors. Apple's new ultra-premium flagship is going to be a big deal and September is the month when new iPhones are typically launched. However
column5: there may be a problem with that timeline. A new report out today says the advanced technology Apple is using is causing manufacturing problems in the supply chain.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleAs a result
column6: the company may be forced to move the iPhone 8 launch to October or even November.The iPhone 8 is Expected to Incorporate New TechnologyApple has been making a big deal about 2017 being the 10th anniversary of the iPhone. While the company is expected to release an iPhone 7s - the usual spec bumped version of last year's model - it is also hard at work on the iPhone 8. This would be an ultra-premium smartphone positioned above the iPhone 7.The technology Apple is packing in this 10th anniversary edition is rumored to include curved OLED panels - an Apple first
column7: although they have been used by rivalSamsung(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) for several years.The new iPhone is also expected to pack arevolutionary 3D FaceTime camera
column8: which could be a key component of AAPL's augmented reality plans. These new features are a big part of the reason whyApple could be charging $1
column9: 000 or morefor its 10th anniversary iPhone.7 Tech Stocks That Will Crush the Market for YearsUnfortunately
column10: they're also causing some problems that could result in an iPhone 8 delay
column11: at least according toDigiTimes
column12: the Chinese website that tracks Apple and its supply chain.Manufacturing Challenges Could Derail iPhone 8 LaunchThis morning
column13: DigiTimesbroke the news on the potential setback.""Technical issues related to the lamination process of curved OLED panels
column14: and the adoption of a 3D sensing system may cause the delay of the new iPhone devices.""Manufacturing delays related to incorporation of advanced new technology have derailed launch plans for several high-tech companies lately.GoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO)faced a shortageof its new Hero5 Black action camera going into the holiday season because of a manufacturing problem.Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) also stumbled going into the holidays when manufacturing issues meant it wasunable to ramp up volume productionon its new Flex 2 fitness tracker. Apple itself ran into production glitches that causedshortages of the iPhone 5at launch.Potential Impact on the iPhone 8 LaunchApple is looking for September to be a monster month and if the iPhone 8 launched gets delayed until October or even November
column15: as theDigiTimesreport suggests
column16: that's going to throw a serious wrench in the company's plans.MacRumorssuggests several scenarios. AAPL may still go ahead with the usual September iPhone event
column17: but use that to showcase the iPhone 7s and 7s Plus
column18: holding a separate iPhone 8 launch later in the year. Or
column19: it may launch the iPhone 7s in September
column20: but also announce the iPhone 8 - with a later release date.Why Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) Stock Won't Stay DownThere's also a possibility that the company may be able to eke out enough iPhone 8 production to go ahead with the September launch
column21: but with very limited iPhone 8 quantities until later in the year.Regardless of the scenario
column22: it's continuing to look like AAPL is not going to entirely get its way with the iPhone 8 launch. The hype will be there and undoubtedly there will be line-ups of people ready to fork out $1000-plus for a new iPhone. The question is
column23: will Apple be able to get an iPhone 8 to them before they get tired of waiting and a buy an iPhone 7s - or worse
column24: one of the competition's new phones - instead?As of this writing

column1: Tech Roundup: YouTube Ad Fiasco
column2: Palmer Luckey Leaves FB;4/4/2017;"The top news from last week included Alphabet'sGOOGLYouTube running into serious trouble with advertisers and Oculus founder Palmer Luckey leaving FacebookFB.Here are the details-The YouTube Ad ControversyYouTube will host its Brandcast event on May 4
column3: a marketing event at which it shares success stories while helping brands reach their targeted audiences. So any controversy at this time is bad for YouTube
column4: because it can be used by brands to negotiate advantageous deals for themselves. And that's exactly what seems to be happening...A couple of weeks back
column5: the UK government discovered that its ads were appearing next to inappropriate content and between then and now
column6: around 250 companies operating in the UK including L'Oreal and McDonald's withdrew their UK ads from the platform. Although Google apologized and made changes to its ad platform giving more control to advertisers
column7: big Fortune 500 companies like Pepsi
column8: Starbucks
column9: General Motors
column10: Wal-Mart
column11: J&J
column12: JPMorgan Chase
column13: Ford
column14: AT&T and Verizon pulled their U.S. ads. Analysts currently estimate that the revenue hit could be anywhere between $750 million to a billion dollars.The main problem according to Moody's is the extremely high volumes (400 hours of video are uploaded to YouTube every minute) that make it very difficult to police the content. But because ads placed alongside content that doesn't correspond to the brand's positioning hurts the brand
column15: Moody's thinks it's an objection well taken and would be credit negative.However
column16: the agency says that these brands contribute relatively fewer dollars than the vast majority of YouTube advertisers that continue to spend on the platform and the pullback is in any case temporary because of measures taken by Google. Also
column17: while Google's fix will increase costs related to investments in personnel
column18: A.I. and machine learning to facilitate review of material being uploaded
column19: this won't be so significant as to warrant a change in the current Aa2 investment rating.Bottom line: There are only two really big digital ad-serving platforms (Facebook and YouTube) that draw a very large number of users and it's advantageous for brands to be on both of them. Moreover
column20: the controversy is an industrywide phenomenon with the problem not restricted to YouTube.So while YouTube can't take too hard a stand when negotiating with brands
column21: it may not get pushed into a corner either; more so because it can also point to Google Preferred to access the top 5% content on YouTube (at a premium of course). The bottom line impact will likely also be insignificant because Google is anyway investing in artificial intelligence and machine learning to improve and enhance its algorithms and search results.Palmer Luckey Leaves FacebookOculus co-founder Palmer Luckey is leaving Facebook and it isn't clear whether it was his own decision. But the young face of virtual reality (VR) has been keeping a low profile over the past few months
column22: as a number of things hit his public image. The first was a lawsuit by ZeniMax that Oculus had misappropriated trade secrets while Luckey had violated a non-disclosure agreement.The jury ruled that there was no misappropriation
column23: but Luckey and co-founder Iribe were asked to pay $500 million for the violation of the non-disclosure agreement. To make matters worse
column24: Luckey had invested $10
column25: 000 in Nimble America
column26: which some people consider a far right organization. A story by The Daily Beast reporters Gideon Resnick and Ben Collins said that Luckey had written unflattering posts/memes on Hillary Clinton
column27: which apparently led some women to resign from the company.Facebook said
column28: ""Palmer will be dearly missed. Palmer's legacy extends far beyond Oculus. His inventive spirit helped kickstart the modern VR revolution and helped build an industry. We're thankful for everything he did for Oculus and VR
column29: and we wish him all the best.""TickerPrice Change Last WeekPrice Change Last QuarterPrice Change Last 6 MonthsAAPL+2.15%+24.03%+27.07%FB+1.21%+21.12%+10.41%GOOGL+1.52%+4.95%+6.00%MSFT+1.35%+4.13%+15.92%CSCO-0.82%+10.71%+8.67%AMZN+4.88%+16.60%+13.67%Other storiesCorporateIntel's New Strategy Officer: Aicha Evans

column32: Washington and Shenzen

The court held that the distinctions in design were clear to consumers and that Baili didn't have grounds to claim exclusivity in its designs. Apple said Baili was trying to pass off Apple's designs as its own. Baili's lawyer said the Chinese company would appeal the decision.Since this follows Tim Cook's visit to the country when he promised further investments

column47: the National Australia Bank
column48: and Bendigo and Adelaide Bank - to collectively bargain for inclusion in Apple Pay or access to Apple's NFC controller. Access would have allowed banks to create their own wallets on Apple devices without paying Apple thus increasing competition with Apple Pay
column49: but the ACCC thought that it would also impact competition between Apple and Google. Apple doesn't allow NFC access to any of its 3
column50: 500 banking partners in the 15 markets where Apple Pay is available.UK Wants WhatsApp Backdoor: U.K. Home Secretary Amber Rudd said that she will be meeting with companies like Google
column51: Facebook and Twitter because it was ""absurd to have a situation where terrorists are talking to each other on a formal platform and it can't be accessed."" And again
column52: ""We need to make sure that our intelligence services have the ability to get into situations like encrypted WhatsApp.""The comment followed a finding that Khalid Masood
column53: the terrorist in this case

column56: but can do little about it because no one

column60: it should also move the allegations of trade-secret theft and unfair competition against Uber into arbitration.The logic is that since both these are related to Levandowski they should be handled similarly. Arbitration proceedings are private and also have different rules related to evidence
column61: which could safeguard Uber's reputation. The company is willing to continue the patent infringement aspect of the case in court.Earlier

column63: a former colleague and close confidant of Levandowski's (the ex-Googler who has allegedly run off with Waymo self-driving technology and trade secrets to form self-driving trucking company Otto
column64: which was subsequently bought by Uber for $680 million).The lawsuit specifies the time at which Levandowski met Uber executives in Jan 2016

Waymo is now seeking an injunction to prevent Uber from using the technology in its self-driving vehicles and seeking damages for any proven infringements.New Technology/ProductsSamsung's New Devices and Services: At the Unpacked event in New York

column70: Ethernet
