column1: Will This Overlooked Cloud Stock Grow 60% by 2018?;4/1/2017;"Shares of cloud storage providerBox(NYSE: BOX) rallied 35% over the past 12 months
column2: but the stock   hovers just 18% above its IPO price of $14. That's because after   hitting $23 on its first trading day in Jan. 2015
column3: Box plunged   below $10 last February before gradually recovering to the   mid-teens.Despite that lackluster performance
column4: Drexel Hamilton analyst   Brian White recently reiterated his ""Buy"" rating on the stock and   his price target of $26 -- which  represents a near-60%   rally from its current price. White claims that Box looks cheap   with an EV/Sales ratio of 3.3 based on its calendar 2018 (fiscal   2019) expectations. Is that ""low"" valuation enough to justify   buying Box
column5: or should investors ignore this overlooked cloud   stock?Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();What are Box's key strengths?Box provides cloud storage and associated services to over   71
column6: 000 businesses
column7: including the majority of the Fortune 500   companies. Its major customers include industrial behemothGeneral Electricand  pharmaceutical giantAstraZeneca. That market presence is impressive
column8: since the cloud storage   market is filled with bigger players likeAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column9: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column10: andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) 's Google.Despite those challenges
column11: Box has posted double-digit sales   growth ever since its IPO. Its revenue rose  32% to $398.6   million in fiscal 2017
column12: and it expects another 25%-26% growth   this year. Much of that growth comes from the addition of new   customers
column13: the introduction of add-on cloud services (like   security and analytics) which boost its revenue per customer
column14: and   integration partnerships with companies like Microsoft
column15: Salesforce
column16: andIBM. Deferred revenue
column17: a key indicator of forward demand
column18: rose 30%   to $242 million at the end of fiscal 2017.What are Box's key weaknesses?Like many high-growth tech companies
column19: Box's robust revenue   growth doesn't trickle down to any profits. However
column20: its non-GAAP   loss narrowed from $1.16 per share in 2016 to $0.56. During that   period
column21: its GAAP loss narrowed from $1.67 to $1.19. That GAAP   loss was heavily weighed down by stock-based compensation   expenses
column22: which gobbled up 20% of Box's revenues during the   year.Wall Street expects Box to report non-GAAP losses this yearandnext year -- although those losses are expected to continue   narrowing. Box faces a dilemma which many cloud SaaS (software as   a service) companies face -- competition keeps price expectations   low
column23: but the cost of securing new customers and developing new   services remains high. We can clearly see that impact in its   operating margins:Source:YChartsThe ongoing cloud storage pricing war  between Amazon
column24: Microsoft
column25: and Google limits Box's ability to raise prices.   However
column26: all three companies can afford to use cloud storage   services as a loss leader to expand their ecosystems. Box has   neither the scale nor ecosystem to follow suit -- so it could   eventually lose customers to those tech giants' bundling   strategies.Box finished 2017 with a negative free cash flow (FCF) of   $24.8 million. That marked a big improvement from its negative   FCF of $116.3 million in 2016
column27: and Box achieved its first quarter   of positive free cash flow ($10.2 million) during the fourth   quarter. However
column28: Box isn't expected to achieve a full-year   positive FCF anytime soon
column29: and a negative FCF could prevent Box   from scaling up to widen its moat against bigger challengers.What do the valuations say?Drexel Hamilton's bullish view on Box is based on the notion   that an EV/Sales ratio of 3.3 is cheap for a company with its   growth figures. For example
column30: two other high-growth cloud service   stocks withcomparable sales growth--TwilioandVeeva-- have respective EV/Sales ratios of 4.6 and 8.2 based on   next year's projected revenues. It's also lower than the current   industry average of 4.8 for application software makers.Assuming that Box is ""fairly valued"" with an EV/Sales ratio   between Twilio and Veeva's
column31: it's certainlypossiblethat Box could rise to White's price target of $26. However
column32: what   bothers me about that estimate is that it's based on a long-range   forecast
column33: and a lot can change in the cloud storage industry   within two years. If Amazon
column34: Microsoft
column35: and Google continue   slashing prices and piling on more features
column36: Box could struggle   to retain its top customers.The key takeawayI think Box has solid sales growth
column37: and its growing list of   big enterprise customers indicate that it has a lot of staying   power. It also did a great job at adding more services and   partnerships
column38: narrowing its losses
column39: and achieving positive free   cash flow last quarter.However
column40: claiming Box can rise 60% based on next year's sales   estimates is a bit too optimistic. It's hard to tell how much   storage prices will fall over the following year
column41: and Box CEO   Aaron Levie even once admitted that  cloud storage would   likely be ""free and infinite"" in the future. Therefore
column42: investors   should temper their expectations for Box based on future   developments across the cloud market.10 stocks we like better than BoxWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The King of Beers Joins the Renewable Energy Bandwagon;4/1/2017;"As politicians and interest groups debate the future of   climate change policies and renewable energy mandates across the   country
column2: a big power in the world of energy is making its   strategy well-known. The business community has made a big   commitment to transform their businesses to renewable energy
column3: which is now driving wind and solar investment around the   world.The latest to make a 100% renewable electricity commitment isAnheuser-Busch InBev(NYSE: BUD)
column4: the world's biggest beer maker
column5: which said on   Monday that it will make the transition by 2025. Make no mistake
column6: AB-InBev isn't suddenly an environmentally focused company.   They're making an economic decision to buy renewable energy. It's   a trend the corporate world is taking very seriously.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();AB-InBev's renewable playBelow is the infographic AB-InBev used to announce its   renewable energy commitment. It highlights the move from 7%   renewable energy to 100% by 2025 and shines a light on Mexico as   a focus.Image source: AB-InBev.The Mexico announcement is interesting because the country   held two renewable energy auctions in 2016 that got very   favorable terms. A year ago
column7: bids were announced at 5.07 cents   per kilowatt-hour (kWh) of electricity and by October bids   averaged 3.35 cents per kWh for clean energy. This compares to   average retail electricity prices of about 12 cents per kWh
column8: so   renewable energy is very economical for big companies.And these projects will be completed by the end of the decade
column9: so the price AB-InBev will pay by 2025 will be lower than the   contracts signed in 2016. In total
column10: the announcement says some 6   terawatt-hours
column11: or around 3 gigawatts (GW) of solar
column12: will produce   energy for AB-InBev.Corporate America loves renewable energyAB-InBev isn't the first company to take interest in renewable   energy. In the U.S.
column13: Target(NYSE: TGT) andWal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) are the two biggest corporate solar users
column14: with 147.5   MW and 145.0 MW
column15: respectively
column16: according toSEIA's Solar Means Business 2016 report.Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) says it has been100% powered by renewable energy since 2014andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google says it willreach that level in 2017.Companies aren't just looking at renewable energy as a PR   move; they're looking at it as a way to save money. Target   and Wal-Mart are primarily installing solar directly on their   rooftops
column17: reducing electricity bills from the utility. And data   centers byApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column18: Microsoft
column19: and Alphabet are now installing   renewable energy nearby so they can use renewable energy   directly. Apple has co-located nearly 100 MW of solar at data   centers in North Carolina and Nevada with another 100 MW in   development. Microsoft recently signed a deal to buy energy from   237 MW of wind farms in Wyoming and Kansas to power a Wyoming   data center. Alphabet has invested $2.5 billion in renewable   energy projects to power its business. This is becoming big   business for wind and solar companies.Corporate buys are the new renewable driverFor over a decade
column20: renewable energy has been driven by   mandates and subsidies around the world
column21: and in many places
column22: it   still is today. But costs have come down so far that corporations   are now looking at it as a way to save money on their operations   long-term. And that'll only drive more wind and solar   installations as more companies join the renewable energy   bandwagon.10 stocks we like better than Anheuser-Busch InBev     NVWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Your Gut Feeling Is Right: Discovery Communications Is Crazy Cheap;3/31/2017;"It's not often that an investor has the opportunity to buy   shares in a fantastic business

column13: down from $103 million in FY 2015.""Discovering"" consistent returnsExceptional profitability is nothing new to Discovery   Communications. In fact

column18: the stock is valued by Mr. Market at just over 13   timesS&P Global Market Intelligence'sEPS estimates for FY 2017 of $2.17. What's more

column21: and the naturally high valuations that go along with such   a trend

column26: Alphabet

column14: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column15: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column16: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased

column1: Lululemon Athletica Inc. (LULU) Stock Shows the Ugly Side of Retail;3/31/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading Tips""I don't do retail
column3: is something my father has always said when it comes to investing. It's one of the wisest pieces of advice I've ever gotten with regards to investing. If you can catch a stock likeLululemon Athletica Inc.(NASDAQ:LULU)during good times
column4: you'll be happy. But as a risk-averse investor
column5: LULU stock is exactly the kind of stock I would not touchin my forthcoming stock advisory newsletter
column6: The Liberty Portfolio.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockQ4 earnings for Lululemon stock came out
column7: and the way the market reacted shows exactly why I avoid stocks like this.Q4 revenue increased 12% to $790 million from $704 million. That's dandy. Even more dandy is that comparable sales increased 8%. Any retail operation that grows comps by more than 5% is impressive. But 8%? Very strong.Gross margins increased dramatically to 54.2% compared to 50.3%. Gross margins are a great indicator that shows how efficient revenue generation is in regards to expenses. This is a gigantic year-over-year gain that is very impressive.Margin expansion filtered to the operating line
column8: also. Operating income was up 18% to $197 million
column9: with margins of 24.9% compared to 23.6%. I ignore earnings-per-share because that is easily muddied using share buybacks. However
column10: backing those out
column11: we find net income rose to $136.1 million from $117.4 million
column12: or 16%.Where Did LULU Stock Go Wrong?There is very little to dislike about any of this. So why was Lululemon stock down 23% as I was writing this article? Let's see if there's something funky about the FY results.10 Stocks You'd Be Foolish to Buy Right NowRevenue increased 14% to $2.3 billion from $2.1 billion. Comparable sales increased 6%. Gross profit increased 20% to $1.2 billion
column13: and once again
column14: gross margins jumped big time
column15: to 51.2% compared to 48.4%.Operating income increased 14% to $421 million
column16: although we can see the operating margin improvement came mostly from this quarter
column17: as FY was 18% compared to 17.9%. FY net income was $303.4 million
column18: up from $266 million
column19: or 14%.What's not to like? Guidance. This is the reason I hate retail stocks like LULU stock. A company can deliver a solid quarter
column20: but then say that sales were going to be weaker in Q1 and then â€¦ BLAM! Specifically
column21: Lululemon said the comps would be in the low-single digits for the quarter and for the year.What I found bizarre
column22: however
column23: was that they are blaming this on manufacturing gear with bland colors
column24: when consumers seem to want brighter colors for spring.Bottom Line on Lululemon StockFirst of all
column25: what athletic clothing maker doesn't do what every other regular retailer figured out decades ago: Spring means color! Second
column26: look what the market does to a dumb move like this! It didn't just sell the stock
column27: it beat it with a baseball bat.Why Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still the Alpha DogSo I don't care how strong margins are or how net income is growing impressively for Lululemon stock. There is too much risk in retail and I have seen this story play out countless times over my investing career. The tiniest thing can crater a stock and that fall could suddenly turn out to be permanent.That's not to say that LULU stock is going to fall apart and the company is going to end in bankruptcy. Hardly. It has $739 million in cash and no long-term debt
column28: and generated $385 million in operating cash flow. This is a very healthy business with a very healthy balance sheet. The problem is that owning Lululemon stock will give you heartburn.Can you do anything with LULU stock? I think most retail stocks are trading vehicles. If you feel like taking on risk
column29: you could buy here
column30: set a 5% to 7% stop loss on Lululemon stock and see if you can catch a rebound.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column31: a specialty lender focusing on consumer finance. He has 20 years' experience in the stock market

column1: Why Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still the Alpha Dog;3/31/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAt the risk of sounding like a broken record
column3: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) is the most elite value stock available. First
column5: the obvious fact is that GOOGL stock owns that little thing called the internet. It may have beeninventedby former Vice-president Al Gore
column6: but Alphabet took it to a whole new level. By logical deduction
column7: an investment in Alphabet stock is an investment in digitalization - not a bad gig at all!makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe other reason why GOOGL stock sits atop an extremely exclusive club is consistency.Find me a company that is as reliable and has as much potential as Alphabet. The night is still young
column8: but shares have only suffered three annual losses. Of those
column9: only one - in 2008 - registered in the double digits. The other down years in 2010 and 2014 average losses of about 5%.On the plus side
column10: from 2005 through the end of 2016
column11: GOOGL stock is averaging over 24%. Granted
column12: not every year is stellar. But if the end game is a long-term
column13: steady buffer for your portfolio
column14: you can't go wrong with Alphabet stock. It probably won't provide the fireworks of yesteryear
column15: but this is more of a slow burn. Sometimes
column16: you have to have patience for quality work.Still
column17: I understand the concerns. Psychologically speaking
column18: GOOGL stock has a hefty price tag. Can investors rely upon it over the next ten to twenty years?The Big Risk With Alphabet StockThe biggest fundamental risk to GOOGL stock is the ""one-trick pony"" argument.10 Safe Dividend Stocks to Own During the Next Market CrashAs InvestorPlace contributor Lawrence Meyersexplains
column19: ""Alphabet is the largest digital advertising billboard in the world
column20: with about 88% of its revenues coming from advertising. Moreover
column21: GOOGL stock's growth has been driven by this spectacular seizure of internet territory from competitors. In fact
column22: during the financial crisis
column23: ad revenues still grew about 8% year-over-year in 2009 despite a worldwide ad revenue decline of 11% that year.""For now
column24: GOOGL exercises unprecedented dominance
column25: and Alphabet stock is surely buoyed by this leverage. As Meyers further notes
column26: ""[i]t could get hit with a 20% decline in total revenues
column27: which would bring it roughly in line with fiscal year 2015 results
column28: and still generate net income of $15 billion or so."" Ordinarily
column29: a double-digit sales hit leads to automatic hemorrhaging in the markets. However
column30: GOOGL stock could earn a reprieve.The problem is what happens in the future? Will people continue toGooglethings on the internet? Or will there be some other innovation brought forth by Silicon Valley? It seems ridiculous to ask the question
column31: but we've seen this trend before. Not too long ago
column32: the science of instant (physical) photography was exclusivelyPolaroid's domain. Today
column33: Polaroid is basically a shell company. Even the term ""instant photography"" isn't used much anymore.As great as Alphabet stock is
column34: let's be real - this is not a balanced investment. A paradigm shift in internet advertising can potentially topple GOOGL.More Good Than Bad for GOOGLWhile I respect the risks
column35: I'm confident that the positives far outweigh the negatives for Alphabet stock. First off
column36: the one-trick pony argument doesn't scare me as much because we're not talking about commoditized leverage.What is the internet? Many might answer what they do on the internet
column37: and quite frankly
column38: I don't want to know. But all the responses you might receive boils down to this - it's the forum for the exchange of ideas. Ideas never go out of style. Because of that one single fact
column39: I highly doubt that Alphabet will
column40: either.The internet has evolved
column41: and dramatically so.What Al Gore invented decades ago metamorphosed into its own
column42: nearly self-aware entity. The true beauty of this network is that it levels the informational playing field. No longer is data strictly limited to the halls of academia. Anybody can propose a new idea
column43: or an innovation
column44: and this can rapidly proliferate without the need for credentials.Yes
column45: FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Is for RealThat
column46: my friends
column47: is the power of GOOGL stock. This is a company that will adapt and evolve to whatever challenges it faces. So long as they keep that corporate culture intact
column48: you're not going to find a better value play than Alphabet stock.GOOGL Stock: Competition Is Still BehindFor those that are worried about Alphabet's competition
column49: I'd set those aside. Yes
column50: Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) can make some noise
column51: andAmazon.com
column52: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) is always up to something. These are companies that service their sectors like no other. Because of that
column53: people use those services based on their earned reputation.GOOGL has the internet. That much is obvious because Google is a verb. Other company names invoke a function. Wefriendeach other on Facebook. Webuystuff on Amazon. The commoditized criticism is more applicable to them. Someone might invent a better way to network online. Another person might offer cheaper and faster e-retailing.But a better way to internet? Again
column54: I highly doubt that anyone can compete with Alphabet. For better or for worse
column55: they've got their tentacles entrenched into everything web-related. So you can rest easy with GOOGL stock. Neither the company nor the opportunity is going anywhere but up.As of this writing

column1: How Many Users Does Facebook Have?;3/30/2017;"On pace to hit 2 billion monthly active users in 2017
column2: Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) is the world's largest social network by a long   shot. But exactly how many users does Facebook have? And what can   be learned about these users?Here's a look at the most telling statistics about Facebook's   users.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();1.86 billion:Facebook has 1.86 billion monthly active users -- far ahead of   the rest of the world's social networks. The next three largest   social networks
column3: for instance
column4: are each 700 million or more users   behind Facebook. WhatsApp has 1.2 billion monthly active users
column5: and YouTube and Facebook Messenger each have about 1 billion   monthly active users as of last count (a complete list of the   world's 10 largest social networks can be foundhere).17%:Facebook's monthly active users continue to grow at a rapid rate.   The company's 1.86 billion monthly active users achieved in the   fourth quarter of 2016 is up 17% year over year.Data source: Facebook's quarterly SEC filings. Chart by     author.66%:Perhaps where Facebook's user statistics shine the most is the   percentage of monthly active users that use the service every   single day. This rate
column6: often referred to Facebook's engagement   rate
column7: was 66% throughout 2016 -- up from 65% in 2015.18%:Facebook's daily active users actually increased slightly faster   than its monthly active users in 2016. Daily active users by the   end of the year were 1.23 billion
column8: up 18% year over year from   1.04 billion in 2015.94%:Today
column9: Facebook is almost entirely mobile driven. Of Facebook's   1.86 billion monthly active users
column10: 94% of them -- or 1.74 billion   -- are also monthly active users on mobile devices.1.15 billion:Further highlighting how important mobile is to Facebook
column11: 1.15   billion monthly active usersonlyuse Facebook on mobile devices. Facebook calls these people   mobile-only monthly active users
column12: and they soared 40% between   2015 and 2016.Data source: Q4 2016 SEC filing. Chart by author.Unsurprisingly
column13: 84% of Facebook's advertising revenue in the   fourth quarter of 2016 came from ads on mobile devices.231 million:Believe it or not
column14: the U.S. and Canada is Facebook's smallest   geographic segment in terms of monthly active users. Facebook   pegs monthly active users in the region at 231 million. It has   349 million in Europe
column15: 673 million in Asia-Pacific
column16: and 606   million in the rest of the world.51%:Despite being its smallest segment measured by monthly active   users
column17: the U.S. and Canada together accounted for over half of   Facebook's advertising revenue in the fourth quarter of 2016.   Advertising revenue in the U.S. and Canada was $4.4 billion. Ad   revenues in Europe
column18: Asia-Pacific
column19: and rest of the world were $2   billion
column20: $1.4 billion
column21: and $832 million
column22: respectively.$15.98:In 2016
column23: Facebook generated an average of $15.98 of revenue per   monthly active user. This is up about 34% from its $11.96 of   average revenue per user in 2015.At the rate Facebook is currently growing its user base
column24: the   company is well on its way to hitting 2 billion monthly active   users in 2017. Indeed
column25: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is aiming far   beyond 2 billion users. The ambitious CEO believes the company   can hit 5 billion users by 2030.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column26: it can pay to listen. After all
column27: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column28: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column29: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Facebook wasn't one of       them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column4: terrorism and hate speeches. Notably

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Lose Its App Store Crown to Android;3/30/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA new report has been released with comprehensive stats for the global market for mobile apps. App Annie says thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) served up a fraction of the downloads ofAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Play for 2016
column4: yet continued to dominate the revenue side of the business.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleApple's App Store revenue is predicted to continue topping Google Play as the most lucrative through to 2021. It's expected that all Android app stores combined will overtake Apple's App Store sales at some point this year.Report on Mobile App Downloads and RevenueApp Annie is a firm that tracks global app downloads and app store revenue. A detailed report - which was made available onAppleInsider- sheds light onwhat's currently happening in the mobile app market
column5: along with forecasts to 2021.According to App Annie
column6: AAPL's App Store revenue is about to be surpassed for the first time by the combination of Google Play and third party Android app stores. While Apple remained on top for 2016
column7: with $34 billion in app sales versus a combined $27 billion for Android
column8: in 2017 the lead is expected to shift. Apple App Store revenue is pegged at $40 billion
column9: while Android app stores are on track to book a combined $41 billion.The 7 Best Stocks to Buy for an Income-Rich RetirementApple continues to be on top as the single largest app store by sales
column10: with its $40 billion for 2017 expected to nearly double second place Google Play's $21 billion. Apple's iOS also stays firmly in the lead as the platform where users are most likely to pay for apps. Apple's $40 billion in revenue is expected to come from 30 billion downloads. Google Play's $21 billion will come from 114 billion downloads
column11: making Apple's App Store a much more lucrative prospect for developers.The App Annie numbers show that Android's sheer numbers advantage
column12: however
column13: is once again showing results.Apple App Store Revenue ExplainsSuper Mario RunOne of the best recent examples of how the difference between appdownloadsversus apppurchasesplays out wasNintendo Co.
column14: Ltd (ADR)'s(OTCMKTS:NTDOY)Super Mario Run.This was Nintendo's first full-fledged foray into mobile gaming. Built around one of the most recognizable Nintendo characters of all time
column15: smartphone ownerssalivated at the chance to play.When the game was released in 2016
column16: if one platform was going to have an edge at getting Mario first
column17: sheer numbers would say it should have been Google Play. With more than double the downloads of the Apple App Store
column18: Google Play would have putSuper Mario Runonto a lot more devices. But Nintendochose to make Super Mario run an iOS exclusiveinstead.Despite there being far fewer iPhones out there than Android smartphones
column19: AAPL's App Store revenue shows that those iPhone users are far more likely topayfor a game. Android users had to wait until last week to finally get their hands on the title. And that's been the model that many premium app developers continue to follow
column20: despite Google Play's numbers lead.If it's a high-profile app that cost a lot to develop and you expect people to pay for it
column21: the Apple App Store tends to get it first - if Google Play gets it at all.Will the Shift to Android Dominance Hurt Apple?Services - which includes App Store revenue - has become anincreasingly important division for AAPL. It posted the highest growth of any of Apple's divisions last year and AAPL netted $3 billion in revenue from app downloads last December alone.Is that revenue in jeopardy? That shouldn't be the case
column22: for three reasons.First
column23: the Apple App Store is expected to remain comfortably on top as the single largest app store for revenue through 2021.Second
column24: a huge chunk of the revenue growth on the Android side is coming from third party Chinese app stores. These tend to be focused on that market
column25: and don't compete against the West.Third
column26: every year it gets more difficult and more expensive to develop and support apps for Android. There are so many versions of the operating system in use and so many different smartphones running it that testing and ensuring a good user experience - something that's critical for premium apps - is time consuming
column27: costly and still doesn't guarantee results.Bottom Line on Apple's App StoreApple has weathered a number of negative milestones as a result of the sheer numbers of Android users. In 2011
column28: the number of Android smartphones leapt past the number of iPhones in the American market. In 2013
column29: Google Play took the lead in the number of app downloads for the first time. And in 2015
column30: the Apple App Store was surpassed by Google Play for having the most apps available.If Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Has a Shot at a Breakout
column31: This Is ItDespite the dominance of Android smartphones
column32: App Store sales continue growing at a healthy pace
column33: and it's expected to keep doing so despite the latest stat. According to App Annie's predictions
column34: that means growth to $40 billion in revenue this year and $60 billion by 2021 (compared to $78 billion combined for Android). Not bad for a platform expected to see appdownloadsat that time outnumbered 7-to-1 by the competition.As of this writing
column35: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 7 Best REITs to Buy for Big (And Growing!) Yields3 Stocks to Buy Before Slow-Growth Dinosaurs Nab ThemThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Will Lose Its App Store Crown to Androidappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Software Update 8.1 Includes Autopilot 2.0
column2: Sketch Pad;3/30/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) has released its 8.1 software update and it includes some new features.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockOne of the major updates that came with 8.1 was the addition of more features for Tesla Inc's Autopilot 2.0. This includes the ability to use the Autosteer feature while going 80 mph. The previous limit was 55 mph.While the Autosteer update is out
column4: it will still be a couple of days before owners of a Tesla Inc vehicle can use it at 80 mph. This is due to thecameras on the car needing calibration. The calibration will take place over the next few days during normal driving.There's also another couple of changes that come to Autopilot 2.0 in the 8.1 software update. The first is Auto Lane Change
column5: which lets users change lanes with Autosteer by using a turn signal. The second new feature is called ""Summon"". It lets owners park and pull out their vehicles from parking spaces without the need to be in them
column6: reportsElectrek.The electric car company also hid a fun feature in its 8.1 software update. If users tap the company's logo on the vehicle's touchscreen three times
column7: it will bring up a Sketch Pad for them to draw with. The secret feature wasrevealed by Tesla Inc CEO Elon MuskonTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR).The 7 Best Stocks to Buy for an Income-Rich RetirementTesla Inc also added a few other small features in the 8.1 software update. They include ratings and details fromAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column8: GOOGL)Google for businesses in the Mapsoption
column9: a Favorites option for radio streaming and a change to the headrest adjustment option.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in AprilThe 10 Best ETFs to Buy for the Rest of 2017The 7 WORST Stocks to Buy Right NowThe postTesla Inc (TSLA) Software Update 8.1 Includes Autopilot 2.0

column1: Why Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Needs an Innovative Edge;3/30/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile stock inApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andAmazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) has been on fire since the start of the year
column4: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) shares seem becalmed. MSFT stock is up 6%
column5: adding about $25 billion to its market cap
column6: but that gain not only trails its tech rivals
column7: as the NASDAQ average is up 9.56%.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockHow bad is it? It's so bad that Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is threatening to overtake Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates as the world's richest man. He's just $10 billion behind after trade closed Mar 29.This is not down to any complacency on the part of CEO Satya Nadella and his team. If anything
column8: they're moving faster than ever. But Microsoft's days as a monopolist are over. Its products must all earn their way. They're all facing competition in the marketplace. A person or even a company can live without MSFT
column9: and while the company may see this as liberating
column10: some investors are treating it as a reason to worry.MSFT Stock: A Gaming CompetitorFor example
column11: Microsoft investors should be bullish at its efforts in gaming
column12: but there is plenty of competition.Gaming is where developers
column13: and customers
column14: are pushing the envelope on PC performance. People will spend a lot more for a game machine than for any other type of console device. MSFT stock is in the middle of it.10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotThe latest version of Windows 10
column15: called Creators Update
column16: will feature lots of new gaming features when itlaunches April 11
column17: butit's not the revolution the company promisedwhen they announced it last fall.Microsoft stock got into gaming through the Xbox console. The latest version brought in $9.1 billion last year and holds26% of the market.But it's not No.1
column18: as that honor goes toSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE) and its PlayStation 4. Nor is it the hottest new console. That's theNintendo Co.
column19: Ltd. (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY)Switch.MSFT has launched its own game streaming service
column20: Beam Streaming
column21: but that must compete with Amazon's market-leading Twitch service. Game delivery is a niche controlled by privately-heldSteam
column22: founded by former Microsoft employees in 1996 and now majority-owned by Gabe Newell.Still
column23: there is ample room for growth in gaming
column24: and Microsoft alone has a position in every important niche.Microsoft Stock's New Hope: AzureNadella made his name at Microsoft building Azure
column25: the company's cloud business. His strategy has been to put all of MSFT's offerings into Azure
column26: to offer its software directly to users through Azure
column27: and to use cloud-based applications to dominate the enterprise market.He can argue that it's working. Microsoft's revenue from Azure-fed businesses
column28: which now includes Office 365
column29: is $14 billion
column30: and Azure should deliver $2.5 billion in hosting revenueall by itself.While Amazon dominates the cloud infrastructure market with a share of over 80%
column31: what investors focus on is the growing competition between Azure andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column32: NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column33: whichsome analysts think Google will win.That would be a disaster for Microsoft stock.Office 365 faces growing competition fromGoogle's G Suite
column34: and that in turn meansgrowing competition for PCs from Google Chromebooks
column35: which are especially gaining share in educationbecause they're cheaper
column36: with more of their functions online.Nothing comes easy anymore.The Bottom Line for MSFT StockAnalysts are generally positive about Microsoft stock
column37: but one-third have it off their buy lists. They expect 69 cents per share of earnings on $22.47 billion in revenue when the company reports April 27
column38: which would represent 10% more revenue and almost 50% more profit than the company delivered in the March quarter last year.Bullish on Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock? Then Answer This QuestionMicrosoft today is the third-largest company in the world
column39: by market cap
column40: at $505 billion. But its operations must race hard to stay in place. Google is ahead
column41: and Amazon is coming up from behind. Technology dominates the stock market
column42: and MSFT stock remains a part of most technology portfolios.Nadella has saved the company. It's no longer at risk to falling off pace likeInternational Business Machines Inc.(NYSE:IBM). Its price-to-earnings ratio of nearly 31 is slightly higher than Google's at 30
column43: and well ahead of Apple's at 17. But there's not one part of Microsoft that can afford to be complacent
column44: and that's a sea change.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column45: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column46: he was long AAPL

column1: Top 10 Social Networks: How Many Users Are on Each?;3/30/2017;"A network effect is arguably one of the most powerful   competitive advantages a business can have. While network effects   can come in different forms
column2: the concept is simple: A business   benefits from a network effect when the value of its platform   increases with each additional user that joins.Social networks are great examples of businesses with network   effects. But which social networks are the largest? Measured by   their monthly active users
column3: the top 10 social networks range from   user counts of 313 million all the way to an impressive 1.9   billion. Here are world's top social networks
column4: along with some   interesting takeaways about this list.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();World's biggest social networksFacebook (1.9 billion users)WhatsApp (1.2 billion users)YouTube (1 billion users since 2013)Messenger (1 billion users since 2016)WeChat/Weixin (889 million users)QQ (869 million users)Qzone (638 million users)Instagram (600 million users)Twitter (319 million users)Weibo (313 million users)In a chart
column5: the world's top 10 social networks look like   this:Data from company press releases and SEC filings. *YouTube     is ranked higher than Messenger since YouTube achieved this     milestone in 2013 and Messenger achieved it in 2016. In     addition
column6: YouTube hasn't shared any recent updates on its     users
column7: but it's likely larger than Messenger today. Platforms     without reliable user data or insignificant social     characteristics were excluded. Chart by author..Facebook dominates the listIt's fair to say thatFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) knows a thing or two about building successful   social networks. The company absolutely dominates this list.Not only do the 1.9 billion monthly active users on the   company's core Facebook app beat out the rest of the world's   social networks by 700 million users or more
column8: but also three of   the top four social networks are all Facebook properties.   Facebook's messaging apps
column9: WhatsApp and Messenger
column10: have 1.2   billion and 1 billion monthly active users
column11: respectively. And   Facebook's photo- and video-sharing app Instagram -- at 600   million users -- made the list as well.Image source: Facebook.In addition
column12: Facebook's social networks continue to grow   rapidly. Even the company's core Facebook app saw its monthly   active users grow a nice 17% year over year in the fourth quarter   of 2016. This growth rate easily beatsTwitter's 4% year-over-year growth in the same period
column13: despite the fact   that Twitter's growth is on a much smaller base.Tencent is crushing it in ChinaBelieve it or not
column14: there's another dominant company on the   list. While many people in North America may be unfamiliar with   its social networks
column15: Chinese internet companyTencent Holdings(NASDAQOTH: TCEHY) owns three of these 10 social networks: WeChat   and Weixin (essentially different modes of the same app)
column16: QQ
column17: and   Qzone. These social networks are the fifth
column18: sixth
column19: and seventh   largest social networks in the world.Image source: WeChat.Notably
column20: the fact that Facebook and Tencent together account   for a whopping seven of the top eight social networks reinforces   how strong of a competitive advantage social networks have. By   flexing the significant reach and breadth across their platforms   and integrating features across the networks under their name
column21: Facebook and Tencent offer significant value to their users and   to the businesses who make money on their networks.Snapchat isn't so hot after allOne surprising social network that didn't even make the list   is Snapchat
column22: owned by parent companySnap(NYSE: SNAP)
column23: which just went public in March. Despite being one   of the biggest IPOs in recent history
column24: Snapchat has about 301   million monthly active users
column25: according to estimates by   Statista.But Snapchat could make it onto this list soon. Though Snap   opts to only share its daily active users with investors
column26: this   metric was up sharply in the fourth quarter of 2016
column27: suggesting   Snapchat still has some growth ahead of it. Snapchat's daily   active users hit 158 million during this period
column28: up 48% year   over year.Image source: Getty Images.Can Facebook and Tencent continue to dominate the list in   years to come
column29: proving the staying power of a network effect? Or   are the world's biggest social networks more susceptible to   disruption than might be thought? For now
column30: Facebook and Tencent's   prevailing presence on this list suggests the biggest social   networks won't be knocked from dominance easily.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column31: it can pay to listen. After all
column32: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column33: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column34: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Facebook wasn't one of   them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column36: an executive at Alphabet
column37: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Daniel Sparksowns shares of Facebook. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A and C shares)
column38: Facebook
column39: and Twitter.     The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column5: 2017 - Zacks Director of Research Sheraz Mian says
column6: ""For Q1 as a whole

You can access the full report that contains detailed   historical actuals and estimates for the current and following   periods
column8: please click here>>>The small sample of Q1 earnings reports that have come out already present a reassuring view of this reporting cycle
column9: with growth as well as positive surprises tracking above what had seen from that same group of companies in the preceding quarter. But with Q1 results from only 17 S&P 500 members out at this stage
column10: the sample's small size stops us from looking for trends. Please note that these initial reports are from companies reporting results for their fiscal quarters in February
column11: which get counted as part of the Q1 tally.For Q1 as a whole
column12: total earnings are expected to be up +6.6% from the same period last year on +6.5% higher revenues. This would follow +7.4% earnings growth in 2016 Q4 on +4.7% top-line gains
column13: which was the highest growth pace in two years.Estimates for Q1 came down as the quarter unfolded
column14: with the current +6.6% growth down from +10.4% at the end of December.Please note that while Q1 estimates have followed this well traversed path that we have been seeing consistently over the last few years
column15: the magnitude of negative revisions compares favorably to other periods. In other words
column16: Q1 estimates have come down
column17: but they haven't come down by as much as has historically been the case. We saw this trend of decelerating negative revisions ahead of the preceding earnings season as well
column18: which justifies the market's favorable view of the overall earnings picture.At the sector level
column19: 8 of the 16 Zacks sectors are expected to earn more relative to the year-earlier period
column20: with earnings growth for the Technology sector expected to be up +10.8% from the same period last year. The sector's strong earnings growth is despite the relatively flattish expectation fromApple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column21: with strong growth atAlphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)
column22: Facebook(NASDAQ:FB-Free Report) and easy comparisons atMicron(NASDAQ:MU-Free Report) as big contributors.Earnings growth for the Finance
column23: Basic Materials and Industrials sectors are expected to be in mid-single digits while the Energy sector moves from a modest loss in the year-earlier period to improving positive earnings this quarter. The aggregate dollar amount of earnings improvement is the highest for the Energy sector of all 16 Zacks sectors
column24: with the sector expected to earn a total of $8.5 billion in Q1 vs. a loss -1.6 billion in the year-earlier quarter.Please note that we have yet to see any 'Trump bump' in estimates along the lines of what we have been seeing in the market since November 8th. The sole exception to that comment would be the Finance sector whose earnings outlook has benefited from the post-election uptrend in interest rates.Note: Sheraz Mian manages the Zacks equity research   department. column1: Ericsson to Power Sasktel's Next Generation IPTV Service;3/30/2017;"EricssonERIChas secured a contract to power SaskTel's next generation IPTV service. The implementation of Ericsson's MediaFirst solution suite will begin this year
column2: with SaskTel planning to commercially launch its enhanced and expanded IPTV service in Saskatchewan in early 2018.As the dominant information and communications technology provider in Saskatchewan
column3: Canada
column4: Ericsson MediaFirst will enable SaskTel to offer subscribers new features over a new Pay TV in-home and TV everywhere product. These features include a highly personalized interface across all screens
column5: and will offer users the ability to watch live TV and access content on demand on any device. They will also be made available to the existing maxTV subscribers.Under its end-to-end MediaFirst solution suite
column6: Ericsson offers Ericsson MediaFirst TV Platform
column7: Video Processing
column8: Video Delivery and Video Storage and Processing Platform. Ericsson MediaFirst TV Platform is a ""software-defined
column9: media-optimized cloud-based TV platform.""Over time
column10: Ericsson has been taking strategic steps to fortify its foothold in the broadcasting and media industry
column11: by extending its technology to broadcasters for merging video and mobility. In the past year
column12: the company entered into multiple contracts - including Liberty Global's operating unit
column13: Liberty Global and Belgian telecommunication player
column14: Proximus - to boost their Digital Video Recording services.Ericsson further partnered with Alphabet Inc.GOOGLto extend the reach of its cloud-based MediaFirst TV Platform into the Android TV ecosystem
column15: Google's operating system for the set-top box. The company has a proven track record
column16: delivering TV and media business transformation for over two decades. Currently
column17: it distributes four million hours of programming in more than 60 languages for over 500 TV channels.Ericsson's share price had a disastrous run on the bourse in 2016
column18: as it plunged 39.3%

column1: Why Alphabet Inc Needs to Act Fast to Reassure Advertisers;3/29/2017;"In this podcast
column2: theMarket Fooleryteam turns its attention to the latest controversy at YouTube     as major advertisers have complained about their ads appearing     next to objectionable videos. As the online advertising race     betweenAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG)  andFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) intensifies
column3: the internet giant has no choice but     to address the issue quickly.To wrap up the show

column9: 2017The author(s) may have a position in any stocks         mentioned.This video was recorded on March 27
column10: 2017.Chris Hill:It's Monday
column11: March 27th. Welcome toMarket Foolery.I'm Chris Hill. Joining me in studio today
column12: fromMillion Dollar Portfolio

column14: Taylor Muckerman. Happy Monday!Jason Moser:Hey
column15: now!Taylor Muckerman:We're doing it!Hill:We are doing it. Welcome back! You've been busy.Muckerman:Yeah
column16: a couple weeks. You were at South by Southwest.     We've been overlapping each other.Hill:There we go. It's good to have you back in the studio.Muckerman:It's good to be back.Hill:We're going to dip into the Fool mailbag. We have to start     with a story that's been brewing for a little while. I'll     be honest. This is a story
column17: I saw a headline on this a     week or two ago
column18: and it registered like
column19: huh
column20: that's interesting
column21: and it continues to balloon. This is     the fact that a week ago

column23: and how it's     one of the most popular places to search. And you see     these stories about
column24: if YouTube was a stand-alone company

column26: and here we     are a week later
column27: and I guess
column28: among other things
column29: Jason
column30: probably a reminder that YouTube is a really     big place with lots of videos
column31: and therefore it's hard even for     the owners to monitor it.The Wall Street Journalhad this big story about howCoca-Cola
column32: Microsoft

column35: these mainstream brands

column37: anti-Semitic
column38: all of this     stuff where the advertisers
column39: rightfully so
column40: say
column41: ""I don't want     my ads next to that.""Moser:Yeah. We're going to hit a point here

column43: it's     going to be like you do with your kids
column44: they can saysorryonly so many times before you're like
column45: ""I get that you're     sorry. Just don't do it again. I'm not looking forsorryanymore."" So
column46: I think with Google and YouTube
column47: this is     obviously something that's a big deal. It's not something that     immediately impacts their bottom line. When we talk about the     bread and butter for Google's money-making machine
column48: it's search     advertising. But
column49: there's a good percentage
column50: close to 20% of     that money
column51: comes through advertising with third-party     customers. So

column53: of     course
column54: those parties are going to express concern
column55: they want     to know what's going on
column56: why is this happening
column57: and what are     you going to do to make it stop? Because there is no middle     ground here. It's just
column58: flat-out
column59: ""This     is unacceptable
column60: don't let it happen anymore."" This     is sort of one of those things with this age of automation
column61: as     we go more toward automating everything
column62: particularly on     the consumer-facing side
column63: I think it's really difficult to     ever fall back on the old
column64: ""Well
column65: the algorithm did it
column66: it     wasn't our fault."" Because
column67: ultimately
column68: someone built     the algorithm.I think what Google needs to figure out here     is
column69: what is happening to make this happen
column70: and how do they     fix it? And whether it is through technology
column71: whether it's     through humanizing it a little bit more
column72: and actually bringing     on more people to add a human touch to these customer     relationships
column73: they need to do something with this before     this gets out of hand.We've talked about this a lot
column74: especially in MDP
column75: we own     shares of Alphabet
column76: and we own shares of Facebook: We     own a far larger position in Facebook
column77: and part of the     reason for that is
column78: when you look at the direction things are     headed in social
column79: and in internet behavior
column80: there's no question     that Facebook is becoming a place
column81: not just Facebook
column82: but     its properties
column83: whether it's WhatsApp or Instagram     or whatever properties they buy in the future
column84: that's a     place where eyeballs go to hang out for a while. Google is     more utilitarian in nature
column85: right? You need some information
column86: you find it on Google
column87: and you go to your next place. Facebook     is catching up very quickly. They've expressed some     concerns that perhaps the last decade was the Google     decade
column88: and perhaps this next decade is the Facebook     decade. If that is the case
column89: and the numbers certainly point     toward that
column90: the argument could at least be made     there
column91: Google has got to figure out something yesterday as     to how to address this and fix it
column92: because blaming it on     the technology is not going to fly.Muckerman:I'm pretty confident that they're going to figure out a way to     fix it. Especially when you're talking about     Facebook
column93: they had the whole issue around the election     with fake news on their site. And you had a group     of college kids come out and make an algorithm that was     able to identify fake news on the site
column94: and they've been     able -- not using their algorithm
column95: but
column96: Facebook has been     able to address that. I'm confident that Google will. You talk     about big headlines about this
column97: but I'm waiting for the     headline to come out that says

column99: people think that     less than 1% of Google's revenue is at risk because of this.     It's a $90 billion revenue company
column100: I've seen headlines     that say $750 million might come off of YouTube's revenue in     2017 because of this. Bigger fraction of YouTube's     revenue
column101: but you're not just an investor in YouTube when     you buy a stock in Alphabet. So
column102: I'm still confident that     they'll figure it out. And between the two of them
column103: Facebook     and Google

column105: I find it hard to believe that     advertisers are going to completely move away from Google.     Right now
column106: Facebook is really the only alternative
column107: and     that space would become far too crowded too quickly if there     was a mass exodus from Google. I'm fairly confident that
column108: because you said 20% of their revenue comes from that search     advertising

column110: and yet
column111: when you look at the     headline ofPepsi

column118: you're     on the phone to different media agencies
column119: and I also think     television networks. If you're a broadcast network or     cable network

column126: and     you're going to get something that associates well with     your brand.""Muckerman:With some of those companies you mentioned
column127: those are     companies that can afford to pull back for a week or two     on advertising and make a statement. That's     almost advertising in itself. They're still advertising     using Google's name
column128: just not using Google's platform.     So
column129: I think they'll come back eventually. Probably not too     far down the line. Those brands are brands already.     You're probably looking at the smaller     players
column130: questioning whether or not they can afford to     back off of Google's platform a little bit more than Coke or     Pepsi.Moser:Yeah
column131: and I think it's also worth noting

What an acquisition Google made for ... what did they buy     it for?Hill:$1.6 billion.Muckerman:Pennies on the current dollar.Hill:And the reason I remember it was $1.6 billion is     because I was one of the people saying

You don't get charged every time they deposit the dividend to     your account. You only get charged if you put it back     into CAD. So

column1: Did Snap Win Gold With $75 Million NBC Winter Olympics Deal?;3/29/2017;"Snapchat's parent company Snap Inc.SNAPjust landed a massive content deal with NBCUniversal for the 2018 Winter Olympics. But what does it mean for the struggling social media app?The Wall Street Journalfirstreported that the dealis worth an estimated $50 million to $75 million based on advertising commitments in the first quarter of 2018. As part of the deal
column2: NBC
column3: owned by Comcast Corp.CMCSA
column4: will sell for the first time Olympic-based Snapchat geofilters and ""lenses"" to advertisers.Snap's stock went up 1.53% to $22.55 per share on Wednesday
column5: before falling slighting in after-hours trading. Snap is currently a Zacks Rank #3 (HOLD).The new NBC and Snap deal is the second recent and major partnership between the two companies. NBC joined forces with Snapchat to help enhance and expand its Rio 2016 coverage in August. NBC also invested $500 million in Snap's March IPO.But does NBC's second Snapchat Olympic deal signal something bigger for the disappearing messaging company?Real Player Going Forward?Snapchat owns the audience that NBC desperately wants to profit from
column6: the coveted 35 and under demographic. Snapchat makes almost all of its money from advertising
column7: so any deal that could land the company $75 million in just over two weeks isn't a bad thing.Comcast paid$4.38 billionfor the U.S. media rights to the four Olympics between 2014 and 2020. NBC then doubled-down and paid $7.65 billion for the rights to broadcast the Olympics through 2032
column8: so the money Snap could see in 2018 is relative peanuts in NBC's grand scheme. Still
column9: it is a solid step forward for the relatively new social media company.NBC lost Olympic viewers for the first time since 2000 this past summer in Rio. NBC drew an average of 25.4 million viewers on its prime time Brazilian coverage. London 2012 drew 31.1 million prime time viewers
column10: according to an NBC release.NBC is fighting to gain as many eyes as possible for its 2018 coverage
column11: and Snapchat helps the cause. According to NBC
column12: nearly 35 million people in the U.S. viewed NBC's Rio coverage on Snapchat.Pyeongchang
column13: South Korea is scheduled to host the 2018 Winter Olympics Games. The Winter Olympics are always less popular overall than its summer counterpart. Still
column14: the Olympics are arguably the biggest and most important television rights deal NBC owns. The prestigious NBC Olympic exposure can't hurt Snapchat.Snapchat will share NBC Olympic content in an NBC Snapchat live story
column15: which will also feature user-generated content live from South Korea. Similar to its Rio deal
column16: BuzzFeed will help NBC produce content that will be posted throughout the games in Snapchat's Discover feature.NBC will sell ad slots that are spaced throughout its Snapchat Olympic coverage. They will also be able to sell branded geofilters and lenses.In Snapchat's fight against Facebook Inc.FBand Alphabet Inc.s' GoogleGOOGLfor online and mobile advertising revenue
column17: every dollar counts. Snapchat's second massive NBC Olympic deal certainly helps the company not only gain more always-needed ad revenue
column18: but it helps further legitimize the social media company with such high faith from a legacy media powerhouse.More Stock News: 8 Companies Verge on Apple-Like   RunDid you miss Apple's 9X stock explosion after they launched their iPhone in 2007? Now 2017 looks to be a pivotal year to get in on another emerging technology expected to rock the market. Demand could soar from almost nothing to $42 billion by 2025. Reports suggest it could save 10 million lives per decade which could in turn save $200 billion in U.S. healthcare costs.A bonus Zacks Special Report names this breakthrough and the 8 best stocks to exploit it. Like Apple in 2007
column19: these companies are already strong and coiling for potential mega-gains.Click to see them right now >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column20: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportmakeArticleAd();Facebook

column1: Looking Ahead to the Q1 Earnings Season;3/29/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Note: The following is an excerpt from this week'sEarnings Trendsreport. You can access the full report that contains detailed historical actuals and estimates for the current and following periods
column2: please click here>>>The small sample of Q1 earnings reports that have come out already present a reassuring view of this reporting cycle
column3: with growth as well as positive surprises tracking above what had seen from that same group of companies in the preceding quarter. But with Q1 results from only 17 S&P 500 members out at this stage
column4: the sample's small size stops us from looking for trends. Please note that these initial reports are from companies reporting results for their fiscal quarters in February
column5: which get counted as part of the Q1 tally.For Q1 as a whole
column6: total earnings are expected to be up +6.6% from the same period last year on +6.5% higher revenues. This would follow +7.4% earnings growth in 2016 Q4 on +4.7% top-line gains
column7: which was the highest growth pace in two years.Estimates for Q1 came down as the quarter unfolded
column8: with the current +6.6% growth down from +10.4% at the end of December. The chart below shows how Q1 earnings growth expectations have evolved over the last three months.Please note that while Q1 estimates have followed this well traversed path that we have been seeing consistently over the last few years
column9: the magnitude of negative revisions compares favorably to other periods. In other words
column10: Q1 estimates have come down
column11: but they haven't come down by as much as has historically been the case. We saw this trend of decelerating negative revisions ahead of the preceding earnings season as well
column12: which justifies the market's favorable view of the overall earnings picture.At the sector level
column13: 8 of the 16 Zacks sectors are expected to earn more relative to the year-earlier period
column14: with earnings growth for the Technology sector expected to be up +10.8% from the same period last year. The sector's strong earnings growth is despite the relatively flattish expectation fromApple(AAPL)
column15: with strong growth atAlphabet(GOOGL)
column16: Facebook(FB) and easy comparisons atMicron(MU) as big contributors.Earnings growth for the Finance
column17: Basic Materials and Industrials sectors are expected to be in mid-single digits while the Energy sector moves from a modest loss in the year-earlier period to improving positive earnings this quarter. The aggregate dollar amount of earnings improvement is the highest for the Energy sector of all 16 Zacks sectors
column18: with the sector expected to earn a total of $8.5 billion in Q1 vs. a loss -1.6 billion in the year-earlier quarter.The chart below shows current consensus growth expectations for the following quarters
column19: which reflects a continuation of the positive growth trend going forward.Please note that we have yet to see any 'Trump bump' in estimates along the lines of what we have been seeing in the market since November 8th. The sole exception to that comment would be the Finance sector whose earnings outlook has benefited from the post-election uptrend in interest rates.Note: Sheraz Mian manages the Zacks equity research department. He is an acknowledged earnings expert whose commentaries and analyses appear on Zacks.com and in the print and electronic media. His weekly earnings related articles includeEarnings TrendsandEarnings Preview. column1: Domino's (DPZ) Robot Delivery Expands to Europe;3/29/2017;"Domino's Pizza Inc.DPZis expanding its robot delivery service to Europe. The recognized world leader in pizza delivery is teaming up with the London-based startup
column2: Starship Technologies
column3: to deliver pizza in Germany and the Netherlands with robots.This isn't the first time that a robot has delivered Domino's pizzas. The company has formed a group called Domino's Robotic Unit (DRU) to oversee this operation.  The first successful robot pizza delivery was done last March in New Zealand. It also made a delivery by drone in November.Starship
column4: founded by two Skype co-founders
column5: Ahti Heinla and Janus Friis
column6: created six-wheeled
column7: self-driving delivery robots that will be able to deliver pizza within a one-mile radius of certain Domino's pizza shops in selected German cities and locations throughout the Netherlands.The robot has a maximum speed of four miles per hour and able to carry up to 20 pounds. Known as DRU
column8: it is designed to travel on the sidewalk and capable of detecting and avoiding obstacles
column9: such as cars
column10: trash cans
column11: and curious bystanders.The public wonders if the robots will eventually take the job of the delivery drivers. The company said the robot is only a ""complement to its deliveries in cars and bicycles
column12: and it will create more jobs for humans too
column13: including maintaining the robots and loading pizzas into DRU.""With our growth plans over the next five to 10 years
column14: we simply won't have enough delivery drivers if we do not look to add to our fleet through initiatives such as this
column15: said Domino's CEO Don Meij.While the robot will only unlock with a code that customers receive through text
column16: it's hard not to wonder if a hungry bystander will just follow the robot till its destination before striking or just hijacking the robot. What will Domino's and Starship do to prevent that from happening?Companies like Amazon.comAMZN
column17: Wal-MartWMT
column18: ChipotleCMGand AlphabetGOOGLhave all been testing out their version of drone delivery
column19: but a lot of work in safety and policy still needs to be done.Domino's is trading at $183.93 per share
column20: down 0.55% on Wednesday.More Stock News: 8 Companies Verge on Apple-Like   RunDid you miss Apple's 9X stock explosion after they launched their iPhone in 2007? Now 2017 looks to be a pivotal year to get in on another emerging technology expected to rock the market. Demand could soar from almost nothing to $42 billion by 2025. Reports suggest it could save 10 million lives per decade which could in turn save $200 billion in U.S. healthcare costs.makeArticleAd();A bonus Zacks Special Report names this breakthrough and the 8 best stocks to exploit it. column1: Samsung (SSNLF) Introduces the Galaxy S8 With Infinity Display;3/29/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThis morning in New York
column3: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) held its most important Samsung Unpacked event to date. This one was for the launch of the Galaxy S8
column4: the company's flagship smartphone. This is a make-or-break moment for Samsung - at least where it comes to its position as the world's biggest smartphone maker.makeArticleAd();Source: SamsungThis is the time where Samsung has to convince consumers to forget about the Galaxy Note 7
column5: exploding battery and all.The Galaxy S8 is the phone that will take onApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and its 10th anniversary iPhone 8 (oriPhone Edition). And it has to hold offAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL) and itsGoogle PixelPhone. In other words
column7: there's a lot riding on the Galaxy S8.Here's everything you need to know about Samsung's most important smartphone
column8: ever.Galaxy S8: Near Bezel-Free Infinity Display
column9: No Home ButtonApple isn't the only one working tobanish bezels and buttonsfrom its phones. Samsung had the same idea and this year it's taken big steps in that direction. Its new Galaxy flagship has no side bezels - just screen right to the curved edge - and its greatly reduced them at the top and bottom. It calls this the Infinity Display - a nameDellsort of already coined with its XPS 13 laptop.This requires a pressure-sensitive virtual home button located beneath the display
column10: and moving the fingerprint scanner to the back. The hardware buttons along the edges do remain
column11: resulting in a huge display housed within a relatively small form factor. Although
column12: adding vertical space has resulted in a ""stretched"" aspect ratio. Samsung does note it has worked with Google to ensure that extra screen real estate gets used. The display isn't just big
column13: it's sharp and is the first to get mobile HDR certification.Two SizesThe Galaxy S8 comes in two sizes. This time the Galaxy S8+ features the same design as its smaller sibling (unlike last year where the larger model got a curved Edge display)
column14: built around the Infinity Display. With that new design
column15: the plus model offers a whopping 6.2-inch display
column16: while even the standard Galaxy S8 has a 5.8-inch screen - without getting cumbersome (thanks to minimizing the bezels).The 7 WORST Stocks to Buy Right NowIn comparison
column17: the iPhone 7 Plus display is 5.5-inches.Bixby to Take on Siri and Google AssistantAI-powered virtual assistants have become key features on smartphones. Apple has Siri and Android has Google Assistant - although Google did keep that as a Pixel Phone exclusive for a few months.Likely in response to that Google exclusivity move
column18: last fallSamsung bought Viv
column19: an AI startup from the creators of Siri. That acquisition paid off with Bixby
column20: Samsung's own AI agent. Samsung considers Bixby important enough that the companypreviewed the technologya week before the Galaxy S8 launch
column21: and also gave Bixby a dedicated button on the new Galaxy smartphone.Where Siri and Google Assistant are focused on answering questions and helping users to accomplish tasks
column22: Bixby does this to an extent
column23: but is currently positioned more as a helper to make using supported applications easier.Key Galaxy S8 SpecsAs is expected with a new generation of a smartphone
column24: the new Galaxy receives significant hardware upgrades
column25: including a snappy new CPU.Quad HD+ Super AMOLED Infinity Display with HDR support (5.8-inches and 6.2-inches)Qualcomm

column1: Will Someone Intercept Thursday Night Football From Twitter?;3/29/2017;"Last year
column2: Twitter(NYSE:TWTR) made a big splash when it won the rights to stream 10 of the   NFL's Thursday Night Football games. The social network quickly   sold all of its ad inventory for the games
column3: and it was immensely   profitable for the company (if at a relatively small scale).   Twitter reportedly sought to bring in $50 million in ad revenue   from its content partnership with the NFL
column4: and probably exceeded   its goal. Considering it paid just $10 million for the streaming   rights
column5: that's a good deal.But there's no guarantee the NFL will renew its deal with   Twitter. Other big tech companies likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column6: Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google are also reportedly   interested in the rights as well. Let's take a look at what   Thursday Night Football might mean to each interested   company.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();TwitterTwitter knows what it's getting with the NFL and the NFL knows   what it's getting with Twitter. Twitter has a relatively broad   established global audience that already talks a lot about sports   on its social network. Last year's results show that at least a   few of them are willing to stream the game on the same platform   they go to talk about it.But Twitter's viewership numbers may have been a bit   disappointing
column7: particularly for advertisers. Twitter averaged   just200
column9: 000 viewers per gameon average. Twitter prefers to point to the 3.5 million unique   viewers per game on average
column10: but the television ratings standard   use average audience. By comparison
column11: the television broadcasts   consistently had over 10 million viewers and even topped 20   million viewers on occasion.Those ratings are noteworthy because marketers paid quite a   bit for Twitter's ads -- around $250
column12: 000 for a package of 20 ads   during the games and some pre-roll ads on NFL highlights. That's   nearly half of what advertisers paid for the television   broadcasts to reach an audience about 2% the size. Twitter is   switching toguaranteed viewershipon some video ads
column13: so the NFL deal might not be as lucrative for   Twitter this time around.FacebookFacebook offers similar benefits to the NFL as Twitter
column14: but it   has a scale that's five times larger. While Twitter is generally   considered the place to discuss live sports events
column15: Facebook   still has the potential to attract a much broader and engaged   audience. Facebook boasts that its users spend 50 minutes per day   on average across Facebook
column16: Instagram
column17: and Messenger. With a   broad portfolio of apps
column18: Facebook should be able to promote and   attract a much bigger audience than Twitter.A deal with the NFL could help Facebook seed its dedicated   video section. The company is interested in paying for premium   video content to attract users to watch and upload more video to   the social network. Facebook is also testing midroll video ads to   directly monetize videos on its platform
column19: and Thursday Night   Football could provide a nice playground for the ad format.AmazonWhile Amazon doesn't sport the same audience as Facebook or   even Twitter
column20: it's certainly willing to pay up for the NFL   streaming rights. In fact
column21: it offered $15 million for the rights   last year
column22: $5 million more than Twitter ended up paying. The NFL   ended up going with Twitter for its ability to reach a global   audience.But things have changed at Amazon over the last year. Most   notably
column23: Amazon expanded Prime Video globally in December. It's   also been negotiating for the rights to stream sports that are   less popular in the U.S.
column24: but very popular internationally like   auto racing and soccer. If Amazon can put together a package of   sports rights for its international subscribers
column25: becoming a   destination to stream games
column26: it could convince the NFL to take a   shot with it.Of course
column27: the NFL will likely stipulate that Amazon stream   the games to everyone
column28: not just Prime subscribers. Nonetheless
column29: Amazon could use it as a marketing tool for Prime Video as well   as way to grow itsburgeoning advertising business.YouTubeYouTube is currently facing some backlash for placing ads next   to objectionable content. A deal with the NFL could provide a   boost to YouTube's reputation as a place for premium digital   video content. At the same time
column30: YouTube's current reputation   struggles could deter the NFL from making a deal in the first   place
column31: as the league is very brand conscious.YouTube is making a play for more television ad dollars
column32: particularly with the impending release of YouTube Unplugged
column33: its   over-the-top linear television service. The company will already   be selling television advertising for YouTube Unplugged
column34: and it   could use Google's ad targeting data to maximize its ad revenue.   That factor will put it at the top of the list for its ability to   successfully monetize an investment in Thursday Night Football
column35: which could enable it to come in with the highest bid among the   companies in this article.Overall
column36: each company has a lot to gain from winning the   rights to Thursday Night Football. Twitter certainly has the most   to lose if it doesn't win
column37: considering analysts already expect a   decline in ad revenue this year. The NFL is expected to announce   a winner in the next month or so
column38: since it announced the Twitter   deal last April.10 stocks we like better than TwitterWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column41: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Twitter wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
