column1: 3 Reasons Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Becoming Tougher to Own;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBy most accounts
column3: the future looks bright forApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). Citi recently upped its price target on Apple stock in anticipation of a massive wave of upgrades from iPhone owners who have aging models
column4: and the company's plans to double its high-margin service revenue over the course of the coming four years doesn't seem un-doable.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAfter all
column5: AAPL has been beefing up its app and digital content business at a rather brisk pace for some time now.And yet
column6: to observers not looking at the company through rose-colored glasses
column7: there's potential trouble ahead. Here's a closer look at three headwinds that could slow AAPL shares down more than most traders might expect.Three Troubling Realities for Apple StockLast week
column8: analysts with Citi raised their price target on Apple stock from $140 to $160 per share (maintaining the research outfit's ""Buy"" rating)
column9: thinking a wide swath of the 715 million iPhone owners out there right now are on the verge of finally upgrading their device
column10: as31% of those owners haven't upgraded in a couple of years.It's not bad logic; we know the company's best new customers are its old ones.10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowMeanwhile
column11: though it was little more than an afterthought just a year ago
column12: CEO Tim Cook has put plenty of emphasis on sales of services and digital content. He's only scratched the surface
column13: however. After generating roughly $25 billion in revenue in 2016
column14: Apple is aiming for $50 billion in services revenue by $50 billion. That's still only a fraction of the $215 billion worth of revenue Apple mustered in 2016
column15: but digital sales now make up the company's second-biggest segment; the iPhone is still the biggest.Before we pop the corks on the champagne bottles though
column16: there are three red flags everyone would be wise to process.1. The iPhone 8 (probably) costs too muchWhile the launch of the iPhone 7 in the fall of last year could be considered a success in that the company sold arecord-breaking 78.2 million units in the previous quarter
column17: given thehype surrounding the device
column18: the company should have blown away sales figures for its iPhone 6.Some (many) suspect the demand that should have materialized for the 7 was ultimately displaced to the iPhone 8
column19: which is supposed to be unveiled in September of this year. The word is that the admittedly impressive device is going togo for a cool $1000 each. At that price
column20: even the most loyal of Apple fans could balk.2. The popular smartphone is preemptively cannibalizing itselfAside from sticker shock
column21: would-be owners of the upcoming iPhone 8 may keep their wallet closed for the same reason many potential buyers of the iPhone 7 didn't pull the trigger - they're waiting for the phone after the next phone
column22: which is sure to be even more amazing.To that end
column23: what's currently being referred to as the iPhone 9 already promises (in rumors) to be an amazing piece of hardware
column24: complete with a folding screen. That may postpone purchases of the iPhone 8 later this year
column25: though 2018's iPhone 9 could see softer demand because whispers of the iPhone 10 rumors will be circulating by then.It's a vicious cycle
column26: with Apple arguably unable to ever really log a blowout iPhone launch.Fitbit Has BlackBerry Syndrome (FIT)3. The Google Pixel is really
column27: really impressiveFinally
column28: as solid as the recent Pixel phone fromAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column29: NASDAQ:GOOGL) subsidiary Google was
column30: it wasn't a game-changer. Analysts estimate the companyonly sold about 2.5 million of the device.Bear in mind
column31: however
column32: this is Google's first direct foray into the smartphone world
column33: and could be considered little more than a dry run.The Pixel 2 is slated to debut sometime this year
column34: and it's a good bet the company has made a point of learning a lot with its first outing.Bottom Line for AAPL StockInvariably
column35: some (or several) owners of Apple stock interpret these concerns as a call that the company is doomed
column36: and then proceed to ""colorfully disagree."" So
column37: let me clarify something that shouldn't need saying. That is
column38: even on AAPL stock's worst day it's still essentially unstoppable to other smartphone players. Don't read too much into the worries.On the flipside
column39: in that Apple stock is all too often found on investors' pedestals - lifted there by assumptions that the company is infallible - it's never a bad idea to recognize all plausible risks. These three risks could each end up stirring up surprising headwinds
column40: and nothing takes a toll on a stock like an unexpected disappointment.As of this writing
column41: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You Back7 Future Blue-Chip Stocks You Need to BuyThe post3 Reasons Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Becoming Tougher to Ownappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: About to Buy Driverless Car Stocks? Read This First;3/13/2017;"There's no shortage of technology companies and automotive   makers that are are betting that autonomous vehicles will   transform both of their industries. But how do you figure   out which companies are poised to benefit the most?To answer that
column2: investors first need to know what the market   potential is for driverless cars
column3: what might slow it down
column4: and   how long it will take for the segment to mature
column5: and then   determine which driverless car investment angle they want to   take. Here are a few steps to help you get started:Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();How much the driverless car market will be     worthBy 2025
column6: the driverless car market is expected to be worth $42   billion
column7: according to Boston Consulting Group. The market size   jumps up to $77 billion by 2035
column8: which is the same year thatIHSestimates that there will be 76 million autonomous vehicles   already on the road.And it doesn't end there. Driverless cars are expected to   transform ride sharing services
column9: allow car owners to rent out   their own vehicles -- asTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has suggested -- and even help   traditional carmakers create their own ride hailing services
column10: likeFord(NYSE: F) has proposed.This might slow driverless car stocks downIt's not going to be all sunshine and lollipops for driverless   car stocks though. There are still many hurdles facing these   companies
column11: including federal regulations
column12: safety concerns
column13: and   consumer adoption issues.The two biggest automotive markets
column14: however -- the U.S. and   China -- have thus far been very open to driverless cars. Back in   September
column15: the federal government released guidelines for states   to help ensure that companies are able to innovate and not be   hampered by differing rules across state lines. But the problem   is that we're still in the very early stages of driverless   car technology (i.e. neither you nor I can buy fully autonomous   vehicles)
column16: so while the government is open to it now
column17: that could   change when more tech starts being used by the general   population.And even if the government doesn't end up stifling autonomous   vehicles
column18: there's currently a growing movement toban driverless cars in New Yorkbecause people are afraid they'll eliminate jobs for taxi   drivers
column19: bus drivers and others in the transportation sector. Add   to that the fact that there are parts of the population thatfeel very uneasyabout driverless cars and it's clear that the autonomous vehicle   market still has a long way to go.There are plenty of ways to investCompanies like Tesla are among the obvious choices for betting   on driverless cars. CEO Elon Musk has said he wants to have a   fully autonomous car capable of driving itself across the country   by 2018
column20: and every new Tesla built right now already has the   hardware capabilities for full autonomy (though not all of the   software is activated).Tech behemothAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is another clear choice. Google's   parent company recently spun out its driverless car segment into   its own company
column21: called Waymo
column22: and is working to bring fully autonomous minivans to the roads   this year for public testing
column23: along with a ride-sharing   service.And then there are chipmakers likeNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column24: which is investing heavily in artificial   intelligence and its own supercomputers to power driverless cars.   The company'sDrive PX 2 supercomputeris already used by 80 automakers and automotive suppliers   (including Tesla) and is likely to expand its automotive revenues   substantially in the coming years.Of course
column25: you could go the traditional route too and bet on   automakers like Ford
column26: which is also focusing its attention on   self-driving technologies. The company recently invested $1   billion in a self-driving car start-up
column27: called Argo AI
column28: and says   that it will release its own fully autonomous vehicle (with no   steering wheel!) by 2021.Ford may be taking a slower approach than some other   self-driving tech makers
column29: but it has plans to have 90   self-driving test vehicles on the road this year and is working   with more than 40 start-ups on driverless car technology.And if you're looking for a driverless car stock outside of   the U.S.
column30: thenBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU)  isprobably your best bet. The company has been developing self-driving technology for   years and just launched a test program in some Chinese cities to   implement its tech. The company wants to release a fully   self-driving car by next year with the hopes of having a   ride-hailing service in the coming years. Aside from its   aggressive driverless car approach
column31: Baidu benefits from China's   openness to self-driving technologies and fewer regulations for   road tests than the U.S.Here's how long you might need to wait for this to play     outAlright
column32: so now we know how big this market will be
column33: some of   the potential hurdles
column34: and who the key players are. So how long   will investors have to wait for this opportunity to pan out? IHS   estimates that we'll reach worldwide driverless car ubiquity by   about 2050.That doesn't mean it'll take that long for driverless car   stocks to benefit of course
column35: but it does mean that we still have   a long way to go before the market will mature -- which makes now   the perfect time for investors to start considering driverless   car stocks.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column39: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Nvidia wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Does DISH
column2: Sony
column3: or AT&T Have the Best Live-Streaming Cable Deal?;3/13/2017;"Cable without an actual cable may be the next big thing not   just for cord-cutters looking to save a buck
column4: but also for   consumers looking to leave their current providers without making   a major sacrifice.DISH Network(NASDAQ: DISH) was the first player in the space with the launch   of its live-streaming cable alternative a little over two years   ago.Sony(NYSE: SNE) began testing its own PlayStation Vue in select   markets not long after that and has since taken its cable-like   streaming product national. Most recently
column5: AT&T(NYSE: T) launched DirecTV Now
column6: giving consumers three distinct   choices (not counting the not-yet-launched options from YouTube   and Hulu which are still developing).For consumers it's a lot of choices
column7: but unlike traditional   cable where every company offers roughly the same package
column8: these   three players are somewhat different. That makes determining the   best one a bit of a moving target
column9: but with three players in the   space (and two more coming) it's clearly a buyer's market.makeArticleAd();DISH Sling has the cheapest offer. Image source: DISH.DISH has the lowest base priceFor consumers looking to cut the cord in order to save money   (or those who never had a cord
column10: but are looking for the cheapest   way to have some live-streaming channels) DISH'sSling   TVmay be the answer. The service offers 30 channels including ESPN
column11: CNN
column12: TNT
column13: and a number of other cable favorites for $20 a month   as part of its ""Orange"" package. For $25 a month consumers could   opt for ""Blue"" which drops ESPN but adds the FOX family of   channels including the broadcast network while offering 44 total   choices.On top of the base packages Sling Subscribers can choose from   a number of extra add-ons in areas like news
column14: sports
column15: and kids   programming which cost $5 or $10 each. Sling members can also add   HBO
column16: Cinemax
column17: Starz
column18: or one of a variety of global programming   options which conveniently all work within the same player making   for a very television-like experience.PlayStation Vue is cord-free cableSony's PlayStation Vue has four packages starting at $29.99 a   month. The entry-level offer
column19: ""Access Slim"" comes with 45   channels
column20: including in very-limited markets some broadcast   networks. Most of the stations offered are the same ones Sling TV   has
column21: with consumers paying slightly more money for them. The   ""Core Slim"" package offers 60 channels for $34.99 (perhaps the   best deal) while ""Elite Slim"" comes with 90 channels for $44.99
column22: and Ultra Slim at $64.99 which has the same 90 channels plus HBO   and Showtime.Like Sling
column23: PlayStation Vue also offers add-on packages of   Spanish-language and news programs. In addition users can buy a   number of premium channels on a stand-alone basis along with HBO   and Showtime. The bottom tiers for PS Vue are very similar to   DISH
column24: albeit pricier
column25: while the higher-end tiers are essentially   full-on cable packages (minus the broadcast networks in most   cases) at better-than-cable pricing.Here's what DirecTV is doingAT&T's entree into the space looks a lot like Sony's.   DirecTV Now offers very similar pricing with 60 channels costing   $35
column26: including ABC and FOX
column27: along with some top-tier cable   favorites. $50 a month gets users 80-plus channels
column28: while $60 a   month comes with over 100
column29: and $70 takes the package to over 120   stations including Starz.Subscribers can also add Starz separately to lower-tier deals
column30: or add HBO or Cinemax. AT&T does not offer add-on channel   packages covering specialty stations the way its rivals do. In   addition DirecTV Now launches with better pricing (the $35 price   for the $50 package) and it seems likely that AT&T will offer   future specials likely tied to bundling other services from the   company.Which one is the best?For consumers it's easy to test each service because all offer   free trials
column31: while also letting users come and go as they please   without contracts or penalties. Sling has the best service for   people looking to cut expenses while Sony and AT&T offer good   deals on services that come close to mirroring actual cable. Of   those two
column32: DirecTV Now gets a slight edge because it offers ABC   and FOX nationally while PlayStation Vue only offers access to   broadcast networks selectively.In addition to varying channel selections
column33: all three services   have different rules when it comes to multiple streams. Sling   Orange
column34: the cheapest service
column35: only offers a single stream
column36: while   the $25 Blue packages allows three. DirectTV Now offers two   streams to all subscribers while Sony's service allows customers   to stream on five registered devices at a time giving PS Vue the   advantage in this area
column37: but it's a minor edge over Blue.When it comes to interface all three leave something to be   desired. Sony's service has a DVR (with a lot of limitations)   while Sling has some on-demand programming
column38: as does DirecTV. The   biggest drawback of the streaming services is that none of them   offer an experience that feels like flipping around with   traditional cable. Still
column39: once you have selected a show
column40: the   viewing experience works and feels familiar.Sony and AT&T have decent products that save consumers   some money over the average comparable cable package. But for a   traditional family watching on multiple televisions
column41: the savings   may not be worth the holes in what's offered along with a viewing   experience that still lags traditional cable. Sling has those   same limitations
column42: but the three streams for $25 Blue package   represents the best combo of content and value
column43: giving it a small   victory in an emerging space.10 stocks we like better than DISH NetworkWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Should Apple Inc. Cut Its Dividend? (AAPL);3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is the world's largest technology company
column3: and it once was one of the best growth stocks on the market. It has shifted gears
column4: though
column5: and now Apple stock is one of the more promising dividend growth plays on the market.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrAAPL paid its first dividend - at least since 1995 - on Aug. 16
column6: 2012. It paid investors 38.9 cents per share on a split-adjusted basis.The payout has been hiked four times since
column7: and currently sits at 57 cents per share. That's a compound annual growth rate of 10%
column8: with 2017's dividend increase expected to be similar. After all
column9: AAPL stock only has a payout ratio of 27% of its trailing earnings and a 1.6% yield.When you look at shareholder yield - dividends plus buybacks - Apple's record is even more impressive. The company spent $12.2 billion on dividends and a whopping $29.2 billion on share repurchases in 2016. That works out to a shareholder yield of 5.6%.AAPL is returning capital at a blistering pace.10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the BillsHowever
column10: while most shareholders are ecstatic with the dividend on Apple stock
column11: allow me to present an alternate argument:Apple should cut its payout â€¦ and maybe even eliminate it altogether.Apple
column12: Meet AlphabetLet's take a minute to compare Apple to one of its peers
column13: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL).Alphabet's dividend policy is pretty clear. It saidin its 2016 10-K filing
column14: ""We have never declared or paid any cash dividend on our common or capital stock. We intend to retain any future earnings and do not expect to pay any cash dividends in the foreseeable future.""Alphabet can easily afford a dividend
column15: too. It made $19.5 billion in 2016
column16: or $28.32 per share.The reasoning behind this is simple. Alphabet is aggressively investing in the kinds of projects that can really boost its top line. It has been working on a self-driving car since 2009. It invested more than$6 billion on Google Fiber. Alphabet also teamed up withFidelitytoinvest $1 billion inSpaceX.In total
column17: Alphabet spent $13.9 billion on research and development in 2016
column18: as well as $10.2 billion on capital expenditures.Apple is still investing in the future
column19: but not as aggressively as Alphabet. AAPL spent $10 billion on research and development and $13.5 billion on capital expenditures in 2016
column20: despite making a net profit of $45.7 billion.In other words
column21: Alphabet reinvested $24.1 billion back into its business in 2016 while earning $19.5 billion. Apple reinvested $23.5 billion while earning $45.7 billion. AAPL barely reinvested half of its earnings back into its business.AAPL Needs to Make Some AcquisitionsApple does have some exciting plans. One of the tech world's worst-kept secrets is Apple's plans to somehow be a part of thecar of the future. It has also been working in thevirtual reality space
column22: and many expect big improvements toApple TV. These investments are great. But I don't think they'll be enough to usher in a new era of growth.It's time for Apple to go shopping.Apple could easily take the $41 billion it gave back to shareholders in 2016 and use it to make a huge splash.Say Apple agreed to buyNetflix
column23: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) at a 50% premium to today's price - so
column24: roughly $91 billion. AAPL could pay off the deal in just a few years from its existing cash flow alone
column25: and would own a company that has doubled revenues in the last three years.Intel Corporation (INTC) Buys Mobileye NV (MBLY) to Win the Auto MarketApple's main growth driver today is service revenue. In its most recent quarter
column26: AAPL grew its top line 3% on a quarter-over-quarter basis.It grew services revenue by 18%. Acquiring Netflix would would not only supercharge that division
column27: it would give Apple access to Netflix's whole library of content.The Bottom Line on Apple StockThere's a reason why AAPL trades at the same multiple as the rest of the market. Investors assume - rightfully so - that it is a mature company with no immediate growth prospects. If Apple slashed its dividend and announced it was using that money for acquisitions
column28: investors would sit up and take notice.There's no guarantee such sentiment would send Apple stock soaring right away. In fact
column29: it'd be easy to see the market taking the short-term view that something is amiss
column30: and selling AAPL as a result.But if executed right
column31: such a strategy would make Apple shareholders richer in the long run.As of this writing

column1: Can NVIDIA Regain Its Mojo?;3/13/2017;"It seems somewhat disingenuous referring to a stock that has   rallied roughly 530% over the last five years as having ""lost its   mojo.""However

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Android Smartphones Found With Pre-Installed Malware;3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMalware made the leap from PCs to smartphones along with users. It's always been known that devices runningAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Android operating system are much more susceptible to being infected thanApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones. However
column3: the situation may be even worse than we realized.makeArticleAd();Source: Check Point Software TechnologiesA mobile security research team posted on Friday that it scanned devices owned by two large companies and found Android malwarepre-installedon smartphones from 38 different manufacturers.That discovery should concern both corporate IT departments
column4: and consumers. And it once again validates Apple's ""controlling"" iPhone approach.Android Malware Illustrates the Downside of Google's ApproachFrom the launch of the first iPhone in 2007
column5: Apple retained full control of its iOS operating system and installed it only on its own hardware. Apps can only be downloaded from the App Store and these are checked and vetted by Apple engineers.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackWith limited hardware configurations
column6: Apple is able to test iOS thoroughly for all iPhone users. The company is aggressive about pushing out new iOS versions (79% of all iPhones are running iOS 10)
column7: and in the event of a security issue
column8: it's able to quickly push out system updates to address it.With Android
column9: GOOGL took a very different approach from Apple. It went wide open
column10: licensing Android to dozens of different smartphone manufacturers. Users are free to tinker with the operating system and they can download apps from virtually anywhere - not just Google Play. This open approach helped Google to dominate the smartphone industry
column11: with nine out of 10 new smartphones running Android.But the approach makes smartphone security a nightmare.Android updates often require manufacturer and/or carrier cooperation. As a result
column12: only 2% of Android devices are running the latest version of Android
column13: while the majority are running software that's at least several years out of date.Freedom to install questionable apps plus an older version of the operating system has let Android malware run rampant. At one point it was estimated to account for97% of all mobile malware.Check Point's Pre-Installed Android Malware DiscoveryCheck Point Software Technologies Ltd.(NASDAQ:CHKP)
column14: an IT security company
column15: reported in aFriday blog postthat it had scanned the smartphones for two large companies (identified only as ""large telecommunications company"" and a ""multinational technology company"") and discovered Android malware had been pre-installed on smartphones from 38 different hardware manufacturers.Android malware identified ranged from adware to mobile ransomware capable of encrypting all data on the device until a fee is paid to unlock it. Some had been added to the smartphone ROM
column16: meaning reinstalling Android would not remove it. And none of this malware was downloaded by users. The smartphones arrived at the two companies pre-infected
column17: with installation happening ""somewhere along the supply chain.""Some of the most popularAndroid smartphones from 38 different manufacturers were infected
column18: includingSamsung Electronics Co Ltd's(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) best-selling Galaxy S7. Also caught in the sweep was the Nexus 5 - anLGsmartphone co-developed with Google.The Nexus 5 is several years old
column19: but the Android malware discovered on it had been there since the time of delivery.If a smartphone released in cooperation with Google itself is not immune from being infected before it even reaches the user
column20: then Android's smartphone security issue is even bigger than previously thought.Apple's Long-Term AdvantageThis isn't the first time Android malware has made headlines. Last November
column21: Check Point discovered a widespreadinfection of Android smartphones with HummingBad. This Chinese malware was found to have infected over 10 million Android smartphones worldwide.3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Mobileye NV (MBLY)
column22: Advanced Micro Devices
column23: Inc. (AMD) and Boeing Co (BA)And of course
column24: there was the infamousWikiLeaks CIA dumplast week that shone a light on smartphone security and the tools used by government agencies to bypass it. Several dozen Android vulnerabilities were revealed
column25: along with 14 iOS exploits.The difference is
column26: Apple had addressed most of the iPhone issues in iOS 10
column27: which has widespread adoption. Google may have patched Android
column28: but chances are most Android smartphones out there won't get the update and will remain vulnerable. This latest Android malware discovery shows that the weakness to GOOGL's approach extends all the way to the supply chain. Even the most trusted manufacturers are not immune to having their smartphones compromised before the consumer even gets their hands on them.Google's wide-open Android approach has let it build a commanding 90% smartphone marketshare. But with Android malware increasingly in the spotlight and no easy solution in sight
column29: the stage is set for Apple to press its advantage over GOOGL's approach.Apple built its iPhone empire around premium design
column30: ease of use and plentiful apps. But its advantage in smartphone security may turn out to be the factor that lets it eat into Google's Android lead in the long term.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceTrade of the Day: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)An Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone Factory in America? Maybe Not.How to Trade Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Near All-Time HighsThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Android Smartphones Found With Pre-Installed Malwareappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Voice: The Next Computing Empire;3/11/2017;"This article is the first in a two-part series aimed at     exploring the rapidly developing state of voice computing from     the investor's perspective. In Part I
column2: I discuss why it's now     increasingly clear that the human voice will become society's     next major computing interface
column3: and why it will continue     proliferating through our homes and businesses. In Part II
column4: I'll dive deeper into the new and emerging business models. In     Part II
column5: I'll discuss the various players involved in the race     to commercialize the technology -- those best-positioned to     profit today
column6: those positioning themselves to thrive tomorrow
column7: and those dropping the ball entirely. I'll also dive deeper     into the fascinating business models voice computing will soon     enable
column8: and how those models will evolve as the technology     continues to improve.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();For nearly 40 years
column9: we've seen the computer evolve into an   indispensable accessory of Western society driven by three   powerful technologies that defined their eras and played a   monumental role for investors along the way.The personal computer gave many of us our first glimpse at the   digital world
column10: normalizing the idea that such machines have a   place in our homes and everyday lives. The internet tapped us   into that world
column11: offering us endless floods of information
column12: entertainment
column13: and commerce around which we willingly began   shaping our civilization. And then the smartphone encouraged us   to take that digital world everywhere we go
column14: leaving nothing but   a few taps on a touchscreen between us
column15: our computers
column16: and   constant immersion.Now
column17: a fourth technology -- voice computing--is removing that last barrier.Reimagining the roles computers playImagine driving down the highway
column18: coming home from work
column19: and     without taking your hands off the wheel or hitting any buttons
column20: asking your car to turn up the heat in your house
column21: preheat the     oven for dinner
column22: and play your favorite album
column23: all in the same     breath. Picture negotiating with a street vendor in Beijing
column24: having your phone translate the entire conversation between     Mandarin and English out loud
column25: so you can haggle in real time.     Or how about a stuffed animal that can tell your daughter     interactive stories every night before bed
column26: reshaping the     adventure at every twist and turn based on her responses and     reactions.These aren't hypothetical scenarios -- they're happening     right now.The human voice is well on its way to becoming the next     major medium we use to interact with computers
column27: and as we'll     explore in this two-part series
column28: voicecomputingis the burgeoning field of technology making it possible.     Already spanning multiple consumer and enterprise ventures     (think call center routing
column29: digital dictation
column30: or the virtual     assistants on smartphones)
column31: the industry's ultimate aim is     enabling people to carry on hands-free
column32: conversational-style     interactions with computers.It's an ambitious prospect capable of significantly     expanding the roles computers play in our everyday lives
column33: but     it's also one that appears inevitable when considering the     trajectory computers have taken
column34: without fail
column35: since their     introduction
column36: evolving in shape and form around contemporary     technology to solve unmet needs.Image Source: Getty ImagesAnd yet voice computing's evolution is different. Unlike any     form of computing to come before it
column37: the technology bypasses     the physical realm
column38: allowing users to query the internet
column39: manage their surroundings
column40: and connect to third-party services     without ever having to touch a physical device -- all in the     time it takes to form a sentence.If that sounds unnecessary
column41: then consider just how limitless     the applications could be. From the surgeon who needs to     rapidly adjust the conditions of her operating room     mid-procedure
column42: to the disabled veteran who simply hopes to     access the appliances in his home. The sheer number of everyday     applications for such a technology has prompted Grand View     Research to project the global market for voice recognition     technology will reach $128 billion annually by 2024
column43: an     estimate that may undershoot the overall economic opportunity     at play considering the potential verticals include healthcare
column44: defense
column45: entertainment
column46: consumer goods
column47: and more (I'll discuss     these in more detail in Part II).There is one thing we can be certain of
column48: however. Voice     computing is extremely likely to transform the way we interact     with technology in society
column49: but before that can happen
column50: a     large-scale societal shift toward adopting the interface must     occur
column51: a shift thatcannotoccur until several key hurdles are overcome.Understanding the challenges aheadTo analyze those obstacles
column52: let's turn to the most       promising application of voice-driven technology today:       virtual digital assistants.Data Sources: Socratic Technologies
column53: Vantiv
column54: Statista.         Chart by AuthorThanks to the success of the iPhone andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) other devices
column55: Siri is currently the most       wildly used virtual assistant in the United States
column56: but until       recently
column57: it's also perfectly exemplified what's holding       voice computing back. To put it simply
column58: speaking with Siri       can often feel more like a novelty than a time-saver
column59: a       sentiment shared not just among Apple users
column60: but most       smartphone owners with access to similar voice computing       technology.It's a problem we can break down into three fundamental       hurdles.The first is that users must often resort to awkward       combinations of hyper-specific phrasing and hurried       robo-speak to have their speech accurately recognized. Andrew       Ng
column61: chief scientist atBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) and one the most respected names in the field
column62: perhaps put it best in 2015 when he noted
column63: ""Speech       recognition
column64: depending on the circumstances
column65: is say 95 per       cent accurate. So maybe it gets one word in 20 wrong. That's       really annoying if it gets one in 20 wrong and you probably       don't want to use it very often. That's probably where speech       recognition is today.""The second hurdle is that even when our speech iscorrectlyrecognized
column66: there still remains a strong chance it will bemisinterpretedwhile undergoing natural language understanding
column67: a process in       which the assistant attempts to comprehend what we want using       the sequence of words (and eventually
column68: the tone
column69: pace
column70: and       inflection) we give. And even if that speech is correctly       understood
column71: an assistant may still simply be unable to solve       for the request due to technical constraints. Examples of       both cases can be seen in the screenshot below
column72: along with a       sense of how frustrating the encounter can be.Image Source: Author's iPhoneEncounters like these make us feel as though we're wasting       our time trusting our phones to do what we could have done       ourselves with only a little more effort upfront. Over time
column73: they build up
column74: eventually discouraging us from even tryingto       use our assistants for anything complex
column75: instead relying on       them only for the most trivial of tasks
column76: like setting alarms       or creating reminders.Thankfully
column77: these first two hurdles are solvable with data
column78: third-party partnerships
column79: and time
column80: each of which the major   players in this space have been actively accruing for years.   Returning to our example
column81: since Siri was introduced to the world   in 2011
column82: virtual assistants have grown far more capable of   correctly interpreting requests thanks to advances in deep   learning
column83: a thriving field of AI being utilized byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column84: Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column85: Baidu
column86: and others to improve speech recognition
column87: natural language understanding
column88: and other components of voice   computing at astounding rates. (Click herefor an outstanding story byThe New York Timeson Google's significant role in making this happen).Equally as important
column89: decisions by Apple and its competitors   to open their platforms up to third-party services have made   today's voice-based assistants feel far more capable than in   years past. These decisions allow Siri
column90: for example
column91: to call you   a ride using your Uber account
column92: or order a pizza through your   storedDomino'sinformation -- not unlike anactualsecretary would do.As the potential behind voice computing becomes increasingly   obvious in the coming months and years
column93: we should expect more and   more third parties to hop on board
column94: eventually expanding the   scope of what a partnership could entail (instead of ordering an   Uber
column95: imagine ordering a plane ticket). One look at the rate of   growth for third-party commands available on Amazon's voice-based   assistant
column96: Alexa
column97: can tell us a lot.Data Source: Voicebot. Chart by AuthorWith time
column98: these technical achievements and partnerships will   continue compounding
column99: eventually making for a highly practical   voice computing experience. Even marginal improvements in the   technology will convince users to begin using voice as an   interface more frequently. In the same talk regarding the current   state of the voice industry
column100: Ng went on to say
column101: ""I think that as   speech recognition accuracy goes from say 95 per cent to 98
column103: all of us in the room will go from barely using it   today
column104: to using it all the time."" He added
column105: ""Most people   underestimate the difference between 95 and 99 per cent ... 99   per cent is a game changer.""Although we're not yet able to predict when the technology   will reach that point
column106: if the recent pace of progress is any   indication -- since Ng's speech
column107: Baidu has built a program   capable of dictating English three times faster
column109: than human beings -- it won't be much longer.In the meantime
column110: an arguably far more important hurdle stands   in the way. It's a problem shared by every other major computing   medium in use today
column111: only voice is actually solving for it.An instantaneous computing experienceNo matter the medium
column112: we've always interacted with computers   by issuing commands. In the 1950s
column113: we meticulously punched those   commands into cards before feeding them into hulking machines.   Now
column114: technology allows us to simply type
column118: speak them and expect a result.Yet despite these advancements
column119: today's mediums still subject   users to a unique set of delays
column120: a sort of friction that   inherently slows down the process betweenthinkinga command and actually being able tocommunicatethat command to your devices. A decade ago
column121: that friction most   likely entailed tracking down a PC with internet
column122: using the mouse   to open a browser
column123: using the keyboard to run a search
column124: and then   sorting for the result. But today
column126: it simply   means reaching into our pockets for our phone
column128: and tapping away.It's a process so effortless
column129: the average American now checks   their phone an estimated 46 times per day. It's even become   fashionable to argue there's no longerenoughfriction separating society from our devices; that we'retooplugged in to the digital world.So when you consider that voice computing's primary advantage   iseliminatingfriction
column130: it becomes tempting to dismiss the technology as a   solution to a trivial problem. What that argument critically   fails to consider
column132: is that friction is about more than   simple convenience
column133: and that any amount of friction
column135: fundamentally limits the dynamic between a user and   their computing medium in two ways.Let's take the smartphone for example.Image Source: PixabayThe seemingly trivial motions we make when reaching for our   phone still require us to be in immediate proximity of the   device. We have to walk over to kitchen counter if we left our   phone there; we have to remember it's on the counter even before   we can do that. Then
column137: we're   required to physically handle it
column138: a process that generally   requires we have one hand free and able.That may not sound like much
column139: but these limitations force our   computing experience to revolve around the location of our   device
column140: as opposed to it revolving around us.They can create roadblocks for those with disabilities affecting   their vision or hands (or really
column141: even those who just have sticky   hands
column144: those far away from their   device
column146: those with an immediate computing   need.There's a reason speech is our most instinctual form of   communication.If we have a question
column147: and if we know those around us can   answer that question
column148: we don't pull out our phone and run a   search
column149: we open our mouths and ask. We do that because it's   instantaneous. Now contrast that with having to locate your   phone
column150: having to type in your password
column151: having to navigate to an   app
column154: or speak your command. These behaviors   are not instinctual
column155: but we put up with them because the people around us usually   don't have the answers
column156: and because smartphones are our best   alternative.But they don't have to be.The rise of voiceIt's not obvious quite yet
column157: but today's physically bound   mediums have left a large hole to fill and voice computing is   starting to fill it.Over the past two years
column158: the technology has begun manifesting   itself in the form of always-on
column159: always-listening devices able to   virtually bypass the friction inherent in today's major computing   mediums. Currently
column160: these devices are best exemplified by   Amazon's line of Echo smart speakers
column161: which employ far-field   voice recognition technology allowing users to command Alexa from   across multiple rooms and through various background noises at   any time simply by calling for it out loud.Image Source: Amazon.com.Put another way
column163: Amazon's Echo is giving   consumers their first glimpse at a frictionless computing   experience. Following its initial setup
column165: no looking around for the device
column166: and no navigating   through screens to issue a command. When it works correctly (like   Siri
column167: Alexa is still very much in its infancy and subject to   misinterpreting commands) it really does allow users to convert   their thoughts to a command in the time it takes to form a   sentence
column168: capturing the essential promise of voice as a   medium.And if the early estimated adoption rate for the device is any   indication -- Amazon hasn't officially released sales   figures
column170: Consumer Intelligence Research   Partners (CIRP) estimates a staggering 8.2 million Echos have   already been sold in the U.S. (a number that pales in comparison   to Morgan Stanley's estimates of over 11 million)
column171: suggesting the   device has achieved well over 5% household penetration -- early   demand for a seamless computing experience is strong
column172: and will   likely grow stronger as capable competitors race to introduce   their own offerings (see Google's Home
column177: and third-party   support continue improving at rapid pace.Data Sources: VoiceLabs
column180: InfoScout. *2017     figures are VoiceLab projections. Chart by AuthorTo be clear
column181: these devices will never replace today's existing   computing mediums
column182: but will rather augment them. While   screens will remain the preferred medium for our more detailed   and visual computing needs
column183: voice will begin its ascent by taking   on an increasing share of our more ""conversational"" demands
column184: common requests we want addressed with the immediacy we expect   from dialogue (""Cancel my doctor's appointment."" ""Pause that   music!"" ""What's a good non-fiction book to read on the beach? ...   Great
column185: order that one."")As the technology grows capable of handling increasingly   nuanced and complex requests
column186: and as voice-enabled devices   proliferate and evolve
column187: we can expect more users to grow   comfortable engaging with the technology around the home
column189: and gradually more pervasive aspects of society.Andthat'swhere the real opportunities begin.The opportunity at handSome of the biggest tech empires in modern history have been   built around the personal computer
column192: each of which has provided the infrastructure for technology to   penetrate deeper and more reflexively into everyday life
column193: allowing creative companies to reach consumers in entirely new   ways.In just 10 years
column194: the iPhone helped Apple grow to become the   largest corporation in the world
column195: but it also popularized   smartphone technology in the U.S.
column196: helping to create the   infrastructure that in turn enabledFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column203: and countless others to create businesses that   reach deeper into our lives than any before.Image Source: Author's iPhoneAnd yet voice technology is going deeper.It's becoming an invisible
column205: weaving itself more seamlessly into the fabric of   our lives than any before it. It's called on using our most   instinctual
column207: and it's accessible   in the time it takes to form words. It's a technology that   provides tomorrow's innovators a far more intimate and pervasive   way to help us satisfy our digital wants.It's a startling but increasingly inevitable reality for both   investors and society.In Part II: The Playing Field
column208: I'll discuss various players   involved in the race to commercialize voice computing. To be the   first to know when Part II is released

column1: The 5 Biggest Challenges to the Driverless Car Revolution;3/11/2017;"The year 2017 is gearing up to be a momentous year for the   driverless car race. But despite major initiatives by   megacorporationsAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column2: Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column3: and others
column4: there are major road blocks ahead   for the driverless car revolution. A recentMcKinseyreport highlights five of them.1. PricingNo matter how incredible an innovation might be
column5: it's useless   if it's not affordable. Although Alphabet's Waymo has clocked   more than 2 million road miles in its autonomous vehicles
column6: McKinsey estimates that self-driving cars are ""unlikely to be   available before 2020."" Alphabet and others are inching closer to   commercializing their products. A partnership withFiat Chrysler Automobiles NV(NYSE: FCAU) will
column7: for the first time
column8: take Alphabet's autonomous   driving technology out of its peculiar ""panda car"" and into 100   Pacifica Hybrid minivans in early 2017. But those minivans aren't   for sale
column9: and
column10: if they were
column11: would probably cost magnitudes more   than an average minivan.2. Consumer UnderstandingmakeArticleAd();Video source: Waymo viaYouTubeEven if driverless cars become affordable
column12: no one will buy   them if they don't understand them. That means that self-driving   car companies need to educate consumers on the advantages of   autonomous vehicles. Informational videos like the one above   produced by Alphabet's Waymo are an important start
column13: and others   like Tesla Motors are producing their ownvideo vignettesto make self-driving cars salient. Tesla Motors and others have a   clear business incentive to make self-driving seem mainstream
column14: and the more that their message is spread
column15: the brighter the   future for their sales and sustainability.3. Safety/Security issuesConsumer understanding goes hand in hand with a major concern   about autonomous technology -- safety and security. At no point   was this clearer than in May 2016
column16: when Tesla Motors reported the   first driver fatality while its Autopilot technology was engaged.   The tragic crash occurred when neither the driver nor Tesla   Motors' technology recognized a truck's white-colored trailer   crossing its path on a highway. There will certainly be more   tragedies in the future of autonomous vehicles
column17: and it will   remain a continuing challenge and the highest priority for   self-driving car companies to minimize safety and security   issues. However
column18: it's also important to remember that these   high-profile cases can cause over-reactions
column19: and sticking to   statistics can help investors
column20: companies
column21: and consumers alike   identify the best autonomous option for investing
column22: manufacturing
column23: and purchasing.4 & 5: Regulation and TechnologyAs with all new innovations
column24: regulation and technology can   make or break a revolution. The McKinsey report is quick to note   that regulation is a hurdle
column25: rather than a never-ending issue. It   makes sense
column26: then
column27: that Ford
column28: Alphabet
column29: Lyft
column30: Uber
column31: and Volvo   Cars have all joined together to create the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets."" Rather than rally for ""wild west"" free market competition
column32: these companies want to see a sensible framework of standardized   regulation upon which they can confidently build their new   business units.Technology isn't a hurdle
column33: but there is a minimum threshold   below which driverless cars will never be the norm. Companies   like Alphabet's Waymo and Tesla Motors are aiming for full   autonomy
column34: while others are taking the more step-wise approach of   offering semi-autonomous additions like Audi's ""Traffic Jam   Assist."" The McKinsey report estimates that
column35: once regulation and   technology issues have been resolved
column36: ""up to 15 percent of new   cars sold in 2030 could be fully autonomous.""Hit the brakes?Image Source: Getty Images.2017 will not be the year self-driving cars take over our   roads. Pricing
column37: consumer understanding
column38: safety/security
column39: regulation
column40: and technology issues will continue to impede this   industry's revolution. But Alphabet
column41: Tesla Motors
column42: and others are   making steady gains on addressing these issues
column43: and the ultimate   widespread adoption of autonomous technology is almost   inarguable. Forward-looking investors with long-term horizons   should acknowledge these issues
column44: select their self-driving stocks   accordingly
column45: and sit back to enjoy this multi-year market road   trip.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Soars Amid Potential for More Closings;3/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSears Holdings Corp(NASDAQ:SHLD) shares were up by double digits on Friday amid what appears to be optimism over the possibility of more store closures prompting a short squeeze in SHLD stock.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrSears is coming off afourth-quarter beat on the top and bottom lines
column3: but with still-horrid numbers. Revenues in Q4 were down more than 16% to $6.1 billion
column4: and the company lost $607 million.Nonetheless
column5: SHLD stock rebounded by 7%-plus Thursday
column6: and now is up another 15% on Friday.Business Insider's Hayley Peterson writes that the company's conference call points to thepossibility of more store closings and sales. CFO Jason Hollar said:""We have a valuable real estate portfolio
column7: which at the end of the fourth quarter comprised 1
column8: 050 leases with significant optionality
column9: as well as 380 owned stores
column10: many in prominent locations. We will continue to assess opportunities to right-size our store footprint and inventory levels aligned to our ongoing transformation to an asset-light integrated retail model.""Hayley surmises that ""By highlighting the leases with optionality
column11: Hollar seems to be suggesting the point that Sears can find ways to either partially or entirely get out of those leases before they expire. Meanwhile
column12: the owned stores can be sold for cash.""3 Short Squeeze Stocks That Are Ready to Fly MUCH HigherSHLD has knocked its store count down by nearly 600 stores over the past five years as it tries to repay debt amid a failure to turn around the core business.The short-term optimism in SHLD stock appears to be scaring what is an overwhelmingly bearish crowd. Roughly 84% of Sears' float was sold short as of the most recent data
column13: good for a short ratio of 8.52 - basically

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe past couple of weeks have been â€¦ well
column4: interesting ones forAdvanced Micro Devices
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) shareholders. AMD stock
column6: after more than quintupling over the course of the prior 12  months
column7: fell 16% in just four days a week ago and has struggled to pick itself up off the mat in the meantime.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrThe prod for the pullback? Reports that its new (and well-hyped) computer processor wasn't performing quite as well as expected once put to the test in real-world applications.As Ars Technica reviewer Mark Walton put it:""The [Ryzen] 1800X lags behind its Intel counterparts in gaming
column8: regardless of whether it's running at the same clock speed or higher.""It was a real blow to optimistic investors
column9: who had bid AMD stock up in a big way on hopes that the new CPU would be the centerpiece of a turnaround story. Now that story is in question.Thing is
column10: the Ryzen may not be as central to the company's rebound as it's been made it to be. Indeed
column11: Advanced Micro Devices has a lot more going for it besides the new CPU that investors aren't giving it credit for. Three specific items come to mind. Note than a handful of AMD's competitors are now becoming partners.3 Things AMD Still Has Going For ItWhile investors had high expectations for Ryzen
column12: the future for Advanced Micro Devices isn't dependent on it. In fact
column13: there are three other areas that may end up meaning even more for its top and bottom lines.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIn no particular order â€¦Penetrating the Cloud Market:While AMD has always had a presence in most key tech markets
column14: cloud computing was never a key one for the company. That's changing now thoughâ€¦ a ball that got rolling just in the past few weeks. In November
column15: Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google division tapped AMD
column16: looking to add its graphical processor units to Google's machine learning architecture.It's a curious development
column17: as GPU chips weren't designed to do anything more than handle a computer's display screen. As it turns out
column18: though
column19: its GPUs are very capable of parallel computing
column20: which is a critical aspect of this new cloud-based function.In the meantime
column21: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) selected AMD processors to power its next-generation open course cloud platform.At stake is a piece of the cloud infrastructure market worth an estimated $300 billion per year.More Licensing Revenue:It's only an unconfirmed rumor thus far
column22: but a reasonably credible one. That is
column23: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) is reportedly interested in using AMDs Radeon graphics technology to power Intel's integrated GPUs in future computers â€¦ displacingNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA). The agreement between Nvidia and Intel ends at the end of March.At the very least
column24: the prospect of such an IP licensing deal could mean a couple hundred million dollars in annual high-margin revenue. If Intel really wants to step up its game
column25: though
column26: it could help fund improvements in the way its CPUs handle graphics.New GPUs Will Enhance New CPU Revenue:While the reviews for the new Ryzen processor have been mixed
column27: AMD stock holders should bear in mind that they're only half the next generation of hardware for Advanced Micro Devices.The other half of the one-two punch combination for AMD this year is the new Vega GPU
column28: which should be unveiled around the middle of this year.As was noted back on Feb. 7:""Vega
column29: is a second-generation high bandwidth memory (or HBM2) design found on a stacked-memory architecture that performs significantly better than the more common GDDR5 (double data rate type-five) utilized by most graphics processing units today. An essentially-infinite amount of memory can be dedicated to handling the display - the maximum virtualization is capped at a ridiculous 512 terabytes. This platform is about twice as powerful as most current alternatives
column30: and will make Advanced Micro Devices competitive with the newest generation of GPU architecture from Nvidia
column31: called Pascal.""More important
column32: Vega was largely built with the Ryzen processor in mend
column33: with each getting the most performance out of one another.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock Is the Perfect Buy at This PriceIn the meantime
column34: it's not like the Ryzen CPU is a lost cause.As the company's CEO Lisa Su recently explained
column35: ""We hear people on wanting to see improved 1080p performance and we fully expect that Ryzen performance in 1080p will only get better as developers get more time with 'Zen.' We have over 300+ developers now working with 'Zen' and several of the developers for Ashes of Singularity and Total [War:] Warhammer are actively optimizing now.""Bottom Line for AMD StockAs encouraging as the future may be for the company whether or not Ryzen ends up performing well
column36: there's still no denying that AMD stock is overbought and ripe for some profit-taking; that 16% dip is nothing compared to 2016's huge rally.But don't confuse any future weakness from AMD as evidence of what's in store
column37: results-wise
column38: from the company. Advanced Micro Devices is very well positioned for a great 2017. The trick is just being patient enough to wait for a truly palatable entry price. That could still be well below the recent low.In other words
column39: you don't want to step into AMD stock for the long haul until it's almost uncomfortable to do so. We aren't there yet.As of this writing

column1: Why Excluding Snap From the S&P 500 Is a Big Deal;3/9/2017;"Snap's(NYSE: SNAP) decision to issue non-voting shares through its   IPO may already have cost it billions of dollars in investor   support.A group of institutional investors have approached stock index   providers S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI to bar the shares   from becoming part of several major indexes. Their argument is   that one of the criteria for inclusion in the indexes is ""a   corporate governance structure consistent with U.S. practice.""   Snap's corporate structure is quite unusual
column2: with the founders   holding about 90% of the voting rights
column3: and average investors   holding no votes at all.Excluding Snap shares from the S&P 500 may not sound like   a big deal -- it doesn't affect the underlying fundamentals of   the company. But the growing popularity of index funds and ETFs   means Snap will miss out on billions of dollars of buyer support   that early investors may have been expecting down the road.makeArticleAd();Image source: Spectacles.com.$6 trillion and growingIndex funds and ETFs are expected to overtake actively managed   investments in the next seven years or so
column4: according to Moody's.   Currently
column5: investors have plowed $6 trillion in assets into the   passive investments. $2 trillion of those assets track the   S&P 500 index.Getting added to the S&P 500 is a big deal. WhenAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) was added to the S&P 500
column6: it   received an immediate 7% bump in its share price.Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) received a 4% boost upon the news that it would have   a place in the index.What's more
column7: the stocks continued to benefit for some time as   active funds that are benchmarked against the index were   compelled to buy more shares of the heavily weighted stocks.   Alphabet and Facebook are two of the largest companies in the   S&P 500. Snap
column8: with its market cap floating around $30   billion
column9: would be more moderately weighted than both
column10: but it   would still see similar benefits.Snap knew this was a possibilityIn Snap's S-1 filing with the SEC
column11: it wrote that it couldn't   predict whether its decision to make its Class A shares   non-voting ""will result in adverse publicity or other adverse   consequences."" Certainly
column12: it saw it as a possibility
column13: and it even   noted that no other company has made an IPO with non-voting   shares.While Snap's capital structure is different from those of most   U.S. companies
column14: it's worth noting that it's not the only company   with non-voting shares. In fact
column15: Alphabet has two publicly traded   share classes -- one voting and one non-voting -- and it's   included in the S&P 500. Likewise
column16: Facebook plans to issue   two non-voting (Class C) shares to current shareholders of any   class under its approved stock split plan.But the fact that investors cannot buy voting shares of Snap   on the open market makes its situation unique.How will it impact investors?While having buyer support in the form of institutional   investors is a nice insurance policy
column17: it's not the only thing   that matters. After all
column18: the primary driver of a stock's value is   the underlying company's performance. If Snap can continue   growing its user base and revenue at a rapid clip
column19: the share   price should inevitably climb to meet its fundamental   performance.There are a lot of question marks surrounding Snap
column20: especially   in light of the recent slowdown in user growth seemingly brought   on by the increased intensity of Facebook's competition. The   potential for several major indexes to exclude the stock make it   even riskier.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column21: it can pay to listen. After all
column22: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column23: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column24: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Snap Inc. wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column26: an executive at Alphabet
column27: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Adam Levyhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A and C shares) and     Facebook. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: 1 Top Small-Cap Stock to Buy Now;3/9/2017;"Small-cap stocks can deliver explosive gains -- or sizable   losses. Choose well

column3: and a small-cap stock can produce painful losses
column4: up to   and including a complete loss of capital should the business be   forced into bankruptcy.That's why it's so important to invest in only the best of   these businesses -- those poised to benefit from undeniable   long-term trends and enjoy the largest growth opportunities. Read   on to learn about one such business that meets these challenging   criteria -- and that is one of the small-cap stocks best   positioned to reward investors in the years ahead.Image source: Mindbody.makeArticleAd();Mindbody(NASDAQ: MB) provides cloud-based software solutions to the   health and wellness industry: Think spas
column5: yoga studios
column6: and   fitness classes. It's a massive market that's gone largely   underserved -- and Mindbody is working to address that need.Mindbody's all-in-one solution helps its clients manage nearly   every aspect of their businesses. Need to post an online class   schedule and allow your clients to book appointments through   their smartphones? Mindbody has you covered. Want an easy way to   manage your employees' schedules? No problem. How about   processing payments? Mindbody can help you with that
column7: too.With plans starting at just $75 per month
column8: Mindbody's   offerings are affordable even for start-ups with the most limited   financial resources. And an increasing number of larger   businesses are utilizing Mindbody's more extensive -- and   higher-priced -- packages. In this way
column9: Mindbody is able to scale   its business along with the success of its customers.More than 60
column10: 000 businesses have turned to Mindbody's platform   for these solutions. That's up from less than 34
column11: 000 subscribers   in the first quarter of 2014. During this time
column12: Mindbody's   revenue has nearly doubled from $70 million in 2014 to $139   million last year.Still
column13: Mindbody isnot yet profitable
column14: which is likely why its stock is currently trading for around   $27; properly valuing early-stage growth companies can be   difficult. But at that price
column15: Mindbody's current $1.1 billion   market cap drastically understates its market potential. The   60
column16: 000 businesses Mindbody currently serves are just a tiny   fraction -- about 1.5% -- of the 4.2 million wellness businesses   that the company says exists around the world. And its $139   million in revenue is just a smidgeon of the $9.5billionthat Mindbody estimates as the current size of its addressable   market -- a market that itself is growing
column17: as more people come to   understand the benefits of fitness and overall healthier living.   That's a massive untapped opportunity that could offer Mindbody   years -- and potentially even decades -- of strong growth.Mindbody's powerful network effects should allow it to capture   the lion's share of this immense market. Each new user expands   the base of potential customers for Mindbody's business clients
column18: and each business that joins Mindbody's platform increases the   number of wellness offerings that users can choose among. It's a   virtuous cycle that should continue to grow stronger as Mindbody   expands its user and subscriber counts in the coming years.To further strengthen its ecosystem
column19: Mindbodyreached a dealwithUnder Armour(NYSE: UA) (NYSE: UAA) that lets the more than 180 million users   of Under Armour's MyFitnessPal app sign up for classes offered by   Mindbody's subscribers. Mindbody also has apartnership withAlphabet's Google(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) allowing people in several major   cities to book classes listed on Mindbody directly through Google   Search and Maps. These two titans choosing to partner with   Mindbody is a major vote of confidence for its platform
column20: and I   wouldn't be surprised if a company like Under Armour makes a bid   for Mindbody at some point in the future.All told
column21: Mindbody is a leader in a huge and expanding   industry with the ability to grow its market share exponentially   in the years ahead. And at current prices
column22: Mindbody offers   long-term investors a chance atmultibagger-type returnsin the coming decade. That makes this currently small-cap stock a   great buy today.10 stocks we like better than MindbodyWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column23: it can pay to listen. After all
column24: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column25: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column26: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Mindbody wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column27: 2017Joe Tenebrusohas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool     recommends Mindbody. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column2: Acquires Kaggle;3/9/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle announced the acquisition of Kaggle
column3: an operator of data science and machine learning competition platform
column4: at the Google Cloud Next conference in San Francisco.Founded in 2010
column5: Kaggle's platform enables data scientists to conduct machine learning contests
column6: host data sets and write and share codes. Over the years
column7: Kaggle has become the world's largest data science community
column8: leveraging on its early mover advantage and focusing on a niche market.Earlier this month
column9: Google and Kaggle hosted a $100
column10: 000 machine learning competition around classifying YouTube videos.In recent times
column11: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning has helped Google in launching innovative products and services for multiple industries. Machine learning is also helping the company to overcome bigger challenges such as improving energy efficiency of data centers.We believe that continuous focus on innovation is likely to drive the Alphabet's stock price going ahead. The shares have appreciated 16.7% in the last one year compared with the ZacksInternet-Servicesindustry'sgain of 14.1%.Google Gearing Up Against Microsoft and AmazonWith more than 0.8 million data scientists on the platform
column12: Kaggle opens up an opportunity for Google to broaden its reach within the data science community and be on an equal footing with Amazon'sAMZNAWS and Microsoft'sMSFTAzure that also offer data science services.As Alphabet generates significant cash from operations and also holds a huge cash balance
column13: management has the flexibility to pursue growth in any area that exhibits true potential. It has the scale and resources to match up to its competitors.Buying Kaggle could also boost Google's recruiting efforts
column14: giving it access to a large pool of scientists.Alphabet Inc. PE Ratio (TTM)Alphabet Inc. PE Ratio (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteKaggle Eyes Infrastructure
column15: Scalability and Improved   ServicesAccording to Kaggle co-founder and chief executive Anthony Goldbloom
column16: the acquisition will help Kaggle better serve its community with more powerful infrastructure
column17: scalable training and deployment services and the capacity to store and query large data sets.The Kaggle team will join Google Cloud but operate as a distinct brand.To ConcludeGoogle's innovations outside the core search business include healthcare (partnership with Johnson & Johnson for the development of surgical robots)
column18: self-driving cars (partnership with Ford)
column19: cloud computing and drones
column20: all being driven significantly by machine learning. We believe that the company has the financial muscle to overcome any short-term adverse conditions to continue pursuing these initiatives.Zacks Rank & Stocks to ConsiderCurrently

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Is Betting BIG on Google Cloud in 2017;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCloud services are a big business that is only getting bigger. When you think of the cloud
column3: the one company that tends to immediately come to mind isAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) - if for no other reason than when its AWS cloud servers go down
column5: half the internet seems to go with them. ButAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) is betting big on the cloud too
column6: and at its Next 2017 event
column7: the company had some big announcements.makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleGoogle cloud is celebrating some much-needed wins
column8: including new partners
column9: a significant steal for G Suite and recognition for topping cloud providers in 2016 for reliability.Google Cloud Takes Aim at AWS
column10: AzureThe public cloud is currently dominated by Amazon's AWS
column11: withover 30% of the market- triple the footprint of second-placeMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Azure. Google cloud is in fourth place
column12: trailingInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM).The cloud is a huge market already and it's expected to get far larger
column13: quickly. Forrester recently pegged the expected value of the public cloud - services like AWS
column14: Azure and Google Cloud - toreach $236 billion by 2020.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonAnd Google wants a bigger piece of that pie.At its Next 2017 conference keynote
column15: the company made the case for choosing Google cloud over AWS or Azure. While noting that it has invested $30 billion in its cloud services
column16: the company rattled off an impressive list of companies that haverecently made the move to Google cloud.eBay Inc.(NASDAQ:EBAY) andColgate-Palmolive Company(NYSE:CL) represent the large corporate side of Google cloud's capabilities
column17: while popular apps likePokemon GoandSnap Inc.'s(NYSE:SNAP) Snapchat show off its suitability for hosting consumer apps.Google cloud's head Diane Greene
column18: took the opportunity to fire a shot at Amazon's AWS and the bad PR it's received for large-scale outages. Chances are
column19: you were affected by anAWS issue at the end of Februarythat slowed or took down thousands of websites
column20: apps and services for hours.Greene noted that Google cloud has been recognized for topping all cloud service providers in availability for 2016. She puts that availability level at 99.999% reliability
column21: which is very impressive.It certainly makes a case for switching from AWS.Big Wins for Google Cloud
column22: and G SuiteSeveral big wins for Google cloud were also touted at Next 2017.SAP SE (ADR)(NYSE:SAP) is the world leader in enterprise resource planning software
column23: counting over 345
column24: 000 companies as customers. Many large corporations rely on SAP software and it's big enough to be hosting its own cloud services. However
column25: it has signed on for its SAP HANA database to be hosted on Google cloud
column26: instead of at its own data centers.AsTechCrunchnotes
column27: Microsoft and Amazon already had deals signed with SAP. Beating AWS and Azure to host HANA has an even greater significance given that the competition already had an established relationship with SAP.Drop Advanced Micro Devices
column28: Inc. (AMD) Stock. Here's Why.Also announced at Next 2017 was a big win for G Suite
column29: Google's cloud-hosted productivity apps.Verizon Communications Inc.(NYSE:VZ) announced it has dropped Microsoft Office for 150
column30: 000 employees
column31: moving them instead to Google's G Suite.Look for Google to continue aggressively pushing Google cloud services in 2017. The company has been spending big on ramping up its infrastructure
column32: its ""Other"" revenue (which includes cloud revenue) wasup 62% in the last quarterand the majority of its 2
column33: 100 hires in Q4 went to cloud operations.As Google cloud's Diane Greene said onstage
column34: ""I think 2017 will be a good year
column35: too.""As of this writing
column36: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowSears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Q4 Earnings Beat

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI'm mostly a value stock investor. Value stocks offer greater returns over the long haul than growth stocks
column4: and there is a greater margin of error should you choose poorly. One of the great things about value stocks and naked puts is that the latter allows you to potentially scale into a value stock position even if you aren't certain the stock has yet hit its bottom. If it has
column5: naked puts are still of use.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockNaked puts that generate income like this are a cornerstone strategy of my forthcoming stock advisory newsletter
column6: The Liberty Portfolio.By selling naked puts on a value stock
column7: should the stock get put to you
column8: you get it at an even better value than just buying shares outright. If you also nibble a little at the value stock

column10: naked puts allow you to hedge by collecting some premium income.Naked Puts on Value Stocks: Teva (TEVA)Source:Open Grid Scheduler (Modified)Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Limited Ltd (ADR)(NYSE:TEVA) is just such a potential play for naked puts and value stocks. TEVA is the largest generics company in the world

column29: actually I consider it a GARP stock - growth at a reasonable price.To me
