column1: 10 Companies Set to Dominate the Next Decade;3/9/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Any investor would love to get their hands on a crystal ball   and take a quick peek at what's going to happen over the next   decade. The problem is
column2: those crystal balls are hard to come by
column3: so we all have to settle for looking at what companies are doing   right now -- and attempt to anticipate how that will help or hurt   them in the future.makeArticleAd();The good news is that therearecompanies positioning themselves for growth over the next decade
column4: and setting themselves up to dominate in their respective   markets. Take a look:Image source: Amazon.1. AmazonAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) has its hands in so many business it's hard to   keep up. For some companies
column5: that degree of diversification can   proof more trouble than it's worth
column6: but Amazon's has shown it can   sell everything from tablets to its Echo speaker
column7: while   simultaneously creating award-winning television shows and   managing a massive online consumer goods marketplace
column8: andstillhave business bandwidth to power some of the biggest websites   through its Amazon Web Services unit.The company's ability to diversify its businesses -- while   still tying many of them to its Prime service -- has given Amazon   a lead over its competitors that won't fade any time soon.Image source: Google.2. AlphabetWith a $581 billion market cap
column9: Google parentAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is a juggernaut of the technology   industry
column10: yet it still innovates like a much smaller
column11: scrappier   company. Alphabet may still earn most of its revenue -- 99% --   from Google
column12: but that hasn't stopped it from making big bets on   thedriverless car marketand even moonshots like curing cancer.Among the more than 20 companies under the Alphabet umbrella
column13: there are units trying to secure major positions in the future of   transportation
column14: artificial intelligence
column15: virtual reality
column16: and the   burgeoning Internet of Things. Add to that the company's mobile   dominance with its Android platform
column17: and its new devices like the   Pixel Phone and Google Home and its crystal clear that Alphabet   will still be one of the most dominant tech giants a decade from   now.Image source: Facebook.3. FacebookEvery day
column18: the world feels like it gets a little bit smaller   and slightly more connected
column19: andFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) deserves at least partial credit for that. With more   than 1.86 billion users on the company's main platform
column20: and more   growth coming in huge markets like India
column21: Facebook shows no sign   of slowing down in the social media space.The company plans to have 5 billion users by 2030. Take a   minute and remember that we have 7 billion people on the planet   right now. That's a hefty goal
column22: but if any company can do it it's   Facebook. Aside from its main Facebook platform
column23: the company is   investing billions in connecting people around the world through   its WhatsApp
column24: Instagram
column25: Messenger
column26: and is investing heavily in   building what CEO Mark Zuckerberg calls ""the next computing   platform"" -- virtual reality.Image source: Lockheed Martin.4. Lockheed MartinLockheed Martin(NYSE: LMT) has gotten some flak for the high price of its F-35   Lightning stealth fighter jet
column27: as President Trump has so kindly   pointed out onTwitter. But despite the criticisms
column28: the F-35 is poised to help Lockheed   Martin dominate the aerospace industry over the next decade.Consider that the F-35 is expected to be in service until 2070   and could bring in more than $1 trillion in revenue for the   company over that time span. Sure
column29: Lockheed may further trim the   cost of the planes -- as it did recently
column30: when it announced its   long-term efforts to reduce costs had cut the price on its next   batch of 90 planes by $700 million -- but with more than 50   years of revenues expect to come from this jet family
column31: there's   little reason to be skeptical of Lockheed's dominance.Image source: Netflix.5. NetflixNot so long ago
column32: the idea ofNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) being capable of creating original
column33: award-winning   programming would have seemed absurd. But over the past few   years
column34: the company has amassed a vast trove of original content   that has not only won over critics but also helped the company   win new customers. In fact
column35: 57% of the streaming service's U.S.   subscribers say they signed up for because of its original   content.Netflix now boasts about 93.8 million subscribers in 190   countries
column36: and it's still growing. The company faces rising   competition from Amazon's Prime video service
column37: but says it plans   on investing $6 billion in original content this year
column38: which   should help it fend off rivals. A decade from now
column39: Netflix will   have the advantage of that much more original content production   under its belt
column40: and more streaming experience than any of its   competitors.Image source: Disney.6. DisneyWalt Disney(NYSE: DIS) expanded its empire back in 2009 when it purchased   Marvel Studios for $4 billion
column41: and followed that up with another   $4 billion purchase -- of Lucasfilm -- in 2012. Those two   entertainment land-grabs alone will provide huge catalysts for   the company over the next decade
column42: as it reaps the benefits from   theStar Warsfranchise
column43: Marvel movies
column44: merchandise
column45: licensing ... you get the   picture.Add to all of that the company's long list of theme parks
column46: cruise ships
column47: resorts
column48: and its Pixar Studios
column49: and it's easy to   foresee Disney holding a powerful position the entertainment   business for years to come. The company will have to adapt to a   shifting pay-TV landscape
column50: and adjust to how those changes will   impact the company's all-important ESPN networks. But investors   would be wise to remember that the company already has many   decades worth of strategy-shifting experience.Image source: GE.7. General ElectricGeneral Electric(NYSE: GE) has weathered more changes than most companies over   its 100-plus year history
column51: and the conglomerate  recently   reinvented itself once again to benefit from the rapidly evolving   industrial and technological landscape.Consider that CEO Jeff Immelt said back in 2015 that his   company is ""on track to become a top 10 software company.""    Software may seem like a far cry from the engine turbines   and other industrial equipment GE is known for
column52: but it's   anticipating the rise of the Industrial Internet of Things   (IIoT)
column53: in which equipment is connected to the Internet
column54: collects   data
column55: and then analyzes it
column56: helping make companies and systems   more efficient. GE is already well on its way in this market
column57: and   with the IIoT estimated to add $14.2 trillion to the global   economy by 2030
column58: there's plenty of room for growth.Image source: Tesla.8. TeslaCompared to other U.S. automakers
column59: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is still  in its infancy
column60: but the electric   carmaker is quickly becoming key player in the space. Tesla   is preparing to launch its fourth vehicle
column61: the Model 3
column62: later   this year
column63: and estimates that it will produce 500
column64: 000 cars   annually starting in 2018.That's not so impressive when compared to
column65: say
column66: Ford's 2.6 million U.S. vehicle sales last year. But Tesla is betting   that the future of passenger cars is electric
column67: and it's building   out a vast network of supercharger stations across the U.S and   Europe to fuel them
column68: has already built the   battery-making Gigafactory to help drive down vehicle costs
column69: and is a leader in the driverless car space. If electric and   self-driving vehicles are the future
column70: then the next decade could   certainly be dominated by Tesla.Image source: Oracle.9. OracleOracle(NYSE: ORCL) is slowly shifting from a hardware-dominated sales   model to one that generates more recurring revenue from software   and services. Its cloud computing revenue was up 64% year over   year in its most recent quarter
column71: and topped $1 billion for   the first time. Oracle is now the leading cloud computing   provider for companies that have 1
column72: 000 or more employees
column73: and has   made major investments in the space with acquisitions such as   cloud provider NetSuite
column74: which it picked up for a cool $9.3   billion.The shift away from hardware to software and services may have   been slow in coming for Oracle
column75: but it's making up for lost time
column76: and betting that its current cloud investments will pay off over   the long term. Given its current position in the tech world
column77: and   its rising power in cloud computing
column78: you can bet Oracle will   maintain its position for years to come.Image source: Nike.10. NikeNo other company dominates the sports apparel world likeNike(NYSE: NKE)
column79: and at this point
column80: there's virtually no stopping   it. It has not only built one of the strongest brands on the   planet
column81: but it also knows how to keep the momentum going.   Consider that the company's $93 billion market cap allows it do   things like sign a lifetime sponsorship deal with Lebron   James that's estimated to be worth up to $1 billion.But branding is only part of the company's staying power. Nike   has proved that it can continue innovating its product lines
column82: and   it has 40-plus years of success in marketing them in the right   way. Others may sprint faster for a time to gain share in   the $320 billion athletic apparel market
column83: but Nike is   running a marathon
column84: and it's clear it trained harder and has more   stamina than any of its competitors.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column22: if not the iPhone Edition

column24: a company Apple wasonce rumored to acquire. PowerVR Furian
column25: as it's being called

column1: Why Alphabet and Microsoft Should Start Disclosing Cloud Revenue;3/8/2017;"Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is currently hosting its Google   Cloud Next '17 developer conference
column2: which kicked off earlier   today in San Francisco and runs through March 10. Speaking at the   event
column3: Google CEO Sundar Pichai made it clear that he sees Google   Cloud as an incredibly important part of the search giant's   future
column4: and not just one of the company's many side bets. ""To me
column5: Google Cloud is a natural extension of our mission to make the   world's information accessible and usable
column6: Pichai said.The distinction is that while search helps regular users   access information
column7: cloud computing infrastructure and the   related value-added services like analytics help the enterprise   organize and access their information. The cloud infrastructure   market is booming
column8: growing 49% last year to $38.1 billion
column9: according to market researcher Canalys. It's expected to jump   another 46% this year to $55.8 billion. As the market grows
column10: so
column11: too
column12: does the impact on the financials of the major players:   Google Cloud
column13: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure
column14: andAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS.Google data center in Council Bluffs
column15: Iowa. Image source:     Google.makeArticleAd();As such
column16: the former two should start disclosing exactly how   much cloud revenue they're bringing in.Follow Amazon's leadI never thought I'd see the day when Amazon was leading the   way in investor transparency
column17: given the e-commerce giant's   long-standing refusal to share various operating metrics that are   pertinent to investors. Yet
column18: when it comes to AWS and cloud   revenue
column19: Amazon is doing just that; Amazon started sharing AWS   financials in 2015. AWS revenue was $12.2 billion last year
column20: translating into $3.1 billion in operating income.Microsoft only discloses growth rates for Azure (up 93% last   quarter)
column21: but lacking a base number
column22: that data point is less   meaningful. We do know that total revenue in Microsoft's   intelligent cloud segment
column23: which includes Azure among other   offerings
column24: was $6.9 billion last quarter
column25: resulting in $2.4   billion in operating income. Lacking an official figure
column26: JPMorgan   analysts estimate Azure revenue for all of 2016 was $2.7 billion
column27: which would make AWS nearly five times bigger.Google includes Google Cloud revenue within its Google other   revenues segment
column28: which generated a hair over $10 billion in   sales in 2016. That also includes revenue from Google Play as   well as the company's growing hardware portfolio. One   particularly prominent Google Cloud customer that just went   public likely spent between $400 million to $450 million last   year
column29: and is committed to $400 million per year for thenext five years
column30: so there's that.Sharing is caringYou could reasonably argue that AWS is far more important to   Amazon than its peers' respective cloud businesses
column31: though
column32: specifically since AWS is by far the market leaderandit's such a major contributor to profitability due to razor-thin   margins in the core e-commerce business. In contrast
column33: Google and   Microsoft enjoy much higher gross margin
column34: as they each specialize   in software and services.Still
column35: the cloud infrastructure market is only going to become   increasingly important in the years ahead
column36: and investors will   want to see the results from the three largest players to assess   each company's competitiveness. Google and Microsoft should start   sharing more
column37: especially if it's as important as Pichai says it   is.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: YouTube TV's Biggest Advantage;3/8/2017;"YouTube recently announced its plans to offer a live   television streaming service to compete with the likes of DirecTV   Now
column2: PlayStation Vue
column3: Sling TV
column4: and more traditional pay-TV   operators. YouTube TV will include 40 live channels and will be   initially available in select markets.While YouTube TV is missing quite a few channels compared with   competing services
column5: it has the potential to attract a lot of   attention from media companies in the future thanks to one huge   advantage over the competitors: Google
column6: theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary and owner of YouTube
column7: is one of the best digital video advertisers in the world.Image source: YouTubemakeArticleAd();Disney already sees the value in digital streamingDisney(NYSE: DIS) CEO Bob Iger is actively trying to get his networks   into digital skinny bundles. Indeed
column8: Disney's networks
column9: including   ESPN
column10: are available in the lowest-priced tiers of all of the   aforementioned streaming services.Importantly
column11: Disney is not sacrificing any of its affiliate   fees to get its channels into those tiers. ""The per-channel fees
column12: which we are not getting too specific about
column13: are commensurate   with what the fees are on the existing services
column14: Iger said about   its deal with DirecTV Now.But there's an added benefit to going digital. ""Some of the   technology platforms will offer dynamic ad insertion. We think   that that has got some real potential for the company
column15: Iger told   investors on the company's third-quarter earnings call last   year.Dynamic ad insertion allows media companies to serve targeted   ads to viewers instead of using the one-size-fits-all system of   traditional live broadcasts. YouTube TV may give media companies   the opportunity to tap into Google's targeting data. On top of   that
column16: YouTube already has millions of advertisers on its   platform
column17: which it could tap for more premium YouTube TV ads.Media companies might give YouTube TV a bigger break on   affiliate fees if it can produce meaningfully higher ad revenue   per viewer than its competitors.YouTube will have a chance to prove itself
column18: tooMedia companies will handle the majority of their ad buying at   the launch of YouTube TV
column19: but YouTube will have access to about   two minutes of ads for every hour of viewing. That's the ad   inventory that every cable company receives. If YouTube can use   its decade of advertising experience and produce outsize results
column20: it could increase interest from media companies for its   services.That bit of advertising is about the only thing that will make   YouTube TV profitable
column21: as analysts estimate its affiliate fees   total about $29 before accounting for various regional sports   networks
column22: which could add $4 to $5.Suffice it to say YouTube TV has a lot running on that small   slice of advertising inventory.Taking on a $71 billion marketThe market Google is going after with YouTube TV isn't so much   the pay-TV market as it is the television advertising market.   Google tried to break into the market before by partnering with   media companies about a decade ago. Now
column23: it's using YouTube TV as   a platform to gain access to that inventory
column24: which generated   about $71 billion in the U.S. last year.Getting YouTube TV off the ground and showing media companies   what it's capable of with advertising is the first step. The more   successful it is with its own ad inventory
column25: the more likely it is   to win the business of more media companies. In turn
column26: more   customers will sign up as the value improves and YouTube is able   to bring on more networks.If YouTube TV is successful
column27: it will be because its superior   advertising makes it a win-win-win -- the media companies
column28: the   consumers
column29: and YouTube.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (C   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Will Snap Inc (SNAP) Succeed or Fall Out of Investors' Favor?;3/8/2017;"Snap Inc.SNAP
column2: the parent company of social network
column3: Snapchat
column4: was off to a brilliant start on its debut. The company's IPO was multiple times oversubscribed and shares soared 44% on the first day of trading. However
column5: shares fell nearly 10% yesterday amid reports that the company has come under fire from several institutional investorsSnap Lands into Trouble with Institutional   InvestorsInvestors aren't happy with the company's offering of 200 million Class A shares that carry no voting rights. Per a Business Insider report
column6: they have ""approached"" stock index providers such as S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI Inc to prevent Snap and other such companies that offer shares without voting rights from getting incorporated into these benchmark indexes. The meeting is scheduled sometime this week.Investors argue that the absence of voting rights completely bars a shareholder from speaking on issues like a company's growth plans or compensation shelled out to executives. Business Insider also adds that if such a company is listed on any of the indices
column7: ""then managers of stock index portfolios will have to buy its shares and other investors
column8: whose performance is tracked against such indexes
column9: would likely follow suit.""The absence of voting rights implies that the company does not intend to dilute its decision making power. Snap will have a three-tier share structure and founders Evan Spigel and Bobby Murphy will have maximum voting rights through the ownership of Class C shares
column10: which carry 10 votes per share. The Class B shares carry one vote per share. Such form of corporate governance might prove detrimental for investors
column11: especially when there is uncertainty about its future.What's Concerning Investors?Snap Inc has been shunned by many Wall Street analysts for various reasons. Citing instances of Twitter Inc.TWTR
column12: Groupon Inc and many others
column13: analysts believe that Snap ""will follow a pattern of hot
column14: then cooling
column15: tech IPOs.""Reportedly
column16: most analysts have initiated coverage on Snap with a ""sell"" rating. These analysts argue that Snap has already started seeing its average daily user growth rate slowdown.  Plus
column17: the company is yet to make profits. Though the company's revenues are on the rise
column18: losses are ballooning. Reportedly
column20: Snap's revenues of $404.5 million were nearly six times higher than 2015 revenues but net loss for the year increased 38% to $514.6 million.Moreover
column21: since Snapchat has just one source of revenues i.e.
column22: advertising
column23: which only began in Oct 2016
column24: it may be a concern for investors. Also
column25: it attracts a particular segment of the demography.Analysts argue that teens are inclined to sudden changes in preferences. Media reports have quoted Snap ""admitting"" that increasing competition from big players like Facebook IncFB
column26: which have better resources
column27: is a big threat as they can easily lure users to their platform.In fact
column28: Facebook outshines Snap in almost all aspects. The company enjoys a first mover advantage in the social media space with over 1.9 billion users from every segment of demography. It has a gargantuan base of over 1 billion DAUs compared with 158 million for Snap. Facebook presents a much larger canvas for advertisers than Snapchat. In fact
column29: Facebook's total addressable market (TAM) has been reported to be 80% bigger than that of Snap.Also
column30: Facebook through its Instagram application has started to emulate Snapchat features
column31: which is a big threat for Snapchat. Analysts observe that Facebook can easily take chances by unveiling features that are similar to other social media services. This is because if these ""inspired"" features do not work
column32: it can easily roll them back like it did previously with Poke
column33: Slingshot and Bolt.After all
column34: platforms like Facebook
column35: Instagram
column36: WhatsApp and Messenger do have their own inherent features that will prevent the loss of users. If these ""inspired"" features become popular like Facebook Live
column37: people will view it as an improvement over the inherent features. This will significantly cut down the risk of migration if Snapchat becomes popular going ahead.An analyst was quoted saying ""Good-enough features plus being the first app to offer them at scale in a market could succeed better than having the best features but showing up late."" Compared to Facebook's worldwide popularity
column38: Snap is mainly popular in the U.S and Canada. Apart from Facebook
column39: Alphabet'sGOOGLYouTube is another formidable opponent for ad dollarsAlso
column40: Snap's valuation is nosebleed. At nearly 60 times its revenues
column41: analysts remain wary as it is too high compared to existing and future growth prospects.Wait
column42: Not All Is Lost!!However
column43: there are some analysts who aren't so negative on the stock. They believe that product innovations might help Snap to sustain the momentum.Thebest partabout the company is that it does not follow the usual advertising model of charging per click
column44: rather it charges advertisers per day. The consistently expanding daily active user base has been attracting more and more consumers.Apart from this
column45: the company's Snapchat Discover feature has enhanced its picture and video library
column46: thereby attracting more and more advertisers. The feature also allows the company to partner with major events like the Oscars and Super Bowl. Discover currently accounts for a majority of the company's advertising revenues.At the Morgan Stanley conference held a couple of months back
column47: CEO Spiegel was quoted by media reports as saying that 50% of its new user base now comprises users over the age of 25. Plus
column48: Snapchat
column49: in order to diversify its revenue base
column50: has started selling Snapchat spectacles worth $130.ConclusionSnap is currently stealing all the limelight. It remains to be seen whether the company can keep the excitement alive by providing a more immersive experience. We can only hope that its success will not be ""ephemeral"" like its messaging features.Want to learn more about Snapchat stock? MSFT stock has risen roughly 150% in just four years - despite little movement in profits.""The lack of fundamental growth is even more perplexing when you consider Microsoft's position within the fierce environment. column25: inc. (NYSE:CRM).""A huge concern for those trading MSFT stock is the market capitalization. I'm not a fan of focusing on any one metric. Still

column29: followed by performances of 28.4%
column30: 21.9% and 16.5%.Microsoft Stock Is a Proven WinnerAdmittedly

column36: nearly four times higher. That also means that those who are concerned about this year's slow start for MSFT stock shouldn't be.The other attribute that is remarkable about Microsoft is its resiliency. Between 2000 and 2011

column38: shares managed to claw back positive returns for the year. That provides a lot of security for those making strongly optimistic calls for Microsoft stock.While investors have reason to look at MSFT cautiously

column41: it can do serious damage in the social media sphere.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!Overall

column45: even in the most trying of circumstances. The only question is

column9: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Tuesday's Analyst Blog:Will Spotify Stream into an IPO in 2017?Launched in 2008 by entrepreneurs Daniel Ek and Martin Lorentzon
column10: Stockholm
column11: Sweden-basedSpotifyis one of the most popular streaming services on the market today. With its desktop and mobile app version
column12: the company allows users to search or browse
column13: for free
column14: through its extensive music library. Spotify also offers a ""Premium"" subscription for $9.99 per month that removes advertisements and lets users download music to listen to offline.CompetitionSpotify recently announced that it now has 100 million monthly active users
column15: with 50 million paying for the service. This achievement has cemented its status as the biggest subscription music service by user count
column16: and the leader in the increasingly crowded music streaming industry.Arguably Spotify's biggest market rival is Apple's (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) Apple Music. Launched in 2015
column17: Apple Music is a streaming music service based on Beats Music
column18: which has drawn listeners with playlists made by experts
column19: not algorithms. The service is also known for its collaborations with high-profile musicians like Drake and Taylor Swift. It costs $9.99 per month
column20: and users can download music from an extensive digital library
column21: just like Spotify. Apple Music offers listeners a free
column22: three-month initial trial.There's also Tidal
column23: the Scandinavian streaming service that rapper and mogul Jay Z scooped up back in 2015 for $56 million. It has a similar price of $9.99 per month for normal streaming
column24: while also offering a $19.99 per month option that includes high-fidelity sound quality. Like Apple Music
column25: Tidal is known for its partnerships with big music names. Rihanna
column26: BeyoncÃ©
column27: and Kanye West all exclusively debuted their latest albums on Tidal before a wider release.Other top rivals include Rdio
column28: which provides access to online radio stations
column29: with different levels of on-demand access
column30: for $3.99 to $9.99 per month; Pandora (NYSE:P-Free Report)
column31: one of the original internet radio companies
column32: goes for $4.99 per month to avoid ads; Rhapsody
column33: the original streaming music subscription service
column34: has been around since 2001
column35: and is available for $9.99 per month; and Alphabet Inc.'s (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Google Play Music
column36: which offers online music storage and a streaming service for $9.99 per month.ControversiesDespite its popularity
column37: Spotify tends to draw out negative publicity
column38: mainly over debates about its free advertising-supported service. This service allows people who are prepared to sit through occasional ads to listen to songs for free on demand. Music labels-Spotify is in compliance with Sony (NYSE:SNE-Free Report)
column39: EMI
column40: Warner Music Group
column41: and Universal
column42: among others-understandably dislike the free service because it dismantles album sales
column43: and pays less in royalties than the subscription does.We all remember Spotify's battle with Taylor Swift. The popstar withdrew her entire catalog from the service because she ""didn't like the way it felt. I think there should be an inherent value placed on art. I didn't see that happening
column44: perception-wise
column45: when I put my music on Spotify
column46: shesaid in an interviewwithTime.Other musicians soon followed in her footsteps. Icelandic singer BjÃ¶rk made her latest albumVulnicuraunavailable on Spotify and other streaming services
column47: though her back catalogue remained available. And in 2015
column48: British songstress Adele similarly restricted her Grammy-winning album25from all streaming services-however
column49: you can currently listen to it on Spotify
column50: along with her other albums
column51: 19and21-on its release date
column52: tellingTimethat ""I believe music should be an event.""Last year
column53: Spotify was embroiled in issues surrounding its updated Terms and Conditions of Use
column54: where in ablog post
column55: the company's user communications manager Candace Katz explains ""We may ask for customer permission to collect information from new sources
column56: such as address book
column57: location
column58: and sensor data [and photos
column59: voice controls
column60: and contacts] from the mobile device to improve the customer experience and inform product decisions.""This unexpectedly caused an uproar
column61: with many calling Spotify's new privacy policy ""eerie"" and ""creepy"" and pledging to unsubscribe from the service. The backlash was bad enough that CEO Ek wrote another blog post
column62: aptly called ""SORRY"" in order to explain that users don't have to share this information if they don't want to. ""We will ask for your express permission before accessing any of this data - and we will only use it for specific purposes that will allow you to customize your Spotify experience.""An IPO on the Horizon?Over the past few years or so
column63: Spotify has been on the hunt for new funding. The company closed funding rounds in 2012 and 2013
column64: raising $100 million and $250 million
column65: respectively. In 2016
column66: Spotify completed a whopping $526 million round of funding
column67: putting it at a valuation of roughly $8.5 billion

column69: Spotify announced its plan to add videos and podcasts from partners like ESPN
column70: NBC
column71: Comedy Central
column72: and CondÃ© Nast.And about a year ago
column73: the company raised $1 billion in convertible debt on the promise that its new investors will receive a 30% discount on shares when it files for an IPO. Spotify will have to pay 5% annual interest on the debt
column74: however
column75: and 1% more every six months
column76: up to a total of 10%

column78: as Spotify was able to maintain its high valuation without diluting its existing shareholders. It does suggest the company is seriously thinking about an IPO

column85: Sony

column87: whom control 80% of recorded music.There's no doubt about Spotify's rapid growth and universal reach
column88: but it remains unprofitable mostly because of the fees paid to these music labels. The company supposedly pays a royalty rate of 55% of its sales
column89: and is fighting to pay less. Nevertheless
column90: its impressive valuation-aTechCrunchsource hopes to target a valuation between $11 billion and $13 billion--and popularity will work in their favor when their public debut comes. Patience is a virtue

column92: so sit back

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8: New Name
column2: Late Release?;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) upcoming flagship smartphone continues to be the subject of intense speculation. With the countdown on to finalizing design and starting production of the new iPhone
column4: two details in particular have seen conflicting theories: the name and the display size.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleA new post from Japan'sMac Otakarasuggests AAPL will go with the iPhone Edition - instead of iPhone 8 or 10th anniversary iPhone - for its flagship model.The website also feels it has nailed the display size
column5: and agrees with a previous report that the new iPhone could arrive significantly later than usual.iPhone 8 = iPhone Edition?What to call the new iPhone is actually a big deal this year. The regular naming sequence will continue with the iPhone 7s and iPhone 7s Plus. Those are the phones for everyone. But what do you call the all-new flagship AAPL is expected to release -the $1
column6: 000+ smartphonethat celebrates a decade in the business (and hopefully helps to propel sales to stratospheric levels)?The iPhone X
column7: 10th Anniversary iPhone and iPhone 8 have been the front runners. But what would you call the 10th Anniversary iPhonenextyear? And iPhone 8 would mess up Apple's naming scheme for its mainstream models.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Can't Commit to HollywoodMac OtakarathinksAAPL will go with the iPhone Edition. The premium Apple Watch model is the Apple Watch Edition
column8: so the precedent has already been set and it would be consistent. This would also solve the continuity problem associated with naming a new iPhone specifically around the 10th anniversary
column9: without messing up the current iPhone naming scheme. iPhone Edition makes sense.About the New iPhone DisplayOutside of whether it would be curved or not
column10: or OLED or not
column11: there have been conflicting reports about the display's size. Most analysts have been calling for a 5.8-inch display with bezels practically eliminated. That would let AAPL fit a larger display into an iPhone that's smaller than the 5.5-inch iPhone 7 Plus.It's a similar approach to whatSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)appears to have taken with the Galaxy S8.However
column12: Mac Otakarahas always maintained - and still insists - that the new iPhone will have a 5-inch display. Which seems weird
column13: given the consumer preference for big screens.Mac Rumorsconnected the dotsand theorizes that the information given to the Japanese website is for theusablespace. The remaining display area would be where AAPL has a row of virtual buttons - a feature that has already been mentioned as replacing the Home button and mimicking the functionality of the new MacBook Pro Touch Bar.Take a 5.8-inch display
column14: reserve the bottom of that display for the virtual buttons
column15: and you end up with what is effectively a 5-inch display in terms of what the owner can make use of.The math is starting to add up.iPhone Edition Could Be DelayedFinally
column16: Mac Otakaraagrees with the growing number of analysts who are predicting the iPhone 8 - or iPhone Edition - is going to face a delayed release.A few days ago
column17: 9to5 Macreported the iPhone 7s series would go into production in July
column18: as expected. But there are rumors that the TouchID sensor that AAPL is integrating into the new iPhone Edition's display is proving challenging. The added manufacturing complexity may push mass production for the new flagship model to September. That would mean severe supply constraints
column19: including the possibility that theiPhone Edition would not begin shipping until a month after the iPhone 7s
column20: with only early pre-orders being delivered in 2017.If the production issues turn out to be true
column21: the results could be problematic â€¦ but not necessarily.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still ""The One""On the downside
column22: Apple would face the possibility that potential iPhone 7s buyers hold off until they can physically compare it against the iPhone Edition
column23: delaying that wave of upgrades. Potential iPhone Edition buyers could also shrug and order the iPhone 7s instead
column24: not wishing to wait a few months for their new smartphone. And without the 1-2 punch of the 7s and iPhone Edition together
column25: AAPL could miss out on the spectacularly record-smashing launch sales weekend it is gunning for to celebrate that 10th anniversary.On the upside
column26: the annual crest of sales that accompany every new iPhone release could be extended. The iPhone 7s would get the first rush
column27: followed by the iPhone Edition.It's possible.As always
column28: stay tuned. At this stage
column29: everything we ""know"" about the new iPhone is speculation. But with AAPL's supply chain starting to crank up for production
column30: the pieces are beginning to fall into place.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceHow to Buy Advanced Micro Devices

column1: Will Snapchat Become the Next Twitter or Facebook?;3/7/2017;"After months of speculations
column2: Snap Inc.
column3: the parent company of social media mobile app Snapchat
column4: finally got listed on the New York Stock Exchange last week. With this
column5: arguments whether the company will become more like FacebookFBor turn to TwitterTWTRin the next few years
column6: have heated up.Notably
column7: shares of the two established social media companies - Facebook and Twitter - have taken divergent paths since their respective Initial Public Offerings (IPO). At yesterday's closing price
column8: Facebook is up 261.6% from its IPO price; while Twitter is trading 40.2% down from its IPO price.Undoubtedly
column9: neither the company nor the stakeholders will ever prefer it to become like Twitter
column10: which is witnessing declining user base
column11: revenues and earnings. On the contrary
column12: it will like to become more like Facebook or even better
column13: which has seen a tremendous rise in user base
column14: revenues as well as earnings.Although
column15: it will be quite early to forecast where the company will find itself after five years from now; the business model demonstrates both positive and negative aspects following thestock's recent decline post IPO.What Makes it More like FacebookSnap is known for its social media mobile app - Snapchat - which was founded in 2011
column16: and officially launched in 2012. The app allows users to take photos and record videos
column17: as well as facilitate editing options and share the same with friends. However
column18: photos or videos can be viewed for few seconds only and then they disappear
column19: and also cannot be saved.Since its launch
column20: the app has been steadily getting popular among teenagers
column21: thanks to its consistent focus on introducing new and unique features. Per the company
column22: the app had 158 million daily active users per day at the end of 2016
column23: which represented year-over-year growth of 48%. Of these
column24: majority are between 18 and 34 years old. The daily users visit the Snapchat app more than 20 times a day
column25: on an average
column26: and spend over 30 minutes.Although
column27: the daily active user count is way lesser than Facebook's over 1.20 billion
column28: it has already surpassed Twitter's over 130-million daily visitors. Also
column29: the rate at which it is growing
column30: it has the potential to reduce the gap with Facebook.Going ahead
column31: the best part of the company is that it has been able to monetize the app. The company does not follow the typical Internet advertising model of charging per click; rather it charges advertisers per day. The consistently growing daily active user base has been attracting more and more consumers.Apart from this
column32: the company's Snapchat Discover feature has expanded its picture and video library
column33: thereby attracting more and more advertisers. The feature also allows the company to partner with major events like the Oscars and Super Bowl. Discover currently accounts for a majority of the company's advertising revenue.It should be noted that the company registered almost a seven-fold year-over-year jump in its 2016 revenues
column34: which reached $404.9 million from $58.7 million recorded in 2015. Going ahead
column35: the company projects its annual revenues and daily active user base to reach approximately $2 billion and 221 million
column36: respectively
column37: in 2018.Snap's constant efforts in introducing new and unique app features
column38: along with its innovative adverting ideas
column39: will enable it in achieving its target.Despite this
column40: it will be far lesser than Facebook
column41: which generated $27.6 billion revenues in 2016
column42: and is still growing. However
column43: if Snap achieved its target for 2018
column44: it will certainly be closing its gap with Twitter which generated $2.5 billion in revenues and has been witnessing a slowdown in growth rate.Why It May Fall to TwitterLooking at the above discussion
column45: it seems that Snap does look like Facebook. However
column46: there are a number of challenges which may trouble it in becoming the next Facebook and put it in Twitter's shoes.The major threat comes from Facebook which introduced the new ""Stories"" feature at its Instagram app last year. This new feature allows users to post photos and video slideshows which disappear after a 24-hour period. Instagram stories directly mirror Snapchat's own stories feature. Reportedly
column47: after this launch
column48: Snapchat has recorded a slowdown in its users' growth rate in the second half of 2016.The second major concern is that even after five years of journey
column49: the company has failed to make itself profitable just like Twitter before its IPO. On the contrary
column50: Facebook had made over $1 billion of profit in the fiscal year just before its IPO in 2012.Furthermore
column51: since the early days of Snapchat
column52: this disappearing messaging app has been associated with sexting. Snapchat has also dealt with a few other embarrassing issues
column53: including two different racially insensitive filters. All this may put the company in unnecessary controversies and bring in unwanted investigation.ConclusionInvestors ideally vision Snap to grow like Facebook and not become Twitter. However
column54: we believe that Facebook's well established position in the social media industry
column55: ever-growing user base and the popular Instagram service are significant threat to Snapchat's growth prospects.In addition
column56: the company will have a tough task grabbing market share in the digital ad space
column57: which is mainly dominated by Facebook and AlphabetGOOGLaka Google.Want to learn more about Snapchat stock? Check out our recent podcast on SNAP with an IPO expert below!8 Stocks with Huge Profit PotentialmakeArticleAd();Just released: Driverless Cars: Your Roadmap to Mega-Profits Today. column1: Instagram: How Facebook's Photo-Sharing App Makes Money;3/7/2017;"Instagram
column2: the photo-sharing app
column3: created by Kevin Systrom and Mike Kreiger in 2010
column4: is now one of the most popular apps among users. The companyreportedreaching half a billion monthly active users in June 2016.In April of 2012
column5: FacebookFB
column6: the social media giant
column7: acquired Instagram for about $1 billion in cash and stock. At the time
column8: Instagram had only been around for less than two years
column9: with initial funding of $500
column10: 000 from Baseline Ventures and Andreessen Horowitz. It was the largest acquisition that Facebook made before its IPO in May 2012 and many on the outside had questioned the purchase.So How Does Instagram Makes Money?Just like its parent company
column11: Instagram makes all of its money from selling advertising. Instagram has three types of ads: image ads
column12: video ads and carousel ads.The ads are shared directly on users' newsfeed and Stories. As the users scroll through their newsfeed
column13: ads are distributed between actual users' content. The users then have the option to follow the brand's account or to click on an ad to learn more about its product or service.Similar to newsfeed
column14: ads are also distributed on Instagram's Stories
column15: a SnapchatSNAP-like feature that lets users share temporary pictures or videos.Users will see the ads in one of the three ad types and have the option to skip or click on the ad.Instagram's advertisers include Nike Inc.NKE
column16: General ElectricGEand GoogleGOOGL.Bottom LineThough Facebook doesn't disclose Instagram's financials

column1: Why Baidu Inc. Probably Won't Spin Off iQiyi.com;3/7/2017;"In late February
column2: Baidu's(NASDAQ: BIDU) video  streaming subsidiary iQiyi raised   $1.53 billion in fresh funds to compete more effectively with   rival sites. Hillhouse Capital
column3: IDG Capital
column4: Sequoia Capital
column5: and   Baidu all purchased the newly issued convertible bonds
column6: and Baidu   disclosed that it had invested $300 million.iQiyi is the largest video streaming site in China
column7: but it   currently faces tough competition fromTencent(NASDAQOTH: TCEHY) Video andAlibaba's Youku Tudou. iQiyi has  been losing money since Baidu   purchased a majority stake in 2012
column8: which has repeatedly sparked   calls for Baidu to sell or spin-off the company to boost its   profitability.The iQiyi app for Android tablets. Image source: Google     Play.makeArticleAd();Last December
column9: theWall Street Journalreported that Baidu was planning to spin off iQiyi in an IPO   which could raise $1 billion. Baidu denied those rumors
column10: and CEO   Robin Li reiterated after the recent bond offering that the site   was ""a great asset and an important part of the Baidu ecosystem.""   Let's take a closer look at iQiyi
column11: and why Baidu prefers to raise   capital through convertible bonds rather than spin off the   company in an IPO.A brief look at iQiyi's historyBaidu and American private equity firm Providence Equity   Partners co-founded iQiyi in 2010. In 2012
column12: Baidu bought out   Providence's stake to become the dominant investor. It acquired   the  popular online video business of PPStream the following   year
column13: and launched its own film production division in 2014. That   same year
column14: smartphone giantXiaomiand Shunwei Capital acquired a 10%-15% stake in  iQiyi for   $300 million.In 2015
column15: it acquired the online rights to top entertainment   shows in China
column16: Taiwan
column17: and  South Korea -- including the   popular Korean variety showRunning Man. In 2016
column18: iQiyi launched in  Taiwan
column19: marking its first step   outside of mainland China.During last quarter's conference call
column20: Robin Li stated that   iQiyi ""performed very well
column21: with ""revenue and subscriber numbers   ramping up nicely."" According to iResearch's Dec. 2016 numbers
column22: iQiyi's mobile app remained the top video streaming app in China
column23: with 125 million daily active users and 480 million monthly   active users
column24: and streamed 335 billion minutes of   monthly content.iQiyi generates most of its revenue from ads
column25: but it launched   a paid service in 2015 that lets subscribers get earlier or   exclusive access to blockbuster shows. iQiyi claimed the service   reached 20 million subscribers last June
column26: up from 5 million at   the end of May 2015.But profitability is toughOn the conference call
column27: Robin Li stated that Baidu planned to   support iQiyi's ""further growth
column28: but noted that higher content   acquisition costs at the site caused its total content costs to   rise from 5.6% of revenues in 2015 to 11% in 2016. That statement   raises some concerns when we look at Baidu's operating margins   over the past five years.Source:YChartsRobin Li still hasn't provided a timeline for iQiyi's bottom   line to break even
column29: but CFO Jennifer Li noted that margins were   ""improving""
column30: and that they would continue doing so in the future.   She also stated that to keep costs under control
column31: Baidu will   invest more heavily in original content to ""further strengthen   and expand"" its subscription user base.YouTube faces the same challengesMaking a profit from streaming video is very tough. The   platform might generate revenue with ads and subscriptions
column32: but   those gains often can't offset the costs of hosting videos on   servers and content acquisition costs.EvenAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) YouTube
column33: the biggest streaming   video platform in the  world with over a billion users
column34: remains unprofitable due to those pressures. Last October
column35: YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki stated that the 12-year-old site was   ""still in investment mode
column36: and that there was ""no timetable"" for   achieving profitability. Like iQiyi
column37: YouTube offers a premium   subscription platform
column38: YouTube Red
column39: but the  service   reportedly only had 1.5 million subscribers at the end of last   summer.Baidu and Alphabet are willing to take losses on iQiyi and   YouTube for a simple reason: streaming videos tether more users   to their ecosystems. If those viewers use iQiyi they're more   likely to use other services -- like Baidu Maps
column40: Search
column41: and   Wallet -- instead of services from rivals like Tencent . Both   companies can also track watched videos
column42: which gives them more   data for targeted ads.The key takeawayiQiyi will probably keep losing money for years
column43: but investors   shouldn't fret over those losses. The platform brings more users   into Baidu's ecosystem
column44: which widens its moat against other   companies and ensures that it remains the top internet   advertising platform in China. Therefore
column45: investors shouldn't   expect Baidu to spin off iQiyi any more than they expect Alphabet   to spin off YouTube.10 stocks we like better than BaiduWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column19: and all have been successful.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017The enterprise cloud has been very
column20: very good for Salesforce.com
column21: and competitors have done more than take notice. Cloud is now the default home of major database applications. Competitors likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column22: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) and IBM all now brag about the size of their clouds
column23: and the sophistication of enterprise applications built on them.The S-shaped ""sales curve
column24: of slow growth in a new market
column25: rocket-like growth as mass markets adopt something and slower growth once that is achieved
column26: is approaching the end of the line for cloud. CRM stock bulls insist that things like the internet of thingswill keep growth going
column27: but each new niche now brings big-time competitors with it
column28: such asGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE)
column29: which calls its industrial IoT cloud Predix.Alliance TimeAs markets mature
column30: they consolidate. Competitors pair up
column31: starting with alliances
column32: then moving naturally toward mergers. Having fewer competitors means they can maintain pricing
column33: and margins
column34: even as growth slows.This is why some analysts are pushinga merger-of-equals that won't happenbetween Salesforce andAdobe Systems Inc.(NASDAQ:ADBE)
column35: whose ""Creative Cloud"" applications would seem a natural fit.Salesforce's strategy has been to pick-off smaller application spaces as they appear
column36: as with its 2016 buy ofDemandware
column37: which serves online merchants
column38: acquired for $2.8 billion. The company made10 acquisitions during 2016
column39: and in January it continued this withSequence
column40: which designs user interfaces
column41: a business now dubbed UX for User Experience.As a software house
column42: rather than a hardware company
column43: Salesforce has always had to manage its hosting carefully. Its original code came from Oracle
column44: and the companies have had a fraught existence. So over the years
column45: Salesforce has added Microsoft andAmazon.com Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) toits partner list
column46: although these relationships are
column47: like love
column48: subject to change on the first suspicion of betrayal.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!You canadd IBM to the list. Salesforce will now mix its data with IBM's Watson - a quick route into artificial intelligence and
column49: perhaps
column50: into IBM itself.Where the Ride Ends for CRM StockI believe the end of the ride for Salesforce is in sight and IBM would make a compelling destination. IBM now sells at half its sales
column51: its revenues have been declining for years
column52: and Salesforce could halt that slide. With CEO Virginia Rometty approaching 60
column53: often a retirement age at Big Blue
column54: Benioff might make a natural successor at age 52.Benioff would also give IBM a more entrepreneurial face
column55: and IBM would give him a much bigger playing field on which to perform cloud magic. He has been telling all who would listen that a ""roaring"" market meansSalesforce is not interested in acquisitions.How about a sale?Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. His latest novel isBridget O'Flynn vs. Something Big & Ugly.Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column56: he was long AMZN
column57: GOOGL and MSFT.The postWill Salesforce.com
column58: Inc. (CRM) Sell Out to International Business Machines Corp. (IBM)?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alexa CAN Drive Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock â€¦ Someday;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) continues to roll along. AMZN stock trades just off all-time highs at the moment
column5: having gained over 2
column6: 000% over the past 10 years.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhile some investors point to the price-to-earnings ratio of Amazon stock as a potential danger sign
column7: I think that viewis short-sighted. The company's legacy business continues to change the face of U.S. retailing. Witness the sharp decline this week atTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT)
column8: which seems directly attributed to Amazon's online success.Of course
column9: online retail isn't the only area where AMZN is having success - or where increased profits can drive Amazon stock higher. The company's Amazon Web Services (AWS) business has become a dominant player in cloud.And
column10: of late
column11: the company's Amazon Echo
column12: built on the Alexa Voice Service
column13: has added another layer to the bull case for AMZN stock.Though I remain bullish on AMZN
column14: I don't think Alexa really changes the value of Amazon stock - at least not yet. Amazon is too big and Amazon Echo usage is too spotty
column15: for Alexa and/or Echo to drive impressive sales or profit growth on their own.But both products highlight the success of Amazon's long-term strategy; Alexa
column16: in particular
column17: may become a bigger point of the AMZN story in the future.Why Alexa And Echo Aren't A Big Deal For AMZN Stock YetFor any other company
column18: Echo would be considered a monster hit. Amazon hasn't broken out sales figures
column19: but it did say in December that it had sold""millions""of Echo devices. An outside firm pegged the numberat over 5 million. With the average sales price for Amazon likely around $100 (including retail markup and sales of lower-priced Amazon Dots)
column20: that implies as muchas half a billion dollarsin sales for AMZN.10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowThat's a huge number - for anyone but Amazon.com
column21: Inc. AMZN generated more than $135 billion in revenue in 2016
column22: meaning Echo-related sales were likely a fraction of 1% of the overall total. Those sales almost certainly come at higher margins for Amazon than
column23: say
column24: shipping a book at the company's usually tiny markup. But from a profit standpoint
column25: Echo seems likely to offer at most a 1%-2% boost
column26: and thus little impact on the fair value of AMZN stock at the moment.Meanwhile
column27: the long-term prospects for Echo aren't completely clear. Usagetends to diminish over time(a trend certainly seen in my household). Echo isn't necessarily being used as a shopping device
column28: either. Rather
column29: the predominant uses are to set a timer
column30: play music
column31: and listen to news summaries.All told
column32: while I do think there's a strong bull case for AMZN stock
column33: that bull case isn't necessarily predicated on Echo. I wouldn't expect that by the end of the decade
column34: consumers across America are ordering Bounty paper towels via drone through Alexa.But that doesn't mean Alexa doesn't matter for Amazon stock.Why Alexa (In Particular) Could Be A Big Deal For AMZN StockOf course
column35: part of the genius of Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos is that Amazon's moves aren't based on the short-term. For all the complaints about AMZN stock's P/E ratio
column36: the company almost certainly could cut costs substantially
column37: and boost earnings
column38: any time it wants.But Amazon continues to play the long game. It continues to expand its addressable markets
column39: taking chances on major successes. (AWS remains the most obvious case of how that strategy has played out well.)From that standpoint
column40: Echo and Alexa are off to a strong early start.Ditch Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock and Look for Greener PasturesAdmittedly
column41: direct Echo revenues are a tiny fraction of overall sales
column42: and Echo-directed e-commerce revenue appears small. But Amazon still benefits from both products. For one
column43: Alexa gives the company a toehold in the important artificial intelligence (AI) space. It allows Amazon to take onApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Siri as well asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL). Google Home sits in second place at the moment.For Alexa
column44: in particular
column45: the opportunities go beyond Echo. Alexa appears in Amazon Tap and the company's Fire Stick. Amazon wisely has opened the platform to third-party developers. They have created thousands of so-called ""skills
column46: which create a virtuous cycle. The more skills there are
column47: the more valuable Alexa is. The more valuable Alexa becomes
column48: the more skills are created. And the more consumers fall in love with the product.Where Alexa Goes From HereThat opens the door to the real potential value in Alexa.Alexa isn't about driving e-commerce sales through Echo. It's about creating the dominant AI framework in the world. Alexa can be used in automobiles
column49: to allow for safer multi-tasking. There are endless potential industrial applications. Because AMZN wisely has opened that system
column50: it's far more likely to see those applications than Siri or Google's AI.That'sthe value in Alexa: its possibilities seem almost endless at the moment. To be sure
column51: that doesn't mean Amazon necessarily will make billions of dollars off Alexa in two years
column52: or in twenty. That's not the point
column53: however. The point is that Amazon.com continues to innovate
column54: and continues to be an ever-increasing part of its consumers' daily lives. From there
column55: the argument goes
column56: the business end will take care of itself
column57: as will AMZN stock.Certainly
column58: it has worked so far.As of this writing
column59: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceiShares Nasdaq Biotechnology Index (ETF) (IBB) Is at a Crossroads5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in MarchThe 7 Best ETFs for Market-Beating ReturnsThe postAlexa CAN Drive Amazon.com
column60: Inc. (AMZN) Stock â€¦ Somedayappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: This Long-Term Trend Makes Facebook an Awesome Buy;3/7/2017;"If you want your marketing message to reach a broad audience
column2: there used to be no better option than national television   commercials. But the growth of digital platforms likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google make it easy to reach   hundreds of millions of people. What's more
column3: you can target your   message so it only reaches the most qualified potential   buyers.That's why digital has been eating into television ad budgets   -- and why analysts expect that trend to continue for the   foreseeable future. eMarketer forecasts that digital advertising   spend in the U.S. will climb to $113 billion by 2020
column4: while TV ad   spend grows much more slowly
column5: reaching just $77 billion. Digital   spend just surpassed television last year.One of the biggest beneficiaries of the shift of ad budgets   from television to digital is Facebook.makeArticleAd();Image source: Facebook.A Super Bowl every dayFacebook COO Sheryl Sandberg once likened Facebook's reach to   the largest television event. ""We have a Super Bowl on mobile   every day
column6: she said.And it's true. Facebook has 1.23 billion daily active users --   1.14 billion on mobile and 180 million in the U.S. and Canada.   The Super Bowl earlier this year attracted 111.3 million viewers   in the U.S.Granted the Super Bowl lasts something like five hours (more   if Tom Brady sends it into overtime). The average Facebook user   spends ""just"" 50 minutes per day across Facebook
column7: Instagram
column8: and   Messenger
column9: the last of which doesn't yet show ads.However
column10: the average American watches less television today   than they did a few years ago. View time across all age groups   fell 11% in the six years ending last fall. The trend is more   pronounced among younger people. People between 18 and 24 spent   35% less time watching traditional television during the second   quarter last year compared to the second quarter of 2010
column11: according to Nielsen.While Facebook isn't the only reason people are watching less   TV
column12: it presents a very good option for advertisers looking to   replace that lost watch time.Facebook is taking a huge share of digital advertising   growthDigital advertising is growing rapidly
column13: but that doesn't mean   all of that ad spend will go to Facebook. Nonetheless
column14: Facebook   has done an excellent job winning those new ad dollars flowing   from television ad budgets to digital.In the third quarter last year
column15: Facebook took 45% of all   digital advertising growth. Google managed to take 54% of   advertising growth
column16: leaving just 1% of growth for everyone   else.Facebook is poised to continue capturing a lion's share of   digital ad spend growth in the future
column17: too. Display advertising   is the largest form of digital advertising today
column18: and eMarketer   expects that to remain the case in the future. Facebook holds a   wide lead in display advertising
column19: bringing in around $12 billion   in the U.S. last year compared to less than $5 billion for   Google.Facebook is also working to attract more video content to its   platform
column20: which fits nicely with the trend of shifting ad   budgets. Facebook is reportedly funding new content productions   for its platform in the hopes of seeding an entire ecosystem   similar to YouTube. YouTube has proven extremely lucrative for   Google
column21: and Facebook wants in on the billions of digital video   adverting revenue it generates every year.Not only are ad budgets shifting from television to digital
column22: Facebook is one of the few companies that's been able to attract   those ad dollars thanks to its audience size
column23: engagement
column24: and ad   targeting capabilities. As the trend continues through the end of   the decade
column25: that makes Facebook an awesome buy.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column26: it can pay to listen. After all
column27: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column28: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column29: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Facebook wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column30: 2017.Suzanne Frey
column31: an executive at Alphabet
column32: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Adam Levyhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A and C shares) and     Facebook. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: YouTube TV Is Here: What Investors Need to Know;3/6/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Americans are changing the way they watch television. More and   more customers are showing interest in over-the-top streaming TV   services. Over 200
column2: 000 people joinedAT&T's(NYSE: T) DirecTVNow in about one month.DISH Network's(NASDAQ: DISH) Sling TV has over 1 million subscribers.Sony's(NYSE: SNE) PlayStation Vue is also very popular.makeArticleAd();Now YouTube -- a subsidiary of Google
column3: theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) company -- is throwing its hat in   the ring as well. The company recently revealed YouTube TV
column4: a   slightly differentiated television service that costs just $35   per month.Here's what investors need to know about YouTube TV.YouTube TV's channel lineup. Image source: YouTubeIt's missing a lot of traditional cable networksYouTube focused on signing deals with the big four broadcast   companies. As a result
column5: cable-only media companies such asViacomandTime Warnerare missing from the bundle. No CNN
column6: Comedy Central
column7: Cartoon Network
column8: TBS
column9: TNT
column10: or HBO. But it does mean cable   networks owned by the big four -- ESPN
column11: FX
column12: USA
column13: E!
column14: and so on --   are all there.That's kind of the opposite approach of Sling TV. Sling   launched without any broadcast networks
column15: inviting subscribers to   buy a television antenna to supplement the service.Importantly
column16: local networks are limited in availability.   That's why YouTube TV is launching only in markets where the   media companies own the local broadcast affiliate. Sony tried   something similar before expanding nationwide with a reduced   price for subscribers where live local channels are not   available.Overall
column17: the channel lineup is somewhat lacking compared with   competing services at around the same price point. Customers that   signed up early for DirecTV Now are receiving 100 channels for   $35 per month
column18: and new customers can still receive 60 channels   for that price. PlayStation Vue customers can get a similar   set of channels for $35 per month
column19: and Sling TV subscribers can   get around 50 channels for $40 per month.The limited geographical reach and channel lineup should   reduce the number of subscribers YouTube TV will attract.YouTube is a veteran at video streamingAlthough YouTube TV may lack some of the content available on   other platforms at similar price points and the geographic reach   of its competition
column20: it has one major advantage. It already owns   leading technology in video streaming.All three of the aforementioned competitors suffered major   technical difficulties following their launches. DirecTV Now   received a lot of bad press as its servers were overloaded making   parts or all of the service unusable. YouTube
column21: on the other hand
column22: already streaming 1 billion hours of video every day.Consumers may be willing to sacrifice some channels for more   reliable service. But YouTube still has to prove that it can   deliver where competitors failed.The bottom line for investorsYouTube TV is a somewhat underwhelming product at launch. With   a limited channel lineup and geographic reach
column23: it's unlikely to   make any significant impact on YouTube's operations in the near   term.In the long term
column24: however
column25: getting a viable product out there   now could lead to a much better product in the future. YouTube is   already offering a few differentiating features such as unlimited   cloud DVR
column26: AI powered search and personalization (likely backed   by YouTube viewer data)
column27: and the ability to split the account six   ways so different users get different recommendations. If YouTube   can get the content deals in place while maintaining competitive   pricing
column28: it could be a big winner in the future.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (C   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 6 Things You Didn't Know About Baidu
column2: Inc.;3/6/2017;"Many tech investors are probably familiar with the basic facts   aboutBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) -- it's the biggest search engine in China
column3: it has   a growing ecosystem of cloud-based services likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google
column4: and it benefited greatly   from Google's exit from the mainland Chinese market in 2010.Those are the bullet points in the growth story that boosted   Baidu stock by nearly 1
column5: 500% over the past decade. But today
column6: we'll take a look at six lesser-known facts about the ""Chinese   Google"" which many investors might have overlooked.Image source: Author's screenshot.makeArticleAd();1. CEO Robin Li cut his teeth in the U.S. tech     industryAfter earning a master's degree in Computer Science from the   University of Buffalo
column7: Baidu co-founder and CEO Robin Li worked   at Dow Jones & Co.'s IDD Information Services and search   company Infoseek in the  1990s.At IDD
column8: Li developed the software for the online version ofThe Wall Street Journaland invented his patented Rankdex site-scoring algorithm for    SEO rankings -- which currently powers Baidu's search   engine. At Infoseek
column9: Li created the image search function
column10: which   was subsequently used inDisney's Go.com network. After spending over five years at those two   companies
column11: Li returned to China and co-founded Baidu with   investor Eric Xu in early 2000.2. Baidu is developing driverless carsLike Google
column12: Baidu believes that autonomous electric cars   would be a natural extension of its data mining ecosystem. The   company started testing out driverless cars on public roads in   late 2015
column13: and formed a driverless tech research center in   Silicon Valley last April.Image source: Getty Images.Baidu is powering these vehicles with a combination ofNVIDIA's automotive chips
column14: HERE Maps
column15: and its own AI algorithms. It's   currently outsourcing production of these vehicles to Chinese   automakers
column16: and has declared that it will launch an autonomous   shuttle bus  by 2018.3. It's beefing up its AI effortsFor search engines like Baidu and Google
column17: AI plays a key role   in recognizing images
column18: analyzing search patterns
column19: and deciding   what types of targeted ads will appeal to users. That's why Baidu   hired a lot of top talent in AI -- its chief scientist Andrew Ng   previously helmed the Google Brain AI project
column20: and its new   augmented reality chief Qi Lu was previously an AI specialist atMicrosoft.Baidu hasn't been shy about challenging Google in the AI arms   race. In January
column21: it pitted its AI program against Google's   AlphaGo AI in  a series of facial and voice recognition   tests in a live TV broadcast.4. Baidu owns a small stake in Didi ChuxingBaidu previously invested in Uber's Chinese division
column22: but Uber   eventually retreated from the market due to tough competition --   especially from market leader Didi Chuxing. Uber sold its Chinese   business to Didi last August
column23: but retained a 17.7% stake in the   new subsidiary. Baidu and Uber China's other  shareholders   received a 2.3% stake.That stake is small
column24: but Baidu could boost it and more tightly   integrate Didi's services into its O2O (online-to-offline)   ecosystem. Didi could also play a key role in automating Baidu's   driverless cars.5. It owns a big part of CtripBaidu owns a 25% stake inCtrip(NASDAQ: CTRP)
column25: the largest online travel agency (OTA) in China.   For years
column26: Ctrip was engaged in a price war with its primary   competitorQunar(NASDAQ: QUNR)
column27: which crushed both companies' margins.Baidu owned a 45% stake in Qunar
column28: but it swapped that stake   for  a 25% stake in Ctrip in 2015 -- which effectively   merged the two companies and ended the price war. That move also   tethered Ctrip's services more tightly to Baidu's growing O2O   ecosystem.6. Baidu also sells smart bikesIn late 2014
column29: Baidu introduced DuBike
column30: a bike equipped with a   wide array of health and motion sensors which sync to a mobile   app. It also features on-board navigation signals
column31: which let   riders follow directions without glancing at their phones
column32: and   lets riders share their routes with friends. To top it off
column33: the   entire system is powered by a rider's kinetic energy -- so the   bike never needs to be recharged.Baidu's DuBike. Image source: Baidu.The key takeawayThe heart of Baidu's business is still search-based   advertising
column34: but that could gradually change as its efforts in   driverless cars
column35: AI
column36: its O2O ecosystem
column37: and even smart bikes pay   off. Therefore
column38: investors should keep an eye on these adjacent   efforts as the company trades blows with other tech titans --   likeTencentandAlibaba-- over the next few years.10 stocks we like better than BaiduWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column41: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Baidu wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: GoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Gutted? Time to Go Long!;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO) is a camera company
column3: yet Wall Street experts expected so much more out the GPRO story. They even once labeled it as ""a YouTube killer."" I betAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) management wasn't too worried then. That exuberance marked the top for GoPro stock.makeArticleAd();Source:ETC-USC via Flickr (Modified)Now
column5: GoPro stock gets a downgrade under $9 per share. I'm sure it's no coincidence that this coincides with the IPO ofSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP)
column6: which had a successful offering last week. Money is probably flocking out of GPRO and into SNAP stock
column7: perhaps to recoup some losses there.I think the two have little in common. GoPro stock is a play on a line of action cameras known for being rugged and for active outdoorsy people. We see videos of extreme base jumping pros to teens clearing a two-foot hedge in their front yard. So far
column8: SNAP appears to capture more general scenarios.The hate for GoPro stock should abate eventually. It still has cool products with very few high-profile direct competitors. I don't have a lot of faith in management
column9: but just like in the case ofTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR)
column10: I think someone will eventually figure the stock out. But for this morning
column11: GPRO stock is down 7.8% on a downgrade from Goldman Sachs.Click to EnlargeBased on that logic
column12: I want to risk a little on a speculative trade going long GPRO stock. I could risk $8 to buy the stock
column13: but instead I will use the options markets to risk even less. My thesis relies on GoPro stock eventually becoming attractive to old fans who revalue their re-entry levels.I do have to note that GPRO is in danger of inviting more technical sellers if it loses these lows. So I will snipe out the entry
column14: perhaps in two tranches.The Bet:Sell the GPRO Jan 2018 $5/$3 credit put spread. This is a bullish trade for which I collect 50 cents to open per contract. If successful
column15: this trade would yield over 30% on money risked. I need GPRO stock to stay above my sold spread to win.Yes
column16: it is a gamble to try and catch falling knives
column17: especially one like GPRO. But I need to add a few speculative plays to my portfolio
column18: and this one qualifies. Again
column19: an underlying assumption is that GoPro will eventually survive. But I don't need it to thrive to profit.Usually
column20: I like to balance my risk by selling upside risk. In this case
column21: however
column22: I won't. GoPro stock has fallen too far
column23: too fast
column24: and I would be selling risk at a severe discount. If GPRO bounced hard
column25: I would face self-inflicted risk against my own thesis.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is the New Amazon.com
column26: Inc. (AMZN)I could juice my bet by buying upside calls
column27: but I will wait out a few more trading hours to flush out an interim bottom. I don't want to turn this trade into an investment yet
column28: however
column29: since I've already said that I don't have much faith in GPRO management's ability.I am not required to hold my options trade option through their expiration. I can close them at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column30: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in March7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe postGoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Gutted? Time to Go Long!appeared first onInvestorPlace."
