column1: IBM to Commercialize Quantum Computing Using Cloud Platform;3/6/2017;"International Business Machines CorporationIBMrecently announced plans to introduce quantum computing systems and services in the commercial space under the brand name ""IBM Q"". The company will leverage its IBM Cloud platform to deliver these systems and services.We note that this is an industry-first initiative undertaken by the technology giant and could revolutionize the way computing is being carried out in the present context.International Business Machines Corporation Price and   ConsensusInternational Business Machines Corporation Price   and Consensus|International Business Machines Corporation QuoteFilling in the Market GapCognitive systems such as IBM Watson run on classical computers and are capable of finding patterns and insights by deciphering huge amount of data. However
column2: in the absence of any such recognizable patterns
column3: these systems are not of much use.This is where quantum computers come into play as they are capable of providing solutions to problems where recognizable patterns don't exist.Quantum computing has its applications in many fields such as artificial intelligence
column4: financial services
column5: cloud security
column6: drug discovery and supply chain and logistics.What Does This Mean for IBM?As per a Market Research Media report
column7: worldwide spending on quantum computing is estimated to reach $5 billion by 2020. Not surprisingly then

column9: with the presence of major players such as MicrosoftMSFT
column10: GoogleGOOGL
column11: Intel
column12: D-Wave Systems
column13: Hewlett Packard and Lockheed Martin.However
column14: IBM with its industry-first initiatives looks poised to carve a niche in this segment.Stock Performance OverviewShares of IBM have underperformed the ZacksComputer - Integrated Systemsindustry over the last one year. While the industry gained 33.8%
column15: the stock appreciated 28.4%.The underperformance of the stock could be due to weakness in the company's traditional businesses and shift toward the cloud that is keeping margins under pressure.  However
column16: we believe that IBM's endeavor in the rapidly growing quantum computing field along with its strategic initiatives will help the stock rebound in 2017.Zacks Rank and Key PickAt present

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Amazon
column2: Google
column3: Facebook  and Apple;3/6/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column4: IL -March 06
column5: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeAmazon.com Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column6: Google(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)
column7: Facebook(NASDAQ:FB-Free Report) andApple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report).Today
column8: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:Amazon to Install Solar Panels to Power DatacentersThe world is fast shifting to alternative energy and this is spurring demand for solar panels.E-commerce giantAmazon.com Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report) is gearing up for its next project associated with renewable energy initiatives. This time
column9: the firm will harness solar energy by installing solar panels on the roof of its fulfillment facilities across the world.Coming to the price performance
column10: over the past year
column11: shares of Amazon outperformed the Zacks categorized Electronic Commerce industry. While the industry gained 39.53%
column12: the stock returned 45.91%.DetailsAs part of its commitment to advance green power
column13: Amazon has plans of deploying large-scale solar systems on rooftops of more than 15 fulfillment and sortation centers in the U.S. this year. By 2020
column14: around 50 data centers are expected to use solar energy to meet their power needs.Amazon said that these solar panels could generate up to 80% of the annual energy requirements of a fulfillment center depending on the project
column15: time of year and other factors. The company already has a network of wind and solar farms in Indiana
column16: North Carolina
column17: Ohio and Virginia. Its largest wind farm is in Texas.Amazon's senior vice president of Worldwide Operations
column18: Dave Clark
column19: said ""As our fulfillment network continues to expand
column20: we want to help generate more renewable energy at both existing and new facilities around the world in partnership with community and business leaders.""Focus on Carbon NeutralityThis initiative by Amazon is the latest in a string of clean energy investments made by U.S. technology giants in recent months. For quite some time

column1: This Odd Little Company Beat the Market in 2016. Is It worth a Look in 2017?;3/6/2017;"It's tough to know what to make ofRaven Industries(NASDAQ: RAVN) . This unique little company's stock jumped 62.7%   in 2016
column2: handily beating larger peers like3M(NYSE: MMM)
column3: as well as the S&P 500. But companies that defy   description can sometimes be hidden buys.If it's tough to describe Raven
column4: it's even tougher to figure   out where the company -- not to mention its stock -- is likely to   head in 2017. That's partly due to a huge issue with the company   that should worry investors who are interested in buying   top-quality stocks.Raven Industries invented the modern hot air balloon. Image     source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();What it doesRaven Industries was formed in 1956
column5: when a group of   businessmen leftGeneral Mills
column6: of all places
column7: to form an industrial balloon company. Over   the next few decades
column8: Raven invented the modern hot air balloon   and dabbled in other materials science industries like fiberglass   tanks
column9: parachutes
column10: cold-weather sportswear
column11: and utility truck   bodies. The company branched out into the businesses of flow   systems and agricultural control systems in the 80s and 90s.Today
column12: Raven still manufactures balloons
column13: covers
column14: liners
column15: and   films used in various applications from grain covers to   wastewater pit liners to industrial packaging. It also has robust   agricultural controls and radar technologies businesses. The   ""internet balloons"" developed byAlphabet's Google to bring broadband access to rural areas utilize   Raven's balloon technology.Even with its 2016 performance
column16: Raven is still a small   company
column17: with a less than $1 billion market cap. So
column18: let's look   at how such a small-yet-diversified company managed to crush the   market last year.The Trump factorAs you might expect with a small-cap company
column19: Raven's growth   was very lumpy throughout 2016
column20: in sharp contrast to the much   larger 3M and the S&P:RAVNdata byYCharts.But as you can see
column21: one of the biggest jumps of the year for   the company came
column22: unsurprisingly
column23: in the wake of Donald Trump's   upset win in the November election. Such a win was seen as a boon   forconstruction companiesbecause of a potential major infrastructure package
column24: fordefense contractorsbecause of potential increases in military spending
column25: and forenergy companiesbecause of the potential removal of environmental   regulations.Raven Industries operates in all of those fields
column26: manufacturing films for the construction industry
column27: surveillance   balloons and equipment for the military
column28: and films to contain   fracking waste. No wonder the market has high hopes for the   company going into 2017.Of course
column29: considering the amount of opposition on Capitol   Hill to some of President Trump's policies and proposals
column30: it   would be a risky bet to buy Raven's stock solely on speculation   about his agenda without more details about how it might be   implemented -- and whether Congress is buying in to his   proposals. But there's an even bigger risk for potential Raven   investors.The red flagRaven is in an unusual situation in that
column31: as of early   February
column32: it was in non-compliance with NASDAQ rules for failure   to submit quarterly reports to the SEC. Since then
column33: the company   has filed five quarterly SEC reports
column34: including amended Q3 2016   and full-year 2016 reports
column35: as well as an amended Q1 2017 report   and Q2 and Q3 reports.The company hadn't held an earnings conference call since   March 2016
column36: but it finally held one on February 16th. On   that call
column37: as you can imagine
column38: there was a heaping helping of   humble pie served up by CEO Dan Rhykus. ""I'd like to address our   reevaluation of our internal control framework and the controlled   deficiencies we identified
column39: he began
column40: before stating the   following:We are responding with the utmost urgency and diligence to     remedy the situation and to ensure that we maintain a more     proactive approach to adapting the changes in the future
column41: so     that our framework design appropriate adapts to whatever     changes our business may experience in the future or to changes     in the regulatory environment. As we work to remediate     these material weaknesses and enhance our control's framework
column42: we will keep you fully informed and updated.Essentially
column43: management discovered that ""The  Company's    controls  relating  to  the response    to  the  risks  of  material    misstatement  were  not  effectively    designed
column44: according to the company's amended 2016 10-K.   Specifically
column45: these control issues could -- and did -- lead the   company to misstate items including goodwill
column46: long-lived assets
column47: income taxes
column48: and inventories on its quarterly and annual   reports.While many of these misstatements were comparatively small --   selling
column49: general
column50: and administrative expenses
column51: for example
column52: were   revised upwards by just $20
column53: 000 for FY 2016 -- some were far more   significant. Long-lived asset impairment losses of $3.8 million
column54: for example
column55: weren't even included in the original 2016 10-K
column56: and   contributed to a $6.7 million drop in EBIT on the amended report.   That in turn helped to drop annual EPS from $0.23 (original) to   $0.13 (restated)
column57: a major change.What's of more concern than these identified issues
column58: however
column59: is the possibility that there are other problems that haven't yet   come to light.Investor takeawayThere's certainly a case to be made that -- with its reporting   now up-to-date and with remediation efforts under way -- Raven's   troubles are behind it
column60: and it's a safe investment moving   forward. Plus
column61: the company's reported third-quarter earningswere actually pretty impressive. Operating income was up 175% year over year
column62: for   example. So maybe I'm being overly cautious when I say that   I don't feel comfortable investing in Raven until it can provide   concrete assurances that it has its house in order (remember
column63: the   company hasn't yet been able to guarantee the issues are   solved).In the third-quarter earnings call
column64: Rhykus has promised to   keep investors updated
column65: so I'll be eagerly awaiting those   updates. In the meantime
column66: there are plenty of other companies   that aregenerating strong earningsthat don't seem to be having the internal problems that Raven is   having. If you're interested in materials science stocks
column67: you   could consider 3M
column68: despite its middling outlook. For now
column69: though
column70: cautious investors should probably look   elsewhere.10 stocks we like better than Raven IndustriesWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column71: it can pay to listen. After all
column72: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Apple Music Just Canâ€™t Catch Spotify;3/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Music is a success by all counts
column3: but one target still remains elusive.makeArticleAd();Despite impressive subscriber gains since its 2015 launch
column4: AAPL's streaming music service has been unable to catch primary rivalSpotify. And in the latest sign that the competition is far from over
column5: Spotify just announced it has hit the 50 million paid subscriber mark.Spotify Hits 50 Million Paid SubscribersApple Music and Spotify are considered to be the two big players in the streaming music war.Spotify launched in 2008
column6: giving it a long lead in which to build up steam over Apple Music
column7: which didn't go live until 2015. Despite that head start - and predictions that after its initial free three-month trial expired
column8: Apple's streaming music service would see a big drop off of subscribers - Apple Music quickly began to gain obliterate Spotify's numbers.Apple Music hit 10 million paid subscribers after just six months
column9: a milestone that took Spotify nearly six years to reach. Since then
column10: Apple Music has continued to add paid subscribers at a rapid pace: 11 million by last February
column11: 13 million in April
column12: 17 million in September and 20 million in December.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Posts Best Q4 Apple Watch Sales EverHowever
column13: despite the rapidly increasing popularity of Apple's streaming music service
column14: Spotify stubbornly refuses to go away. In fact
column15: rather than stalling or beginning to slip as many expected
column16: Spotify's numbers have also been growing strongly.Spotify had roughly 20 million paid subscribers at the time Apple Music launched. This week
column17: the company announced it hashit 50 million.In other words
column18: Spotify is not going anywhere any time soon.A Little More CompetitionWhile the big streaming music battle has been between Apple Music and Spotify
column19: many other competitors are duking it out for the dollars of music fans. And rather than scare off new entrants
column20: the success of Apple Music led to a big new competitor taking a shot at the business.Amazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)launched Amazon Music Unlimited last fall
column22: matching Apple Music's basic subscription rates. But Amazon added a twist by discounting the service for Amazon Prime members and slashing it it less than half the regular $9.99 monthly fee for owners of its Amazon Echo smart speaker.Will Apple Music Ever Catch Spotify? (And Does It Need to?)The success of Apple Music isn't just about bragging rights.The streaming music service is part of Apple's Services division. That division is increasingly important to the bottom line. It provides recurring revenue
column23: which helps to protect against shocks when hardware sales hit rough patches. In AAPL's most recent quarter
column24: Services posted thestrongest year-over-year growth of any of Apple's divisions.2016 revenue numbers for Spotify aren't yet available
column25: but the music streaming service has consistently lost money
column26: including $176.9 million in 2014 and $188.7 million. Thesituation looked grim a year ago
column27: with Apple Music growing rapidly. However
column28: big increases in paid subscriber drove a revenue gain of80% to $2.12 billion. That marked a turning point in the outlook for Spotify's survival.With profitability a distinct possibility in 2017
column29: Spotify could be in acquisition territory.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) andFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) have both been floated aspotential buyers. An initial public offering could also be in its future.Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 Lightning Port Drama ContinuesRegardless
column30: Apple Music seems unlikely to knock Spotify off the top of the streaming music charts
column31: at least not in the near future.That doesn't mean Apple Music isn't a success. It quickly vaulted from zero to a contender for top spot in mere months and has continued to grow. As shown by the number of streaming music services that continue to attract paid subscribers
column32: there is still plenty of room for multiple big players to make money.Apple Music will continue to drive revenue into AAPL's Services division
column33: even if that coveted No. 1 spot remains elusive.As of this writing
column34: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceFriday Apple Rumors: iPhone Delay

column1: Believe It or Not
column2: Apple Came in Dead Last in Customer Loyalty in This $24 Billion Market;3/3/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) knows what it's doing. The company is a market   leader in many fields
column3: and would often rather abandon a product   category rather than struggle on as a minor competitor to bigger   and better rivals.But even mighty Apple does the occasional swing-and-a-miss   routine. And some of Cupertino's whiffs come in vibrant   billion-dollar markets.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Apple ranks dead last in the $24 billion file-hosting   marketBrand Keysis a branding consultancy firm with more than three decades of   expertise-building history under its belt. The firm is best known   for its Customer Loyalty Engagement Index (CLEI) rankings
column4: where   a proprietary data-collection process builds customer-loyalty   ratings in more than 80 specific product categories.Apple
column5: of course
column6: dominates several of the latest Brand Keysratings. The iPhone shows up all comers in the smartphone category
column7: no   tablet can beat the iPad's consumer loyalty
column8: and MacBooks walks   away with the top rating among laptop brands. In something of an   upset
column9: Apple Musiceven takes home the online music segment.And then there's the file-storage category. There
column10: Apple   doesn't just miss the top spot
column11: but falls all the way to the   bottom of 13 ranked services.How bad is that result for Apple?To be clear
column12: Brand Keys claims that its measurements translate   directly into future sales prospects and revenues. According to   independent metrics fromMarkets and Markets
column13: cloud storage is a $24 billion market today -- and expected to   reach annual sales of $75 billion in just five years.In other words
column14: it looks like Apple is leaving a lot of cash   on the table. The iCloud file-storage service is not pulling its   weight
column15: or moving the needle for Apple. Instead
column16: consumers with a   need for off-site file-storage tools prefer free services like   Brand Keys' category winner
column17: Sabrecat -- or a plethora of   better-known options such as runner-up Dropbox
column18: or third-place   finisherGoogle(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Drive.Apple is not only missing a significant market opportunity
column19: but leaving a lot of that cash for Google parent Alphabet to grab   instead.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.Why is Apple missing the boat?Apple's iCloud is
column20: in many ways
column21: very similar to Google Drive   and Dropbox. All three services allow users to store nearly any   type of file in a centrally managed cloud server
column22: accessible from   any networked computer. They all come with small storage limits   for a free account
column23: all offer a terabyte of storage for $9.99 per   month
column24: and come with various tools for managing your stored   files. But Apple does a few things differently.First and foremost
column25: the easiest way to access iCloud content   is via an iPhone
column26: iPad
column27: or MacBook. In fact
column28: signing up for an   iCloud account is part of the setup process for all of these   systems. Then
column29: the service is integrated into your Apple   experience as the destination for system backup files
column30: the   default storage location for files created in the iWork office   suite
column31: and an option for storing user files in newer versions of   the macOS system.All of this is designed to keep users tightly bound to Apple's   multi-device ecosystem. Once you're in
column32: it's not easy to get   untangled. Given Apple's massive market reach
column33: especially in the   tablet and smartphone segments
column34: this alone should make iCloud a   winner. Apple CEO Tim Cook introduced the package as ""a strategy   for the next decade"" in 2012.However
column35: Apple never quite delivered on that grand ambition.   iCloud is reportedly ostracized by other working groups within   the company
column36: starved of resources
column37: and mostly seen as a necessary   evil. Apple is a product company
column38: and iCloud is not a marketable   product on its own -- at least not in its current Apple-centric   form. So
column39: this odd piece of infrastructure machinery is left out   in the cold.And there goes Apple's ticket to a $24 billion industry that's   also on a rapid growth tear.Google sure is building its Drive product into everything from   Gmail to mobile photo storage to storage space for corporate   accounts. Dropbox is doing the same
column40: while on the lookout for   another buyout bid. And this market should only grow faster as   theInternet of Thingsgrows up
column41: requiring acres of cloud-based storage space. These   companies treat online file storage as an important business
column42: valuable on its own merits.Apple doesn't. Hence
column43: the company is holding back on promoting   iCloud
column44: developing it further
column45: or building it into other   products
column46: when appropriate. Cupertino misses out on a major   growth story
column47: with absolutely no loyalty from the customers who   do sign up.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Googleâ€™s Groundbreaking Oscar Nod Could Pave the Way for VR;3/3/2017;"Virtual reality (VR) is a technology that is still in the   early stages of adoption. While headsets are available
column2: VR has   yet to gain wide acceptance due to the high cost of consoles and   equipment
column3: and the lack of sufficient content. Additionally
column4: the   technology is still largely unfamiliar to the majority of   consumers

column8: a VR   storytelling venue

column10: Pearl
column11: is centered on the life and times of a musical father and   daughter traveling the country in pursuit of stardom. The   animated scenes all take place from the point-of-view of a   passenger in the front seat of their car. The ground-breaking   film was directed by Patrick Osbourne who received an Oscar in   2015 for his work onWalt Disney's(NYSE: DIS)Feast
column12: a short film about a man and his adopted dog

column23: andHasbro'sTransformersfranchise.Samsung Gear VR. column18: Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin and Chairman Eric Schmidt traveled to Omaha to talk to Buffett when setting up the new Alphabet structure
column19: which is molded after Berkshire.Shortly before the trip
column20: they brought in CFO Ruth Porat
column21: who understands the tech founders' goals for the company.Buffett included the following paragraphs in the 2017 shareholder letter
column22: putting my spider senses on red alert:""In 2002
column23: entrepreneur Mitch Kapor asserted that 'By 2029 no computer - or 'machine intelligence' - will have passed the Turing Test
column24: ' which deals with whether a computer can successfully impersonate a human being. Inventor Ray Kurzweil took the opposing view. Each backed up his opinion with $10
column25: 000. I don't know who will win this bet
column26: but I will confidently wager that no computer will ever replicate Charlie.That same year
column27: Craig Mundie of Microsoft asserted that pilotless planes would routinely fly passengers by 2030
column28: while Eric Schmidt of Google argued otherwise. The stakes were $1
column29: 000 each. To ease any heartburn Eric might be experiencing from his outsized exposure
column30: I recently offered to take a piece of his action. He promptly laid off $500 with me. (I like his assumption that I'll be around in 2030 to contribute my payment
column31: should we lose.)""This paragraph shows Buffett has been studying the tech world very hard and is open to the possibility the Turing test will be cracked by 2029. He also must have looked into the dynamics of driverless or pilotless technology
column32: note the recent investment into airlines
column33: to take on a $500 bet. I do not think betting against Buffett is generally a profitable endeavour. What jumped out at me is
column34: apparently
column35: Alphabet's chairman and Buffett recently spoke again. They must have spoken for quite some time for the subject of this casual bet to come up.All these factors have led me to speculate on the potential of an Alphabet investment.The pieces are falling into place.Buffett has been studying tech intensely.Berkshire has made a 180 as far as tech investments go.Buffett and Munger view Alphabet as having an incredibly strong moat.Alphabet's valuation is at an attractive level given the interest from the value investing greats. Porat is a great addition to the executive suite
column36: covering up pre-existing weaknesses in the team.Google executives have met with Buffett on multiple occasions and Schmidt talked to him recently.The one thing I could see keeping Buffett from making an investment is his distaste for stock-based compensation. Alphabet continues to dole it out like it is candy on Halloween.I would go as far as to say it would greatly surprise me if we do not see Berkshire buying a stake in Alphabet in the next five years.Disclosure: Author owns none of these stocks.Start afree 7-day trial of Premium Membershipto GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Does Alphabet's Self-Driving Car Lawsuit Spell Disaster for Uber?;3/2/2017;"Last week
column2: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)  spinoff Waymo sued Uber for   stealing some of its key autonomous car technology. It doesn't   take a lawyer to know that things don't look good for Uber
column3: but   does this spell disaster for the ride-sharing company's   self-driving dream? Here's what you need to know.The not-so-secret dirty detailsNow that this is in the rearview mirror
column4: it's clear we   should've seen it coming. According to Alphabet
column5: former Waymo   employee Anthony Levandowski illegally downloaded 14
column6: 000 ""highly   confidential and proprietary files""  in December 2015 that   detailed the secret software and hardware designs   for Waymo's LIDAR system. LIDAR systems are being developed   as the ""eyes"" of most companies' attempts at autonomous vehicles
column7: allowing them to ""see"" the world around them via millions of   low-power laser beams blasted out every second. In January   2016
column8: Levandowski started his own self-driving company in   and
column9: two weeks later
column10: resigned without notice from Waymo.   In August 2016
column11: he sold his company to Uber for $680 million.IMAGE SOURCE: ALPHABET (WAYMO)makeArticleAd();Levandowski and Uber might've managed to keep things under the   radar
column12: were it not for a LIDAR component vendor (apparently   inadvertently) copying Waymo on an email to Uber
column13: in which   attached documents bore a ""striking resemblance"" to Waymo's own   LIDAR designs.Alphabet knows a thing or two about computers
column14: and the details   of Levandowski's data dig only served to make the alleged act of   design theft look even more provable. So what does this mean for   Alphabet
column15: Uber
column16: and the future of self-driving car stocks?Blinded by the smite?Lawsuits are a norm
column17: not an anomaly
column18: among major corporations.   Alphabet itself is under constant legal attack: At the moment
column19: it's facing antitrust inquiries in the European Union
column20: Argentina
column21: India
column22: Brazil
column23: Russia
column24: and South Korea
column25: as well as patent   violation and intellectual property claims by the likes ofOracle. As a privately held company
column26: Uber doesn't announce its legal   matters in a single spot
column27: but a quick search turns up hundreds of   suits.On issues of intellectual property
column28: in particular
column29: lawsuits   can get particularly sticky. If proven guilty
column30: Uber will likely   cough up buckets of cash to Alphabet since
column31: in Alphabet's words
column32: Uber has avoided ""incurring the risk
column33: time
column34: and expense of   independently developing their own technology."" By Alphabet's   calculation
column35: that includes the $680 million valuation of OttoandUber's entire self-driving program
column36: since they believe it   would've otherwise stayed stalled.That counterfactual claim is hard to prove
column37: and it may also be   difficult to disentangle Uber's own recent advances in   self-driving technology. It's impossible for Uber staff to forget   what they now know
column38: and almost as impossible for them to even   determine whether what they know is Alphabet's or Uber's.A signal for self-driving car stocksImage source: Getty Images.More so than anything else
column39: this lawsuit serves as a warning   for self-driving car companies and their shareholders. Alphabet
column40: Uber
column41: and others are in a fierce competition to build the best   self-driving car out there
column42: and any attempt to cheat will be met   with the full force of the law.But investors shouldn't equate lawsuits with bankruptcy.   Rather
column43: they should take a ""buyer beware"" stance and ask whether   a given lawsuit is a warning sign of a deeper issue. An   intellectual property lawsuit could be an indicator of an overly   competitive company culture
column44: a short-term issue
column45: or even a lack   of creative talent. Which problem is at the root of the suit   could be a better indicator about the ultimate direction of the   corporate defendant's stock than the specific legal details. So   if you're an investor in autonomous car companies
column46: remember to   look out for lawsuits
column47: read into them the right things
column48: and make   informed choices as you hunt for the biggest potential winners in   this increasingly competitive race.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column52: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right nowâ€¦ and Alphabet (A shares) wasn't     one of them! column1: Google Submits Updated Designs for Charleston East Campus;3/2/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle has submitted updated plans for its iconic office complex in Silicon Valley.The 18.6 acre Google Charleston East office space is the search giant's first ground-up project. Initially announced in 2015

column11: 000 square foot extensive campus. Also

column2: 000+ Engineers Working on AR;3/2/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere is growing speculation thatApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) next big thing is augmented reality. Of course
column4: the 10th anniversary iPhone 8 looms large as the critical hardware release this year
column5: but the new iPhone could well be part of that Apple AR strategy. A new report adds more fuel to the fire
column6: suggesting Apple may have over 1
column7: 000 engineers currently working on an augmented reality project in Israel.makeArticleAd();Source: NianticBusiness Insiderpublished a report based on a research note by UBS
column8: suggesting augmented reality is likely to be ""Apple's next major product innovation.""The UBS Report on Apple AR ProjectUBS analyst Steven Milunovich points out the increasing frequency of Apple CEO Tim Cook's public comments about augmented reality.He has repeatedly stated that AR will be a much bigger deal than virtual reality
column9: suggesting that Apple is not following the path ofFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) and its Oculus Rift VR headset. While suggesting that he believes augmented reality could be as big as the iPhone
column10: Cook also points out that he doesn't see it as a standalone product
column11: but more as a core technology that is incorporated into other products.That suggests the Apple AR focus is on implementing advanced augmented reality technology that could be part of the iPhone 8. There have already been clues that AAPL isup to something big with the new iPhone's camera. Apple has also acquired a number of companies working on technology that could be applicable to augmented reality
column12: includingPrimeSense(3D sensing)
column13: RealFace(facial recognition) andMetaio(software-based augmented reality solution).7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeCiting industry sources
column14: Milunovich says
column15: ""the company may have over 1
column16: 000 engineers working on a project in Israel that could be related to AR."" Why Israel? Both PrimeSense and RealFace are Israeli companies. Keeping the Apple AR team in that country would minimize disruption
column17: and remove it from snooping media in Silicon Valley.The UBS research note concludes that Apple's moves could result in ""moderate 3D mapping â€¦ and possibly an AR software development kit"" being available as early as the iPhone 8 launch.How Likely Is the Apple AR Project?Predicting AAPL product development is always risky because the company seldom confirms any details
column18: it maintains a veil of secrecy around new products and some prototypes never see the light of day as an actual product release. Like that long-rumoredApple television.However
column19: the fact that Tim Cook has been so vocal about playing up augmented reality suggests he is setting the stage for anAAPL augmented reality announcement.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Just Succeeded Where Apple Inc. (AAPL) FailedThe number of people the analyst believes are currently working on the Apple AR project also lends credence to the theory that it is both real
column20: and a big deal. Apple is a huge company
column21: but a team of over 1
column22: 000 engineers still stands out. For comparison
column23: in the lead-up to the Apple Watch release
column24: it was reported that AAPL hadassembled a team of 100 engineersto work on that top-secret product.Then there's the reality - not AR or VR
column25: but real life reality - that for the past decade Apple stock has been propelled by the iPhone. And the smartphone market is maturing. The 10th anniversary iPhone 8 will undoubtedly pay off with a big spike in sales
column26: but that is unlikely to last. The company needs something compelling enough to kick off a whole new cycle of iPhone upgrades.That's the Apple AR project. If Tim Cook can convince people that augmented reality is our spectacular future
column27: and Apple can deliver a compelling AR experience that's built right into an iPhone - no dorky headsets required
column28: no additional equipment to buy and no VR motion sickness - then Apple stock is just getting started.As of this writing
column29: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhat Is Apple Inc. Doing With Its iPhone 8 Lightning Port?Report: Apple Inc. iPhone 8 Could Cost More Than $1

column1: Snap Admits It Has No Moat;3/1/2017;"A moat is one of the most important things needed for a   company to succeed. The term
column2: coined by Warren Buffett
column3: is a   flowery way of describing a competitive advantage
column4: which will   protect the company's profits and market share (the castle) from   competing businesses.Snap(NYSE: SNAP)
column5: by its own admission
column6: doesn't have a moat.""In a world where anyone can distribute products instantly and   provide them for free
column7: the best way to compete is by innovating   to create the most engaging products. That's because it's   difficult to use distribution or cost as a competitive advantage   -- new software is available to users immediately
column8: and for free
column9: management wrote in the company's S-1 filing.makeArticleAd();In other words
column10: Snap believes the only way to compete in its   market is to out-innovate its competitors likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) and Google
column11: theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary. But what we've already   seen is that simply being innovative isn't enough if a larger   competitor can just copy the innovation.Image source: Snap.Snap's ""innovation"" budget is significantly smaller than   competitors'Snap spent $184 million on research and development (R&D)   last year. That's nothing compared to Alphabet
column12: Facebook
column13: or evenTwitter(NYSE:TWTR) . Keep in mind
column14: Twitter is reducing its R&D   expenditure.Company2016 R&D ExpenseR&D as a Percentage of RevenueSnap$0.18 billion45.4%Alphabet$13.95 billion15.5%Facebook$5.92 billion21.4%Twitter$0.71 billion28.2%Data source: SEC filings and company quarterly reports.To be sure
column15: as a percentage of revenue
column16: Snap reinvested much   more than any of its competitors. But it's unlikely Snap will   continue investing that high of a percentage of revenue into   R&D. It simply can't afford to if it wants to show investors   that it has any potential at all of becoming profitable at some   point.Snap's cost of revenue is its biggest expense
column17: and it alreadycommitted to spending $3 billion on cloud   infrastructure over the next five years.Snap doesn't have the resources to out-innovate its   competition
column18: even if it's significantly more focused than any of   them.Even if it does out-innovate...Snapchat is certainly an innovative app. It's changed the way   people communicate
column19: and it quickly grew very popular. Growth has   slowed in recent months
column20: however
column21: as its competitors --   specifically Facebook -- have attempted to copy some of its core   functionality.Facebook has been trying to copy Snapchat ever since it tried   to buy the company way back in 2013. While several attempts were   unsuccessful
column22: Facebook kept at it until it found a winner. Its   recent success withInstagram Storiesdemonstrates the risk Snapchat explains in its S-1. It must keep   innovating to stay ahead of competitors copying its product.But where Snap claims ""it's difficult to use distribution   [...] as a competitive advantage
column23: Facebook is showing exactly   the opposite. It's developed a huge competitive advantage because   it has a launching pad for new products like Instagram Stories or   Facebook Live. The company went from nearly 0 to 100 million   hours of video views per day in just over a year and a half.To say distribution isn't a competitive advantage ignores a   significant part of the value of Facebook's massive audience.   While not everything it launches succeeds
column24: the odds are stacked   in Facebook's favor. That's evident from the success of Instagram   Stories and other product features Facebook blatantly borrowed   from competitors like Twitter
column25: such as live video and trending   topics.Distribution isn't a competitive advantage for Snap (at least   relative to giants like Facebook and Google)
column26: but that doesn't   mean it's not a competitive advantage for Facebook or Google.   That fact makes Snap's admitted lack of a moat even more of a   risk for investors.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Snap Inc. wasn't one of     them! column1: YouTube Tops 1 Billion Hours a Day: Can It Pass TV?;3/1/2017;"YouTube looks to take down television as the most watched format in the U.S.The Wall Street Journalreported users worldwide are watching more than one billion hours of videos a day on the online video platform.The one billion hours is partially the result of the artificial intelligence that is used to recommend videos and keep people tuned in. The number of hours watched has increased 10-fold since 2012
column2: when YouTube started building algorithms that look into user data to give each user a personalized lineup of videos.Currently
column3: TV still holds the title as the most watched platform in the U.S. with 1.25 billion hours people spent watching each day
column4: while TV also beat YouTube and other online streaming services in revenue generated from ads. YouTube may not be far off on the hours but it still has a long way to go on revenue.The content on the website is generated by users all around the world
column5: professional or not. These users are uploading 400 hours of video each minute
column6: or 65 years of video a day to YouTube.YouTube Profits?It is not clear how much money YouTube is generating for Alphabet Inc.GOOGLThe Wall Street Journalreported in 2015 that YouTube generated about $4 billion in 2014 and that division is ""roughly break-even.""The video-sharing website makes most of its revenue by running ads before videos; however
column7: it is not enough when taking the heavy cost of technology and rights to content into account. YouTube struggles to expand its core audience beyond teens and to gain users that visit YouTube.com daily instead of coming from other websites from links or embedded videos. The company relies on popular videos
column8: music videos and content created by the users to gain traffic. YouTube's content tends to attract only a few population groups; as a result
column9: not all companies are willing to pay for ads on YouTube
column10: even when YouTube has one billion hours watched.While YouTube focuses on the content that its users put out
column11: competitors like Amazon.com Inc.AMZNand Netflix Inc.NFLXfocus on licensing Hollywood-produced content and creating original programmingto attract a wide range of audiences.Next StepsHowever
column12: the new deal between Alphabet Inc.and Comcast Corp.CMCSAmight increase the traffic on YouTube. On Monday
column13: YouTube and Comcast announced that Comcast customers with the latest gear would be able to search and watch YouTube videos through their cable boxes.Google also helps YouTube tremendously in gaining new viewers with its enormous reach on the Internet. YouTube videos are embedded in search results and Google pre-installs the YouTube app on its Android software. The website is also starting to secure rights to sports videos and shows for children.On Tuesday
column14: YouTube announced YouTube TV
column15: their service to disrupt traditional cable providers. For $35 per month
column16: users will be able to stream major broadcast networks like CBS
column17: ABC
column18: NBC and FOX. Users will still get YouTube's original programming and sports networks like ESPN.""Millennial love great TV content
column19: but they don't want to watch it in the traditional setting
column20: said Susan Wojcicki
column21: YouTube CEO at YouTube TV's launch event.While YouTube is on pace to surpass TV in hours spent watching in the U.S.
column22: the company also focuses on their algorithms and software in identifying and catering the needs of their audiences. By expanding in this regard and working on their targeting
column23: YouTube can become America's favorite visual platform.Everything You Need to Know About Snapchat BEFORE It Goes PublicmakeArticleAd();You may be curious about the buzz surrounding Snap Inc.'s IPO on March 2. With the company expected to be valued around $22 billion
column24: it is expected to be the largest IPO since 2014. But should you snap up this tech stock on Day 1?In the 2017 IPO Watch List
column25: you'll get an inside look at Snap's exciting prospects and potential challenges. You'll also learn about 4 other exciting tech companies with jaw-dropping growth. Each could go public in the coming months.Imagine being in the first wave of investors to jump on a company with almost unlimited growth potential? column2: Inc.â€™s (AMZN) AWS Outage Is a Big Deal;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsYesterday
column4: Amazon.com
column5: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) vice president of cloud architecture strategy

column7: gave apresentation at a tech conference. Of course

column12: investors should still be concerned. Let's face it
column13: AWS is critical for AMZN stock.Last year
column14: this business segment reported a56% spike in revenues to $12.2 billionand operating income came to $3.1 billion. There are over 1 million active customers. More importantly
column15: Amazon Web Services essentially subsidizes the core ecommerce business - which has razor-thin margins - but also allows for the heavy investments in efforts like video/music streaming
column16: Alexa and devices like the Kindle.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017As for the AWS outage
column17: it lasted roughlyfour hoursand resulted in the disruption of thousands of websites and cloud apps across the US. Some of the high-profile companies that were impacted includedApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column18: Twitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) andTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO).At the heart of this was the failure of the S3 system
column19: which provides for the efficient storage of content. The irony is that AMZN could not even access its own dashboard to deal with the problems - since it was also hosted on the AWS platform!The Real Impact?It is important to keep the outage in perspective. For the most part
column20: Amazon Web Services has a great track record
column21: with uptime that is over 99%. As a result
column22: whenever there is a major outage
column23: there is quite a bit of buzz.Besides
column24: AWS is a standout offering. Over the years
column25: AMZN has added great features - such as for data analytics
column26: AI (artificial intelligence) and improved security functions - and has also been diligent with lowering pricing. Yet
column27: this does not mean the outage is trivial. It's reasonable to assume that there are many companies that are evaluating the situation. After all
column28: should there be more usage of alternative systems?Well
column29: I think so. Note that other internet giants are leveraging their own systems to provide cloud services
column30: as seen withAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column31: NASDAQ:GOOG). Google is even the main vendor for the fast-growingSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP)
column32: which has signed a$2 billion contract.Oh
column33: and many old-line tech operators have been investing heavily in their cloud systems. Just some includeInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column34: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL)
column35: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co(NYSE:HPE) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). All these companies have key advantages like trusted brands
column36: global infrastructures and massive customer bases.Interestingly enough
column37: these companies also have something else: They provide hybrid solutions
column38: such as a blend of cloud services and on-premise technologies. This means a customer can place their mission-critical systems on private servers
column39: which would mean no disruption if there was an outage of AWS.Bottom Line for AMZN StockOK then
column40: with the outage of AWS
column41: there should still not necessarily panic. The market opportunity for the cloud is massive - with plenty of room for multiple players. What's more
column42: the financial costs for the outage will probably be immaterial. According to Global Equities' Trip Chowdhry
column43: he thinks that there could be a2% drop in revenues for the first quarter.Procter & Gamble Co (PG) Stock Remains a Good Bet for InvestorsIf there are a couple more outages
column44: however
column45: then the situation could get dicey. When it comes to cloud hosting
column46: there aren't too many second chances.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is the author of various books
column47: includingTaxes 2017: Saving A Bundle.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column48: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Marijuana Stocks to Buy on a Federal Crackdown7 MLPs to Buy With High (And Growing!) YieldsThe postAmazon.com

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Just Succeeded Where Apple Inc. (AAPL) Failed;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) isn't exactly a direct competitor toApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column3: but the former just eclipsed the latter
column4: and seemingly out of nowhere.makeAd('4'
column6: 'mktsnews'
column7: 'vanguard'
column9: '');Source: GoogleOne of the worst-kept secrets in the industry has been Apple's determination to get into the TV business. The company has been working for years trying to put together an online TV service
column10: hoping to offer 25 channels for between $30 and $40 monthly. That project seemed to have been put on hold when AAPL and broadcasters couldn't reach an agreement on price.But Alphabet has just succeeded where Apple failed.YouTube TV - live TV from over 40 providers including the big networks for $35 per month - is now official.YouTube TV Takes on CableYouTube TVwas announced on Tuesday. Launching ""soon"" in the U.S.
column11: this is Google's skinny TV bundle for cord cutters. The four major networks are onboard. So isWalt Disney Co's(NYSE:DIS) ESPN
column12: along with regional sports networks. Google is also including some content from its premium YouTube Red service. All told
column13: there will be over 40 different content providers - not bad for $35 per month.Subscribers get unlimited cloud DVR storage
column14: search powered by Google's AI
column15: six user accounts (three streams can be active simultaneously) and the ability to watch YouTube TV on a variety of devices including smartphones
column16: tablets
column17: PCs and Google Chromecast.Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Become a Trillion-Dollar CompanyIn other word
column18: this is pretty much what Apple has been struggling to release.YouTubeTV is Eerily Similar to Apple's Television PlansApple has to have been watching Google's YouTube TV announcement with dismay. Its rival beat it to the punch with the streaming TV bundle it had envisioned offering with the Apple TV.What makes it even more galling is how close YouTube TV is to what AAPL was negotiating.In May 2015
column19: AAPL andCBS Corporation(NYSE:CBS) were in talks about a subscription Apple television streaming service
column20: butmoney was reportedly a sticking point. In December of that year
column21: CBS CEO Les Moonves confirmed toBusiness Insiderthat his network had been in talks with Apple
column22: and were close to settling on a monthly price to charge consumers. Moonves was throwing around $35 - exactly the price that YouTube TV is charging.Apple balked. Apparently Google was waiting in the wings.Where Does This Leave AAPL and Its TV Strategy?At this point
column23: Apple's entire television strategy seems to be struggling.There was hope that the new Apple TV that launched in 2015 would come with a streaming TV bundle. That didn't happen. Now Apple's set-top streamer is suffering from disappointing sales. The box costs twice what Google andAmazon.com
column24: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) charge for their streamers
column25: but lacks the 4K support rivals offer.Last year
column26: AAPL was showing off anew TV appthat would serve as a hub for streaming content
column27: tracking use across multiple services and devices. But it failed to get buy-in fromNetflix
column28: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)
column29: making its usefulness questionable.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Could Break $1
column30: 000 If ...Google's YouTube TV launch is the icing on the cake.Where Can Apple Go From Here?Don't expect Apple to give up on its plans
column31: of course.The signs of a renewed push toward taking over your living room began last month. Applehired the former head of Amazon's Fire TVto take over as the head of marketing for Apple TV. This move has raised expectations that AAPL will revamp its Apple TV hardware. It also freed up the previous head of Apple TV to helplead Apple's efforts to sign content deals- something he had considerable experience in from his previous role as senior VP of content distribution atHulu.While YouTube TV offers a fixed content bundle
column32: AAPL had always pushed for subscribers having an option to choose their own bundle
column33: Moonves says. If the company can accomplish that goal
column34: it still can position an Apple television streaming service as being something unique.With YouTube TV
column35: Google may have beaten Apple to the punch when it comes to being first of the tech giants to offer a cheap way to cut the cable
column36: but the war is likely just beginning.As of this writing
column37: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhat Is Apple Inc. Doing With Its iPhone 8 Lightning Port?The 7 Most Popular Vanguard Funds for 401k Plans7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017The postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Just Succeeded Where Apple Inc. column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAndroid
column4: fromAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column5: is the dominant mobile operating system. It runs on nearly nine of every 10 mobile phones
column6: worldwide. But that's never really been a primary reason to by GOOGL stock â€¦ or at least not directly.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFrom an investor standpoint
column7: you would still rather buyApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) because Apple monetizes iOS the way a butcher monetizes a pig. Google
column8: on the other hand
column9: just gives its OS away to OEMs.That's not to say Google doesn't make any money off Android
column10: though. Simply by offering its search engine and Google Play store through the software
column11: GOOGL rakes in billions of dollars.But
column12: the Android ecosystem is extremely fragmented. Compared toAmazon.com
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) - which runs its own store and hasits own browser and search engine- Google's take is a mere fraction.What if that changed? Would it mean anything to GOOGL stock holders?Controlling AndroidWhile Google is not yet charging OEMs to use its software
column14: the company has been quietly trying to gain control of its creation. Management is pushing OEMs to deliver security updates on a monthly basis. This is important
column15: as crooks push malware onto older
column16: unpatched phones.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017Google's newest handset
column17: the Pixel
column18: is designed to be as good as an iPhone. Reviews
column19: however
column20: have been mixed. The company is even trying to getback into Chinathrough its OEMs (the world's largest market tossed Google back in 2010 over censorship).Still
column21: Google has its work cut out for itself.Samsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) dominates the Android market. OEMs and consumers see this fragmentation as an advantage
column22: even though it allows bugs to multiply because they may appear on one device or brand only.The operating system itself is hopelessly fragmented. Google is only now rolling out its Marshmallow and Nougat versions of Android andstill developing the ""O"" version
column23: while many users have devices that still run the KitKat version. My own Android phone runs on Lollipop
column24: (simply because it lacks the storage to run anything newer).The way Google eventually gets its arms around all of this may be throughAndromeda
column25: an operating system for both Android and its laptop Chromebook devices. Unifying software platforms would give Alphabet Inc the kind of power that Microsoft only dreamed of with its Windows operating system.Bottom Line on GOOGL StockIf Alphabetwereto start monetizing Android
column26: would investors even notice?Alphabet continues to grow at 20% per year
column27: powered by advertising on its main Search site and YouTube. The company brings approximately 25 cents of every dollar to the net income line
column28: its balance sheet carries almost no debt
column29: and operating cash flow is ridiculous ($36 billion last year alone
column30: more than twice what it achieved just two years prior). In 2016
column31: Alphabet had revenue in excess of $90 billion.Over the last year
column32: the price of GOOGL stock is up nearly 17%
column33: and the non-voting GOOG shares are up even more. The company's market cap of $577 billion trails only that of Apple. Six months ago
column34: they were nearly level
column35: but that was before Apple's recent run to new highs.Alphabet Inc CFO Ruth Porat's program of paring non-performing assets and forcing ""other bets"" (like the company's self-driving car unit
column36: now called Waymo) to make it on their own has paid off. Google's investment balances have been growing steadily
column37: along with its asset base.Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Become a Trillion-Dollar CompanyWhat's most amazing is how Alphabet continues to underperform. Android is not a major profit center
column38: and Google Cloud is often considered third in the market
column39: behind Amazon and Microsoft. Google was late to the voice party with Google Assistant
column40: which allowed Amazon to get the drop on it. Plus
column41: the hardware line is loaded with ""me too"" products
column42: and GOOGL leads in precisely zero categories.Still
column43: Porat has performed well in providing discipline to Google executives
column44: but she has not propelled Alphabet to market leadership outside of Search.If assets such as Android became true profit centers
column45: GOOGL stock would be well on its way to $1
column46: 000 per share and becoming the first trillion-dollar company.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud

column1: AT&T Inc. (T) Stockâ€™s Relationship with Facebook and Alphabet: Friends
column2: Enemies or Both?;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMajor telecom companies
column4: likeAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T)
column5: have a complicated relationship with tech companies likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL).makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrTelecoms envy Facebook and Alphabet's profits and stock performance. Since January 2009
column7: Alphabet stock is up 460%
column8: while AT&T stock rose only 49%. And telecoms like AT&T particularly resent the fact that internet companies like Alphabet and Facebook gained these profits while piggybacking on the equipment the telecoms spent tens of billions of dollars installing. You wouldn't be able to access websites such as this one or Facebook without the help of a telecom
column9: such as AT&T.On the other hand
column10: when people access Facebook or search Google
column11: they are using data
column12: which means more business for telecoms.But tech companies hurt telecoms when they cannibalize their revenue with apps like Viber and Messenger and WhatsApp. Using WhatsApp is cheaper than sending a text message
column13: and has causedtext message volumeto decline.Storm Clouds on AT&T's HorizonBut that's not all. Alphabet and Facebook now are looking to compete with the core business of telecom providers such as AT&T. Alphabet'sProject Fi
column14: in collaboration withSprint Corp(NYSE:S) andT-Mobile US Inc(NASDAQ:TMUS)
column15: will free users from signing a contract with a single network. This allows users to switch between networks depending on which one has the best signal quality.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowAnd that's not all. Alphabet has more projects
column16: includingProject LoonandGoogle Fiber
column17: in the works. These also threaten telecoms like AT&T. And Facebook is doing likewise
column18: withFree Basics
column19: Express Wi-Fiand theAquiladrone project.Why are tech companies like Alphabet and Facebook doing this? Why don't they just stick to their core businesses
column20: search and social networks?Well
column21: Alphabet and Facebook derive most of their revenue from advertising. More people receiving access to the internet means more people viewing ads
column22: and more revenue for Alphabet and Facebook's core businesses. If people can't access the internet
column23: they can't bring the two companies revenue.Alphabet and Facebook want to see more people using the internet
column24: and if this means using drones or balloons to bring access to remote regions
column25: so be it. With greater availability of bandwidth
column26: traffic on their websites will go up.So are Facebook and Alphabet threats to T stock? Well
column27: yes
column28: in some ways. But in other ways they may help telecoms like AT&T by pioneering open-source hardware and software-defined networking. They have their own reasons for doing so
column29: and this could help AT&T by lowering the cost of equipment which AT&T uses.Facebook/Alphabet vs. T Stock: FriendsIn an article I wrote inNovember
column30: I discussed Facebook and Alphabet's efforts to develop open-source networking equipment. Currently
column31: companies likeCisco Systems
column32: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) make money by selling proprietary hardware and software to telecoms and internet providers like AT&T.Networking equipment has been described as a""black box
column33: where hardware and software are bundled together by the same vendor. Software from other companies might not run smoothly on one company's hardware. Companies like Cisco can earn high margins on these proprietary products. Routing equipment has not yet beencommoditizedlike other hardware
column34: such as servers.But the development ofsoftware-defined networkingandnetwork functions virtualizationcould change this. These trends involve using open-source software and hardware instead of more expensive proprietary versions. Telecoms like AT&T can then save money by switching to cheaper
column35: interchangeable""white box""switches and routers.Alphabet and Facebook are taking advantage of this
column36: and making their own networking equipment.Facebook developed its ownSDNswitch
column37: theWedge
column38: and open-sourced the Linux-based software to go along with that
column39: FBOSS. It made the design for the Wedgeavailable to the publicthrough the Open Compute Project. Customers can order this from contract manufacturers
column40: which sell it at a low margin
column41: cheaper than Cisco's products. Facebook also released an open-sourcetransponderthrough theTelecom Infrastructure Project
column42: which focuses on networking hardware for telecoms.Facebook hopes that releasing these to the public will speed up innovation
column43: which will in turn benefit Facebook
column44: a major hardware user.Similarly
column45: Alphabet built its own massivesoftware-defined network.How does this benefit AT&T? Well
column46: GOOG and FB are pioneering a technology which promises to lower costs for T stock. Through itsDomain 2.0program
column47: AT&T is taking advantage of software-defined networking and network function virtualization. Last year
column48: AT&T announced its intention tovirtualize 75% of its network by 2020. These technologies allow it to do more with less. They appear to bereducing capexat AT&T
column49: which would boost free cash flow and raise T stock. It also expects SDN and NFV to save it money onoperating costs.Facebook/Alphabet vs. AT&T: EnemiesBut GOOG and FB also may harm T stock by getting into the telecom business.GOOG'sProject Ficonnects users to the network with the best signal at the moment
column50: whether that's Wi-Fi or 4G LTE offered by T-Mobile and Sprint. Normally
column51: mobile phone subscribers must go with one service: AT&T
column52: Verizon Communications Inc(NYSE:VZ)
column53: or others. This could force telecom operators to improve their signal quality in order to compete.Alphabet also offers Google Fiber
column54: a high-speed fiber optics service available in some select cities in the United States. AT&T must feel threatened by this; last year AT&T andComcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA)sued Nashvilleafter the cityvoted to approveGoogle Fiber.Alphabet is also working on the previously mentioned Project Loon
column55: an effort to deploy telecom equipment in balloons 20km from the earth's surface. Since the equipment in a balloon is higher off the ground than an LTE tower
column56: it can provide a greater area with internet access.Facebook is doing likewise with the Aquila drone
column57: Facebook Express Wi-Fi and Facebook Free Basics. Free Basics brings internet access to200 million peoplein countries like Brazil and the Philippines.Impact on AT&TThe harmful effects of Facebook and Alphabet on AT&T stock may be a bit overstated.Facebook has expressed its intention towork togetherwith telecoms to roll out 5G technology.Nick Foxof Alphabet has stated that Alphabet's intention is not to compete with telecoms and put them out of business. Indeed
column58: Alphabet is cooperating withthree telecomsin Indonesia to test Project Loon.And Alphabet and Facebook may be doing telecoms like AT&T a favor by bearing some of the risk in these ventures. Telecoms are more conservative than Facebook and Alphabet and wouldn't want to bear these risks on their own. Telecoms like AT&T may benefit from the more efficient deployment of telecom equipment via balloons
column59: which cover a wider area than towers.Also
column60: many of these regions the two are targeting are regionswithout much internet access.Facebook and Alphabet wouldn't be threatening AT&T by bringing internet access to regions in Africa
column61: where T stock derives little if any revenue.Could Amazon.com
column62: Inc. (AMZN) Take a Hint From Best Buy Co Inc (BBY)?But some of these undertakings
column63: such as Google Fiber and Project Fi
column64: will probably be a headache for AT&T and holders of T stock.So it seems Facebook and Alphabet could best be described as AT&T's ""frenemies.""As of writing
column65: Lucas Hahn did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 MLPs to Buy With High (And Growing!) Yields7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightThe postAT&T Inc. (T) Stock's Relationship with Facebook and Alphabet: Friends
column66: Enemies or Both?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Potential Stock Market Winners of 2025;3/1/2017;"If you're a long-term investor
column2: you have to think on an   investment time scale that is more than a year or two away. The   greatest investments are the ones that can generate positive   returns for decades into the future. It sounds simple at first
column3: but when you start asking yourself questions like
column4: ""Where is this   company/stock in 2025?"" it becomes much more difficult .So
column5: we asked three of our contributors that very question.   Which companies do you see generating great returns for investors   all the way out to 2025? Here's a quick rundown as to why they   picked retail bankU.S. Bancorp(NYSE: USB)
column6: solar panel manufacturerFirst Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column7: and water utilityAmerican Water Works(NYSE: AWK) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();A bank to buy and holdJordan Wathen(U.S. Bancorp):One of the best-managed banks in the country
column8: U.S. Bancorp   has been left out of the post-election bank stock boom. That's no   fault of its own
column9: though. After provisions for losses
column10: U.S.   Bancorp enjoys a roughly 50-50 split of interest income and fee   income
column11: making its earnings less sensitive to rate increases like   other banks that have seen their share prices surge.I think investors are undervaluing the downside protection   afforded by diversified sources of fee income
column12: and overvaluing   the potential for higher rates to fuel bank profits. In effect
column13: investors are placing too much importance on what makes banks   great over the short term rather than what makes them great over   the long haul.U.S. Bancorp's historical underwriting performance tells the   tale of its conservative culture. At the depths of the financial   crisis
column14: net charge-offs peaked at 2.17% of average loans in 2010.   Though it may seem unremarkable on an absolute basis
column15: consider   that ""retail loans"" made up 33% of its loan book at the time
column16: a   majority of which were clustered in credit cards and home equity   loans that ravaged banks across the country.U.S. Bancorp can play offense
column17: too. Its deposit franchise   gives it pricing power to hold down its cost of deposits
column18: which   recently averaged just 0.28%. On the asset side of the equation
column19: its commercial loan portfolio should generate incremental income   from rate increases.On a recent conference call
column20: a bank executive pointed out that   its commercial customers were using an average of 25% of their   credit lines. One would expect that faster economic growth could   bring higher balances
column21: higher benchmark interest rates
column22: and more   interest income. U.S. Bancorp has everything investors could want   in a bank to hold for years at a time.The sun is still rising on this investment opportunityTyler Crowe(First Solar):The solar industry is a difficult-to-understand
column23: and at times   frustrating
column24: industry to follow. That's because it's both a   high-growthanda cyclical industry at the same time. The problem is
column25: too many   investors simply look at it as the former and neglect to remember   the latter. While overall solar power consumption grows at   near-exponential rates every year
column26: panel manufacturers like First   Solar go through fierce supply-and-demand cycles as new capacity   and new technology come online.This past year is a great example of an industry downturn. The   industry is still growing
column27: but it hit a patch of slower growth   recently that brought down prices for new panels and   utility-scale projects. However
column28: the industry is expected to pick   back up again in earnest as renewable sources such as solar have   moved so far down the cost curve that they are now competitive   with fossil fuel power plants even without subsidies. As   technology improves
column29: costs will continue to decline
column30: and solar   will be able to take a larger market share and expand margins.   Keep in mind
column31: global electricity demand over the next 25 years   will require that we build 8 times the current generation   capacity in the U.S.This gives First Solar an immense growth runway over the next   decade
column32: and it is one of the best-positioned panel manufacturers   and utility-scale power developers out there to reap rewards from   this opportunity. The company has one of the most pristine   balance sheets in the business
column33: its low-cost
column34: thin-film solar   panel design is rapidly improving its efficiency metrics
column35: and it   is one of the only companies in the business whose returns on   invested capital have outpaced its cost of capital -- which is   essential for a company to grow and create wealth over time.The solar industry still very much looks like the wild west of   energy
column36: with new entrants rising and falling quickly
column37: but First   Solar is looking like the company that has the potential to turn   this fast-growing market into one that really generates long-term   returns for investors.As close to a sure-thing
column38: long-term winner as it getsBeth McKenna(American Water Works):I believe American Water Works -- the largest publicly traded   water and wastewater utility in the United States -- is as close   as it gets to a sure-thing 2025 winning stock. Moreover
column39: I   believe it has a good shot at significantly outperforming the   market over the next nearly nine years -- through the end of 2025   -- just as it has done in the nearly-nine years since going   public:Data byYCharts.Since its April 2008 IPO
column40: American Water's total return of   376% has crushed the S&P 500's return of 108% and pulverized   the returns of popular stocksIBMandGeneral Electric. Moreover
column41: it's also beat the 212% return of Google parentAlphabetover this period -- and in April 2008
column42: this tech stock was   less than four years off of its hot IPO. These stats should help   dispel the widespread belief that all utility stocks are stodgy   slow-growers. Moreover
column43: American Water's return leaves underwater   the solid 172% return of its closest peer
column44: Aqua America
column45: while also significantly beating the 158% return of   the largest electric utility on the S&P 500
column46: NextEra Energy.I'm confident American Water's winning streak will continue   over the long term. The company supplies the most essential   product in the world
column47: and it's the largest and most   geographically diverse player in its industry. These latter   attributes provide it with greater resources and opportunities   than its peers to more efficiently expand its regulated business   by acquisitions. The water industry in the U.S. is extremely   fragmented
column48: which means the potential acquisition pool (pun   intended) is a very large one.10 stocks we like better than American Water   WorksWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column51: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column52: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and American Water Works wasn't   one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column53: 2017.Suzanne Frey
column54: an executive at Alphabet
column55: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Beth McKennahas no position in any stocks mentioned.Jordan Wathenhas no position in any stocks mentioned.Tyler Croweowns shares of First Solar and General Electric. The Motley     Fool owns shares of and recommends Alphabet (A and C shares).     The Motley Fool owns shares of General Electric. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."
