column1: Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Offers the Easiest Profits Ever;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLost in the collapse ofUnder Armour Inc(NYSE:UA) stock over the past year is an odd divergence between two classes of stock. Shares of UAA stock (Class A) have traded at a substantial premium to UA stock (Class C). The difference is about 10% at the moment
column3: in fact.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat gap makes little sense. Class C UA stock has no voting rights. Class A UAA stock does have voting rights of one vote per share. But those rights don't have much value. CEO and founder Kevin Plank owns all of the non-trading Class B shares
column4: which have 10 votes each
column5: giving Plank 65% of the voting power as of December 2016.UAA shareholders are paying a premium for votes which are largely symbolic. And it's not as if other considerations justify that gap. The market is figuring out the divergence
column6: as the 10% premium has narrowed of late. But there's still time for easy profits in shorting UAA and going long UA.As for investors bullish on Under Armour
column7: there's basically no reason to pay up for the UAA stock.No
column8: UAA Stock Isn't Worth More Than UA StockAs seen in the chart below
column9: the gap between UA and UAA has narrowed of late
column10: after peaking in November.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightAt one point in late November - less than a year after the Class C UA stock was issued - the gap was over 20%
column11: a huge number. In dollars
column12: the difference has dropped to near $2 per share from as high as $7 - but some of that compression has come from the fact that Under Armour stock has declined precipitously after two disappointing earnings reports.With the largely symbolic voting rights not likely to change anytime soon
column13: there's simply very little reason for UA to trade above UAA.According to theregistration statementfiled by Under Armour with the SEC
column14: Class C holders of Under Armour stock are entitled to the same dividends. The only way for Class A shareholders to gain some sort of majority voting power would be for Plank to be terminated for cause or to give up his shares.Neither outcome seems particularly likely given that the CEO is 42 years old
column15: intensely competitive
column16: and intent on turning around his beloved Under Armour himself.Liquidity doesn't justify the different prices for Under Armour stock
column17: either
column18: with one possible exception.There was a notable divergence in equity volume a few months ago. UA stock had an average volume under 1 million shares per day in October
column19: roughly 20% of UAA stock. But volume over the past month is almost equal: 6.5 million shares a day for UA and 6.9 million for UAA. The increase in UA volume probably has something to do with the narrowing premium and implies that the spread will continue to tighten.How To Play Under Armour StockThere is one notable difference between UA and UAA: options volume. For instance
column20: open interest in the UA Jan 2018 $20 puts is just over 400. In contrast
column21: there are more than 11
column22: 000 UAA Jan 2018 $20 calls open at the moment.That difference is not enough to justify a 10% premium
column23: however
column24: particularly for smaller investors. And it seems the market is figuring that out. But the gap remains wide enough that there's still room to make what should be close to risk-free profits by going long UA and short UAA.Nvidia Corporation (NVDA): Amazing Company
column25: Not-So-Good Stock ... For NowAny major event - like an acquisition
column26: as unlikely as that seems at the moment - will treat shareholders equally. Any dividend payments will be the same. The only difference between UA and UAA is the opportunity to vote even though those votes have no practical impact.So an arbitrage trade still looks like it has some upside. Voting rights between classes at other stocks usually are below 5%
column27: meaning a long UA/short UAA trade could make another $1 per share with very low risk.For investors who still think Under Armour stock is a better opportunity
column28: then Class C UA stock is the right choice. The premium for UAA stock simply doesn't make a lot of sense - and it's still wide enough to profit from.The author is long UA and short UAA.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Tesla Inc (TSLA)

column1: Incredible! Here's How Many Internet Gadgets the Average Home Has;2/26/2017;"The notion that the world around us
column2: particularly in   tech-friendly North America
column3: is becoming more connected by the   day isn't necessarily surprising. What may raise an eyebrow or   two is just how prevalent connected internet gadgets already   are.What makes the sheer volume of the average homeowner's online   devices jaw-dropping is that by most accounts the Internet of   Things (IoT) in general
column4: and ""smart"" homes in particular
column5: haven't   even gone mainstream yet as most pundits expected last year. But   that's about to change
column6: and today's average North American   consumer's penchant for online devices could prove to be just the   tip of the iceberg.You're kidding
column7: right?It's not surprising the use of smartphones to access the   internet by North American's is skyrocketing. Five years ago   ""home roaming
column8: in other words using a smartphone to get   connected
column9: accounted for a mere 9% of fixed access traffic via a   Wi-Fi network. According to a recent study of North American   consumers
column10: that figure has jumped to nearly 30%.makeArticleAd();But mobile phones are just a small piece of the connected   smart home. Gaming consoles are another fast-growing means of   accessing the internet. Surprisingly
column11: few consumers actually use   consoles like theSony(NYSE: SNE) PlayStation to play games: a mere 2.5% according to   the study. However
column12: a full 65% use their PlayStation to stream   movies and other entertainment from over-the-top (OTT) providers   includingNetflix.Laptops and PCs
column13: while still prevalent in North American   households
column14: now account for less than 25% of total internet   traffic. Toss in smart personal home assistants such asAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN) Alexa and similar solutions and the average home   in North American has over seven ""active devices in use each   day."" A mind-boggling 6% of homes use more than 15 connected   devices on a daily basis.If those figures seem a bit much
column15: the stunning thing is   connected homes are expected to grow almost exponentially this   year
column16: and continue to climb for years to come.Alphabet Nest unit. Image source: Nest.Ready
column17: set
column18: go!Last year there were an estimated 80 million smart home   devices delivered to consumers across the globe
column19: up a whopping   64% compared to 2015. The stunning part of last year's explosive   smart home growth is it was woefully short of expectations.The problems are largely centered on providers like Amazon andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) with its Next thermostat hub not   doing an adequate job of explaining the value proposition of   ""intelligent"" homes. As some analysts described it
column20: this will be   the year of the smart home because providers ""will be smarter   about educating their consumers.""Consolidation of smart device manufacturers
column21: Alphabet's $3.2   billion deal for Nest three years ago is one notable example
column22: is   also expected to help in educating consumers as well as bring   costs down. Another factor key to even more widespread existence   of smart homes and devices is security.No more secretsA recent move byIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) to further its IoT initiatives -- a key effort on   CEO Brian Krzanich's transformation agenda -- included partnering   with tech giants includingGEandAT&Tinstalling cameras
column23: microphones
column24: and sensors on 3
column25: 200   street lights in San Diego
column26: CA. The objective is to identify   activities including gunshots
column27: monitor crowd sizes
column28: and track   vehicle speeds.Though no San Diego citizen reportedly complained about   privacy issues
column29: others certainly have. Which begs the question:   if the general public is concerned about smart cities invading   our privacy
column30: imagine the unease as our homes become ""smarter"" by   the year? Maybe privacy isn't the issue some have suggested: it   certainly hasn't prevented the average North American consumer   from staying connected at home

column1: 3 Horrendously Bad Stock Market Predictions From Otherwise Smart People;2/26/2017;"""It's tough to make predictions
column2: especially about the   future.""-- Yogi BerraEvery year
column3: the stock market either advances
column4: declines
column5: or   stays flat. It's never clear beforehand which direction these   indexes
column6: or the stocks that comprise them
column7: will move; the reasons   for their price swings only make sense in retrospect.makeArticleAd();But that truth doesn't stop people from making aggressive   predictions attempting to identify the Next Big Thing or to call   a coming crash or boom. Here are a few classic examples of some   smart market watchers getting burned by their stock calls.1. McDonald's will trounce Google as an investmentWhitney   Tilsonhas used his value investing approach to produce awesome returns   for himself and his investors over the years. Yet his tendency to   bash ""expensive"" companies with high price-to-earnings ratios has   also burned the hedge fund giant -- big time.For example
column8: back in 2004
column9: Tilson made abold prediction. Writing for The Motley Fool at the time
column10: he said the   soon-to-be-publicAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) (a.k.a. Google) would almost   certainly flame out as a business. ""I'd wager that odds are at   least 90% that its profit margins and growth rate will be   materially lower five years from now
column11: he argued.Tilson got even more specific
column12: saying thatMcDonald's(NYSE: MCD) would make a much better bet given its far lower   valuation. ""I believe that it is virtually certain that Google's   stock will be highly disappointing to investors foolish enough to   participate in its overhyped offering -- you can hold me to   that
column13: he concluded.GOOGL Market Capdata byYCharts.So how did that prediction pan out? Since 2005
column14: Alphabet   shares are up roughly 16 times
column15: compared to less than a 400%   return for the fast food titan. The search engine giant produced   nearly $20 billion of net income last year
column16: versus McDonald's   $4.5 billion. Today
column17: Alphabet is worth almost six times   McDonald's in the eyes of the market.2. Smartphones will be a bustA deep understanding of technology isn't enough to protect you   from being surprised by major shifts in the industry. Andrew   Grove was one of the founders ofIntel
column18: which profoundly shaped the semiconductor industry. He wasTime Magazine's Man of The Year in 1997. Yet in 1992 he made a prediction that   looks amazingly shortsighted in retrospect.Image source: Getty Images.ANew York Timesarticledescribed Grove as standing diametrically opposed to the position   taken byApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)  that smartphones
column19: then imagined as ""personal   communicators
column20: might develop into a huge business. They'd be   ""the mother of all markets
column21: according to Apple's then-CEO
column22: John   Sculley.Grove disagreed. The idea of a communicating device that   people carried around with them is ""a pipe dream driven by   greed
column23: he said. Ironically
column24: the article lists a few predictions   about the technology that proved prescient. These personal   communicators might handle emails
column25: use GPS to map directions
column26: and   even allow someone to ""order pizza using a combination of custom   electronic forms and wireless fax.""Today
column27: the smartphone industry is massive
column28: with Apple   accounting for nearly 150 million iPhone sales in the past year.   These devices helped spur over $24 billion of complementary   service-based revenue
column29: which demonstrates that
column30: if anything
column31: investors weren't being greedy enough about the potential for   smartphones to find a huge market.3. The Dow is headed to 36
column32: 000James Glassman's 1999 book titledDow 36
column33: 000hasn't aged well. In fact
column34: Washington Post economics columnist   Neil Irwincalled it""perhaps the most spectacularly wrong investing book ever"" given   that it forecast a massive rally for stocks between 1999 and   2004.Glassman's timing couldn't have been worse. The Dow hit 14
column35: 000   the year his book published before plummeting to a 15-year low of   7
column36: 000 in 2009. A roaring rally has pushed the blue-chip index   back to new highs recently
column37: but today it's still 42% below the   mark he believed the Dow would achieve over a decade ago.^DJIdata byYCharts.To his credit
column38: Glassman has taken a hard look at how his   prediction could have been so far off the mark. He identified two   major factors thathe and his co-author missed: earnings growth and the attitude of investors as reflected in   the price-to-earnings multiples they are willing to pay for   stocks. Neither trend went in the direction they had   targeted.A better wayThese failed forecasts illustrate how overconfidence can prove   fatal to your portfolio while predictions about economic trends   are rarely more than a distraction from the business of   accumulating stock market returns.Bold predictions are compelling because they attract debate   and can pay big dividends if proven correct. But no one knows   which direction stocks or markets will move over the short term.   That's why investors are better off simply buying a diverse group   of solid stocks and holding on to the shares for years (or   decades) while allowing the power of compound returns to do all   of the hard work.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: GoPro Hasn't Bought Back Any Shares in 2017. Should Investors Be Happy?;2/25/2017;"In late 2015
column2: GoPro(NASDAQ: GPRO) approved a $300 million buyback plan that lasted   for 12 months. However
column3: the action camera maker only spent $35.6   million on buybacks before the plan expired last September.Those purchases were poorly timed
column4: since GoPro bought back    about 1.5 million shares at an average price of $23.05 per   share -- roughly 140% higher than its price today. GoPro made    all those purchases during the fourth quarter of 2015
column5: and   didn't buy back any more stock until the plan expired.Image source: GoPro.makeArticleAd();By doing so
column6: GoPro has seemingly acknowledged that initiating   a buyback plan was a really bad move
column7: and the company doesn't   seem interested in buying back any more stock for the foreseeable   future. Should investors be happy or upset about this strategic   shift?Why investors should be happyGoPro's prior buyback plan burned cash that should have been   applied to R&D or acquisitions of smaller companies
column8: since   the company is gradually falling behind the tech curve.The Hero 5 isn't much more powerful than the Hero 4
column9: the Karma   drone's recall practically handed the market toDJI
column10: and GoPro still hasn't launched a stand-alone 360-degree camera   to counterSamsung's(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) Gear 360
column11: Ricoh's Theta
column12: and other similar cameras. GoPro's software ecosystem   also remains small
column13: despite the introduction of new editing apps   and acloud backup service. Investing heavily in those areas would make more sense than   buying back stock.Samsung's Gear 360. Image source: Samsung.Even if GoPro wanted to repurchase stock
column14: it can no longer do   so from its free cash flow. The company generated a negative free   cash flow of $151 million over the past 12 months
column15: due to four   straight quarters of losses that only recently ended with areturn to profitabilitylast quarter.The lack of a new buyback plan also  indicates that CFO   Brian McGee
column16: who replaced Jack Lazar last March
column17: doesn't plan to   follow in his predecessor's footsteps. When Lazar unveiled the   previous buyback in 2015
column18: some analysts saw the plan as a thinly   veiled attempt to offset GoPro's liberal use of stock-based   compensation -- which inflated its share count and diluted   existing shares. That move arguably benefited insiders much more   than investors.Why investors should be upsetHowever
column19: launching a new buyback plan this year would give   investors a sign that the stock's downside potential is limited.   GoPro stock also isn't expensive
column20: with an EV/Sales ratio of 0.96   and a 5-year PEG ratio of 0.7. Since a PEG ratio under 1 is   considered cheap
column21: GoPro is undervalued relative to its earnings   growth potential --ifit can match analysts' long-term expectations.Many of GoPro's investors would likely welcome a buyback
column22: since the stock's only near-term catalyst is the relaunch of the   Karma
column23: which could struggle to reach customers after missing the   crucial holiday season.A big buyback could also flush out short sellers -- who were   shorting 33% of the company's outstanding shares as of Feb. 9 --   and spark a short squeeze. That rally could inspire GoPro's   insiders
column24: who sold more shares than they bought over the past 12   months
column25: to  finally buy more shares. That
column26: in turn
column27: could   inspire institutional investors
column28: who only hold about 38% of GoPro   shares
column29: to finally come back.Forget about buybacks... for nowGoPro's abandonment of buybacks can be considered positive or   negative
column30: but I believe that the company should focus more on   improving its core technologies.The company has repeatedly claimed that it has a bright future   in virtual reality
column31: but its multi-camera Omni and Odyssey rigs   were too bulky and pricey compared to cheaper action-camera sized   solutions like the Gear 360. GoPro secured an early 360-degree   video partnership withAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) YouTube
column32: but YouTube   subsequentlyopened up that platformto a wide range of other cheaper cameras.GoPro's cloud backup platform also doesn't make sense
column33: since   it charges a $5 monthly fee for a service which Google Photos   provides for free on smartphones. Moreover
column34: the platform doesn't   backup videos in 4K quality -- which likely disappoints hardcore   GoPro users. Lastly
column35: GoPro must execute a smart marketing blitz   to get the Karma back on track
column36: especially after DJI's Mavic Pro   delivered many similar features in a superior package last   year.The key takeawayBuybacks are often considered a strategy that mature companies   use after they run out of ways to significantly improve their   core businesses. GoPro is in a slump
column37: but it hasn't reached   maturity yet since it still has plenty of ways to improve its   camera
column38: drone
column39: and software businesses. Therefore
column40: I believe that   investors should be happy that GoPro didn't initiate a new   buyback plan this year.10 stocks we like better than GoProWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tiny Company That Bought Google's Satellites Becomes a Rising Star;2/25/2017;"There's a battle going on in outer space
column2: for control of the   Earth imaging market.Yesterday morning
column3: we learned thatDigitalGlobe(NYSE: DGI) hassold itselfto Canadian space-tech specialistMacDonald
column4: Dettwiler and Associatesfor a purchase price of $2.4 billion -- and not a moment too   soon. DigitalGlobe
column5: if you recall
column6: is the American   satellite-imaging company that itselfbought one-time Motley Fool recommendation   GeoEyea few years ago.Just before announcingits ownsale
column7: DigitalGlobe reported a loss for its fiscal fourth quarter.   And if you ask me
column8: this suggests the time is ripe for   DigitalGlobe to cash out -- the more so because its primary area   of business is about to get even tougher to compete in.makeArticleAd();How hi-res is a high-resolution snapshot from space? Here's     one that Planet Labs' now-acquired Terra Bella satellites     recently snapped of the U.S. Air Force's Davis-Monthan airplane     ""boneyard"" of decommissioned military aircraft. Image source:     Terra Bella.Who is DigitalGlobe?DigitalGlobe is one of the biggest names in satellite-based
column9: highly detailed Earth imaging. The company operates a   constellation of five satellites capable of snapping photographs   from orbit at resolutions as minute as 30 centimeters per pixel.   DigitalGlobe calls its constellation ""the best in the world"" and   ""the largest constellation in the industry
column10: and that's at least   half right.Problem is
column11: it's also half wrong. DigitalGlobe may dominate   the market for highly detailed Earth imaging. But over at upstart   Planet Labs (also known simply as ""Planet"")
column12: one of the leaders   of the ""new space"" industry is rapidly overtaking DigitalGlobe in   breadth of coverage.(Re-)Introducing Planet LabsAs we discussed last month
column13: Planet had for some time been   discussing acquiringAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)satellite imaging business
column14: Terra Bella. The purchase price remains a mystery -- but the deal itself is   apparently now a ""go."" On Feb. 3
column15: Planet confirmed that it will   indeed acquire Terra Bella from Alphabet
column16: along with its fleet of   seven high-resolution (capable of sub-meter resolutions)   satellites.Then
column17: last week
column18: Planet announced the launch of 88 new ""Dove""   medium-resolution (three to five meters per pixel) satellites
column19: more than doubling the size of its medium-res constellation to   144 birds in orbit.Planet made history here in a couple of ways. First
column20: its   deployment was part of an Indian government PSLV (Polar Satellite   Launch Vehicle) launch that sent 16 other satellites
column21: in addition   to Planet's
column22: into space. At 104 satellites total
column23: the mission   that carried Planet's Doves was the largest-ever satellite   deployment made from a single rocket.More important
column24: Planet says that its 144 Doves in orbit
column25: plus   five RapidEye satellites acquired from BlackBridge in 2015
column26: give   it a constellation of 149 satellites in orbit today. Feel free to   mentally add seven more to that number once the Terra Bella   acquisition is finalized
column27: if you like. But already
column28: Planet's   mixed bag of 149 satellites gives it ""the largest private   satellite constellation in history.""This is significant not only because it gives Planet bragging   rights. By more than doubling its satellite constellation
column29: Planet   says it now has the ability to ""image all of Earth's landmass   every day."" Alone among satellite operators
column30: Planet can now take   a snapshot of every square foot of Earth's solid surface once per   day
column31: every day of the year.What it means to investorsWith every passing day
column32: Planet Labs is getting bigger
column33: treading more and more on DigitalGlobe's astro-turf
column34: and making   its rival's products nonunique. Indeed
column35: even if the photos taken   by Planet's Doves don't offer quite the same resolution as   DigitalGlobe offers
column36: Planet's ability to take somanysnapshots every day gives the company a more all-encompassing   view of what's happening around the globe.It's difficult to guess what advances will flow from access to   such data. Better weather forecasting
column37: certainly. A clearer view   of the progression of global warming
column38: its effects and its causes
column39: very likely. But we can also anticipate Planet generating better   data on traffic patterns on highways
column40: at ports
column41: and along   shipping routes; on the spread of residential development that   could guide brick-and-mortar retailers on where to place their   next big-box stores; and in countless other ways.The future is looking awfully bright for Planet Labs. And it's   getting brighter every day
column42: one Dove at a time.Look! Up in the sky! This time it really is a bird -- in     fact

column1: What Google and IMAX Are Cooking Up in Virtual Reality;2/25/2017;"IMAX forecasts profits in the field of virtual reality.     Image source: IMAX.IMAX Corporation(NYSE: IMAX)  is the acknowledged industry leader in the   premium large theater format and has built its reputation on the   continuous innovation of its digital movie camera and   high-performance laser projection system. With that expertise
column2: it   should come as no surprise that
column3: whenAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) Google decided to enter the   field of virtual reality
column4: it partnered with IMAX to develop the   best ""cinema-grade virtual reality (VR) camera."" IMAX is   providing a crew of engineers and technicians that will   collaborate with Google to develop a high-resolution camera from   scratch to address the unique challenges presented by virtual   reality. It will leverage Google's Jump platform
column5: which stitches   together 360 degree video into a seamless panoramic view
column6: providing an immersive experience.makeArticleAd();IMAX then announced a virtual reality location-based   initiative
column7: in a joint venture with the game developer Starbreeze   AB. This agreement would integrate the company's StarVR headset
column8: which provides an industry-leading 210-degree view
column9: and its   library of virtual reality games and entertainment with content   produced on the IMAX Google VR camera. Going further
column10: IMAX is   looking to leverage its existing relationships with Hollywood   studios and directors to create new movie-based content.Google's Jump 360 degree camera rig. Image source:     Google.Deep Hollywood backingSeveral notable Hollywood heavyweights are already onboard.Lions Gate Entertainment Corp.(NYSE: LGF-A)  will lend the lead character from itsJohn Wickmovies to the effort. Peter Levin
column11: President of Interactive   Ventures and Games for Lionsgate had this to say:We are big believers in location-based entertainment VR and     this is a great opportunity to expand the reach of our VR     portfolio.Michael Bay
column12: best known as the director ofHasbro's(NASDAQ: HAS) highly successfulTransformersfranchise said:I've always been a big believer in IMAX
column13: which has been a     great longtime partner...As a filmmaker
column14: IMAX's location-based     VR offering presents an exciting opportunity to transport     audiences even further into the worlds we create. We are in     advanced discussions with IMAX now on some fun VR concepts and     I look forward to test-driving their new technology.John Wick joins IMAX VR team. Image source: IMAX.IMAX envisions a communal virtual reality experience that   friends would enjoy together
column15: which would be available at   multiplexes and shopping malls
column16: as well as popular tourist   destinations. Late last year
column17: the company announced that it
column18: and   a number of its partners

column1: Tech Most Popular Sector for Investment Fund Managers in 2017;2/24/2017;"Data show that Silicon Valley darlings once again captured the interest of stock fund managers looking to cash in on the sector's growth and dreams in the fourth quarter of 2016.In a ranking of the 20 S&P 500 stocks that U.S. funds managing more than $1 million bought the most

column1: IMAX's Mediocre Results Belie Blockbuster Opportunities;2/24/2017;"For those invested inIMAX Corporation(NYSE: IMAX)
column2: the industry leader in large screen movie   theaters
column3: it should come as no surprise that the company's   performance follows the slate of movies for the year -- the   company lives and dies by blockbusters.In 2016
column4: box office growth was tepid
column5: so the company had some   tough comps going into its fourth-quarter and full year financial   report
column6: and investors were preparing for the worst.Will IMAX's outlook improve in 2017? Image source: IMAX.makeArticleAd();Tough compsIMAX reported revenue of $106.9 million for the quarter
column7: down   10% from $119.3 million from the prior year quarter
column8: though it   was better than the $99.6 million analysts were expecting. Net   income of $0.27 per diluted share also exceeded expectations of   $0.21 expected by analysts. Pulling back to a wider view
column9: the   overall annual results looked better. For the full year
column10: IMAX   produced revenue of $377 million compared to $374 million in the   prior year.Let's face it: While 2016 was a good year at the movies
column11: this   was never going to be easy. The slate from 2015 boasted such   cinematic heavyweights asJurassic World
column12: Furious 7
column13: Avengers: Age of Ultron
column14: Minions
column15: andStar Wars: The Force Awakens. These top five movies pulled in a combined $7.8 billion in box   office. Even though 2016 leadersCaptain America: Civil War
column16: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story
column17: Finding DoryandZootopia
column18: andThe Jungle Bookwere each an unqualified success
column19: their combined box office of   $5.2 billion was nearly $2.6 billion below the results of 2015's   all-stars. That's a lot of popcorn.Expanding network and dealsThere was
column20: however
column21: plenty of good news in the report for   investors willing to dig a little deeper. The company installed   166 new IMAX theaters during the year
column22: up 22% over the prior   year. This brings the installed base of theaters to 1
column23: 215 screens   in 75 countries. The company also signed installation agreements   for a record 319 IMAX theater systems during the year and the   backlog of theaters waiting to be built now totals 498. The   majority of these new signings were joint-revenue sharing   agreements
column24: which cost more up front

This all indicates that   the company is well positioned to take advantage of an improved   slate of movies in 2017 and beyond.IMAX also announced that it had extended its existing   agreement withThe Walt Disney Company(NYSE: DIS) with a multi-picture deal through 2019. column1: Buy the Kinder Morgan Inc (KMI) Stock Dip and Sit Tight;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsKinder Morgan Inc(NYSE:KMI) is one of the largest midstream energy players in the U.S. In the energy patch
column3: there are upstream firms (exploration and production)
column4: midstream firms (pipelines and storage terminals) and downstream firms (retail
column5: refining and distribution). Big energy companies likeExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) are vertically integrated across all of these sectors.makeArticleAd();Source:Roy Luck via FlickrThe midstream players have been interesting for two core reasons: Many were master limited partnerships (MLPs) that treated shareholders as owners
column6: and distributed profits on a regular basis in the form of dividends. And those dividends were very juicy for a while.The second reason is
column7: midstream players are more like toll booth operators. Unlike their upstream or downstream brethren
column8: the price of whatever commodity is flowing through pipes matters little to midstream players. It's the volume that matters.3 Earnings Reports That Should Be on Your RadarWith all this in mind
column9: we can now explore where KMI fits into the picture right now.KMI Stock TurnaroundIn late 2014
column10: KMI announced it was going to buy up its MLPs and consolidate them into the general partner firm Kinder Morgan. This was a $76 billion internal acquisition and made KMI ""the largest midstream company and third largest energy firm in the U.S.""
column11: according to its CEO and Chairman Richard Kinder. It now operates 84
column12: 000 miles of pipelines in the US and Canada
column13: with 155 terminals.The goal was likely to consolidate the profits into KMI and not have to distribute so much of the profits to shareholders. That was all well and good
column14: but then the bottom fell out of the energy markets. As the merger was announced
column15: oil was nearly $100 a barrel and natural gas was around $4 per million BTU. Now
column16: oil and natural gas are slightly better than half those prices.Needless to say
column17: the past couple of years have been tough on KMI in particular and the U.S. energy patch in general. But there is a turnaround under way. Rig counts in the U.S. are up
column18: week after week. Mergers are popping in the midstream space and companies that have cash are looking to gain market share.U.S. inventories are growing and exports are booming. Shale production is getting back online. The economy is getting back on its feet. Things are looking up.And even if this increased production keeps prices low
column19: it doesn't matter to KMI. It will be making money on the increased flow
column20: not the prices. This is why the midstream sector is the best place to get back into the U.S. energy game
column21: since it's about increasing demand and is slightly agnostic about supply.This Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Trade Is a Sure ThingWhile KMI doesn't throw off a huge MLP-like dividend
column22: it does provide a 2.3% dividend that will at least pay you for your patience as the stock and the sector get back to full capacity.Richard Band'sProfitable Investingadvisory service helps retirement savers outperform the market without losing a minute of sleep along the way. His straightforward style and low-risk value approach has won seven Best Financial Advisory awards from the Newsletter and Electronic Publishers Foundation.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right Now7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowThe postBuy the Kinder Morgan Inc (KMI) Stock Dip and Sit Tightappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column33: there   are a lot of investors that are interested in it.Niu:Yeah

column36: which is the exact opposite storyline that Snap is   going to try to sell doing its roadshow.Lewis:Yeah. Listeners
column37: to give you an idea of what we're going to   talk about today
column38: give you a little overview of Snap
column39: the   Snapchat property specifically
column40: talk a bit about their plans to   go public
column41: and what Evan and I noticed when we dug through the   S-1 that recently became available. So
column42: we talked about
column43: they are   social media company
column44: but they call themselves a camera   company
column45: which is interesting.Niu:I noticed this really funny coincidence -- I don't know if   you would call it a coincidence -- Snapchat used to consider   itself a storytelling company
column46: and now it's calling itself a   camera company. Meanwhile
column47: GoProused to call itself a camera company and now is trying to   call itself a storytelling company. So
column48: these two companies
column49: they   have this weird identity thing where they want to be each other
column50: and I don't get why

column52: they have the new Spectacle glasses   with cameras
column53: but I don't know. It's just a weird identity to   me.Lewis:Yeah. For listeners who might not be familiar with the   social media platform Snapchat
column54: basically
column55: you can think of it as   a messaging platform where you are
column56: for the most part
column57: shooting   quick
column58: instantly deleted pictures and videos to you and your   friends. You can also post them as stories. It has gained a lot   of popularity with the millennial group. User count is still kind   of low
column59: we can talk about that a little bit
column60: but the company is   planning to go public
column61: looking to raise $3 billion via the public   markets in an issuance that would value the whole company   a somewhere between $20 [billion] to $25 billion. As tech   IPOs go
column62: this might be one of the biggest ones for 2017.Niu:Yeah
column63: definitely. It's definitely the most exciting
column64: the   most looked forward to. People have been waiting for this thing   for years.Lewis:Yeah
column65: and anything that's consumer-facing is naturally   going to have a lot more buzz to it. I think there might be some   folks out there who are saying
column66: ""Wait a minute
column67: I thought I saw   an announcement that this company planned to IPO back in the fall   of 2016. Why are we just getting the S-1 and all the   information about the company in the past couple weeks?""   That's because Snap opted to go public via the confidential IPO   process. This process and this approach is a byproduct of the   2012 Jumpstart Our Businesses Act. Basically
column68: under this updated   legislation
column69: companies with under $1 billion in annual revenue   can file paperwork for an IPO confidentially with the SEC. That   allows the company to go back and forth with the regulatory   agency without alerting the public that they are planning on   IPO-ing
column70: although Snap chose to do so anyway. Then
column71: once the   company decides they do want to go forward with an issuance
column72: the   filing must be made public at least three weeks prior to the IPO   roadshow beginning
column73: which is when the underwriting investment   banks begin talking to clients and building interest in a   potential issuance. This is all to say
column74: while the ""confidential   IPO"" name might sound kind of shady
column75: this is something that's   totally on the up-and-up. And that is the reason why we only got   a look at the company's books and the S-1 earlier this month
column76: even though they announced intentions to IPO a ways back.Niu:Right. I think part of the purpose is to
column77: like you   mentioned
column78: avoid public scrutiny for the early drafts of the S-1.   All companies always have to file the S-1
column79: but this way they can   refine it without all the public scrutiny
column80: looking at it and   scrutinizing it. I think the idea is to encourage more companies   to explore the IPO process
column81: and if companies do end up going   public
column82: they get more capital
column83: and it just boosts the economy in   terms of more investments happening. I think that's the goal.   But
column84: yeah
column85: it is a little weird when you hear ""confidential.""Lewis:Yeah
column86: and I think it also gives companies the opportunity   to maybe think about going public and walk back without sharing   all of their business information publicly. So
column87: you can test the   waters and see if you're ready
column88: and you might decide you're not
column89: but you don't have to go through the question of your business   practices
column90: if you think you're going to file and you have to   publicly walk back.Niu:Right
column91: exactly.Lewis:So
column92: that's part of it. There are some adjustments in the   regulatory requirements for how far back a company needs to   provide financial statements
column93: as well. But really
column94: all in all
column95: it's a tool that allows small-growing companies to keep some of   their core business info private and make the going-public   process a little bit easier. And that's really all there is to   the confidential IPO process. Given that the company's S-1 filing   became public earlier this month
column96: I think it's fairly safe to   assume we're going to see Snap trading on the New York Stock   Exchange sometime in the next couple months. Evan?Niu:Yeah
column97: seems like it's coming.Lewis:Considering that they are a social media company
column98: I think   it makes the most sense to start looking at their user base and   what's going on there. That's kind of the lifeblood of businesses   like Facebook and Twitter
column99: and Snap is really no different.   Within their S-1

column105: which is right around 160 million. With social media companies

column107: because with user base

column142: we're going to see what we   can do with this on our own."" If they wind up going public at   this gaudy valuation

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Sues Uber Over Allegedly Stolen Technology;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: GOOGL) Waymo is suing Uber for using technology that it claims was stolen from it by a former employee.makeArticleAd();Source:GoogleWaymo
column4: the self-driving car company that belongs to GOOGL
column5: claims that one of Uber's employees stole technology from it and used it for the company's own self-driving car efforts. The company says this employee is Anthony Levandowski.Anthony Levandowski is the founder of Otto. Otto is a self-driving car startup that was created in 2016. Uber bought this startup in 2016 and added Levandowski to its team. Levandowski was a previous employee of the GOOGL car company before founding Otto.According to Waymo
column6: Anthony Levandowski downloaded more than14
column7: 000 confidential and proprietary design filesfor its hardware systems six weeks before resigning from the GOOGL company. Among those files were the company's design data for its LiDAR system.Waymo says that it has decided to file a lawsuit against Uber after receiving an email from one of its suppliers. The supplier makes parts for the GOOGL company's LiDAR system. In the email was a picture of a circuit board for Uber's own LiDAR technology. Waymo says this circuit board looked incredibly like the one it created for its own LiDAR system.Waymo says that after conducting some research
column8: it has discovered that other former employees also downloaded confidential information from the company. These employees now work for Uber and Otto. The GOOGL company claims this was an organized act to steal its trade secrets and intellectual property.Waymo also claims that Anthony Levandowski expressed his desire to ""replicate"" the company's technology as a rival. It claims he told employees of this plan months before his retirement.More From InvestorPlace7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You Deserve7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All Worlds10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Sues Uber Over Allegedly Stolen Technologyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Aiphabet's Waymo Alleges Uber of Theft of Confidential Files;2/24/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLWaymo has sued Uber and its subsidiary Otto
column2: alleging intellectual property theft and patent violation.In a lawsuit filed Thursday in San Francisco federal court

column4: Anthony Levandowski
column5: had downloaded over 14
column6: 000 highly confidential and proprietary files before leaving to work at his newly formed self-driving truck company Otto.Waymo claimed that Levandowski downloaded 9.7 GB of confidential files and trade secrets consisting of design files
column7: blue prints and test documentation from a Google-issued laptop to an external drive and formatted the laptop to delete forensic fingerprints.Waymo also alleged other Google employees who joined Otto to have stolen trade secrets. The company claims that without those stolen stuff

column1: Facebook (FB) Launches Mid Roll Video Ads Beta Testing;2/24/2017;"Facebook IncFBsaid that it will now insert mid roll ads in its video content but as a  ""beta test"" for the time being.In a blog post
column2: Facebook said ""We want to help our partners monetize their premium video content
column3: both on Facebook and on their own websites and apps. The company further stated ""As the name implies
column4: Ad Breaks allows creators to take short breaks for ads during their live videos. When a broadcaster chooses to take an ad break
column5: people watching the video will see an in-stream ad of up to 15 seconds in length. The broadcaster will earn a share of the resulting ad revenue.""Facebook added that the feature will now be accessible to more Live creators. Only Pages and profiles with over 2k followers and 300 Plus views for recent live video can beta test mid roll ads. The first ad break can be taken only after the video has been live for a minimum of four minutes and for more ad breaks
column6: there has to be at least a gap of five minutes between each ad break. Ad breaks will last up to 20 seconds. Ad breaks beta testing will be available only in the U.S for the time being.Analysts observe that ever since Facebook has opted out of pre-roll ads
column7: most publishers haven't been able to earn money from their videos on the social networking platform. Plus
column8: it has kept sports publishers from running ""valuable content"" on the platform.  With mid roll ads
column9: Facebook is giving publishers an opportunity to make more money. Reports add that Facebook will share revenues with publishers in a 45:55 ratio
column10: similar to that of Alphabet'sGOOGLYouTube.Facebook is aggressively promoting ""Live"" in order to boost its top line further. Facebook is trying to bring more video content to attract more ad dollars. Ad revenues contribute over 95% to Facebook's total revenue. It intends to capture the opportunity presented by ever increasing video viewing on social media platforms. At its last earnings call
column11: Facebook said that video has emerged as a ""megatrend"" on the same lines as mobile.Facebook

column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Thursday's Analyst   Blog:Google Finds 'Waze' to Build Self-Driving TechnologyWhen asked some time back about the use cases for self-driving cars
column11: Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) executives said that they were exploring alternatives. Things have changed somewhat since then and we have slightly greater clarity on whether Google will maintain its own fleet
column12: renting out for delivery of goods
column13: food and/or passenger transport
column14: or whether it will rent vehicles from their makers and sell those services itself.My bet was always on the latter
column15: first because Google is primarily a technology company and thrives on making the kind of software that can take over our lives. Getting into the low-margin business of vehicle maintenance and renting just isn't its area of expertise.Furthermore
column16: the kind of investment that is going into getting these animals on the road isn't justified unless there is a lucrative business out there with a relatively quick payback time.So the company's initial step toward commercialization by getting key people on board and announcing the name of the unit as Waymo was heartening. The goal of this unit is to develop self-driving technology for car makers.How Does All This Tie In with the Waze Carpool   Service?Waze was an Israeli crowd-sourced mapping service providing users with information such as traffic
column17: road conditions and other helpful pointers
column18: so they could quickly decide their route. At least that's what it was in 2013 when Google acquired it for $1.15 billion.Today
column19: Waze is also a carpooling service that gets people travelling in the same direction to travel together and share the cost of gas. So yes
column20: there are headaches to availing the service like having to book way in advance or not having anybody to pick one up on occasion. It also doesn't allow anyone to become a driver
column21: so they can't make a living from it.All this goes to show that Google's plans in the area probably aren't crystallized and the service is a temporary measure to access that all-important thing these days called data. Data that can add to the treasure trove Google's already collecting through the test driving of its self-driving cars.The difficulties don't seem to have deterred users
column22: however
column23: because Google just announced the expansion of the service to unannounced locations in the U.S. and Latin America. And while not all Waze users are signing up for carpooling
column24: it's significant that their numbers have reportedly swelled from 45 million in 2013 to 75 million today. So even if a small percentage of this growing number of people goes for it
column25: it can still be a compelling number.Taxi Service Is What Uber
column26: Lyft Do WellThere's no doubt about it
column27: these two companies have been growing in leaps and bounds as the convenience and quality of service have attracted more and more people. So the prospect of other
column28: perhaps cheaper (because a self-driving car doesn't need a driver) services coming online certainly isn't good news.Google was an initial investor in Uber
column29: but when the company started developing self-driving technology to save its neck
column30: Google representative David Drummond removed himself from its board. Uber still uses Google mapping services
column31: but has increased investments to develop maps of its own.ConclusionUber and its pals have popularized the concept of ride-hailing/car-sharing services but now that the concept has caught on
column32: there will be new entrants. This is a big opportunity for car makers because this is the space where new cars will be deployed in the future.On the technology side
column33: there is the need for machine learning and cloud support
column34: mapping technology
column35: and sensors
column36: which have to be installed on cars built to house the technology. And that's exactly why companies like Intel (NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report) are tying up with companies like Mobileye
column37: while NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA-Free Report) pairs up with Baidu (NASDAQ:BIDU-Free Report) and Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report). Then of course there's Google. These companies are in turn testing the technology through collaboration agreements with automakers.But who will get there first? Industry watchers don't expect anything viable until 2020. Even if it's a couple of years out from there
column38: it does look like there will be more than one approach/technology driving the experience. And since the possibilities are tremendous
column39: there won't necessarily be a single winner.Google

column1: Facebook Inc Stock (FB) Pulls Back After Another High: Now What?;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(FB) stock apparently hit a ceiling when it touched yetanother record high- the second record high in less than a month.makeArticleAd();FB shares soared to $136.79 on Wednesday before retreating on Thursday. The previous all-time high for Facebook stock was $135.49
column3: which was set on February 2.Facebook's Stock Move is Just Part of a Wider Tech TrendFB shares also managed a new record closing price on Wednesday at $136.12
column4: ahead of the previous record set on February 8
column5: which was $134.20.As Facebook stock retreated on Thursday
column6: so did most of the other big tech names that have also set record highs this year.Microsoft Corporation(MSFT)
column7: Amazon.com
column8: Inc.(AMZN)
column9: Netflix
column10: Inc.(NFLX)
column11: Alphabet Inc(GOOG) andApple Inc.(AAPL) were all in the red at the time of this writing.And all these big tech names are rising and falling pretty much in tandem with major indices
column12: including theS&P 500
column13: NASDAQ CompositeandDow Jones Industrial Average.Facebook Stock Could Drop Off SoonSo will Facebook stock be able to keep up themomentumfor the near future?Apple Inc. vs. Alphabet Inc: Value or Growth?Seeking Alphacontributor Damon Verial warns that it might not
column14: particularly because it almost always loses in March. He describes himself as ""strongly bullish"" on the name but adds that he only feels ""the urge to write about"" it when he thinks it is overvalued.He says he did call a pullback in Facebook stock in the past when it fell $10 to $123 per share over the four days following his call. Then it fell to $115 over the next two weeks.Of course the stock rallied
column15: as he says it ""always"" will
column16: but he notes that anyone who held through that pullback ""missed a significant buyback opportunity that would have more than accommodated a transition from capital gains tax on long-term holdings to income tax on short-term holdings for most sizable positions.""Verial noted that Facebook Inc (FB) stock has been in overbought territory since the end of January
column17: which means it probably won't take much to set off a downward spiral. He pointed to seasonal patterns in data on the stock showing where it almost always goes in each month.According to him
column18: Facebook stock almost always ends January in the green
column19: and its highest Sharpe ratio also is in January. Average gains during the month stand at 10%.But in February
column20: he said the stock's Sharpe ratio has fallen to zero
column21: making the month neutral. Then in March
column22: the Sharpe ratio turns negative
column23: ""hinting at a significant opportunity cost."" He adds that even long-term holders may find it beneficial to avoid the stock during the worst months
column24: which includes March
column25: May and August. These months aren't usuallyearningsmonths anyway
column26: and they're well after the holiday season at a time when spending on digital advertising starts to fall.He does feel that long is the only ""logical"" position to take on Facebook when looking at it from a long-term fundamental perspective.The postFacebook Stock Pulls Back After Touching Another Record Highappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column27: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" Your number one source for breaking news and evergreen content on everything value investing and hedge funds.Check out our new free Underrated Small Cap Stocks newsletterAlso Sign Up For Our Free Newsletter and receive in-depth ebooks on famous investorsMore From InvestorPlace7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right Now7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeThe postFacebook Inc Stock (FB) Pulls Back After Another High: Now What?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Qualcomm
column2: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Has Big Prospects Despite Its Problems;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's a bittersweet victory
column4: to be sure. Just whenQualcomm
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) starts to unveil a game-changing technology
column6: a legal hurricane starts to make landfall. If any current or would-be owners of QCOM stock are torn as to what the future likely holds
column7: there's good reason.makeArticleAd();Source:Karlis Dambrans via FlickrAnd yet
column8: as much jeopardy as the company's bottom line may be in at this time
column9: the fact that Qualcomm stock is still down more than 25% over the past three years suggests the market saw a litigation headwind coming sooner or later. The worst-case scenario may already be priced into QCOM stock
column10: which means the recent weakness makes for a compelling entry point.The BadThe legal wrangling is mostly withApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column11: superficially. But
column12: should Apple be successful with its effort
column13: it opens the door to other litigation
column14: not to mention emboldens a similar case being brought against Qualcomm by the Federal Trade Commission.The short version of the story: Apple (and the FTC and the Korea Fair Trade Commission
column15: for that matter) are all arguing the same thing - Qualcomm's business model of licensing its technologies to phonemakers isnot only exorbitant
column16: but unlawfully stifles competition. That's a legal no-no in most any country. The Korea Fair Trade Commission isseeking $873 million for essentially the same.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold ForeverFor the record
column17: QCOM has lost this argument before. In 2015
column18: thecompany forked over $975 million to Chinafor breaking that country's antitrust laws. Indeed
column19: Qualcomm wasallegedly charging all-encompassing licensing feesto phonemakers that may or may not have needed access to all of the technology in that IP packageâ€¦ another dubious practice.Years of sharp dealing have finally caught up with Qualcomm.The GoodThe irony is
column20: while the company was over-milking its aging patent portfolio
column21: QCOM was also developing some new - and highly marketable - intellectual property.The idea of the Internet of Things (IoT) is an exciting one
column22: but the reality is
column23: the technology and bandwidth needed to meet the need just isn't ready
column24: yet. Or
column25: it wasn't anyway. This week
column26: Qualcommunveiled its 802.11ax technology
column27: which can carry four times the amount of data current Wi-Fi technology carries
column28: but without using any more bandwidth.Qualcomm Technologies VP Rahul Patel explained:It is taking Wi-Fi to a new level from a user-experience point of view. What it is trying to do is prepare the Wi-Fi network
column29: which in many cases is experiencing a lot of congestion
column30: largely because the network is becoming dense and is not able to deal with the amount of traffic.At the same time
column31: the company has created a whole new kind of RF ""front end
column32: or the radio connection between a mobile phone's modem and the transceiver. Not only is it a superior solution to current alternatives
column33: it's a simpler solution that works with a variety of connection protocols
column34: such as LTE and MIMO
column35: by the utilization of modem intelligence.They're not the kind of advances the average consumer cares about
column36: or even understands. With 5G connectivity about to become the norm
column37: however
column38: these little advances are actually big advances that phonemakers will desperately need.Bottom Line for QCOM StockIn simplest terms
column39: the future of QCOM stock lies somewhere between the two ends of this good/bad continuum. One way or another
column40: sooner or later
column41: Qualcomm's business model of leveraging an aging patent portfolio - and doing so in a questionable manner - is going to falter. If the company wants to continue being an IP player
column42: it's going to need some new IP.The question is
column43: will 802.11ax and new RF front-end platforms be enough? It matters
column44: simply becausethe company's licensing and royalty revenue is roughly twice its revenue from outright chip sales.3 Stocks That Could Soar on a Short SqueezeThe answer to this question is a qualified yes; the qualification is the speed with which lawsuits will result in a decision
column45: and the time that will be needed for IoT and 5G to reach critical mass. Odds are good the former will hurt before the latter helps
column46: meaning Qualcomm could be headed for a dry spell
column47: earnings-wise.Still
column48: for the true long-termer who can stomach the ""in the meantime"" volatility
column49: the market may start to appreciate the potential of the distant future nowâ€¦after a few years of strong bearish pressure.QCOM stock may not be appropriate for grandma's retirement portfolio
column50: but there's little doubt the company's new technologies will be crucial to the next generation of connectivity.As of this writing
column51: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) vs. Alphabet Inc (GOOGL)Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Feelings. Nothing More Than Feelings.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowThe postQualcomm
column52: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Has Big Prospects Despite Its Problemsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Will Your Next New Car Help Build Maps for Self-Driving?;2/23/2017;"Mobileye N.V.(NYSE: MBLY)
column2: an Israeli company that specializes in advanced   driver-safety systems
column3: has begun rolling out a new offering that   will help the self-driving cars of the near future function in   more areas -- and your next new car might be enlisted to   help.The new offering
column4: called Road Experience Management
column5: or ""REM
column6: is a system that will create highly detailed maps that   self-driving cars can use to back up (or double-check) the inputs   from their sensors. It will use data collected by cameras on many   new cars
column7: starting with the 2018 model year.This is a big deal
column8: not just for Mobileye but also for its   customers -- which include nearly all of the world's automakers   -- and people who are hoping to have access to self-driving cars   in the near future.makeArticleAd();Mobileye's chief technology officer
column9: Amnon Shashua
column10: outlined     the company's approach to self-driving in a presentation last     month. Image source: Mobileye N.V.The problem: Self-driving cars need special mapsWhen the first fully self-driving cars arrive on the market in   a few years
column11: their capabilities will be limited. In most cases
column12: the cars will be ""geofenced
column13: restricted to driving in particular   areas. (In the widely used industry nomenclature
column14: these are   called ""Level 4"" systems. ""Level 5"" systems that are self-driving   with no restrictions are probably still many years away.)The cars will be geofenced because most of the self-driving   systems under development require specialized high-definition   maps to work safely. The maps help the car's ""brain"" figure out   exactly where it is relative to things like curbs and road   barriers
column15: providing a layer of redundancy beyond the car's   sensors. (That may sound
column16: well
column17: redundant. But it's critical to   ensuring that self-driving systems meet the required standards of   safety.)Obviously
column18: the companies that can access the best and most   extensive maps will have a competitive advantage. Cars equipped   with their systems will be able to drive themselves to more   places. That means that the race is on not only to create maps   covering the widest possible areas
column19: but to create ways to ensure   that the maps are always up to date.Mobileye has a direct stake in this race. It's gearing up to   bring aLevel 4 system to market by the end of 2019
column20: in partnership withDelphi Automotive(NYSE: DLPH) andIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) . That system will be marketed to automakers
column21: who   will probably be able to have it in showrooms (or in service with   ride-hailing companies) by about 2021.This self-driving test vehicle incorporates a prototype of     the system being developed by Delphi
column22: Mobileye
column23: and Intel.     Image source: Delphi Automotive PLC.The partners will almost certainly have competition from   companies likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo unit
column24: Ford Motor Company's(NYSE: F)Argo AI subsidiary-- and likely others.Mobileye's Road Experience Management initiative is intended   to make sure that its Level 4 offering is as complete
column25: and as   compelling
column26: as possible. And your next new car might help.How Mobileye will build -- and profit from -- the mapsThe idea behind REM is that Mobileye can use the cameras on   existing cars as a low-cost way to harvest the data needed to   make the maps
column27: as well as other information that will be useful   to self-driving cars. Many new cars have front-facing cameras   that are used for adaptive cruise control
column28: lane-departure   warnings
column29: and other advanced driver-assist systems (or ""ADAS"") --   and many of those camera-based systems were sold to the   automakers by Mobileye.In recent months
column30: Mobileye has been reaching out to its   automaker clients
column31: inviting them to join the REM effort by   allowing data from their vehicles to be collected. In exchange
column32: Mobileye is offering a share of the revenue it expects to   generate from selling that data to mapmaking companies.So far
column33: Volkswagen AGandBMW AGhave signed up to allow REM to gather data from their vehicles
column34: starting in the 2018 model year. Duringthis past week's earnings call
column35: Mobileye's CTO Amnon Shashua said that his company expects to   announce a third deal within a few weeks
column36: and to have the   majority of its automaker partners signed up by the end of 2017.   (These deals include extensive privacy safeguards; the data won't   be linked to specific car owners.)Shashua explained how revenue will be generated from the REM   effort:We believe revenue will be generated from two separate     products [of REM]. One is the map
column37: which is a critical input to     autonomous vehicle systems. The other is a broad set of     real-time dynamic information such as traffic density
column38: weather     conditions and open parking spots. We expect the primary     customers for each of these products to be mapmakers
column39: and we     recently announced engagements with both [high-definition     mapping company] HERE and the Japanese mapping company     Zenrin.The upshot: An important step as the self-driving race shapes   upAssuming that a majority of the world's major automakers do in   fact join the REM program
column40: Mobileye's effort stands to put its   venture with Delphi and Intel in a strong competitive position as   the market for self-driving systems takes shape.I've argued that the idea of a ""race"" to self-driving   technologyisn't a useful way for investors to think. Level 4 systems will be available to all automakers within four   or five years; there won't be much advantage to the company that   comes to market first. We won't be able to think in terms of   ""winners"" until the details of the different offerings become   clear.That process is starting. REM makes it likely that the   Delphi-Mobileye-Intel offering will have access to maps that   allow it to operate in many areas of the world
column41: right from the   start. For investors
column42: that makes the success of the partners'   system more likely
column43: and an investment in Mobileye -- the purest   play of the three -- a little more compelling.10 stocks we like better than MobileyeWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Mobileye wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column49: an executive at Alphabet
column50: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.John Rosevearowns shares of Ford. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A and C shares) and Ford. The Motley Fool     recommends BMW and Intel. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Is Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) In a Dividend Aristocrat Bubble?;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn May 23
column4: one of the greatest financial bubbles in the history of the world kicked off when the Compagnie Perpetuelle des Indes was granted a monopoly by the French monarchy over all the trading rights of all French colonies worldwide.makeArticleAd();The company's stock price quickly soared
column5: from 300 livres per share to more than 1
column6: 000 just a few months later. It was quite a jump. But the enthusiasm continued for more than 18-months.In fact there was such a frenzy to buy shares that it wasn't uncommon for the stock price to double in a single day. By November
column7: share price had surpassed 10
column8: 000.Based on modern-day calculations
column9: a share price of 10
column10: 000 livres would have valued the company at more than the entire GDP of France at the time.That would be likeAlphabet Inc(GOOGL) orAmazon.com
column11: Inc.(AMZN) having a $20 TRILLION stock market capitalization today. Insane.As with all bubbles throughout history
column12: that one burst as wellâ€¦ quickly and violently. Call it 'reversion to the mean'. Stein's Law. Or just plain old common sense.It's pretty simple- there are certain anomalies that are too absurd to last. And nature always finds a way to correct them.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveWhile it's nowhere near as extreme as the Compagnie Perpetuelle des Indes
column13: the market today is also in a completely unsustainable position.I'll show you what I mean-Take a look atExxon Mobil Corporation(XOM); it's one of the largest companies in the world and a favorite among investors due to its 3.7% dividend yield.Quarter after quarter
column14: Exxon Mobile has been paying dividends to its shareholders without fail for decades
column15: even at the peak of the financial crisis.Not only that
column16: but the company has generally increased its dividend each year as well. To stock investors
column17: that kind of consistency is a gold mine. But there's a small problem.For the last several years
column18: Exxon has been borrowing money in order to maintain its dividend payments. Last month
column19: for example
column20: the company reported $26.4 billion in cashflow from its business operations during 2016.But in order to maintain the business
column21: the company had to spend $16.7 billion on what's known in finance as ""capital expenditures"" or ""capex"". Capex is critical to a big business like Exxon Mobil; every year they have to replace old machinery
column22: purchase more land
column23: etc.If they don't do these things
column24: the business will suffer and revenues will decline. So after subtracting the capex
column25: Exxon Mobil had $9.7 billion remaining in ""free cash flow"".Not bad.Except that
column26: according to the company
column27: they paid $12.5 billion in dividends.Hang on a sec. How is it possible that the company could pay $12.5 billion in dividends when they only had $9.7 billion in free cash flow remaining after the capex spending?Easy. They went into debt. Exxon borrowed billions of dollars in order to pay its shareholders a healthy dividend. And they've been doing this for years. Exxon Mobil is FAR from alone.Verizon Communications Inc.(VZ) is another shining example: in 2016
column28: the company earned $22.7 billion from its business operations
column29: but had $17.1 billion worth of capex. That left $5.6 billion remaining. Yet Verizon paid $9.3 billion in dividends.Once again
column30: the company took on billions of dollars in additional debt.This has been a major trend across the biggest companies in the market.There's nothing wrong with debt; sometimes it can be a smart move that creates value for the company.Our manufacturing business in Australia recently took on some debt to buy some new equipment
column31: for example. It's been a great decision; we're able to generate more revenue with less cost
column32: so the overall growth in our profit is multiples greater than the interest payment.But borrowing billions of dollars just to pay out what amounts to sham dividends is a complete waste of moneyâ€¦ and irresponsible.It also means that these record high stock prices are artificial
column33: based on debt-fueled dividends and share buybacks instead of healthy free cash flow.This is totally unsustainable.In addition
column34: with an average P/E ratio of 26.5
column35: stock valuations are at their highest level since the financial crisis; it's yet another layer of risk in this market.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayFew people ever got rich buying what was popular and expensive. But that doesn't stop anyone from trying.Sometimes the hardest thing to do is wait patiently on the sidelines.But successful people don't follow the crowd. They get out in front of the crowd
column36: even if it means being early.The postDividend Aristocrat Bubble?appeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column37: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still a Top Tech Stock;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI'm a firm believer inAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL). In the markets
column4: there is an elite group of companies that define their respective industries. For example
column5: Amazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) owns e-commerce
column7: whileFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) has forever changed social media. And for now
column8: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is the king of smart devices. But in my humble opinion
column9: GOOGL stock tops them all.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockDon't get me wrong as this is not a slight against any of the above companies. Just let me forward a very basic observation - all these other names essentially require the internet to function. If not directly
column10: then certainly
column11: access to the internet represents their core marketing message.But what happens when you own the internet? That's a theoretical question to everyone except GOOGL.As I mentioned in a prior contribution
column12: thedominanceof the GOOGL search engine is unparalleled. The margin between Alphabet Inc and the next biggest competitor
column13: Bing
column14: is a whopping 300%. It just gets worse as you go down the rankings. By the time you hit fifth place
column15: it's just not even worth considering. In any other industry
column16: such a statement would be the death knell for the competition.Essentially
column17: GOOGL stock is an investment in life itself. Many people thought that thename changeto Alphabet - a play on the financial term ""alpha"" and the gambling term ""bet"" - was cheeky and a bit ridiculous. But it also signified that Alphabet Inc could do whatever it wants because no one can stop it. GOOGL stock was essentially either an asset or a threat
column18: depending on your perspective.Volatility Is a Risk to GOOGL StockUnfortunately
column19: where it matters most for investors
column20: GOOGL stock hasn't always shown its best stuff. True
column21: it's early into 2017
column22: and so far
column23: it's up over 4% year-to-date. Keep that up every month and you're guaranteed a stellar annual return. But Alphabet Inc has also beeninconsistent
column24: as InvestorPlace contributor Chris Tyler points out. For example
column25: GOOGL was looking at closing January at over 6%. Instead
column26: it only secured 1.4%.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowOn a strictly nominal basis
column27: that's not much of a swing. But on percentage basis
column28: it's a much different story. It has been well over a decade since Alphabet stock introduced itself to the markets. The crazy dynamics involved in a fresh tech company should be over by now. Today
column29: GOOGL and its subsidiaries are comparable toGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE) if GE was a little more hip.But with great size comes great envy. Alphabet Inc now faces a fundamental problem.Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) wants to reengage acourt rulingthat went in favor of GOOGL. At issue is the company's generous use of Oracle's Java software in order to design the Android operating system. GOOGL contends that using Java - which is open-source - is fair game. Oracle contends that it violates the ""fair use "" component of copyright law.For those that acquired GOOGL stock
column30: it's an ugly situation that might be a legitimate risk. Here's the thing - whether it's legitimate or not doesn't matter. If the markets think it's a problem
column31: it's a problem. That makes the sighting of what appears to be a bearish head-and-shoulders pattern (between early December until now) a curious development.Don't Panic on Alphabet IncGenerally
column32: it's not the best idea to buy an investment with baggage. Certainly
column33: it's not a good idea when the baggage is from a giant company like Oracle. Ditto that for its 6'3â€³ CEO that doesn't come off as someone you want to mess with. In other words
column34: GOOGL stock has some challenges.3 Struggling Stocks That Could Make Epic RunsI also don't think it's a coincidence that the head-and-shoulders pattern is emerging right now. If I'm looking at Alphabet Inc purely as a swing trade
column35: I wouldn't go full bore at this juncture. I expect shares to at least test its 50-day moving average
column36: which stands just under $800. It would not shock me
column37: however
column38: to see GOOGL stock slide towards its 200-day moving average
column39: which is around $763.Again
column40: that's looking at Alphabet Inc from a short-term perspective. For those that have a wider time horizon
column41: the king of the internet is as strong technically as it is fundamentally. Aside from some bumps in the road
column42: GOOGL stock is enjoying clear blue skies. Most importantly
column43: those bumps have never affected Alphabet Inc in a permanent way.The bottom line here is that I would be content holding GOOGL stock. Further
column44: any dips are justifiable buying opportunities
column45: not mere contrarianism for its own sake. Alphabet Inc isgoing to $1
column46: 000- just try to ignore the turbulence as best you can.As of this writing
