column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Wednesday's Analyst   Blog:Tech Stock Roundup: Facebook's TV App
column11: Apple's Original     ContentTechnology stocks had a relatively quiet week although there were increased signs that companies like Facebook (NASDAQ:FB-Free Report) and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) were getting more serious about not just content acquisition but also content creation. While this may not be in direct competition with Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX-Free Report) it does look like competition for Alphabet's (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) YouTube
column12: Spotify and Pandora (NYSE:P-Free Report). It's also definitely competition for eyeballs in what is limited free time for all-Facebook TV AppFacebook has launched a new TV app for Amazon Fire TV
column13: Apple TV and Samsung Smart TV
column14: with possible plans to further expand to other platforms like Microsoft Xbox
column15: Sony PlayStation and other streaming devices. While this will likely enable/support longer video formats
column16: Facebook has said its intention is not to compete with Netflix but rather to enable Facebook users to watch their preferred video on just about any screen of their choice (and that includes TV screens).Of course that's not the only video announcement Facebook made. The company says that henceforth
column17: videos will play automatically with the sound turned on by default (if the device sound is turned on) and the window will retreat to the bottom corner of the screen so you can keep watching the video while scrolling through your newsfeed. Facebook says that testing is showing a positive reaction from users
column18: although it's obvious that not everyone will be overjoyed.Facebook is also reportedly in talks with music labels to bring their content to the app
column19: which seems like an open challenge to YouTube
column20: Google's competing site. For labels
column21: the new distribution channel will increase their leverage against YouTube for more favorable terms. On the flip side
column22: the chances of piracy will increase given the nature of Facebook's free platform.The increased scope for advertising is also an indication that the company is gearing up to grab its share of TV ad dollars.Apple Getting Ready to Debut Reality ShowEddie Cue
column23: Apple's SVP of Internet software and services used the Recode Media Conference to express a lot of enthusiasm for Apple's soon-to-be released ""Planet of the Apps"" reality show on its music subscription service. Contestants will get 60 seconds to explain their idea on an escalator and could win up to millions in venture capital funding if judges will.i.am
column24: Jessica Alba
column25: Gary Vaynerchuk and Gwyneth Paltrow approve. This is the first attempt by Apple to create original content and will likely be joined by Carpool Karaoke in April (Apple bought out the unscripted version of this show in the summer of last year).Google Fiber RestructuringAlphabet has been trimming staff at its Access unit
column26: which is responsible for its high-speed Internet service called Fiber. But last week
column27: the trimming was more in the nature of hacking as it transferred hundreds of employees to other units
column28: retaining just enough to work in the field. The unit also has a new CEO in Greg McCray
column29: who was formerly CEO of Aero Communications and currently also serves on the board of telecom company CenturyLink.The changes while significant are not really surprising
column30: because Google has had a lot of trouble with Fiber not only because of the expense but also because of tussles with telecom companies over their control on telecom poles. In fact
column31: ever since its acquisition of WebPass last year
column32: speculation has been rife that the company will replace or reduce fiber deployment with a cheaper wireless service. That plan seems to have crystallized now as Google cuts staff but remains committed to expanding its Fiber service.Today

column1: Will Driverless Cars End Traditional Car Ownership?;2/23/2017;"I bought a used car recently
column2: and a few days after I brought   it home
column3: a friend asked me
column4: ""Do you think this is the last car   you'll ever buy?""We talk a lot about self-driving cars
column5: so I knew exactly where   he was going with his question. He was hinting at the   fact that both autonomous car technologies and ride-sharing   services are advancing so quickly that by the time I'd be in   the market for another vehicle
column6: I might not actually need to buy   one.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();By 2035
column7: the IHS estimates there will be 76 million cars on   the road worldwide with some level of autonomy.Even now
column8: semi-autonomous cars that can keep themselves in   their lanes
column9: automatically brake in emergency situations
column10: and   slow down to match the speed of the car in front of themcan be purchasedfor as little as $20
column11: 000.And as genuinely driverless cars get cheaper and become   ubiquitous
column12: you and I may opt out of monthly car payments and   opt-in to a monthly mileage subscription service instead.Automakers are investing in this futureTo understand how it's possible that we could soon live in a   world where most people don't own cars
column13: we need to look no   further than what the automakers themselves are doing.Elon Musk's recently updated version ofTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA)  master plan includes details on a new   service: When the company's vehicles become fully autonomous (by   2018 or 2019
column14: according to Musk)
column15: Tesla owners will be able to   allow their vehicles to drive themselves around and be rented out   by other people.As Musk wrote:You will also be able to add your car to the Tesla shared     fleet just by tapping a button on the Tesla phone app and have     it generate income for you while you're at work or on vacation
column16: significantly offsetting and at times potentially exceeding the     monthly loan or lease cost.Image source: Tesla.Musk also said that Tesla would deploy its own fleet of   driverless vehicles for rent in areas where there was more demand   for Tesla vehicles than privately owned cars could meet
column17: so that    ""you can always hail a ride from us no matter where you   are."" Remember
column18: this isn't the catchphrase of a taxi company
column19: nor   even a ride-hailing service -- but rather the direction where   Musk sees his automaker headed.And just in case think this mentality is unique to the   innovative Tesla
column20: consider whatGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM)  is doing. The giant automaker launched a   ride-sharing service last year called Maven
column21: which allows some GM   owners to rent out their vehicles when they're not in use. The   cars don't drive themselves yet
column22: but the company sees it as a   first step toward a future where people are less inclined to own   cars.In a press release at the time
column23: GM said that more than 25   million of its customers around the world will use some form of   shared mobility by 2020
column24: and describe Maven as ""a key element of   our strategy to changing ownership models in the automotive   industry."" Maven has spread to 17 cities across North America in   just 11 months
column25: has 22
column26: 000 members
column27: and has been used for 57   million miles of driving.Not to be outdone
column28: Ford(NYSE: F) has launched i ts own ride-sharing service
column29: and is   developing autonomous cars just like GM. Ford has made it clear   that it intends to launch a ""high-volume"" driverless car paired   with ride-hailing and ride-sharing services by 2021. The   company is already testing 30 self-driving Fusion Hybrids in   several states
column30: and plans to triple the number of test vehicles   this year.Other automakers are moving in this direction as well.Fiat Chrysler(NYSE: FCAU) is working withAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google to test a fleet of 100   self-driving minivans that will be the basis for aride-hailing serviceset to launch later this year. It's still unclear what the   service will look like
column31: or if Fiat Chrysler will play a critical   role in it
column32: but what is clear is that the automaker believes in   the viability of Waymo's cars-as-a-service goal.Will this really end car ownership?It's hard to answer this question conclusively
column33: of course.   After all
column34: most people haven't even seen a fully autonomous   vehicle on the road
column35: let alone ridden in one.But John Zimmer
column36: the co-founder and president of   ride-hailing company Lyft
column37: believes thatby 2025 ""private car ownership will all-but end in major U.S.   cities."" Lyft expects the majority of its vehicles to be   self-driving by 2021
column38: and rival Uber is testing similar   strategies as well.Others have set similar timelines for the demise of car   ownership. Georg Bauer
column39: who has held executive positions at   Daimler
column40: BMW
column41: and TeslatoldBusiness Insiderlast year that he thinks car ownership could be dead within   five to 10 years.Government regulations and our own apprehension about giving   up control over our vehicles may preserve the widespread car   ownership culture for longer than some expect. But what's crystal   clear is that tech companies and automakers alike are betting on   an automotive future that looks very different than today. Like   many things
column42: the transition from owning cars to renting   driverless ones on an as-needed basis will likely occur in stages   -- but let's be clear
column43: things are certainly moving in this   direction. And I
column44: for one
column45: would welcome a world without car   payments.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column46: it can pay to listen. After all
column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column48: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column49: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column52: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Chris Neigerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares)
column53: Alphabet (C     shares)
column54: Ford
column55: and Tesla. The Motley Fool recommends General     Motors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Mobileye NV Q4 Earnings Are Good Enough for Now
column2: But â€¦;2/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI've long thoughtMobileye NV(NYSE:MBLY) is too expensive. Mobileye has an interesting opportunity in driver assistance
column4: and eventually
column5: autonomous driving. But it also has intense competition from companies ranging fromNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) toAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) to Tier 1 suppliers likeDelphi Automotive PLC(NYSE:DLPH) andAutoliv Inc.(NYSE:ALV). But I haven't shorted MBLY stock - yet - and I hardly thought Mobileye's fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday presented an opportunity.makeArticleAd();Source:U.S. Embassy Tel Aviv via FlickrAfter all
column6: MBLY is a story stock
column7: and the story looked strong heading into Mobileye earnings. A series of deals and partnerships announced in the past few weeks led MBLY stock up 35% from late December lows. Optimism around autonomous driving and increasing automotive technology continues to rise; there's a reasonTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) stock is near all-time highs. Betting against that in the short-term seemed foolish.That story appears to hold for a little while longer
column8: as Mobileye earnings out Wednesday morning came in ahead of consensus estimates and the company's own guidance. In response
column9: MBLY stock reversed from modest gains to modest losses back to 2%-plus gains again in premarket trading. That seems to imply that investors already are looking forward.But it's there the Mobileye story might have some holes.Mobileye Earnings Look SolidMobileye earnings for Q4 beat both Street consensus and its own guidance on the top and bottom line. Revenue of $104.6 million
column10: in particular
column11: looks impressive. MBLY had guided for roughly $96 million coming out of Q3 in moving expectations to the high end of a full-year $344 million-$350 million range. Heading into the earnings report
column12: analysts largely backed those projections.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowThe beat
column13: then
column14: implies growth roughly 11 points higher than thought
column15: with revenue growing almost 46% year-over-year.The driver (no pun intended) appears to be aftermarket sales. Those sales - largely dash-mounted systems on existing cars
column16: rather than installed systems in new cars - increased 156% year-over-year. MBLY management had raised full-year projections for that division after Q2 to 20% of total sales. In fact
column17: Q4 Mobileye earnings show the aftermarket drove 23% of full-year revenue
column18: with sales increasing 113% for full-year 2016.Earnings per share beat consensus and implied guidance by 2 cents
column19: which implies that profit margins were roughly as expected. The reason likely is that aftermarket sales offer lower gross margins
column20: and thus aren't quite as profitable. MBLY has improved gross margins in the business
column21: but mix seems like the most significant reason why the company didn't better leverage sales growth.Long-Term Questions Remain for MBLY StockThe fact that the revenue beat came from aftermarket growth isn't quite the outcome that Mobileye stock bulls would have preferred for Q4.The exciting business here is in OEM
column22: from both the standpoint of market opportunity and profit margins. While 113% growth for aftermarket sales is nothing to sneeze at
column23: it's still off a rather small base. And $82 million in aftermarket sales for 2016
column24: on its own
column25: isn't near enough to support a stock with an enterprise value over $10 billion.That seems to mean investors are looking forward. 2017 guidance on the conference call is for EPS of $1.01-$1.05 and revenue of $490 million-$505 million. Earnings appear just shy of analyst estimates of $1.04
column26: while revenue of $490 million-$505 million suggests an outperformance to Street expectations of $491 million.That combination
column27: however
column28: means margins will be a bit lower than forecast by analysts. That
column29: in turn
column30: likely comes from a higher-than-expected proportion of aftermarket revenue - again
column31: not what the bulls necessarily wanted to hear.And that may be enough for some of the long-term concerns to enter the narrative in MBLY stock in post-earnings trading.Looking ForwardMorgan Stanley downgraded Mobileye stock at the beginning of the month based on margin concerns - a move that took MBLY stock down 3%. And the ability of Mobileye to maintain margins is a big concern of mine
column32: longer-term.I'm still skeptical that any semiconductor company can hold pricing (and thus margins) longer-term. One of the few exceptions
column33: of course
column34: is Nvidia itself. But Mobileye stock
column35: now trading at ~45x 2017 EPS
column36: still is priced higher than NVDA
column37: and part of Nvidia's huge gains over the past year have come from optimism over prospects for its Drive PX 2 platform.How to Trade Facebook Inc for 470% ReturnsThat platform is what Tesla turned to after its relationship ended with Mobileye (and somewhat acrimoniously). That decision alone illustrates the long-term challenges. Competition will be intense
column38: and pricing will be too. It's important to remember that MBLY is a semiconductor company (though it has software capabilities
column39: admittedly) and an automotive supplier. Neither industry traditionally gets very high earnings multiple
column40: because both businesses are extremely tough.For Mobileye to be an outlier on both fronts
column41: its execution needs to be perfect
column42: and its growth flawless. Mobileye earnings for Q4 show a step in the right direction from that standpoint.But with the earnings beat driven largely by aftermarket sales
column43: that step probably isn't big enough for MBLY stock to take another step higher.As of this writing

column6: if one man has a shot at becoming a trillionaire

Finance *Based on the   midpoint of Snap's expected pricing range.Despite its relatively small valuation

column1: Warren Buffett Might Make These 3 Driverless Car Investing Mistakes;2/22/2017;"Warren Buffett is well-known for having
column2: among the core tenets   of his investment strategy
column3: a preference for companies with   serious ""competitive moats"" -- attributes that give them the   ability to sustainably keep ahead of their competition. But based   on his rues
column4: Buffett would never invest in an emerging industry   like self-driving cars
column5: and his competitive moat ideas don't   necessarily hold water in this world. If you're a fan of the   Oracle of Omaha
column6: beware of following his investment philosophy   into these three mistakes.1. Focusing too much on sizeImage source: Alphabet (Waymo)makeArticleAd();Economies of scale are an important indicator for almost any   company. As the logic goes
column7: the bigger a company is
column8: the greater   its ability to cut per-unit costs.Ford's(NYSE: F) ability to keep its car costs lower thanTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column9: for example
column10: isn't just based on the fact that   it produces more economically designed vehicles. It's also due to   the fact that Ford produced 1.5 million cars in the third quarter   of 2016
column11: compared to the 24
column12: 800 cars Tesla Motors delivered   during the same period.But scalability in the driverless car industry doesn't   necessarily have anything to do with car sales. The automaker   with the best technology may ultimately come out ahead.   Technology is scalable at almost no cost. When Tesla Motors   wirelessly uploads its latest software to its already-sold   vehicles around the world
column13: the company pays nearly nothing in   per-unit costs. The race to build the best driverless car at this   stage has much more to do with technology than with numbers of   vehicles sold
column14: and the quantity of cars a company has sold thus   far isn't a indicator for which company is best placed to scale   in the future.2. Exaggerating the value of network effectsWhat network?Network effects are often touted as one of the strongest   competitive moats around.Facebook
column15: an actual social network
column16: perfectly defines the allure of the   network effect. If everyone is using a specific product or   platform
column17: it can be extremely difficult for another company to   make inroads.At first glance
column18: driverless cars seem to be an excellent   opportunity to build network effects. If one company's cars all   ""talk"" to each other as they navigate the roads
column19: they'll get to   their destinations faster and more safely than competitors' --   right? Wrong. Driverless car technology must necessarily take   into account public safety
column20: and unique
column21: exclusionary networks fly   in the face of a universal platform for safe self-driving cars.   Automakers engaged in this space already know this; it's why   Ford
column22: Tesla
column23: and others are equipping their driverless cars with   the best real-world object detection technology available.When Ford announced earlier last week that it would invest $1   billion over five years in Argo AI
column24: it wasn't because   the startup has thousands of self-driving cars on the road   -- it was because the company's robotics expertise ""gives Ford a   distinct competitive advantage at the intersection of the   automotive and technology industries
column25: explained Ford Chief   Technology Officer Raj Nair in a press release. Likewise
column26: Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) spinoff Waymo isn't relying on   Google's treasure troves of data to guide its vehicles as they   drive around. Instead
column27: Waymo cars are equipped with sensors and   software designed to detect obstacles up to ""two football fields   away in all directions."" Ford
column28: Alphabet
column29: Tesla Motors
column30: and others   aren't interested in network effects in this arena. They're   interested in their cars having the most acute local-area   awareness they can contain.3. Expecting government regulation to limit competitionRegular regulationRegulation can provide some of the widest competitive moats   around. If only one company is able to meet all the regulatory   requirements of being in a business
column31: it's essentially illegal for   others to try to compete with it. The driverless car industry   recognizes this
column32: and is making moves to ensure a level playing   field for all involved.Alphabet
column33: Ford
column34: Lyft
column35: Uber
column36: and Volvo Cars joined together   last April to create the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets
column37: "" a lobbying group whose stated mission is to ""work with   lawmakers
column38: regulators
column39: and the public to realize the safety and   societal benefits of self-driving vehicles."" These companies are   interested in standardizing national policy with simple and   low-cost barriers to entry for all interested automakers. So for   Buffett fans looking to back the company with the strongest   regulation-related advantages
column40: know that some of the biggest   names in the business are working proactively to push   policies that ensure no company can ever build a regulatory   moat.Picking the right self-driving car stockWarren Buffett is an incredible investor
column41: but he doesn't have   answers for every industry. There are many open questions around   self-driving cars
column42: and some companies are morepoised to profitthan others. Rather than sticking to one-size-fits-all investment   mantras
column43: equip yourself with the factsyou need to know
column44: make informed investments
column45: and set your   portfolio to auto-pilot for years to come.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is the Perfect VALUE Play;2/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI love growth stocks as much as the next guy
column3: butAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) might just be my favorite at the moment. That's because GOOGL stock has something that a lot of other high-growth dynamos simply don't have:makeAd('4'
column5: 'mktsnews'
column6: 'vanguard'
column8: '');Source: ShutterstockAny value left whatsoever.I'm prudent when it comes to hyper-growth stocks such asAmazon.com
column9: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andNetflix
column10: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX). I've missed out on some great runs as a result
column11: but I also haven't gotten burned when growth flags. Instead
column12: I prefer to focus on ""growth at a reasonable price
column13: or GARP - and I believe GOOGL stock falls into this category.Go With GARPWith growth stocks
column14: I look for a price-to-earnings ratio of a stock that is no more than 2x its earnings growth rate
column15: if earnings are growing at 15% annually or more. And I want to back out stock buyback effects. To me
column16: a GARP stock has a PEG ratio of 1.0
column17: though I'll allow up to 1.5 depending on the earnings growth rate.GOOGL stock trades at 29x FY16 earnings and about 21x FY17 earnings. Analysts see five-year annualized growth at 19.2%. So on the surface
column18: Alphabet seems to qualify as a GARP pick.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksBut there's even more good news.This doesn't consider the net cash position of GOOGL stock. See
column19: I value a company net of its net cash hoard
column20: just as Peter Lynch used to do. With $86.4 billion on its balance sheet
column21: that pulls the market cap for Alphabet down to about $480 billion.On $19.5 billion in net income for FY16
column22: we suddenly find that Alphabet stock trades at 24.6 times FY16 earnings and only about 17.5 times FY17 earnings.That's the first step for me in even determining if GOOGL stock is a stock to get involved in.How Is Alphabet's Business?The next thing I examine is how healthy Alphabet Inc's actual businesses are.I still don't like the idea that GOOGL is basically a giant digital advertising billboard with a venture capital arm. However
column23: I can't deny that Google's search engineholds an astonishing 80.47% market share. As long as four out of every five searches are conducted on Google
column24: advertisers will throw money at Alphabet. There would have to be a scandal of monumental proportions
column25: or some incredibly innovative new method of searching
column26: to change this significantly.Alphabet's 17% year-over-year increase in advertising revenue to $22.4 billion comes as no surprise.So next I look at the YOY metrics
column27: which look fantastic Aggregate paid clicks up 36%
column28: paid clicks on Google properties up 43%
column29: and paid clicks on Network properties up 7%. A lot of people freaked out that cost-per-click fell 15%
column30: 16% and 19% for each of the above categories
column31: respectively. The market doesn't seem to realize that this is because more advertising is being pushed to mobile.As for Other Bets
column32: which is basically the company's VC arm
column33: I don't love that it blew a billion dollars in the quarter. But considering free cash flow was $6.33 billion
column34: and net cash is $86.4 billion
column35: GOOGL has that money to spend. With portfolio strategy
column36: all it takes is one of these VC bets to hit
column37: and all that money spent will be made back and more.This brief glance tells me that Alphabet is an advertising business with dominant market share that is literally printing money. I mean
column38: it generated $26 billion in free cash flow in FY16. That'sfreecash flow
column39: meaning it can do whatever it wants with it.Go Long the Super Spike In Tesla Inc (TSLA) EarningsThat's even after spending about $10 billion in capex.Bottom Line on GOOGL StockNormally

column1: Can Amazon's Chime Challenge Microsoft's Skype and Cisco's Spark?;2/21/2017;"Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) recently introduced Chime
column2: an  enterprise   collaboration service for online meetings
column3: video conferencing
column4: voice calls
column5: chat
column6: and content sharing. Chime's apps work on iOS
column7: Android
column8: Windows
column9: and Mac
column10: and the content is synchronized across   all platforms via Amazon Web Services (AWS).Chime comes in three versions -- Chime Basis
column11: for 1:1 voice   and video calls and chat; Chime Plus
column12: which adds screen sharing   and the integration of company directories; and Chime Pro
column13: which   adds tools for scheduling
column14: hosting
column15: recording
column16: and personalizing   meetings for up to 100 people.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();These features indicate that Amazon is taking aim at   collaborative tools likeMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Skype andCisco's(NASDAQ: CSCO) Spark. But are those rivals already too deeply   entrenched in the enterprise market for Amazon to disrupt? Let's   take a closer look at Amazon's game plan to find out.Entering the crowded SaaS marketAmazon's AWS
column17: which has an annual run rate of $14 billion
column18: is   the  biggest cloud infrastructure platform in the world.   It's several times larger than its closest competitor
column19: Microsoft's Azure. But while AWS dominates the cloud platform   (infrastructure/platform as a service) market -- which hosts   storage space
column20: processing power
column21: and other tools for companies   and developers -- it doesn't have a major presence in the SaaS   (software as a service) market yet.The SaaS market is the crowded
column22: consumer-facing side of the   cloud
column23: which includes services like Microsoft's Office 365
column24: Dynamics CRM
column25: and Skype. The lion's share of Microsoft's   commercialized cloud revenue run  rate of $14 billion is   generated by those SaaS products instead of Azure. Microsoft has   also been expanding Skype's capabilities as an enterprise   collaboration tool with  Microsoft Teams
column26: which enhances   Skype's cloud-based communication features and tightly integrates   the service into Office 365.Microsoft Teams. Image source: Microsoft.Meanwhile
column27: networking giant Cisco aggressively bundles   software and security products with its routers
column28: switches
column29: and   unified computing systems. Those bundles include collaboration   tools like Spark
column30: the cloud-based platform for  messages
column31: meetings
column32: and calls it launched in late 2015. Last quarter
column33: Cisco's collaboration revenues rose 4% annually to $1.06 billion   -- making it its third largest business after its  core   businesses of router and switches.But Microsoft and Cisco aren't the only players in the crowded   field of cloud-based collaborative tools.Alphabet's Google has been promoting Hangouts to enterprise customers   over  the past year
column34: Boxhas added collaborative tools on top of its cloud storage   platform
column35: andLogMeInacquiredCitrix's GoToMeeting video conferencing platform for the same purposes.   However
column36: all these challengers notably lack Microsoft and Cisco's   clout in the enterprise market.That's why Amazon believes it can succeedBut like Microsoft and Cisco
column37: Amazon also has leverage -- the   growing importance of AWS to enterprise customers. Amazon likely   believes that by offering Chime as an extension of AWS   (especially with its 30-day free trial) to its enterprise   customer base
column38: it can gain a foothold in the crowded ""unified   communication"" platform market.Amazon previously launched enterprise SaaS products like    WorkSpaces
column39: WorkDocs
column40: and WorkMail
column41: but it hasn't ever   released official growth figures for those products. However
column42: most industry watchers believe that those products are still   dwarfed by comparable solutions from Microsoft and Cisco. This   strongly indicates that AWS' dominance of the PaaS/IaaS markets   doesn't guarantee that Chime will become a Skype or Spark killer   anytime soon. Chime Pro also  costs more than Skype for   Business -- so it doesn't look like Amazon plans to undercut its   way into the market.The key takeawayChime sounds like a logical way for AWS to straddle the   PaaS/IaaS and SaaS markets
column43: but it's easier said than done. The   market for cloud-based unified communication platforms is   incredibly crowded
column44: and it's doubtful that a new service -- even   one bundled with AWS -- can claim a meaningful slice of the   market. However
column45: Amazon investors should still keep an eye out   for future SaaS products to see if the company can eventually   challenge heavyweights like Microsoft and Cisco.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: These Are the 10-Most Admired Companies in the World;2/21/2017;"When the public votes for something the results can skew based   on perception
column2: emotion
column3: or sometimes even the desire to mess with   the outcome.That's how a $300 million state-of-the-art British polar   research ship earned the name ""Boaty McBoatface."" The question of   the ship's name was put to an internet vote
column4: and while over 7
column5: 000   names were submitted
column6: according toCNN
column7: ""Boaty McBoatface"" won easily with 124
column8: 109 votes. Votes being   open to the public have given us many questionable
column9: past-their-prime Major League Baseball all-stars
column10: as well as a   whale being tracked by Greenpeace being named Mr. Splashy   Pants.These are all ridiculous votes skewed by a playful public
column11: but   they illustrate that sometimes open voting can produce less-than   reliable results. In creating its annualMost-Admired Companies ListFortune does not leave the question open to a public vote
column12: instead the publication works with its partner Korn Ferry Hay   Group to build a list and then survey executives from the   companies that make the initial cut.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty.After starting with about 1
column13: 500 candidates (the 1
column14: 000 largest   U.S. companies ranked by revenue
column15: along with non-U.S. companies   in Fortune's Global 500 database that have revenues of $10   billion or more)
column16: the selections are cut down to the   highest-revenue companies in each industry. That leaves 680   companies in 28 countries
column17: and 3
column18: 800 insiders affiliated with   those companies voted on the list.""To determine the best-regarded companies in 51 industries
column19: Korn Ferry Hay Group asked executives
column20: directors
column21: and analysts to   rate enterprises in their own industry on nine criteria
column22: from   investment value and quality of management and products to social   responsibility and ability to attract talent
column23: Fortune explained.   This
column24: as you can see
column25: is not a fan vote
column26: but an insider's   perspective on which companies are most admired by their own   executives
column27: competitors
column28: and people who should actually know.Apple topped the list of most-admired companies. column29: there's a clear value in being well-regarded             by industry insiders. The 10 companies above are not             only successful
column30: but those best-placed to judge are             saying they admire them
column31: which should be taken as a             strong positive by shareholders and potential             investors.""Having the respect of your peers and your             competitors is absolutely crucial in business and             almost everywhere else
column32: said Fortune's Assistant             Managing Editor Nicholas Varchaver in avideothat accompanied the list. ""Fortune's World's             Most-Admired Company's List is a list that embodies             precisely that idea.""This isn't a popularity contest or a thrown-off             quick vote. It's a fairly in-depth look at the             companies most-admired by business leaders. Making the             list suggests that these are brands that do things the             right way
column33: companies with solid foundations likely to             not only be around for the long haul
column34: but to continue             to thrive.Being held in this type of high regard by your             competitors may also come with actual advantages.             In-demand workers are likely to want to work for             companies they admire. The brands on this list likely             have an easier time recruiting top talent because they             are thought of this way and in competitive markets like             coders

column1: 3 Virtual Reality Stock Investing Tips That Will Pay Off Long Term;2/21/2017;"Virtual reality (VR) is forecast to become a $162 billion   market by 2020
column2: and the opportunities for investors to benefit   are growing. Nearly every major technology company is pursuing   VR
column3: or at least looking into it
column4: and some are spending billions   in order to make it the next popular computing platform.So how can individual investors benefit from all of this?   Start with these three tips:Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Don't focus on hardwareYou're probably hearing a lot about VR headsets these days.   Oculus released its long-awaited Rift headset last year;Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) purchased the company more than two years ago for $2   billion.Sony's(NYSE: SNE) PlayStation VR headset launched back in October
column5: giving PS4 users the ability to play and view VR content on their   consoles. AndAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) recently launched its new mobile   VR headset
column6: called the Daydream View. The company also just hired   a key VR headset designer away from HTC
column7: which makes the popular   HTC Vive headset.But don't focus on any of that.VR headsets and other hardware are clearly an important part   of this market
column8: but the real gains will come from software and   services. Tom Mainelli
column9: vice president of devices and AR/VR at   IDC
column10: said last year that ""... what people can do with   that hardware will depend upon the applications and services that   power it.""According to IDC
column11: hardware sales will account for more than half of VR and   augmented reality (AR) revenues through 2020
column12: but that it's   software and services that have the real long-term potential.""AR/VR software revenues will also get off to a quick start
column13: growing more than 200% year over year in 2016
column14: but will quickly   be overtaken by services revenues in the middle years of the   forecast
column15: as logistics and manufacturing demand enterprise-class   support
column16: Mainelli said.The bigger
column17: the betterIn the technology sector
column18: it's often the players that start   out the biggest that win in the end
column19: and virtual reality will   likely be the same.That's why it's important to look at what Facebook
column20: Alphabet
column21: and Sony are doing in the space. Facebook's long-term goal isn't   to just sell high-end VR headsets
column22: but rather to create the next   widely adopted computing platform.CEO Mark Zuckerberg said in aninterviewwithBusiness Insider last year that Facebook is ""mostly interested in the software""   aspect of VR
column23: though he noted that the early stages of VR   development will require a focus on both hardware and   software.His long-term goal for AR and VR is to create an entirely new   computing platform. ""So I do think a new computing platform   always emerges every 10 or 15 years. VR is currently the most   promising candidate
column24: he said.While Facebook is looking ahead to the next computing   platform
column25: Alphabet is busy focusing on how it can gain from the   mobile VR market. The company recently debuted its Daydream   platform for Android users to find VR videos and apps.The importance of this VR hub can't be overstated. Smaller   companies may be making VR content
column26: but Alphabet's Google has   built one of the only places where all of this content can live
column27: and be easily found. As mobile VR takes off
column28: Daydream will   likely be the place where users go to get their content. Think of   it like a Google Play store for VR.And while Facebook and Alphabet are busy building out   platforms
column29: don't forget Sony's potential to make itself a   powerhouse in the VR gaming market. The company already   working with more than 230 developers and publishers to create   160 PlayStation VR software titles.Sony's Game and Network Services is the company'ssecond-most profitablebusiness
column30: and the company has said the VR ""offers great   future potential"" for the segment.Stay the courseHonestly
column31: the payoff for VR investors will likely take some   time to materialize. That's because while the market is growing   fast
column32: VR represents only a small portion of revenues -- if any --   for many of the companies involved in the space right now.Facebook said its investments in VR weren't material to the   company's 2016 financials
column33: and Zuckerberg has stated several   times that VR probably won't truly take off for another five to   10 years.But that shouldn't be a deterrent for investors. Virtual   reality has the potential to transform how people access   information
column34: view content
column35: and interact with each other. If it   does become the next big computing platform
column36: then taking a   long-term approach to the will be the wise course.Investors should heed this advice Zuckerberg gave last year:   ""We are betting that virtual reality is going to be an important   technology. I am pretty confident about this. And now is the time   to invest.""10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Ignore the Management Shakeup Drama -- Viacom Is a Fantastic Buy Today;2/20/2017;"Long a pillar of the entertainment industry
column2: Viacom(NASDAQ: VIAB) has fallen on hard times as of late. First
column3: its   Paramount film division has suffered a string of box-office   flops
column4: with its share of the box office falling to just 8% in   2016. Then there's its portfolio of television networks
column5: once the   envy of the entertainment industry
column6: but have suffered amid   increasing competition not only from peers likeWalt Disney
column7: but from the internet itself. Viewers used to have to tune   into Viacom'sMTVto view the latest music video
column8: or to itsComedy Centralnetwork for a laugh -- now consumers need only head over toAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOGL)YouTubefor the latest hit song and a laugh.However
column9: for reasons that are detailed below
column10: shares in the   entertainment conglomerate offer a compelling value to   prospective investors. Read on to learn more.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Recent eventsThere's no other way to put it -- the last year or so has   tumultuous within the C-suite of Viacom's management. The drama
column11: which has been more than covered by the media
column12: culminated with   theresignation of multibillionaire Viacom   Chairmanand former CEO Sumner Redstone. Now
column13: with the appointment of new   CEO Robert Bakish
column14: the situation appears to be on the mend
column15: which   is great news
column16: because all has not been well
column17: not only in the   C-suite
column18: but on the income statement as well:Metric20162015ChangeRevenue$3.32 billion$3.15 billion5%Operating income$706 million$839 million(16%)Diluted EPS$1.00$1.13(12%)Data source:Viacom February 9
column19: 2017 Quarterly Earnings   Results.While revenues were obviously headed in the right direction
column20: profits were not -- which partially explains the company's low   earnings multiple. However
column21: this has not always been the case. In   fact
column22: lackluster growth could very well be considered an anomaly   in the company's operating history.A look backHistorically
column23: Viacom has a history of profit growth and solid   returns on capital. In fact
column24: its record over the years has been   quite good.VIAB Normalized Diluted EPS (TTM)data byYCharts.Alas
column25: perhaps caused by or contributing to the myriad problems   at the top that the public has been more than privy to over the   past year
column26: the company's momentum has been all but   derailed. Fortunately
column27: there lies a strong case to be made   that the company's inherent advantages remain intact
column28: and   brighter days lie ahead.Content is king!Viacom was built into what it is today by 93-year-old Sumner   Redstone
column29: who built his empire on the belief that it was content
column30: not distribution
column31: that would fuel the entertainment industry in   the decades ahead. When he made this shift
column32: in the 1970s when he   was working for his father's National Amusements theater chain
column33: this was a novel innovation. Today
column34: the world has caught onto   this insight and is giving the company a run for its money.   However
column35: this should not detract from the company's prime   properties
column36: networks like MTV (and its derivative channels)
column37: as   well as Nickelodeon
column38: Comedy Central
column39: Spike
column40: BET
column41: and CMT. On top   of all this
column42: the company is also the owner of Paramount   Studios.Despite increasing competition from all quarters
column43: Viacom's   networks are holding their own. For the quarter ended December   31
column45: Media Networks' revenues rose 1% to $2.6 billion -- and   this ignores an averse 2% impact due to foreign exchange losses.   Softness in total advertising revenues (-2% to $1.29 billion) was   balanced out by an increase in affiliate (essentially   international) revenues
column46: which climbed 2% to $1.14 billion. These   results are nothing to write home about
column47: but they aren't   terrible
column48: either. All the more
column49: when looking at the situation   holistically and holding shares up to the light of its enviable   brands and good-not-great recent financial results
column50: shares become   increasingly attractive when one reflects on their current   valuation.VIAB PE Ratio (TTM)data byYCharts.Should Viacom be able to right the ship
column51: investors will more   than likely be handsomely rewarded given the stock's historically   low valuation. Here
column52: the situation appears to be positive as   well. Management is no longer distracted by the drama surrounding   the departure of Sumner Redstone and will be able to focus on   international expansion of its brands. Also
column53: Paramount Studios   has recently been given a ""booster shot"" of sorts via a$1 billion dollar
column54: 3-year dealby Chinese film studios Shanghai Film Group and Huahua Media. The   cash infusion
column55: coupled with the potential for allowing Paramount   to make strong inroads into the fast-growing Chinese film market   all bode well. These facts are perhaps why analysts polled byS&P Global Market Intelligencethink Viacom's EPS will likely grow from $3.85 per share in FY   2017 to a respectable $5.26 per share (an annualized 8%   annualized increase).A few words of cautionThe world continues to change
column56: and while few could have   imagined Viacom's reach 30 years ago
column57: the same could have been   said of potential threats to its core entertainment   brands. The fact is
column58: the company faces threats from all   quarters
column59: from individuals in their homes posting comedic videos   on YouTube to Time Warner'sHBO. Consumers only have so many hours in the day
column60: and fantastic   content is now everywhere they turn. Viacom likely has what it   takes to continue to compete and garner viewers' eyeballs and   attention -- but the ever-present risk that the company will   slowly be overtaken is there.Foolish final thoughtsIt appears that now is a rare time to buy into a fantastic   media enterprise at a time when its shares are trading hands at a   historically low valuation. True
column61: its competitive position isn't   what it used to be
column62: and yes
column63: the company has been mired in an   ugly battle for control that was only recently resolved. But   these negatives should not detract from the company's   one-of-a-kind media properties
column64: nor its attractive valuation that   brings with it a 1.8% dividend yield to boot. Overall

column1: 5 Finalists for Google Lunar XPrize Race to the Moon;2/19/2017;"Only 46 weeks remain for one of five lucky companies to claim   a $20 million prize -- and the first one to arrive on the Moon   gets it.For the past 18 months
column2: I've kept you up to date on the   loomingGoogle Lunar XPRIZE competition
column3: a $40 million effort (recently increased from $30 million) --   sponsored byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) and organized by Peter   Diamandis' nonprofit XPRIZE organization -- to encourage   private development of the Moon. But it's only now
column4: this year
column5: that the clock really starts ticking. At some time within the   next 10 and a half months
column6: one company must succeed in achieving   XPRIZE's three key stated requirements -- or forfeit its chance   to win the $20 million purse for placing first.Sometime in 2017
column7: someone will land on the Moon. Bet on it.     Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();First thing's firstIn case youhaven'tbeen paying attention to the Google Lunar XPRIZE competition
column8: let's bring you up to date. So far
column9: $5.25 million in prizes have   been doled out to teams demonstrating ""milestone"" capabilities in   the skills of conducting lunar landings
column10: moving about on the   lunar surface
column11: and lunar imaging.Still up for grabs is the grand prize -- $20 million for being   the first team to successfully land on the Moon
column12: travel at least   500 meters from the landing site
column13: and transmit two   high-definition ""Mooncasts"" back to Earth. The second team to   complete all three missions will receive $5 million
column14: and then   there are up to $17 million in additional prizes for   accomplishing various add-on missions (e.g.
column15: conducting a   Mooncast from the Apollo 11
column20: or 17 landing sites
column21: keeping a rover alive and functioning for at least two days
column22: or   finding water on the Moon).But to win any share at all of this loot
column23: someone has to land   on the Moon -- and someone has to be first.Round up some unusual suspectsWho will the winner be? I've already introduced you to two of   the leading contenders:Israeli start-up SpaceIL
column24: which has contracted with     Spaceflight Industries for room aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket     to carry its spacecraft and lander to the Moon.And America's ownMoon Express
column25: the first company to receive U.S. government approval to land     on the Moon (with a little help from Rocket Lab's Electron     rocket
column26: which will be carrying it up there).Both these rivals have set launch dates vaguely in the ""late   2017"" range
column27: ensuring this race will go down to the wire. As for   the other participants
column28: last month
column29: XPRIZE announced the   remaining three finalists ready to take a shot at the Moon. These   include:Synergy Moon
column30: an international alliance among the Human     Synergy Project
column31: California-based Interplanetary Ventures
column32: British satcom company RPC Telecommunications
column33: and American     aerospace manufacturer Interorbital Systems. Interorbital will     provide the rocket for this team -- a NEPTUNE 8 launch vehicle     launching from sea
column34: off the California coast
column35: sometime later     this year.Team Indus
column36: flying aboard an ISRO space agency     PSLV rocket from India before attempting to land an ""ECA""     moon rover.And finally
column37: Japanese competitor Hakuto
column38: an eclectic team     backed by everyone from Japanese space agency JAXA to Suzuki to     a rock band called ""Sakanaction.""Curiously
column39: both Indus and Hakuto will ride the same PSLV   rocket to the Moon
column40: and land their rovers on the same lander.   This could make it difficult deciding which one lands ""first"" and   gets the big $20 million prize. But seeing as they have to land   on the Moon successfully before they encounter this dilemma
column41: figuring out who arrived first will be a nice problem to have   once they get there. Indus and Hakuto plan to launch their XPRIZE   mission on Dec. 28
column42: 2017.What it means to investors$20 million
column43: $30 million
column44: $40 million -- however much prize   money Google ultimately antes up for the winners
column45: it's unlikely   thatanyof these teams will make much of a profit from running the first   privately funded Moon landing. But that's not the point.First and foremost
column46: the point will be earning bragging rights   for accomplishing something no nongovernmental agency -- not even   SpaceX -- has ever done before: landing a spacecraft on the Moon.   And as we saw when privately held Scaled Composites won the   Ansari XPRIZE back in 2004 -- and was later bought out byNorthrop Grumman(NYSE: NOC)
column47: which had previously owned only a minority stake --   just placing first in an XPRIZE competition could make a company   more attractive to would-be acquirers.Of greater import to investors
column48: though
column49: is what comesaftersomeone successfully lands a spacecraft on the Moon. Proving the   mission is feasible will almost certainly invite imitation by   larger companies
column50: and with any luck
column51: publicly traded companies   that we can invest in ourselves. It will open up not just a new   market
column52: but literally a whole new world of opportunities for   those who follow the trail blazed by this year's space pioneers.   All we need now is for someone to take that first step.And by Dec. 31
column54: we should know who that will be.10 stocks we like better than Northrop GrummanWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column55: it can pay to listen. After all
column56: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Are General Motors and Lyft About to Crush All Self-Driving Rivals?;2/19/2017;"General Motors(NYSE: GM) is planning to build and deploy thousands of   self-driving electric cars in test fleets with Lyft next year
column2: according to a newReutersreport.If that's for real
column3: it will be by far the largest fleet of   autonomous test vehicles in operation. It's a very big deal that   has huge implications for GM
column4: Lyft
column5: and their   rivals.What the report saidAccording to the Reuters article
column6: GM will build thousands of   Chevy Bolts equipped with prototype versions of the self-driving   system GM has developed with its subsidiary
column7: Cruise Automation.   Most of these self-driving Bolts will go into ride-hailing   service with Lyft in several states starting sometime in   2018.makeArticleAd();GM has no plans right now to sell the self-driving Bolts to   the general public.CEO Mary Barra announced in December that GM would begin     producing self-driving Chevrolet Bolt test vehicles in early     2017. Image source: General Motors.What it would mean for GMGM has been working on self-driving technology for years. That   work seemed to take a big leap forward with the acquisition of   San Francisco-based start-up Cruise Automation early last year.   It appears that Cruise has since become the center of GM's   research efforts. Cruise's self-driving Chevy Bolt test cars have   become regular sights on San Francisco streets
column8: and recent videos   taken from inside self-driving Bolt test cars suggest thatthe GM/Cruise technology is at a fairly advanced   level. GM announced in December that it would soon begin   producing self-driving Bolt test vehicles
column9: but the hint was that   -- at least in the near term -- they'd be produced in   small quantities for GM's own testing.A mass deployment would demonstrate two things: First
column10: that   GM's technology really is at a high level
column11: and second
column12: that GM   and its supplier partners are ready and able to mass-produce   self-driving cars.Both of those things are significant. Taken together
column13: it would   be a strong argument that GM is leading the way to mass-produced   Level 4 self-driving vehicles. Companies likeAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) have attracted a lot of investor attention for   (among other things) their self-driving efforts
column14: but --   as of right now
column15: at least -- GM seems poised to leapfrog just   about everybody.What it would mean for LyftLyft
column16: like its larger rival Uber Technologies
column17: knows that   replacing its human drivers with self-driving vehicles is crucial   to its future. Autonomous ride-hailing vehicles will allow Lyft   to lower its prices while generating (hopefully) strong   profits.Uber has been working on its own self-driving technology for a   couple of years
column18: and has a fewprototype self-driving test cars in servicenow. Lyft isn't known to have done any work on a self-driving   system of its own
column19: but it doesn't need to: GMowns a 9% stakein Lyft
column20: and GM seems to have it handled.If Lyft beats Uber to a self-driving fleet at scale
column21: Uber will   have a big challenge on its hands.GM president Dan Ammann (center) with Lyft co-founders Logan     Green (left) and John Zimmer. GM owns 9% of the ride-hailing     company
column22: and Ammann is a member of its board of directors.     Image source: General Motors.Could this be for real?The Reuters report
column23: by veteran auto-business journalist Paul   Lienert
column24: cites two unnamed ""sources familiar with the automaker's   plans."" Generally
column25: investors (and everyone else) should take   reports based on information from unnamed sources with a grain or   two of salt. But a few things suggest to me that this is probably   for real.First
column26: Lienert is a veteran with good sources
column27: and Reuters   holds its reporting to high standards. Second
column28: the report fits   with the known facts: GM and Lyft have both said that atest of autonomous GM vehicles in Lyft service is   forthcoming. Third
column29: GM's Orion
column30: Michigan
column31: factory
column32: where the Bolt is built
column33: has plenty of capacity to do a special production run in the   thousands.Finally
column34: and most tellingly
column35: neither Lyft nor GM denied the   report. In fact
column36: GM's statement in response was almost a smiling   hint:We do not provide specific details on potential future     products or technology rollout plans. We have said that our AV     technology will appear in an on-demand ride sharing network     applicationsooner than you might think. [Emphasis added.]Translation: This is likely to happen
column37: and it might begin   sooner than 2018.How important is this for GM investors?If it happens
column38: it will be a big deal. While the idea of a   ""race"" to self-driving technologyisn't really useful to investors
column39: a big test like this next year (or sooner) will show that GM   isn't about to be disrupted by Silicon Valley when it comes to   self-driving. It will also give lots of people an   opportunity to experience self-driving technology firsthand
column40: which will almost certainly speed its adoption by increasing   consumer demand.If nothing else
column41: it seems very likely to attract investors'   attention and give GM shares a boost.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and General Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Does Thinking About Your IRA Give You Heartburn? Let Us Help;2/17/2017;"An IRA is a fantastic retirement saving tool
column2: but many   Americans don't take advantage of it
column3: and when they do
column4: they fail   to make the most of it. If you're among them
column5: don't worry. Here   are some rules to help you build a bigger nest egg with an   IRA.What are IRAs?As a refresher
column6: you can get big tax benefits by saving money   for retirement in a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA.In 2017
column7: you can set aside up to $5
column8: 500 of your earnings in   either a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA or a combination of the   two. If you're 50 years old or older
column9: then you can save up to   $6
column10: 500 of your earnings in an IRA.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.Traditional IRAs can be funded with pre-tax money
column16: which means   that money you put in now isn't taxed at your current tax rate.   Instead
column17: that money
column18: and any future gains
column19: are taxed when its   withdrawn. Because of this feature
column20: traditional IRAs can make   sense if you think your income tax rate in retirement will belowerthan it is today.Alternatively
column21: Roth IRAs are funded with after-tax money
column22: which means you're paying taxes on your contributions now so that   you can withdraw them -- and future gains -- tax-free in   retirement. Because of up-front taxation
column23: a Roth IRA can make   sense if you expect your income tax rate in retirement to behigherthan it is today.Some important IRA withdrawal rulesIn the case of a traditional IRA
column24: if you don't wait until   you're at least 59.5 years old
column25: the IRS will charge you income   taxes on any money that you withdraw
column26: plus a 10% penalty
column27: unless   you qualify for an early withdrawal exemption (more on that in a   minute).In the case of a Roth IRA
column28: you can withdraw your contributions   tax-free at any age without a penalty
column29: as long as the Roth IRA   has been established for at least five years. However
column30: any gains   that you withdraw prior to reaching age 59.5 can be subject to   income tax and penalties.Both traditional IRAs and Roth IRAs do allow penalty free
column31: early withdrawals in specific instances. A full list of these   exemptions can be foundhere
column32: but the big ones to know about include purchasing a first home   (up to $10
column34: or payingcollege tuitionfor you
column35: or an immediate relative
column36: such as a spouse or child. The   rules for taking advantage of these exemptions can be quite   complex
column37: so make sure you consult a tax professional before   taking any early withdrawals. After all
column38: the last thing you want   is a surprise at tax time!Overall
column39: a Roth IRA might be a better option if you think   you'll need to withdraw contributions five or more years from   now
column40: and you won't be 59.5 years old or qualify for an early   withdrawal exemption at that time.Navigating the IRA income capsIn order to qualify for a tax deduction on a traditional IRA   contribution
column41: your modified adjusted gross income has to be below   set limits if you
column42: or your spouse
column43: are covered by a retirement   plan at work. Similarly
column44: in order to contribute to a Roth IRA
column45: your modified adjusted gross income needs to be below set limits   too.Recently
column46: fellow Motley Fool Matthew Frankel did a great job   at explaining adjusted income limits for IRA'shere
column47: but in short
column48: if you're single and you are covered by a   retirement plan at work
column49: you can take the full deduction on a   traditional IRA contribution if your adjusted income is below   $62
column50: 000 in 2017. You can qualify for a partial deduction if your   adjusted income is between $62
column52: 000.If you're single
column53: you can make a contribution to a Roth IRA as   long as your adjusted income is less than $118
column54: 000. You can make   a partial contribution if your adjusted income is between   $118
column56: 000.If you're married filing jointly and covered by a retirement   plan at work
column57: then you can take a tax deduction on your   traditional IRA contribution
column58: as long as your adjusted income is   below $99
column59: 000. A partial deduction is possible if your adjusted   income is between $99
column61: 000.If you're not covered by a plan at work but your spouse is
column62: then you can make a tax deductible contribution to traditional   IRA if your adjusted income is below $186
column63: 000 or a partial   deduction if your adjusted income is between $186
column65: 000.If you're married filing jointly
column66: you can contribute to a Roth   IRA as long as your adjusted income is below $184
column67: 000. A partial   contribution can be made if your income is between $184
column69: 000.If you think you're close to these limits and you're unsure of   how to calculate your modified adjusted gross income
column70: you can   read up on the subjecthere.How to invest in an IRAOnce you've contributed to an IRA
column71: you'll need to pick some   investments. There are a lot of choices
column72: and you'll want to think   carefully about your age
column73: your health
column74: and the number of years   you have until you begin withdrawals.If you're young
column75: in good health
column76: and have plenty of years to   ride out the inevitable recession
column77: then an IRA that includes   stocks
column78: stock ETFs
column79: and stock mutual funds can make sense.   Usually
column80: buying and holding stocks and ETFs for long periods of   time is cheaper than buying an actively managed mutual fund
column81: so   make sure that you balance the potential return
column82: risk
column83: and   expenses associated with these choices.Some investors may prefer owning individual stocks for the   long term
column84: such as disruptive growth companies likeAmazonorAlphabet. Other investors may prefer owning an S&P 500 ETF that   tracks the stock market's returns more closely. If so
column85: a low-cost   S&P 500 ETF that might fit the bill is theVanguardS&P 500 ETF(NYSEMKT: VOO) . It has an annual expense ratio of just   0.05%.It may also pay off to own dividend-paying stocks in an IRA.   Because IRAs offer tax advantages
column86: dividend payments can compound   over time tax-deferred
column87: or in the case of a Roth IRA
column88: potentially   tax-free. Historically
column89: dividend-paying stocks have outperformed   non-dividend-paying stocks. However
column90: the performance ofdividend   stockstends to be lower during periods of rising interest rates
column91: when   they have to compete with bonds for income investors'   attention.Overall
column92: building a diversified IRA that includes exposure to   stocks and stock ETFs can provide financial security in   retirement. For example
column93: if you're 30
column94: and you contribute $5
column95: 500   per year for 35 years and earn a hypothetical 6% return per year
column96: then you'll have a nest egg valued at $612
column97: 886 at age 65. That's   not chump change
column98: so make sure that you take advantage of this   powerful savings tool.The $16
column99: 122 Social Security bonus most retirees   completely overlookIf you're like most Americans
column100: you're a few years (or more)   behind on your retirement savings. But a handful of little-known   ""Social Security secrets"" could help ensure a boost in your   retirement income. For example: one easy trick could pay you as   much as $16
column101: 122 more... each year! Once you learn how to maximize   your Social Security benefits
column102: we think you could retire   confidently with the peace of mind we're all after.Simply click here to discover how to learn more   about these strategies.Suzanne Frey

column1: VMware
column2: Inc. (VMW) Keeps the Momentum Going;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsVMware
column4: Inc.(NYSE:VMW) may not be one of the first companies that comes to mind when you're thinking about cloud services stocks. But
column5: it should be.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrBelieve it or not
column6: VMW is one of the top enterprise cloud services and virtualization companies out there. And
column7: its growth up to now
column8: while impressive
column9: is just the beginning. In the past 12 months
column10: VMW stock has almost doubled.That sounds compelling
column11: but the underlying story is what makes VMW's rise something you should understand
column12: especially if you're looking for exposure in this massively disruptive market.Simply put
column13: cloud computing means that your computer doesn't need to have individual software packages for each specific job you want it to do. In the old days
column14: you ran a word processing program
column15: a spreadsheet program
column16: a design program
column17: etc. And
column18: every machine had to have its individual software suite.The rise of networked computers meant that all of this software could be stored on a network ""library"" and each user could access what they needed.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThe next iteration of these networks were housed in the ""cloud
column19: which simply implies a virtual space built into servers. One of the primary advantages is the ability to access your information from the cloud
column20: regardless of where you are or what computer you're using.Cloud computing has been around for a long time
column21: and companies such asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column22: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column23: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andAmazon.com
column24: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) have been using the cloud for many years.Now
column25: companies of all sizes are migrating to the cloud
column26: and within the cloud universe there both public clouds (where many people have access) and private clouds (where only select people have access). VMW provides the ability to develop each of these systems
column27: and also facilitates unique access between public and private clouds.Why Don't We Hear Much About VMware?VMWare is actually owned byDell Technologies Inc(NYSE:DVMT) subsidiary
column28: EMC Corporation(NYSE:EMC). Last April
column29: Dell bought EMC to become the largest privately-held tech company in the world. So
column30: VMWare is a cloud-based
column31: publicly-traded branch of this major tech player now.Part of the reason you don't hear about VMWare as much as its competitors is because the company's relationship to its owners is a bit convoluted
column32: and analysts aren't very confident in figuring out how to value VMW stock. Their loss is your gain.3 Stocks to Buy for Under $10 With 25%-Plus UpsideQ4 and full-year numbers were posted in late January
column33: and they show how strong VMW stock remains. Earnings beat analyst expectations and revenue continued to grow at a solid clip. A new strategic partnership with AMZN's cloud-computing juggernaut
column34: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column35: adds some serious firepower to the VMW arsenal. It also helps the company remain competitive in a very dynamic field.When you have a tech parent like EMC and a tech partner like AWS
column36: you are doing very well. These brands are major players in the enterprise sector and will open even more doors for VMW in the future. VMWare stock is on a significant growth trajectory that should last years
column37: not months.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth

column1: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock: The Pause That Refreshes;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) is all about visual computing.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe company started as a high-end graphics card maker for users who were interested in having the best display quality you could get. That ranged from online gamers to research scientists.Given that chip and card makers aren't exactly in short supply
column3: few investors gave this niche player much time. The thought was
column4: NVDA may have a great graphics card
column5: but it's a ""nice to have
column6: not a ""need to have"" kind of product.What's more
column7: most chipmakers had perfectly serviceable graphics cards. Why contract out to yet another vendor when you already had a chipmaker that could provide you with a decent graphics card?Those Days Are Gone NowQuality graphics are no longer just a nice add on; they're crucial now that processing speeds have soared and new technologies have been able to thrive. In this visual computing space
column8: Big Data
column9: virtual reality (VR) and the Internet of Things (IoT) are three major disruptive forces that lean heavily on quality rendering and fast processing.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteSimply put
column10: Big Data packages large data sets and then analyzes them to find any discernible patterns or trends. For example
column11: a store can figure out what day and time is best for 30-something women to buy a shirt. Visualizing these data sets is very helpful in analyzing this process.VR and its cousin
column12: augmented reality (AR)
column13: are not only the hottest technologies in gaming
column14: but are already revolutionizing other fields where interaction is highly prized. For example
column15: medical schools are using AR tech to virtually operate on an augmented cadaver
column16: rather than physically operating on one. The possibilities are just being tapped at this point.IoT is another technology in its infancy. As artificial intelligence and bandwidth merge
column17: opportunities are appearing everywhere
column18: for instance in ""smart"" cars
column19: homes
column20: offices
column21: you name it. One of the best examples nowadays isAmazon.com
column22: Inc's(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa orAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home device
column23: where you can do everything from order a pizza to set your thermostat just by talking to the thing. It recognizes your commands and then
column24: through its connectivity
column25: turns your request into reality.NVDA is already working with many major car companies to create the next-generation car dashboard
column26: as well as other interactive possibilities. It is helping scientists manipulate molecules and atoms to build better drugs. And
column27: it's building the chips that are featured in the newest gaming system fromNintendo Co.
column28: Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY).These are just a few reasons that NVDA is up 282% in the past 12 months.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeservePart of this big move was because the entire semiconductor industry was weak because demand had slackened. But
column29: this is a cyclical industry and it's ""game on"" once again. Plus
column30: NVDA has shown that it's more than just a graphics card maker at this point. It is on the leading edge of the next generation of visual computing.NVDA numbers for Q4 were recently released
column31: and the stock came down from its 52-week highs on the news.But
column32: this is simply the pause that refreshes. The numbers were still impressive and there is significant untapped growth for NVDA stock. Management's guidance may have been slightly conservative
column33: but it's likely that stellar growth will remain in Nvidia's future for many years to come.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth
