column1: Why Ford is Spending $1 Billion on a Tiny Self-Driving Start-Up;2/10/2017;"Ford Motor Company(NYSE: F) announced on Friday that it is acquiring a majority   stake in artificial-intelligence start-up Argo AI for $1 billion
column2: to be paid over five years.What is Argo AI?Argo AI is a new company
column3: founded late last year by CEO Bryan   Salesky and COO Peter Rander. Both are big names in self-driving   circles: Salesky was the head of hardware atAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo unit (formerly known as   the Google Self-Driving Car Project); Rander was a top engineer   in Uber Technologies' autonomous-vehicle division. Both were   previously at the robotics institute at Carnegie Mellon   University
column4: where they worked on artificial-intelligence (AI)   technology.The plan for Argo AI is to use the founders' expertise in AI   to develop autonomous-vehicle software. The company is   headquartered in Pittsburgh. It's small now
column5: but it expects to   have more than 200 employees by the end of 2017.makeArticleAd();Argo COO Peter Rander (left)
column6: Ford CEO Mark Fields
column7: Argo CEO     Brian Salesky
column8: and Ford CTO Raj Nair. Image source: Ford Motor     Company.What Ford said about the dealFord said that Argo AI ""is bringing together some of the most   experienced roboticists and engineers working in autonomy from   inside and outside of Ford."" An existing Ford team that has been   working on what Ford calls its ""virtual driver system
column9: the brain   of an autonomous vehicle
column10: will become part of Argo AI.While Ford will continue to develop its self-driving hardware   in-house
column11: it appears that Argo AI will be responsible for much of   the software development. That software could be licensed to   other companies
column12: CEO Mark Fields said
column13: and it's possible that   Argo AI will go public at some point.""The next decade will be defined by the automation of the   automobile
column14: and autonomous vehicles will have as significant an   impact on society as Ford's moving assembly line did 100 years   ago
column15: Fields said. ""As Ford expands to be an auto and a mobility   company
column16: we believe that investing in Argo AI will create   significant value for our shareholders by strengthening Ford's   leadership in bringing self-driving vehicles to market in the   near term and by creating technology that could be licensed to   others in the future.""Ford will hold a majority stake in the new company. Fields   wouldn't say exactly what Ford's ownership percentage will be
column17: but he did say that it was gauged to leave plenty of room to   provide equity compensation to new employees.Ford's global product chief and CTO
column18: Raj Nair
column19: and group vice   president of global strategy
column20: John Casesa
column21: will hold two of the   five seats on Argo AI's board. Salesky and Rander will hold two   more
column22: and the fifth will go to an independent director to be   named later.Investors
column23: take note: Fields said that Argo AI's spending and   results will be consolidated into Ford's automotive financial   results
column24: primarily in the North America region.What this deal is really aboutHere's how I'm thinking about this deal: Ford just hired two   rock stars in AI and autonomous vehicles
column25: put them in charge of   its self-driving software team
column26: and structured the whole thing to   give the team members -- and very importantly
column27: future hires
column28: in a   field in which the competition for talent is fierce -- the upside   of a start-up with lower risk
column29: because Ford's investment has   essentially capitalized the company and Ford will be its first   customer. It's an intriguing idea; it could turn out to be a   brilliant one.During a conference call for analysts and media
column30: Salesky   emphasized that the structure of what he called the   ""collaboration"" between Argo AI and Ford would help recruiting:   New hires (and Ford's existing virtual-driver team) will go to   work for a start-up with significant potential upside
column31: not   (directly
column32: at least) for giant Ford.And while it's a start-up
column33: Ford's involvement means that new   hires can be assured that Argo AI has both solid funding and a   major customer. The combination of relatively low risk with high   potential upside should make for a potent recruiting tool in a   field where the competition for talent has been extremely   fierce.The upshot: An intriguing move to boost Ford's technology   pushFor Ford
column34: this is a way to bring some deep AI expertise into   its self-driving development project
column35: structured in a way that   will help boost its recruiting efforts going forward. Nair said   that he doesn't expect the deal to ""accelerate"" Ford's effort --   he stuck by thepreviously announced 2021 deadlinefor Ford's first mass-produced self-driving vehicle.But there's a clear advantage to putting the team under the   leadership of Salesky and Rander
column36: in a company that offers the   upside of a start-up with less risk than most. We'll have to wait   to learn more about the structure of the deal to evaluate it   fully
column37: but right now it looks like Ford has taken an intriguing   step ahead.10 stocks we like better than FordWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column2: Facebook Hires MTV Executive to Create Original Content;2/10/2017;"Earlier this week

column1: Alphabet Inc. Takes Another Shot at Amazon With Home Control;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home connected speaker takes onAmazon.com
column3: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa on its home turf. But what about Google's big advantage over Amazon in the smart home war - all those smartphones?makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleThe company has just begun rolling out Home Control
column4: a new feature that lets Google Assistant control smart home devices by voice.However
column5: at this point
column6: Home Control - like Google Assistant - remains a feature that's exclusive to Google's own Pixel Phones.The Battle for the Smart HomeGoogle Home is a connected speaker with Google Assistant baked in. Owners can use Google Assistant on the speaker to answer questions
column7: find music and control a growing number of smart home devices using their voice only.The device is GOOGL's answer to the Amazon Echo. Amazon's Alexa-enabled speaker has been a surprise hit and allowed Amazon to take a big lead in the race to become the smart home hub - despite the distinct disadvantage of lacking a smartphone platform to host its digital assistant.Google has Google Now and the new Google Assistant
column8: whileApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has Siri. Between them
column9: the two companies have billions of mobile devices in consumers' hands
column10: yet Amazon still managed to leapfrog them with its personal assistant hosted in a speaker
column11: to build an impressive smart home lead.Apple's Siri can control HomeKit-compatible smart home devices using voice commands
column12: and now GOOGL is rolling out asimilar feature for its Google Assistant
column13: Home Control.Home ControlGoogle's new feature for voice control of smart devices isn't actually new. Anyone who owns both a Pixel Phone and a Google Home speaker already had a Home Control setting on their smartphone.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayHowever
column14: as of yesterday
column15: GOOGL has begun to roll out Home Control to all Google Assistant users. This amounts to all Pixel Phone owners
column16: since Google Assistant remains an exclusive that third-party Android smartphones don't get.With Home Control
column17: someone with a Pixel Phone gets the same voice control ability for smart devices they would have if they owned a Google Home speaker. They can use voice commands on their phone to change the temperature on their Nest Learning Thermostat or turn off the smart lighting in the room they just left.The Battle for the Smart Home Enters a New Phase (Sort of)At the start of this fight to be the company that becomes the hub of the smart home - the one who controls all those smart devices - the smartphone was it.Smartphones ran all the apps that controlled each of the devices and everyone owned one. With smartphones
column18: the battle came down to iOS and Android
column19: Apple and Google.Then Amazon disrupted everything with the Echo and Alexa. With thousands of compatible products and services
column20: consumers have been snapping them up. Amazon sold out of the Echo at Christmas
column21: afterselling nine times moreof the smart speaker than the previous year.Voice control is in. Having to poke buttons on a smartphone is out.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0However
column22: Apple and Google are not about to cede the smart home to Amazon. GOOGL began its assault on Amazon with the Google Home smart speaker to directly take on the Echo and Alexa. With Home Control
column23: it's bringing voice control of smart devices to the smartphone
column24: leveraging its massive lead over Amazon when it comes to numbers. There may be millions of Alexa-powered homes
column25: but there are billions of people already carrying an Android smartphone.Except
column26: most of those people still won't be able to use Home Control. GOOGL has baked Home Control into Google Assistant
column27: a feature that's been exclusive to its Pixel Phones since they were released last fall. With Google Home and now Home Control
column28: Alphabet clearly has Amazon's number. The question will be whether Amazon gets Alexa into more third-party devices before Google decides to let third-party Android smartphone makers have access to Google Assistant.For GOOGL
column29: the decision comes down to which is more valuable: maintaining a key competitive advantage for its own Pixel Phones
column30: or giving up that Google Assistant and Home Control exclusivity to take a real shot at unseating Amazon in the smart home.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceNo

column2: Apple Inc. Is Not Releasing the iPhone 8 Early;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA report began circulating several days ago thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) may start production of the iPhone 8 early. Typically
column4: when a company starts manufacturing sooner than usual
column5: that points to an accelerated release date for a new product.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleIn this case
column6: it seems unlikely the move will result in an iPhone release date before Apple's standard September launch.If not to get it on shelves sooner
column7: why would the company want to get an early start on new iPhone production?The iPhone 8 Early Production Ramp UpApple has a pretty standard roadmap when it comes to new iPhone releases. With a late September iPhone release date
column8: the company starts to ramp up production of the new model in late summer. However
column9: this year it looks as though Apple may be breaking with tradition.According to a report from BlueFin Research Partners
column10: there are indicators in the company's supply chain that point to an unusually early production ramp up for the iPhone 8. Quoted inMSN Money
column11: the BlueFin report notes:""The most intriguing data points that we have uncovered suggests that Apple is ramping the next generation iPhones earlier than historical norms.""Why Early Production Won't Lead to an Earlier iPhone Release DateBefore anyone gets too excited about the possibility of an early iPhone 8 release
column12: that scenario is highly unlikely.First
column13: ramping up production in June means Apple will begin having stock of the new iPhones in warehouses by the summer. But no one releases a flagship smartphone during the summer months - that's a slow time for consumer technology news. People are on vacation and not only would an iPhone announcement not get the coverage Apple expects for its new product launches
column14: with so many people away the line-ups at Apple Stores the company is hoping for wouldn't happen.3 Warren Buffett Stocks to Buy in the Trump EraAn early release would also reduce iPhone 7 sales. Now that production is humming on that model
column15: Apple wouldn't want to kneecap it by releasing the iPhone 8 early.So Why Would Apple Ramp up iPhone 8 Production Early?It's become increasingly obvious that companies like Apple are pushing the limits of their supply chain and manufacturing partners with their latest smartphones. The new dual camera system
column16: haptic Home button and other components led to a shortage of some iPhone 7 models at launch. Apple ramped up production in late summer as usual
column17: but these issues caused delays.I preordered an iPhone 7 Plus
column18: but still waited a month after the new iPhones went on sale before mine was available â€¦Then there's the issue of batteries. Apple has had to face its own headaches withiPhone 6 and 6s batteries
column19: but those problems pale in comparison to the nightmare rivalSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) has gone through with the Galaxy Note 7 and its exploding batteries.There's a lot riding on the iPhone 8 and Apple appears to be throwing all sorts of new features
column20: cutting-edge technology and a completely new design at its 10th anniversary iPhone. Glass construction
column21: wireless charging
column22: an OLED display
column23: virtual Home button and more. The company is even rumored to becharging $1
column24: 000-plusfor its new flagship
column25: an unprecedented price for a smartphone.In addition
column26: Samsung will likely be introducing its new Galaxy Note around the same time
column27: and pulling out all the stops to make that phablet such a smash hit that everyone forgets about the Galaxy Note 7.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column28: NASDAQ:GOOGL) is also expected to release the followup to the worryingly successful Google Pixel Phone in the fall.Rather than ramping up for an early launch
column29: it's far more likely that Apple is starting iPhone 8 production early in order to iron out all the manufacturing bugs early. Virtually all of the components will be new and Apple will undoubtedly be pushing the limits of manufacturing capability. Having an early start will ensure any issues are caught well before the iPhone 8 goes on sale
column30: ensuring a smooth
column31: scandal-free
column32: launch. And no embarrassing issues for the competition to take advantage of.The early ramp up also ensures that even if things don't go smoothly at first
column33: there will be plenty of iPhone 8 smartphones sitting in Apple warehouses in September
column34: ensuring a record-setting launch.Should Under Armour Inc (UAA) CEO Kevin Plank Step Aside?Despite the apparent early production ramp up
column35: don't expect an iPhone release date in the summer. But Apple's move does mean you should have a flawless iPhone 8 in your hands at the launch
column36: instead of waiting weeks or months for supply to catch up to demand.As of this writing
column37: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's Pen7 High-Risk

column1: Don't Overlook These 6 Incredible Amazon.com Numbers;2/9/2017;"Shares ofAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) fell more than 3% on Feb. 3 after the tech giant   posted mixed fourth quarter earnings and  soft guidance for   the first quarter. Revenue rose 22% annually to $43.7 billion
column2: but that  missed expectations by $980 million. The company   was hit hard by currency headwinds
column3: which reduced its top line by   about $558 million. Amazon's closely watched AWS (Amazon Web   Services) revenue rose 47% annually to $3.54 billion
column4: but that   also missed expectations of $3.6 billion and represented a   slowdown from 55% growth in the third quarter.For the first quarter
column5: Amazon expects 14.1% to 22.7%   year-over-year sales growth
column6: which missed analyst forecasts for   23.4% growth. But on a currency neutral basis
column7: which excludes an   expected currency impact of $730 million
column8: Amazon expects its   revenue to rise 17% to 25%.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();Some negative reports about Amazon focused on those headline   numbers
column9: but they glossed over many of the positive growth   figures. Let's take a look at six incredible numbers from that   report that investors shouldn't overlook.1. $749 million in net incomeDuring the fourth quarter
column10: Amazon's net income rose 55%   annually to $749 million
column11: or $1.54 per share -- which beat   expectations by $0.19. For the full year
column12: its net income surged   over 300% to $2.4 billion.That incredible growth was mostly attributed to the rapid   growth of AWS' high-margin business
column13: which gives Amazon much more   freedom to expand its e-commerce ecosystem with low-margin   hardware like its Echo speakers
column14: loss-leading services like   Amazon Video and Prime Now
column15: and logistics solutions like new   fulfillment centers and drones.2. AWS' operating margin of 26%AWS finished last quarter with an operating margin of 26%
column16: compared to 24% in the year-ago quarter. That margin expansion   indicates that AWS' massive scale is offsetting tough price   competition across the cloud platform market
column17: which caused Amazon   and its rivals to reduce their prices throughout the year.3. AWS' annual run rate of $14 billionAmazon announced that AWS had achieved an annual run rate of   $14 billion
column18: indicating that it maintains a commanding lead overMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure in the cloud platform race.Microsoft claimed that its ""commercial cloud"" had achieved an   annual run rate of over $14 billion last quarter
column19: but most of   that total came from SaaS platforms like Office 365 and Dynamics   CRM. Azure -- which competes directly against AWS in the   IaaS/PaaS ""cloud platform"" markets -- accounts for a much smaller   percentage.Microsoft doesn't disclose how much revenue Azure generates
column20: but  combining earlier industry estimates and its reported   growth rate  over the past few quarters indicates that its   annual run rate could be around $3 billion.4. Over 1
column21: 000 new AWS featuresAmazon already serves massive customers like NASA
column22: the CDC
column23: andNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) with AWS
column24: but it's continuously widening the   platform's competitive moat against rival platforms like Azure   with new features. Amazon added over  1
column25: 000 new features and   services to AWS in fiscal 2016
column26: compared to about 700 in   2015.It also opened eleven new AWS Availability Zones across five   geographic regions in 2016
column27: bringing AWS' total coverage to 42   Availability Zones across 16 regions globally. That massive data   center expansion will help AWS reach more companies and   developers
column28: all while supporting the expansion of its e-commerce   and digital ecosystem into new markets.5. Prime Video in over 200 countriesA big part of that digital ecosystem expansion is Prime Video
column29: the company's streaming answer to Netflix. Amazon has made the   platform a ""free"" perk for Prime subscribers and a stand-alone   subscription service that costs slightly less than Netflix.Like Netflix
column30: Amazon is investing heavily in original content
column31: and popular shows likeTransparentandMan in the High Castlehelped it become the third largest video streaming platform in   the U.S. after YouTube and  Netflix last year
column32: according to   research firm Sandvine. Amazon is also following Netflix's lead   and investing heavily in localized original content in key   markets like Japan and India
column33: which could help  expand its   Prime user base worldwide.6. 4
column34: 000 new skills for AlexaAmazon also taught its voice recognition platform Alexa 4
column35: 000   new skills since last October. It noted that ""tens of thousands   of developers"" are building new skills for the platform -- which   powers the Echo
column36: Kindle
column37: and Fire TV devices -- and that it was   working with ""a lot of major companies"" to integrate their   products with that ecosystem.The expansion of the Alexa ecosystem is important
column38: because it   can give Amazon control of users' connected homes via Dash   buttons
column39: DRS-enabled appliances
column40: and other connected devices. In   addition to boosting its e-commerce revenue with ""frictionless""   orders
column41: that platform can process data through AWS and widen its   moat in the smart home race againstAlphabet's Google
column42: which is trying to establish its own home-based   ecosystem around its Home smart speaker.The key takeawayAmazon's fourth quarter report was lumpy
column43: but investors   shouldn't overlook these positive numbers. Analysts still expect   Amazon's revenue and  earnings to respectively rise 22% and   53% next year -- so its overall growth won't peak anytime soon.   Therefore
column44: I believe that investors should take advantage of   Amazon's temporary swoon and pick up a few more shares for the   long term.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How salesforce.com
column2: Inc. Gained 15.5% in January;2/9/2017;"What happenedShares ofsalesforce.com(NYSE: CRM) rose 15.5% in January of 2017
column3: according to data fromS&P Global Market Intelligence.So whatThis month-long surge started on Jan. 4
column4: when the company   publisheda ""state of the service"" reportthat painted Salesforce's target market in bright
column5: cheerful   colors. The momentum continued as several analyst firms issued   positive research reports on the stock
column6: often describing it as a   probable turnaround winner.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Finally
column7: as January wrapped up
column8: rumor had it thatAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) might be preparing a buyout offer   for the company.Now whatOf course
column9: Alphabet has not presented any takeover bid for   Salesforce
column10: and I'd be surprised to see it happen. January's   burst of share price gains came aftera disappointing 2016 as a whole
column11: setting the bar low for quick gains.CRMdata byYCharts.Is there a solid turnaround on the horizon? Salesforce does   generate plenty of cash
column12: but the stock valuation remains firmly   in the nosebleed section. The stock is simply priced for absolute   perfection. I'm more than comfortable staying on the sidelines --   but sudden price drops could make Salesforce shares interesting.   This one goes on my long-term watch list.10 stocks we like better than Salesforce.comWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Snap
column2: Inc. Is Also Spending $1 Billion With Amazon AWS;2/9/2017;"Earlier today
column3: Snap(NYSE: SNAP) filed its first amended S-1 with the Securities and   Exchange Commission. Companies often modify their initial   registration statements leading up to their IPOs
column4: prior to   issuing a formal prospectus. Prospective investors already knew   that Snap is a big spender atAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google Cloud
column5: which it relies on   for its cloud infrastructure needs.Snap is unique in its continued use of third-party   infrastructure vendorsat the scale at which it is operating; most companies invest in their own infrastructure once they   grow to a point where it's warranted. To a lesser extent
column6: Snap   also purchases infrastructure services fromAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();In the amended filing
column7: Snap provided some additional detail on   its relationship with the e-commerce giant.Always have a contingency planTo be clear
column8: Google Cloud is still Snap's main flame
column9: but it   never hurts to have backup. In fact
column10: contingency planning is   absolutely critical when your entire service relies on   third-party infrastructure partners
column11: and this is the role that   AWS will play. The deal was inked just yesterday
column12: which is what's   triggering the S-1 amendment.In last week's version
column13: Snap said: ""We are currently   negotiating an agreement with another cloud provider for   redundant infrastructure support of our business operations.""   That line was replaced in this week's version with: ""We have also   committed to spend $1 billion with Amazon Web Services over the   next five years for redundant infrastructure support of our   business operations."" Snap says an existing agreement with AWS   that was originally entered into in March 2016 was amended on   Feb. 8
column14: 2017.That $1 billion commitment will slowly ramp up
column15: starting with   $50 million in spending this year. That's a tiny drop in the   bucket compared to the $12.2 billion in sales that AWS did in   2016. Snap is on the hook to spend $350 million with AWS in 2021.   In contrast
column16: the agreement with Google Cloud that was finalized   on Jan. 30
column17: 2017 calls for a flat $400 million per year for five   years
column18: with a little bit of leeway in shifting spending to   subsequent years (up to 15% in each of the first four years).Data source: Snapchat amended S-1. Chart by author.Combined with its $2 billion commitment with Google Cloud
column19: we're looking at $3 billion pledged between Google Cloud and AWS   over the next five years. Snap's cloud strategy of relying   entirely on third-party partners is risky for many operational   reasons
column20: but that's an awful lot of financial pressure for the   start-up. In 2016
column21: cost of revenue exceeded revenue
column22: resulting in   a negative gross profit of nearly $50 million
column23: and infrastructure   costs are the largest component of cost of revenue.Snap only recently rolled out its automated ad sales API in   October
column24: which exited beta just a couple weeks ago. The company   will now need to ramp ad sales faster than its infrastructure   spending commitments if it hopes to generate gross profit in the   years ahead. And we haven't even started talking about operating   expenses yet
column25: which totaled $473 million last year.Hopefully
column26: that API works pretty darn well.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Twitter (TWTR) Q4 Loss Narrower than Expected
column2: Revenues Miss;2/9/2017;"Twitter
column3: Inc.TWTRshares are down nearly 10% inpre-market tradingfollowing its fourth-quarter 2016 earnings report. Twitter's adjusted loss per share of 3 cents was narrower than the Zacks Consensus Estimate of a loss of 11 cents per share. However
column4: revenues of $717.2 million missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $737.7 million.On a year-over-year basis
column5: revenues were up a mere 1%. This is the company's lowest gain since it went public. Revenue growth has been decelerating over the last several quarters.Moreover
column6: advertising revenues were down in the quarter to $638 million from $641 million reported in the prior-year quarter.Twitter's user growth wasn't overly impressive
column7: yet again. Monthly average users (MAUs) increased from 317 million to 319 million this quarter
column8: up 0.6% sequentially. Year over year
column9: MAUs increased 4%. Mobile MAUs were 83% of total MAUs. Average DAUs were up11% year over year.Quarterly Numbers in DetailsThe company posted non-GAAP earnings per share of 16 cents per share
column10: flat year over year.Coming to ad metrics
column11: there was a 151% year-over-year surge in ad engagements but cost per ad engagement was down 60%
column12: given the shift to auto play video
column13: which has lower cost per view compared to click to play.Mobile advertising revenues contributed 89% to total advertising revenue in the quarter. Data licensing and other revenues increased 14% to $79 million.Twitter earned nearly 38.6% of its revenues from international markets. International revenues rose 12% year over year to $277 million in the reported quarter. U.S. revenues decreased 5% year over year to $440 million.The company reported 12% increase in adjusted EBITDA to $215 million. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 30%
column14: up from 27% in the year-ago quarter.Twitter

column1: Snap Just Became One of Google's Most Important Cloud Customers;2/9/2017;"One of the many interesting details revealed inSnap's S-1 filing with the SEC is that it agreed to a $2 billion   contract with Google Cloud in January. The agreement with theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary spans five years with   relatively equal payments scheduled for every year.Snap has used Google Cloud since its creation
column2: but had been   spending considerably less than the $400 million per year it's   slated to spend through 2021. For the first few years of its   existence
column3: it spent less than $30 million per year on Google   Cloud. Last year
column4: however
column5: it started seeing its hosting costs   increase considerably
column6: up $192 million for the year.Image Source: GettymakeArticleAd();Google's cloud service competes against the largerAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) Web Services andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure. A $2 billion infusion could help it catch   up to the competition.What does $2 billion mean to Google Cloud?Alphabet isn't exactly forthright with its cloud revenue. It   lumps Google Cloud in with Google's other revenue line item
column7: which also includes Google Play and hardware sales. In 2016
column8: the   three categories produced $10.1 billion in revenue. Google Play   likely accounts for the bulk of revenue.The cloud unit had an estimated run rate of just $1 billion as   of the end of 2015
column9: according to RBC Capital. Snap's new contract   likely makes it Google's biggest cloud customer.While Google has made several advancements in its cloud   services over the past year
column10: so have its competitors. Microsoft   boasted that its Azure revenue increased 93% last quarter
column11: but   Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss estimates the unit brought in   just $1.6 billion. Bernstein's Mark Mordler estimates Azure's run   rate at $3 billion as of last quarter.Meanwhile
column12: Amazon just reported AWS sales topped $12 billion   in 2016. Sales surpassed $3.5 billion in the fourth quarter   alone
column13: although that fell short of analysts expectations.Google still needs to diversifyThe growth of Snapchat has been a major boon to Google's cloud   services
column14: but it's still actively seeking to pull customers away   from its competitors and take market share. The hiring of   cloud-computing veteran Diane Greene to lead the division has   helped the company attract numerous high-profile customers
column15: but   there's still more work to do.On Alphabet's fourth-quarter earnings call
column16: Google CEO Sundar   Pichai said
column17: ""We have truly differentiated offerings in four key   areas: data analytics and machine learning
column18: security and privacy
column19: tools for application development
column20: and the ability to create   connected business platforms."" Snap can take advantage of at   least three of those four factors
column21: so it's clear why it was   willing to lock down a long-term contract.At the same time
column22: the contract is not exclusive. If Snap wants   to enter China
column23: for example
column24: where Google doesn't operate
column25: it   could tap one of Google's competitors. Or it could build its   own servers.Snap recently hired Jerry Hunter from AWS
column26: who ran global data   centers for the cloud-computing giant. In Snap's S-1 filing
column27: management notes
column28: ""In the future
column29: we may invest in building our   own infrastructure to better serve our customers.""If Snap continues to grow at the pace it has been for the last   few years
column30: it may make economic sense for it to switch to its own   cloud infrastructure
column31: which would be a huge blow for Google.What this means for SnapSnap is now on the hook for $400 million per year in cloud   costs. There is some wiggle room: The contract says it can   postpone up to 15% of expenses for a year
column32: so it only has to   spend $340 million this first year. Still
column33: that's a huge amount   for a company that generated just $404.5 million in revenue last   year.It also means that switching service providers will be   difficult
column34: considering it would either have to eat the contract   as a loss
column35: or leave at least some of its operations on Google   Cloud in order not to waste the money. That makes the economics   of building out its own infrastructure within the next five years   even costlier.On the flip side
column36: analysts expect Snap's revenue to continue   growing at a rapid pace
column37: approaching $1 billion this year fueled   by continued user growth and product expansion that will surely   put additional demands on Google's servers. It has plenty of   capital to cover the expense
column38: and if last year's growth is any   indication of what to expect
column39: it will need to spend at least $340   million on cloud infrastructure this year. The deal with Google   ensures that it gets the lowest rates possible
column40: so it can to make   the most of its spend.Overall
column41: it's not a bad deal for Snap
column42: but it does tie the   company to Google for a long time.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter delaying the release for months
column3: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) finally launched Android Wear 2.0
column5: the new version of its smartwatch operating system. Along with the new OS
column6: which incorporates advanced features like Google Assistant
column7: new Google smartwatch hardware was announced. Made in partnership withLG
column8: the new devices are premium quality
column9: made to take full advantage of Android Wear 2.0 and ready to take on the Apple Watch.makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleHere's what you need to know.Google knows it didn't exactly hit the ball out of the park when it first released its Android Wear smartwatch OS.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has dominated the smartwatch market since its release and despite an overall cooling for smartwatches in general
column10: it looks as thoughApple Watch absolutely destroyed the competition over Christmas.That has to be especially galling to Google
column11: considering the Apple Watch is only compatible with iPhones
column12: while Android Wear smartwatches work with nearly 90% of the smartphones being sold today. And while Apple Watch remains locked into a clunky square watch face
column13: Android Wear supports the traditional
column14: round wristwatch look.Android Wear 2.0 Key FeaturesGoogle was originally supposed to release Android Wear 2.0 last September
column15: but decided todelay it to this spring. Theofficial announcementlanded yesterday afternoon on GOOGL's blog.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendWhat did Google engineers spend the extra time working on? It appears that they had several major goals: improving on the basic features most smartwatch owners use (such as fitness tracking)
column16: cutting the cord to a smartphone with LTE support
column17: and making Android Wear 2.0 smartwatches as compatible as possible with the iPhone.Key features Google is showing off include:Improved fitness tracking with Google Fit appLTE support for running apps and making voice calls directly from a smartwatch without requiring connection to a smartphoneGoogle Assistant is integratedCustomizable watch face componentsGoogle Play access direct from smartwatchSupport for hardware control similar to Apple Watch digital crownIn particular
column18: the ability for more apps to run independently on Android Wear 2.0 devices - with no need to be connected to a smartwatch - means iPhone users will get almost the same experience as Android phone owners. Assuming GOOGL can convince them to skip the Apple Watch.New Google Smartwatch Is From LGRumors had been flying that alongside the new operating system
column19: the first Google smartwatch would make an appearance. That made sense considering GOOGL's push into branded hardware with the Google Pixel Phone and devices like Google Home and Google WiFi.Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock -- What Happened?However
column20: the two new smartwatches unveiled as part of the announcement are from LG
column21: in collaboration with GOOGL.The LG Watch Style is a relatively basic model. It lacks advanced capabilities like GPS (or even a heart rate monitor)
column22: but delivers smartwatch features in a slim
column23: traditional wristwatch form factor. The round display is a 1.2-inch OLED screen at 360 x 360 pixel resolution and the watch has all-day battery life. It comes with a leather strap and for an extra $30
column24: a Rose Gold color option.The LG Watch Style is the bigger and more capable device
column25: fully able to take full advantage of all Android Wear 2.0's new features. The 1.38-inch P-OLED display has a crisp 480 x 480 pixel resolution. The round frame is stainless steel
column26: with IP68 water resistance. There's a heart rate monitor and GPS for fitness
column27: Connectivity includes Bluetooth
column28: Wi-Fi
column29: LTE and NFC for Android Pay. Battery life is rated for all-day
column30: but use of features like LTE and the heart rate monitor can significantly cut that.They're premium devices
column31: designed to take on the Apple Watch and GOOGL's involvement means they make the most of Android Wear 2.0. But they aren't the official Google smartwatch â€¦ well see if that comes later.Availability and PricingGoogle says Android Wear 2.0 will begin rolling out ""in the coming weeks."" Most current Android Wear smartwatches should be eligible for the free update
column32: but not all watches will support all features. The LG Watch Style and LG Watch Sport will retail for $249 and $349 respectively and will go on sale in the U.S. starting Feb. 10.As of this writing
column33: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!Is Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?The postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column6: 2017 -Zacks Equity ResearchhighlightsIntevac(NASDAQ:IVAC-Free Report) as the Bull of the Day andHP Inc(NYSE:HPQ-Free Report) as the Bear of the Day. In addition

column8: Facebook(NASDAQ:FB-Free Report) andGoogle(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report).Here is a synopsis of all five stocks:Bull of the Day:Intevac (NASDAQ:IVAC-Free Report) recently reported a very strong quarter at the start of February. The company posted EPS of $0.13 when the Zacks Consensus Estimate was calling for $0.07. That $0.06 beat was good for a positive earnings surprise of 85%. That big beat put the stock on a lot of radar screen but it is the Bull of the Day for another
column9: much more important reason.DescriptionIntevac makes vacuum deposition equipment for various thin-film applications
column10: and digital night-vision technologies and products. Intevac
column11: Inc. was founded in 1990 and is headquartered in Santa Clara
column12: California.Growth And ValueGrowth investors and value investors are looking for different things and usually a good growth stock is not a value. IVAC posted revenue growth of 76% on a year over years basis in the most recent report. That followed growth of 23% in the previous period.On the value side
column13: the company noted that book value at the end of the quarter as $71M
column14: and with the stock trading at just under $200M in market cap we have a 2.8x price to book multiple. Usually
column15: value investors are looking at stocks that have a price to book multiple of less than 3x
column16: and IVAC fits the bill.Follow Brian Bolan on Twitter @BBolan1Why I Like ItThis stock is the Bull of the Day because of the tremendous increase in earnings estimates. Over the last five or so years of being at Zacks I don't think I have ever seen an estimate increase like this from a company as small as this.Bear of the Day:HP Inc (NYSE:HPQ-Free Report) has slipped to a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) with earnings just a few weeks away. This is not a good signal for investors that want to trade around earnings and it could extend the stock's losing streak to 3 - as in the number of times the stock has traded lower in the session following the report.HP Inc is part of the old Hewlett-Packard and is still a widely held stock.Earnings HistoryThe earnings history is pretty good of late
column17: with a couple of beats of the Zacks Consensus Estimate and a few meets. On the top line I see only one miss in the last five quarters
column18: so that too is a good thing to see.EstimatesHere is where we separate the pretenders from the contenders. Estimates for HP Inc have fallen of late
column19: moving from $1.62 in August down to $1.60 at the current level. That doesn't seem like enough to merit a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) but then I looked at the next fiscal year.The fiscal 2018 estimate has slipped from $1.68 to $1.65
column20: and again this is another small move.Going ForwardThis stock is a probably the ""softest"" Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) that I have ever seen. That said

column1: What Is Unearned Revenue
column2: and Why Should Amazon Investors Care About It?;2/9/2017;"A small line item onAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) balance sheet has been growing rapidly over the   past couple years. Since the end of 2014
column3: Amazon's unearned   revenue liability increased from $1.8 billion to $4.8   billion. Some investors might see a growing liability and   think that's bad news
column4: but in fact this is very good news.Unearned revenue is simply cash customers have paid to Amazon   in advance for services it has yet to render. For example
column5: Prime   members typically pay $99 up front for a full year of the two-day   shipping program. Amazon immediately takes the cash and puts it   on its balance sheet
column6: but it amortizes the $99 of revenue over   the 12 months of the membership. So it accounts for only $8.25   per month in revenue per month for each Prime member. The rest of   the cash received for Prime is held in the unearned-revenue   balance.Prime growth has been very good over the past few years.   Amazon says it added ""tens of millions"" of new members last year.   But Prime isn't the biggest driver of unearned revenue. More   likely
column7: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is the biggest factor pushing   the balance higher.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Maybe last quarter wasn't so disappointingFor the first time since Amazon started breaking out AWS   revenue and income
column8: the cloud-computing segment missed analysts'   expectations. Sales totaled $3.5 billion in the fourth quarter
column9: where analysts were expecting $3.6 billion on average.But unearned revenue climbed $568 million from the previous   quarter. That's unusual for Amazon's fourth quarter. Usually
column10: unearned revenue spikes in the first quarter as cloud customers   presumably re-up short-term contracts for the year.Most of Amazon's AWS customers are small businesses using its   pay-as-you-go pricing
column11: which allows them to quickly scale their   use. The solution works well for companies with small or   unpredictable user bases.But a lot of AWS's money comes from the big enterprises that   spend hundreds of millions every year on cloud computing. For   those companies
column12: with more predictable usage needs
column13: Amazon offers   ""reserved instances
column14: which offers a discount if customers pay up   front. Growth in reserved instances
column15: or other long-term   contracts
column16: may have resulted in lower revenue in the short term
column17: but it nearly guaranteed revenue in the future.Locking in customersAs the competition for cloud-computing infrastructure   continues to heat up
column18: long-term contracts may prove invaluable.   Locking in customers for a relatively long term means those   enterprises will start optimizing their code so that it runs more   efficiently on the specific hardware and platform they're   using.Such is the case withSnap(NYSE: SNAP)
column19: which uses Google's cloud. In its S-1 filing
column20: Snap   says it built its app to use ""services provided by Google
column21: some   of which do not have an alternative in the market
column22: asRe/Code'sPeter Guagenti points out. Not only did Snap just agree to a $2   billion five-year contract with Google
column23: but it's also going to be   hard for it to leave Google even after the five years is up.   That's excellent news forAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) investors.
column24: and not as excellent   for Snap investors.Ultimately
column25: signing long-term contracts provides a moat   against the growing competition. Not only does it lock in   customers for the length of the contract
column26: but it could also lock   them in longer if they become dependent on certain features of a   cloud platform. In that light
column27: Amazon's fourth-quarter AWS   results look quite strong.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column28: the newsletter they   run
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market!*)Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for   investors to buy right now. Amazonis on the list-- but there are nine others you may be overlooking.Click here to get access to the full list!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column32: an executive at Alphabet
column33: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Adam Levyowns shares of Amazon. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A shares)
column34: Alphabet (C shares)
column35: and     Amazon. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Snap
column2: Inc. Is Pioneering a New Cloud Strategy. Will It Work?;2/8/2017;"Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) may be leading the growing market for cloud   infrastructure
column3: butAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is still putting up a fight.Cloud infrastructure vendors have been crucial in enabling   smaller start-ups
column4: particularly those that are building mobile   apps
column5: to get up and running without having to worry as much about   the back end. It's an appealing model since it allows smaller   companies to simply pay for what they need without having to   invest in building the infrastructure themselves. In other words
column6: it's an OpEx model versus a CapEx model
column7: andGoogle is betting bigthat the market is going to shift to the OpEx model in a major   way in the years ahead.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();But as companies grow
column8: they often choose to invest in their   own cloud infrastructure. This gives them much more control over   their own destinies
column9: reduces risk
column10: and over time the cost   efficiencies improve after the large upfront investment.Social media peersFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) andTwitterboth operate their own data centers; Facebook announced itsseventh data centera few months back
column11: while Twitter's infrastructure operations are   expanding more slowly
column12: as it operates in co-located facilities.   Data centers are so strategically important to Facebook that it   helped create the Open Compute Project back in 2011
column13: publicly   sharing Facebook's infrastructure innovations for the greater   good.But notSnap(NYSE: SNAP) .Hey
column14: big spenderSnap primarily relies on Google Cloud for its infrastructure   needs. While this is entirely par for the course for mobile app   start-ups
column15: Snap has grown to a size (nearly 160 million daily   active users) that would typically warrant investing in   infrastructure. The sheer scale of Snap's use of Google Cloud is   what's unprecedented here. The Information reports that Google   landed Snap with numerous discounts and other benefits
column16: and Snap   very much relies on Google Cloud at this point
column17: although it also   uses Amazon's AWS to a lesser degree.Back in 2014
column18: Snap CTO Bobby Murphy said the company picked   Google Cloud over AWS because the company could scale better on   Google Cloud. Snap poached AWS' head of data centers in October   of last year
column19: which is a peculiar move as it may imply that Snap   has longer-term ambitions to build out its own   infrastructure.But for now
column20: Snap is firmly in bed with Google Cloud
column21: and   spends quite a bit of money. Infrastructure costs comprise the   bulk of Snap's cost of revenue. From the S-1: ""Cost of revenue   consists primarily of payments to third-party infrastructure   partners for hosting our products. Hosting costs primarily   include expenses related to bandwidth
column22: computing
column23: and storage   costs."" Cost of revenue in 2016 was $452 million
column24: and Snap has   committed to spending $2 billion with Google Cloud over the next   five years.But at what cost?In discussing its operating leverage
column25: Snap believes that using   a capital-light business model will translate into ""lower costs   for us in both the short and long term."" That's definitely true   in the short term
column26: but much more debatable in the long term.Having a larger proportion of fixed costs actually helps with   operating leverage as the business grows
column27: since those fixed costs   get spread out over an increasing revenue base over time
column28: reducing total average costs. In contrast
column29: if a company's cost   structure has a larger proportion of variable costs
column30: those costs   will scale commensurately with revenue
column31: so you don't get as much   margin expansion. It's already telling that Snap's cost of   revenueexceededrevenue in 2016 ($405 million)
column32: resulting in negative gross   margin.We saw this all play out years ago in the semiconductor   industry
column33: with the rise of the ""fab-less"" and ""fab-lite"" models   that are dominant today. Building a chip fab costs billions of   dollars
column34: which was a significant barrier to entry. Then contract   chip manufacturers came around and allowed companies to focus   more on designing the chips while the manufacturing partners   would produce them. By outsourcing production to a few large chip   manufacturers
column35: the industry collectively saved billions and   innovation flourished. Semiconductors mostly shifted to the OpEx   model long ago
column36: and there are only a handful of companies that   currently manufacture their own chips these days.Snap is wading into uncharted territory by relying on   third-party infrastructure partners at this scale. Whether or not   this proves right or wrong will also depend on how Snap grows   from here. One thing is for sure
column37: though: Both aspiring start-ups   and infrastructure vendors will be watching closely to see how   this experiment unfolds.10 stocks we like better than SnapWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Snap wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

Partnerships outside of the U.S. will be key as the company tries to expand and grow Snapchat's user base.Snap is set to issue only nonvoting shares come March. column1: Amazon and Samsung Offerings Could Eat Into Google Search;2/8/2017;"Let me start by stating the obvious:Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google is the undisputed   champion of search. With over 60% of the US market and more than   90% of worldwide of worldwide search
column2: Google is ubiquitous   and is not going anywhere any time soon. But even 800-pound   gorillas need to look around the room every now and then and see   what might be coming their way. From the looks of it
column3: two fellow   titans are pushing products that might test Google's   strength.Google is the undisputed king of search. Image source:     Google.makeArticleAd();Bixby to bypass Google?Samsung acquires Viv virtual personal assistant. Image     source :VivLate last year
column4: Samsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) acquired Viv
column5: an artificial intelligence   company whose founders were the original developers ofApple'sSiri. With this purchase
column6: Samsung joined the fray of thevirtual personal assistant. With several more years of development under its belt
column7: Viv was   being billed as Siri's smarter sister that would work and play   well with others. In addition to the standard assistant chores   fare of language search
column8: map directions
column9: and weather
column10: Viv was   able to respond successfully respond to extremely complex   questions and follow-ups
column11: a skill lacking in other assistants.   With Samsung's acquisition
column12: Viv was updated and reemerged as   Bixby
column13: a virtual assistant which will make its debut in the   soon-to-be-released Galaxy S8. Samsung has plans to integrate its   recently acquired assistant into the majority of the native apps   on its upcoming phone.One of the more interesting features is the   camera featuring an optical character recognition system. By   pointing the camera at an object
column14: and engaging the ""Bixby""   button
column15: it seeks to identify said item and launches a native   search engine that circumvents Google search and locates the item   for purchase.There arepersistent rumorsthat Google has tried to prevent Samsung from making Bixby the   default on its phone
column16: and it may find legal standing to do so.   Samsung phones use Google's Android operating system and the pair   have a non-compete as part of their patent-sharing agreement.Google may not want Bixby to bypass its search
column17: though it   would not be the first such occurrence. Those familiar withAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) failed Fire phone will recall a similar feature   -- Firefly -- that allowed users to take a picture of an object   and launch the item listing on Amazon's website. Amazon's phone   never gained any traction
column18: so the fact that it bypassed Google's   search never resulted in any significant threat to Google's   search. The Galaxy S8 is unlikely to meet that same fate
column19: even in   light of the the Galaxy Note 7'srecent difficulties.Consumers begin product searches on Amazon.comMore products searches start on Amazon than Google. Image     source: Amazon.comSpeaking of Amazon
column20: astudyin June 2016 by PowerReviews found that 38% of US consumers   initiated a product search on Amazon versus 35% on Google.This   may be only the beginning. A largerstudyin September 2016 by BloomReach found that 55% of consumers begin   their search for a product on Amazon versus 28% on search   engines. The same report issued a year earlier reported 44% and   34% respectively. Amazon revealed that it is seeking to leverage   this and its massive library of product reviews by expanding paid   search
column21: which will include not only products it sells
column22: but items   not available on the site. This product and paid search will   extend to its virtual personal assistantAlexa and its Echohome systems. Few details have been released by Amazon
column23: but this   will likely compete directly for Google's advertising   dollars. There is not yet any indication of a wider entry   into search
column24: but with some estimates placing Amazon's Prime   membership at nearly half of US households
column25: that might provide a   natural entry into the field.Those little things can add upGoogle is already dealing with lower costs-per-click as a   result of the migration from desktop search to mobile
column26: with rates   falling 15% year over year in its most recent quarter. The   company was able to still grow the top line 22% in the most   recent quarter by making it up with volume
column27: with aggregate paid   clicks up 36% year over year.Alphabet earns nearly 88% of all its revenue from Google's   search
column28: and small challenges like these to its dominant position   could become legitimate threats to the company's cash cow   over time.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A       shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: Your Snap Shares Won't Get You Any Votes;2/8/2017;"One of the most interesting aspects ofSnap's(NYSE: SNAP) IPO filing is that the shares it's offering to the   public will have no voting rights at all. As a result
column2: co-founders Evan Spiegel and Bob Murphy will continue to control   a combined 88.6% of the company -- 44.3% each. ""Although other   U.S.-based companies have publicly traded classes of non-voting   stock
column3: to our knowledge
column4: no other company has completed an   initial public offering of non-voting stock on a U.S. stock   exchange
column5: management wrote in its S-1 filing.Indeed
column6: other companies have restructured their stock classes   so that a founder-CEO can remain in control. Snap is just being   more blunt about who's really running the show here.Image source: Snap.makeArticleAd();Most recently
column7: Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) announced plans for a stock split so Mark Zuckerberg   could maintain control of the company as he gives away most of   his wealth to nonprofits and other causes.Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) also restructured its shares in   2014 to keep its founders in control. Snap is setting things   straight from the get-go.A simple look at Snap's voting rightsSnap has three classes of stock
column8: and the voting rights are   laid out like so:ClassVotes Per ShareClass A0Class B1Class C10Source: Snap S1 filing.Individual investors will only be able to buy Class A shares   at Snap's IPO. The share classes do convert. One share of Class C   is convertible into one share of Class B. One share of class B is   convertible into one share of Class A. (No
column9: you can't convert   shares the other way around.) As such
column10: all shares of Snap stock
column11: regardless of class
column12: will participate equally in the profit of   the company.How much is a vote worth?Alphabet has the same voting structure for its stock
column13: with the   caveat that A shares have one vote
column14: B shares have 10
column15: and C   shares have no vote. Facebook announced it would split its shares   the same way at some point in the future.Shares of Alphabet provide the best look at how much investors   value voting rights. Class A shares
column16: which provide one vote
column17: trade for a slight premium to the non-voting Class C shares. That   premium is currently about 2.5%.Alphabet A shares vs C shares. Source: Ycharts.So voting rights do represent some value to shareholders
column18: or   at least potential shareholders. Activist investors could buy up   a significant portion of voting rights such that they can at   least have some sway at shareholder meetings. With Snap's IPO
column19: those shares won't be available to buy.Where things get messyFollowing the IPO
column20: Evan Spiegel will receive an additional 3%   of all shares outstanding paid out quarterly over the next three   years as a bonus. Those will be Class C shares
column21: and Spiegel will   then be able to exercise complete control over the company. In   the meantime
column22: there's potential for deadlock votes between   Spiegel and co-founder Bob Murphy
column23: as they each control   equal-sized stakes.But that's not the most concerning thing about the capital   structure at Snap. The only way for the founders to lose control   of the company is if they both die. As described in the S-1   filing
column24: ""Either of our co-founders' shares of Class C common   stock will automatically convert into Class B common stock
column25: on a   one-to-one basis
column26: nine months following his death."" If that   happens
column27: the other co-founder will have a controlling share of   the votes.In other words
column28: both founders could leave the company but   still be able to exercise control over it.Facebook made provisions to its stock split to ensure that   Zuckerberg would only control the company's voting rights as long   as he remained CEO.There's a provision on Alphabet's Class B shareholders that   for every Class C non-voting share they sell
column29: they must convert   one Class B share into a Class A share
column30: and presumably sell that   as well. That makes it more difficult for the founders to retain   complete control. In fact
column31: their combined percentage of the   shareholders' vote has fallen from 61% at the time of the stock   split to about 57% today.Snap's structure makes it so that not only do individual   investors have no voting rights
column32: but the founders will continue   to control the company until both of them die. That's putting a   lot of trust in the founders
column33: adding more risk to an already   risky investment.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column35: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: Priceline Inks Deal to Buy Momonndo Group
column2: Eyes Europe;2/8/2017;"The Priceline Group Inc.PCLNyesterday announced that it has reached a deal to acquire Momondo Group from Boston-based private equity firm Great Hill Partners.Over the last one year
column3: the stock has outperformed the ZacksElectronic Commerceindustry. It has gained 64.17% compared with the industry's gain of 57.95%.Momondo Group operates momondo
column4: a travel meta engine that provides hotels flights and car rentals and Cheapflights
column5: a global flight comparison and travel deals publishing platform. Great Hill Partners invested $130 million in the company in 2014 and acquired a majority stake.As a part of the cash deal
column6: Priceline will buy all outstanding shares of Momondo for $550 million. Momondo will be absorbed into Priceline's travel meta brand
column7: KAYAK. The deal
column8: subject to regulatory approval
column9: is expected to be completed by the end of this year.Momondo Group is Priceline's largest acquisition after OpenTable
column10: which it acquired for $2.6 billion in 2014.Focus Shifts to EuropePriceline generates the bulk of its business from international markets where growth prospects are greater than in the domestic market. According to PhoCusWright
column11: online travel booking in Europe is growing at a faster rate than in the U.S.Since Priceline is very strongly positioned here it will be able to benefit from increasing penetration rates through Momondo. Over the years
column12: Kayak has failed to gain much traction in Europe but the addition of Momondo could help it to consolidate its presence in this market.The Priceline Group Inc. Revenue (TTM)The Priceline Group Inc. Revenue (TTM)|The Priceline Group Inc. QuoteAn Intensely Competitive SpaceThe move makes sense in an extremely competitive online travel space. CtripCTRPpurchased flight-metasearch company Skyscanner in November. ExpediaEXPEowned hotel-metasearch site Trivago went for its Initial Public Offering (IPO) in December.  Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle is also flexing its muscles in the space with flights and hotels metasearch features. Notably

column1: Snap IPO: Millennials Love It
column2: Should Investors?;2/7/2017;"After months of anticipation
column3: Snap(NYSE: SNAP)  finally made its publicS-1 filingwith the SEC. Form S-1 is used to register securities with the   SEC and provides prospective investors the first glimpse at a   company's financials and other data the company wishes to   disclose. Snap's S-1 has the standard balance sheet and income   and cash flow statements
column4: but it includes a lot of juicy details
column5: as well.Image source: Snap
column6: Author.makeArticleAd();We already know millennials love Snapchat
column7: and management made   sure to highlight that fact. But should investors be equally   enamored with the highly anticipated IPO?Key financialsMetric/Year20152016Revenue$58.7 million$404.5 millionNet income($372.9 million)($514.6 million)Free cash flow($325.8 million)($677.7 million)Snap S-1 SEC filing.Snap is considered a growth company
column8: and as such
column9: its main   focus is on improving its top line. To that end
column10: it managed to   increase revenue to $404.5 million last year from $58.7 million   the year before. That growth was fueled by an increase in the   total number of ads shown per user
column11: as well as an increase in   total users. Snap introduced several new ad formats on Snapchat   last year and opened an application program interface (API)
column12: which made it easier for more companies to buy ads.But that revenue growth came at a price. Snap invested heavily   in new research and development to create new ad products
column13: as   well as sales teams to sell those ads. Snap also experienced a   148% increase in its cost of revenue
column14: mostly related to hosting   costs it pays toAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) for its cloud platform. (It also   announced plans to spend even more with Google over the next five   years.)The result was a widening net loss. The company lost $514.6   million last year
column15: 38% more than its $372.9 million loss in   2015.Snap also believes free cash flow is an important financial   metric since its reliance on Google's servers means it doesn't   incur huge capital expenses likeFacebookorTwitter
column16: which own their own servers. Snap burned through $677.7 million   last year
column17: up from $325.8 million in 2015.User growth and engagementSnap focused on daily active users in its filing
column18: noting that   it's the most useful perspective of its business. Over the last   year
column19: daily average users (DAUs) increased 48%
column20: to 158 million.   The company noted it averaged 161 million DAUs in the month of   December
column21: but it will use a quarterly average when it reports   results in the future.Source: Snap S-1.Snapchat's user growth has notably slowed over the last few   quarters
column22: and Snap expects user growth to continue slowing.   Investors expecting Snapchat to reach any size resembling   Facebook will be disappointed.Snapchat's users are highly engaged
column23: however. The company   notes the average user opens the app 18 times per day and spends   between 25 minutes and 30 minutes per day in the app.Over 2.5 billion Snaps are created every day. That compares   with Facebook
column24: which says its users spend 50 minutes per day   between Facebook
column25: Instagram
column26: and Messenger. Twitter users spend   considerably less time in its app -- Comscore estimated just one   minute per user last year.That strong engagement implies that Snap has room to improve   its average revenue per user. Last quarter
column27: Snapchat's ARPU was   just $1.05
column28: $2.15 in North America. By comparison
column29: Facebook   generated $4.83 per monthly user globally and $19.81 per user in   the U.S. and Canada.Even Twitter managed to produce $2.33 per global monthly user   in the fourth quarter last year. Considering Snapchat ads are   generally considered high value
column30: there's a lot of room for   improvement in monetization of the existing user base.Should you buy it?Snap represents a very risky investment. It's going up against   stiff competition from Facebook
column31: which is unabashedly copying its   main stories feature in Instagram. Its user growth is slowing as   a result. Users are also heavily concentrated in a few areas
column32: which Snap spins as a positive by saying it has a large presence   in some of the largest advertising markets. For most advertising   companies
column33: however
column34: breadth is the name of the game.Snap's also heavily dependent on Google Cloud for its   infrastructure
column35: which will continue to cut into its gross income.   Management even lists potential disruption of Google Cloud as a   risk factor in the S-1 filing.Still
column36: its revenue growth is exciting. The $405 million it   generated last year surpassed its internal expectations according   to a leaked document early last year. Analysts expect revenue to   reach nearly $1 billion this year
column37: and its execution last year is   an encouraging sign that it can reach those expectations.   Snapchat's ad products are extremely compelling and unique   (although Facebook is doing its best to copy it)
column38: and it has the   young audience brand that advertisers covet.Ultimately
column39: an investment in Snap at its IPO is an investment   in Evan Spiegel
column40: the visionary CEO that's led numerous product   innovations at Snapchat. The S-1 filing also reveals that he's   done extremely well in acquiring technology and talent to support   Snapchat's growth.For investors willing to take on significant risk and who   believe in the vision and abilities of Evan Spiegel as a CEO
column41: Snap could make an interesting investment.10 stocks we like better than SnapchatWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Can Ubiquitiâ€™s Run Continue in 2017?;2/7/2017;"While many technology investors no doubt enjoyed major gains   in the high-profile large-cap tech names in 2016
column2: mid-cap   wireless companyUbiquiti Networks(NASDAQ: UBNT)  also had itself quite a year
column3: rocketing 125%   in just the past 12 months. The company continues to fly under   the radar
column4: despite having 38-year-old CEO who not only owns the   Memphis Grizzlies but can alsodunk a basketball.Take that
column5: Zuckerberg and Musk!In its most recent quarter ended Sept. 30
column6: revenues grew 35%
column7: and non-GAAP EPS grew a whopping 55% year over year
column8: largely on   the strength of the Unifi segment. With the recent move in the   stock
column9: investors may be wondering if they've missed the boat
column10: but   I think the momentum can continue in 2017 for the following   reasons.makeArticleAd();IMAGE SOURCE: UBIQUITI NETWORKS
column11: INC.Unifi goes up the value chainAs I mentioned
column12: the star of 2016 for Ubiquiti was Unifi
column13: which   grew 75% in the September quarter. This segment makes low-cost   enterprise hardware products
column14: such as wireless access points
column15: switches
column16: routers
column17: security cameras
column18: and VOIP phones
column19: along with   software that allows IT professionals to track large networks   from a single user interface. Ubiquiti's low-cost business model   -- the company employs almost no sales force or service   professionals
column20: and hires a limited number of ""all-star"" engineers   -- enables it to produce solid wi-fi products at rock-bottom   prices
column21: and the product line caught fire in 2016. In January
column22: however
column23: the company unveiled a new line of advanced products   aimed at higher-end customers
column24: which is the turf of IT giants   such asCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andHP(NYSE: HPE) . The new products included the US-16-XG Switch for   $599 and a new Wave 2 access point for $349. These are much   higher price points than traditional Unifi products
column25: but still   much lower than high-end access point vendors such as   Cisco's Meraki ($1
column27: HP's Aruba ($1
column28: 395) andBrocade's(NASDAQ: BRCD) Ruckus ($1
column29: 295). Should Ubiquiti make inroads   into higher-end deployments
column30: these new products could drive   Ubiquiti's already-sky-high 35% operating margin even higher.Ubiquiti looks as if it is finally making its move to disrupt   legacy IT players
column31: just as prominent venture capitalist (and   former Ubiquiti board member) Bill Gurley predicted in 2014:""The fact that Cisco has never had a price disruptor over 30     years seems to violate the rules of the ""Innovator's Dilemma.""     I think many people believe that a disruption from underneath     is overdue. If I had to bet on anyone pulling that off it would     be [Ubiquiti CEO] Robert [Pera].""Airmax refreshWhile Unifi was the star of 2016
column32: Ubiquiti's biggest segment   is still Service Provider
column33: which accounts for 59% of total   revenues. Under the Airmax and Airfiber brands
column34: this segment   makes high-powered radios that beam Wi-Fi over long distances   while achieving cable-like speeds. These radios are the building   blocks for Wireless Internet Service Providers (WISPs) in rural   and emerging markets worldwide
column35: where fiber or satellite is too   expensive
column36: and the spectrum is less cluttered. Airmax growth had   stalled in the past two years from its hyper-growth period a few   years ago
column37: yet still grew 15% year over year in the September   quarter.There are reasons to think that 2017 could bring a   reacceleration for Airmax and its associated products. First
column38: Ubiquiti dropped the ball somewhat when it initially released   Airmax AC
column39: as these hyper-fast products were not   backwards-compatible with older Airmax M radios. That meant   service provider customers would have to refresh their entire   networks of radios in order to upgrade
column40: as opposed to upgrading   radio-by-radio. This was fixed in December with the release of   new firmware AirOS 8.0
column41: which was no small task (it took over a   year!). Second
column42: Pera recently revealed several new Airmax   products for 2017
column43: including a GPON fiber product. While   Ubiquiti's radios are normally used to replace fiber
column44: Ubiquiti   found out that many of its emerging-market customers can lay   fiber along power lines very cheaply
column45: and this new product should   add to their arsenals. Even more exciting
column46: the company revealed   an entirely new ASIC (application-specific integrated chip) it   has developed called LTU. As Pera explained:""It's been well over 3 years in the making
column47: and we're going     to launch it next year. And it's going to be essentially     airFiber multipoint. But it's going to be light-years ahead of     anything in the market
column48: and at cost points relevant to airMAX
column49: we're going to price it higher. The margins are going to be a     lot better... we think that's going to be a really big     differentiator in the market.""Again
column50: we see Ubiquiti making a move to grow out of its   reputation as just a low-cost vendor
column51: and into a company that   sells higher-quality (and
column52: therefore
column53: higher-margin) products as   well.AmplifiWhile Pera & Co. are at it
column54: why not enter a completely new   customer segment? That's what Ubiquiti did this summer with the   introduction of Amplifi
column55: a consumer router that will take onNetgear's(NASDAQ: NTGR) Orbi andGoogle's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) home router. Amplifi is gettingstellar reviewsso far
column56: and just like Unifi's access points
column57: it might pave   the way for other ancillary products for the connected home.Even though the Amplifi was unveiled last summer
column58: it hasn't   produced much revenue for Ubiquiti yet. This is not because the   product wasn't great
column59: but because the company was   capacity-constrained for the last half of 2016. As Pera said:""What I'm really
column60: really
column61: really frustrated about
column62: is we     didn't execute on the production side. So we had demand for     tens of thousands of units out of the gate
column63: and we've just been     slow to get these out.""That is what I'd call having ""champagne problems."" And while   Ubiquiti is going up against strong competitors such as Google
column64: Netgear
column65: and others
column66: the price-performance characteristics of the   product
column67: as well as the secular tailwind of the connected home   makes me a believer that Amplifi could become a meaningful growth   driver as early as this year.The valuation is still reasonableEven after Ubiquiti's big move
column68: the stock trades at a fairly   reasonable 23 times trailing earnings
column69: which means the market is   pricing in decent
column70: though not spectacular
column71: growth from here.   Still
column72: with a disruptive business model
column73: a rock-solid balance   sheet
column74: and a long runway in a secular growth industry
column75: I think   Ubiquiti's stock can exit 2017 a good deal higher than where it   entered.Offer from the Motley Fool: The 10 best stocks to buy       nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. In fact

column1: 3 Stocks to Buy for Their Coming Rebound;2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
